abstract: Editorial sees signs of trouble in southern Missouri
snippet: Editorial sees signs of trouble in southern Missouri
lead_paragraph: -- There are signs of troubles again in Southern Missouri. Gen. PRICE, with that part of his troops which he took to Corinth, crossed the Mississippi into Arkansas a few weeks ago; and part of his forces is reported to be again on the southern border of Missouri. We have but one or two small bodies of troops in that vicinity -- a few regiments at the historic town of Springfield, and a few near the northern border of the Indian Territory. These latter, as will be seen by the letter of our Leavenworth correspondent given this morning, have, for some reason or other, after penetrating far down among the Indian Nations, been again ordered back to Fort Scott, in Kansas.

abstract: It seems, from the letterof our correspondent at Harrison's Landing that the rebel cannonade of that point, on Thursday night, from the south side of the river, was not a surprise to Gen. MCCLELLAN, as the dispatch which announced it intimated On the contrary, Gen. MCCLELLAN was, like all the rest of us, anticipating an attack from that very quarter, and was so thoroughly prepared for the cannonade, that he silenced it almost as soon as it was opened, and immediately, by a handsome and successful movement, took measures which render any future attack of the same kind impossible. It was not only a complete failure on the part of he rebels, but resulted in a triumph on our part, which possibly has in it the presage of a moat important and successul movement of the army.

abstract: We are indebted to the Secretary of the Chamber of Commerce for an early copy of the Annual Report, which will be found unusually interesting and suggestive. We are glad to find that it is proposed to extend, in various appropriate ways, the practical influence of this corporation to the mercantile classes of the Metropolis. The increased powers of the Arbitration Committee, under the recent action of the State Legislature, are attracting attention, and this mode of avoiding litigation and adjusting disputed points of law and custom, has the obvious advantage of saving the expense and avoiding the delay attendant on proceedings before the regular courts of law. One of the new features of the report is a very lucidly arranged catalogue of the extensive library which the Chamber of Commerce has purchased, and which, in consequence of the new duties and responsibilities devolving on the Arbitration Committee, is proposed to be greatly extended during the present year. In addition to the usual trade reports, the volume contains some very interesting tables from the last census returns, comprising a full view of the manufacturing industry of the City and State of New-York, with the large increase which has been realized since the National census of 1850 and the State census of 1855. At present it appears that the State of New-York produces about 20 per cent. of the manufactures of the whole country, more than two hundred thousand of her population being actively engaged in this department of industrial enterprise.

abstract: The annual commencement exercises of Norwich University will take place on Thursday and Friday, Aug. 14 and 15. Bishop CLARK, of Rhode Island, will be the orator of the societies, and PARK BENJAMIN, Esq., of New-York, their poet. abstract: -The Committee on Enlistment of this City have issued a series of recommendations to the people, which we published yesterday. Among them is one which is worthy of repetition. They urge that "it is a plain and imperative duty of the National and State Governments, without an exception, to organize, arm, equip, and make ready for service the whole militia of the States;" and that "it is the duty of every able-bodied man to arm himself and unite with some military organization, or if there be none convenient, to form with his neighbors a rifle club or other military association for drill and exercise in arms." This is a good suggestion, and we trust it will be acted upon by the people at once. There are a hundred thousand fighting men within a radius of three or four miles around the City Hall. While it would do them all personally a great deal of good, it would add immensely to the military power and safety of the City and the nation to have them drilled in ordinary military tactics, and in the use of weapons. We are into a war now whose issue no man can foresee, and which may give rise to complications which will imperil our very existence. But with such a tremendous force as this State and her sister Free States could put under arms, actually prepared and ready to use those arms, there would be no doubt of the issue of this war, and little danger of any others. It would take but little time from those whose time is already fully occupied. A good part of the drilling could be done at night; and, instead of tiring out those who are already weary, it would give them strength, vivacity and health. On Saturday afternoon, there might be a turn out for field exercise, or the larger manoeuvres of war. Why should not this thing be started at once? War is now the business of the nation, and we will never have a permanent peace until we are strong enough to overcome and overawe all foes, domestic and foreign.

abstract: War meetings are now very frequent in the large towns and villages of New-Jersey, and they are well attended and enthusiastic. No bounty for recruits has been offered by the State Government; but at those meetings measures are adopted to procure subscriptions, and citizens are offering comparatively large bounties from their private purses. Thus, in nearly all parts of the State, enlistments are encouraged by special inducements. On Thursday very enthusiastic meetings were held at Elizabeth and Bergen, and measures inaugurated which will stimulate volunteering.

abstract: Process and provisions for establishing military draft discussed

lead_paragraph: It seems likely that a draft may shortly be expected in this and all the other loyal States, for the purpose of promptly making up the quotas demanded to meet the late call for 300,000 additional troops. Nothing could more strikingly illustrate the temper of the public mind than the fact that it is the Government that is unwilling to resort to this method of raising men. The people wish it.

abstract: There are some pretty strong contrasts in life. From the tapestried parlor where no sound harsher than the low ripple of soft music falls on the ear, where no direr want than of a partner for a polka is known, we can turn to the squalid misery of the streets by simply raising a latch.
lead_paragraph: There are some pretty strong contrasts in life. From the tapestried parlor where no sound harsher than the low ripple of soft music falls on the ear, where no direr want than of a partner for a polka is known, we can turn to the squalid misery of the streets by simply raising a latch. Leaning on the arm of the groom, the bride goes tripping down the street, white plumes in her hat and smiles on her blushing face, while side by side with her walks a woman in sad widows' weeds, alone. The gatherings in quiet parlors and those on the pavement outside do not much resemble each other even by gaslight, and the marked difference between bridal feathers and hearse plumes will readily suggest itself to the most unimaginative mind. But to see contrast, real contrast -- to obtain what clergymen call "a realizing sense" of how far contrast can possibly go, -- it is necessary to spend some months in camp, and then be suddenly transported to Nixon's Cremorne Gardens, after the lamps are lighted and the music playing.

lead_paragraph: The necessity of giving the navy a new life was strongly borne in upon the mind of Congress at the late session. It resolved to appropriate money to establish a new naval depository, workshop and station, at some convenient point, where all the material of maritime warfare might be easily aggregated; and where the machinery for realizing the most gigantic plans of engineering and architectural invention might be erected. The purpose, in brief, was to create an American Woolwich and Chatham at one legislative blow.

abstract: During the past month the issue of nickels from the Mint was over three millions and a half of coins. The rush for them has been extremely urgent. People who have cut their eye teeth have resorted of late to a new dodge in securing pennies, and an early supply of them. They, yesterday, sent young women to procure the nickels.
lead_paragraph: From the Philadelphia North American, Aug. 2.

abstract: To-night, a grand demonstration takes place under the auspices of the Fire Department of this City, for the purpose of recruiting the Second Fire Zouaves (Fourth Regiment Excelsior Brigade) to the maximum standard.
lead_paragraph: To-night, a grand demonstration takes place under the auspices of the Fire Department of this City, for the purpose of recruiting the Second Fire Zouaves (Fourth Regiment Excelsior Brigade) to the maximum standard. The meeting takes place at the Armory of the Seventh Regiment, Tompkins Market. Gen. D.E. SICKLES, with other distinguished speakers, will be present, and address the meeting. The Fourth Regiment (Second Fire Zouaves) have participated in every battle on the Peninsula since the landing of Gen. MCCLELLAN's forces. Their ranks have been greatly decimated by the casualties of the field, as well as the malaria of the Chickahominy swamps. The regiments, originally 800 strong, are now reduced to less than 300. The Colonel, W.R. BREWSTER, and the Lieutenant-Colonel, L. BENEDICT, are both prisoners in Richmond, and the Major resigned. The regiment is now commanded by the senior Captain. They look to their comrades to fill up their ranks, as volunteers instead of the drafting process. Let the meeting at the Seventh Regiment Armory Hall to night, be one of the greatest gatherings of the present year. Every member of the Fire Department is expected to be present, and lend his aid to the immediate recruiting of the Second Fire Zouave up its full complement.

lead_paragraph: The APPLETONS, in this work, have undertaken to supply a very serious want in the current literature of this country. Although it would seem a work of the most obvious necessity, we have never had an Annual Register of current events. Several attempts have been made, at various times, to secure the publication of a work so useful to every class, and so indispensable to professional men -- but hitherto without success. The late JOSEPH BLUNT did publish one for several successive years, but it was discontinued for lack of support a long time ago, and none of the numerous attempts that have been made to revive it have been successful.

abstract: An enthusiastic meeting was held at Brockport, on Thursday evening, Hon. S.E. CHURCH made an address. He said that a division of this country will be the overthrow and dissolution of the Government. Some folks thought that we were fighting for division line. He had as lief that a line be drawn between the Free and Slave States as between the Border and Cotton States. If a division of the North and South is allowed, but few years will elapse before the great West will divide, and either join the South or set up for itself. The result will be a lot of little principalities and Powers. We have gone on for nearly eighteen months gaining victory after victory. The rebels have been driven from forts, and driven into a small circle. The rebels have concentrated all their forces at Richmond, and when we marched our army upon that capital, what did we find! Why, that the enemy outnumbered us two to one. Our brave soldiers, with masterly skill and courage, defended themselves and finally reached a safe place. You have brave sons in that army, and when they left your firesides, I have no doubt that you pledged them to stand by them and protect them. Now is your time to do so. We cannot give up Richmond. If we do, we inflict a stain upon this Government which we never can wipe out. Our greatest danger lies in intervention. It let alone we can crush this rebellion. 20,000,000 of men can crush 6,000,000. It is only a question of time. This rebellion is a great injury to France and England. Their laboring classes are thrown out of employment and reduced in circumstances, and the people and Government have to support them. There is an irrepressible conflict between the Governments of the Old World and the Government we have established here.

abstract: ITEMS. At all early hour Saturday morning, a bed caught fire from a lamp in a house at the rear of No. 663 Myrtle-avenue, occupied by Mrs. DELIA HACKETT. The inmates of the house were all asleep at the time, and before the fire was discovered, one of two children sleeping in the bed was seriously burned.
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- At all early hour Saturday morning, a bed caught fire from a lamp in a house at the rear of No. 663 Myrtle-avenue, occupied by Mrs. DELIA HACKETT. The inmates of the house were all asleep at the time, and before the fire was discovered, one of two children sleeping in the bed was seriously burned. The fire, when discovered, was speedily extinguished....The street lamps are not lighted now on nights when the almanacs indicate that the moon is to shine. People whose business or pleasure, requires them to be out late are again beginning to carry arms for self-protection, and housekeepers begin to tremble. More houses were robbed during thelast week than in any four weeks during the last three years. The whole reserve Police force in the city has been ordered on duty every night....A portion of the wall of School-house No. 17, in North Fifth-street, fell to the ground on Friday night last. The building is being enlarged, and a portion of one of thesides was left so exposed that it gave way and fell....The body of an infant was taken out of the East River yesterday, at the foot of Main-street....A woman was prostrated by the heat Saturday, whilewalking through Nassau-street....JOHN FREEMAN, charged with stealing a gold watch from Mr. STOUTENBURGH, at Coney Island, was on Saturday committed in full by Justice PERRY to answer the charge.

abstract: The United States Steamship Magnolia, Commander BUDD, from Charleston bar, S.C., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, having under convoy the British steamship Memphis, Capt. CRUIKSHANK, which she captured off Charleston bar, while attempting to run the blockade of that port. Commander BUDD reports: Left New-York, July 20, for Key West, July 31st lat. 32° 50' lon. 78° 37', made the British steamship Memphis, Capt. CRUIKSHANK, from Charleston, S.C., bound for Europe with a cargo of cotton, she having run the blockade the evening of July 27 put a prize master on board and accompanied her to port.

abstract: The Louisville News contains an extract from a private letter from a member of the Fourteenth Kentucky Regiment, dated Camp Baird, Claiborne County, Tennessee. The writer gives the particulars of an affair which occurred near Tazewell on the 22d. He says that on the night of the 22d, a flag of truce came in from the rebels, and, through a mistake, some four or five on each side were killed outright or seriously wounded. The bearers of the flag were allowed inside of the pickets to the camp of Col. MUNDY, who sent them to Gen. MORGAN. According to the General's orders they were removed a mile and a half beyond the outposts, to remain till morning. As there was no camping ground at that point, they all concluded to go to Tazewell, nine miles further along. The party consisted of Lieut.-Col. KEGWIN, of the Forty-ninth Indiana; Capt. LYONS, Chief of Topographical Engineers, of Gen. MORGAN's Staff, and several other officers, besides the truce bearers. All went except Col. MUNDY, who said his orders would not permit him to go any further. In the meantime one of the soldiers out on duty saw the party and informed Gen. CARTER that there was a party of rebel cavalry just beyond our lines. Gen. C, sent a regiment to the point designated, and posted them in different positions. As the truce party returned, on the morning of the 23d, they were fired upon by CARTER's men. Lieut.-Col. KEGWIN was was shot through the hips, and so seriously wounded that he may not possibly recover. Capt. LYONS had one arm broken. A rebel Lieutenant was killed on the spot, and three or four other rebels were so seriously injured that they cannot recover. Every rider was unhorsed, and quite a number of horses were killed. The officers went out with the party through courtesy, Later information says that six or eight were killed on the spot.

abstract: Editorial urges Government draft militia now so full power of country can be put into ending war
snippet: Editorial urges Government draft militia now so full power of country can be put into ending war
lead_paragraph: There is very great danger that the Union cause will be utterly ruined by the half-way measures of the Government. While the country demands that the rebellion shall be crushed, the Government seems content with preventing or postponing its triumph. We have gone on the principle that it would die out of itself, -- that every day's delay was equivalent to a Union victory, -- and that so long as Washington was not captured and the Army of the Potomac was "safe," the progress of the war was satisfactory. Our Government has been acting on the defensive from the beginning. We have governed our conduct by the conduct of the enemy. When they have increased their numbers we have increased ours. When theirs were supposed to be exaggerated we have stopped recruiting. Thirty days have elapsed since they drove back our army in front of Richmond, and satisfied the country that they outnumbered us two to one. From that day to this every railroad in the South has been swelling the numbers of their army, -- thousands and tens of thousands already organized, armed and in readiness for action, pouring in from every part of the Southern States, until now no one doubts that they have a force in Richmond three times as great as we can bring against them.

abstract: current scene, New Mexico
snippet: current scene, New Mexico
lead_paragraph: Three months ago Fort Union was the only fort in New-Mexico held by United States troops, and the public, both here and in the East, alarmed for the fate of this Territory, were eagerly inquiring if this post could be held against a superior force. The supposition, founded on the fact that extensive and costly fortifications had been in progress for six months, was that it could.

abstract: ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Friday, Aug. 1, 1862. At about 1 o'clock this morning the rebels  opened a rapid fire from three batteries of six guns each, planted on the South side of James River, at three different points. One battery was stationed on the bank nearly opposite the Harrison House, another opposite the mail dock, and the third opposite the Westover House.

abstract: Rev. C.C. Burr has again got himself into trouble in New-Jersey by ventilating his rebel sympathies too freely. Recently he announced a lecture in a rural neighborhood named Pascack, when, as we ...
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. C.C. Burr has again got himself into trouble in New-Jersey by ventilating his rebel sympathies too freely. Recently he announced a lecture in a rural neighborhood named Pascack, when, as we learn from a correspondent of the Paterson Guardian, he vehemently counseled resistance to the collection of taxes for sustaining the Government, and in various other ways displayed the cloven foot. This was too much for the loyalists of the place, and the lecture was brought to an abrupt termination after the fashion thus described: "The fellow at last unmasked a battery, which, judging from the volley at once directed to the speaker, must have been a heavy one, though it was evidently manned by volunteers who as yet had never had much practice at the business. Soon, however, the engagement became general along the line, and eggs flying thick and fast, burst in alarming proximity to the speaker, till the brave Chauncey ordered a hasty retreat, double-quicked himself out of a back passage, got into a wagon he had in readiness for such service, and retreated in great disorder, and not even doing as much as to stop and bid a fellow good-bye."

abstract: We learn from the Kinderhook Rough Notes, that during the heavy rainstorm last Tuesday evening, the steam cotton factory in that village was struck by lightning, and three persons were injured. The fluid entered through a window in the lower story, occupied as the carding-room, and was distributed round the room by following the iron steam-pipe used in warming the building. A Mrs. BELL, an operative, who was leaning against these pipes, near the window where the lightning entered, had her right hip paralyzed by the shock, and was carried out into the open air, where she recovered sufficiently to be carried home. Her back and thigh are marked with green spots. A young man standing near her had his elbow burnt to a blister, and another one was rendered motionless by the lightning playing tag over his feet.

abstract: editorial sees important movement about to take place
snippet: editorial sees important movement about to take place
lead_paragraph: Our correspondents intimate that there is some important movement about to be made, if it is not now being made, by the army of Gen. MCCLELLAN. What it may be, is not distinctly given out -- though any person who has read our correspondence carefully for the last two or three days, and who will peruse sagaciously the letters and telegrams of this morning, with a map of Virginia before him, will be able to form a theory that will be plausible enough to stand until we get the facts. The facts, we venture to say, will confirm the theory.

abstract: Yesterday was set apart by a large portion of the colored population of New-York and vicinity for a grand Union celebration of emancipation in NewYork, the West Indies, and the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was set apart by a large portion of the colored population of New-York and vicinity for a grand Union celebration of emancipation in New-York, the West Indies, and the District of Columbia. HANEST's Myrtle-avenue Park, Long Island, near East New-York, was the locality selected for the festivities, and thither thousands thronged at an early hour in the morning, with the view of having choice places to witness the following programme of performances: 11 o'clock, Prof. C.L. TROWER's first performance; 2 o'clock, Public and Sunday Schools will assemble; 2 1/2 o'clock, Speaking will commence; 3 1/9 o'clock, Prof. C.L. TROWER's second performance; 5 o'clock, Prof. KELLIES will perform.

abstract: The Government has at last concluded to resort to a draft to swell the army to the requisite standard, and the official order from the War Department on the subject is published this morning.
lead_paragraph: The Government has at last concluded to resort to a draft to swell the army to the requisite standard, and the official order from the War Department on the subject is published this morning. It directs -- first, an immediate draft of three hundred thousand militia, to serve for nine months, unless sooner discharged by the Government; second, a further draft to fill any deficiency in answer to the call for three hundred thousand volunteers which may exist on the 15th inst., at which time the draft is to go into effect. This will place a new army of six hundred thousand men in the field immediately. The quotas for the States will be assigned by the Secretary of War, who will also establish regulations for the draft. Regulations are also to be prepared to secure the promotion of meritorious officers, and to prevent the nomination and appointment of incompetent ones.

abstract: Negro employes of tobacco factory in Brooklyn attacked at work by pro-slavery mob
snippet: Negro employes of tobacco factory in Brooklyn attacked at work by pro-slavery mob
lead_paragraph: The contest provoked by a certain portion of the secession Press at the West, which resulted in a riotous attack by Irishmen upon the negroes in Chicago and elsewhere in that section of the country has been duly imitated by a portion of the Press of this city, until at last their teachings have culminated in a similar result. The first overt act was committed last Saturday night, when some colored women and children employed in the Sedgwick-street tobacco factories were hooted and stoned by a party of Irishmen, but without doing any serious damage. Yesterday afternoon, however, a systematic attack was made by a party of between four and five hundred Irishmen upon WATSON's tobacco factory, at the foot of Sedgwick-street, and with splendid success. The factory is a large three-story brick building and devoted exclusively to the manufacture of tobacco. At the time all the employes present were colored persons -- twenty in number -- five men and the balance women and children.

abstract: The steamship Northern Light arrived at this port yesterday morning, with the passengers and treasure from California. She left Aspinwall on the 26th of July. Her treasure list foots up nearly a million dollars.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Northern Light arrived at this port yesterday morning, with the passengers and treasure from California. She left Aspinwall on the 26th of July. Her treasure list foots up nearly a million dollars. Our correspondence, giving details of intelligence from the United States of Colombia, and Central and South America, will be found interesting. There had been some excitement on the Isthmus, arising from reports, apparently well founded, that a large body of men would soon make their appearance at Panama, "to aid the Governor in quelling the spirit of insubordination recently displayed." We interpret this as signifying an attempt to drive out the small body of troops dispatched thither some weeks ago by President MOSQUERA. Another excitement was produced at Panama by an order from the Bishop to take all the valuable ornaments and jewels from the churches and deposit them in some safe place, to prevent their falling into the hands of Gen. MOSQUERA, should he issue an order for their confiscation. There was a general outcry raised when the valuables were being removed from the Church of Santa Ana, the women turning out in great force, and threatening to offer resistance. A party of about, fifty soldiers, belonging to MOSQUERA's garrison, seized the muskets and ammunition belonging to the police force of Panama, on the 22d, removing the booty to the barracks. The reason assigned for that step was to guard it from being stolen by the conservatives. A number of the police had previously gone to Veraguas to join the Governor, who is now collecting a force at that place. From rumors afloat it is not improbable that Panama will soon be declared under military government.

abstract: DESPERATE ATTEMPT TO MURDER AN OFFICER  ARREST OF THE DESPERADO. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, as officer SAMUEL ROTHSCHILD, of the Sixth Precinct, was on duty corner of Chatham and Pearl streets, FRANK CONSALLI, a Cuban, 27 years of age, ...
lead_paragraph: DESPERATE ATTEMPT TO MURDER AN OFFICER -- ARREST OF THE DESPERADO. -- About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, as officer SAMUEL ROTHSCHILD, of the Sixth Precinct, was on duty corner of Chatham and Pearl streets, FRANK CONSALLI, a Cuban, 27 years of age, approached in a hurried manner and stopped a moment in front of him. Without saying a word. FRANK drew a razor from his pocket and struck the officer across the face with it, inflicting a deep and dangerous wound, extending from the lip of his ear along his neck and face for a distance of nearly six inches. The desperado then fled across Chatham-street to Roosevelt, pursued by officer KENNEDY, of the Sixth and COAKLEY, of the Fourth Wards, who succeeded in arresting him. The prisoner was taken to the Station-house and locked up. The wounded officer was removed to the New-York Hospital for surgical treatment, and was afterward taken home. No provocation whatever, it is said, was given for the murderous assault, and what prompted it is only known to the prisoner himself.

abstract: One of the most startling and magnificent displays or the Aurora Borealis, or "Northern Lights," ever witnessed in this latitude, arrested the attention of thousands last night. The first glow of this beautiful phenomenon was noticed about 9 P.M. Commencing on the northern horizon, it, in the course of an hour, overspread the greater surface of the heavens, extending in long streams of wavy effulgence to the zenith, and thence to every quarter of the compass. Bars of dense black vapor appearing about 10 o'clock, intercepted the display, and about midnight, when the light was brightest, surrounded the entire horizon with a bank of gloom that heightened, by contrast, the beauty of the pearly light that for many hours continued to flit to and fro over the unobscured portions of the sky.

abstract: The preparatory sessions of Congress commenced on the 13th of July; the constitutional installment follows on the 28th. The President will present a law of general amnesty to political offenders, which will be unanimously voted by Congress.
lead_paragraph: The preparatory sessions of Congress commenced on the 13th of July; the constitutional installment follows on the 28th. The President will present a law of general amnesty to political offenders, which will be unanimously voted by Congress. It is expected that Don MIGUEL CARPIO will be elected President of the Senate, and Don JOSE DEL CARMEN DELGADO President of the Deputies. Gen. SAN ROMAN will be declared elected President of the Republic, but it appears that no person has received the constitutional number of votes for Vice-President The question of Mexico will give rise to much exciting discussion in the debates of Congress, and some important action may be taken. There are many who contend that all the Spanish-American Republics should close their ports against French commerce if France continues to make war on Mexico. It is thought that "in this great movement the United States of America, who have been not less offended than ourselves, would naturally not stand aloof" -- so says the Lima Comercio. A Consul from Peru for Mexico has just been appointed, to watch matters, in the person of a young poet, Don ARNOLDO MARQUEZ. Another Consul is to be sent to Acapulco for the same purpose.

abstract: Messrs. A.H. DAVENPORT and J.W. COLLIER take a joint benefit on Friday evening at the Winter Garden. abstract: The first of a home-and-home match between these celebrated Clubs took place yesterday afternoon at Hoboken, in presence of nearly 3,000 spectators, a large number of whom were ladies. The game was well contested from first to last; but at the close of the first innings it was generally considered to be an ...
lead_paragraph: The first of a home-and-home match between these celebrated Clubs took place yesterday afternoon at Hoboken, in presence of nearly 3,000 spectators, a large number of whom were ladies. The game was well contested from first to last; but at the close of the first innings it was generally considered to be an almost sure victory for the Mutuals, whose batting far exceeded the expectations of the Eckfords, who did not field far enough out to intercept the balls. In the subsequent innings this was remedied, and a change in the position of some of the fielders was judiciously made, by which, and remarkably fine fielding, the victory finally rested with the Eckfords.

abstract: Since the assassination of President GUARDIOLA, Honduras has been quiet, under the rule of Senor CASTELLANOS, Vice-President. But the Vice-President does not appear to possess the capacity for governing that was accorded on all hands to his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Since the assassination of President GUARDIOLA, Honduras has been quiet, under the rule of Senor CASTELLANOS, Vice-President. But the Vice-President does not appear to possess the capacity for governing that was accorded on all hands to his predecessor. He is charged with being the tool of designing men, and many think he will get the country into trouble in some alliances, defensive and offensive, which are projected, and which may again light the flames of civil war in Central America. Congress has rejected the concordat lately made with the Pope, and instructed the President to make a new one. It has also passed a bill allowing the President to make his official residence in any portion of the Country he may select.

abstract: The long suspense which the community has endured for some time past, was finally relieved yesterday by the publication of an order from the War Department, calling for an additional draft from the militia meaning the militia already enrolled of...
lead_paragraph: The long suspense which the community has endured for some time past, was finally relieved yesterday by the publication of an order from the War Department, calling for an additional draft from the militia -- meaning the militia already enrolled -- of 300,000 troops, who are to serve for nine months, unless sooner discharged; and, in another section, declaring that unless the 300,000 previously demanded are ready by the 15th of this month, the deficit in that number will also be made up by drafting.

abstract: The only matter of note we have from this State is the fact that a party of 400 New-Granadians, from the Province of Pasto, in Cauca, followed an opposing and retreating force one league into Ecuadorian territory, and when ordered to retire, fired upon and wounded an officer of Ecuador, in command of the frontier station. The Ecuatorian Government had demanded the dismission, within 48 hours, of the Colonel commanding the New-Granadian or Colombian troops, and also that of the Prefect of the District, which demands were refused, upon which 1,000 men were marched into Pasto to obtain satisfaction. The result is not known.

abstract: A very large and enthusiastic meeting of the firemen and exempt firemen of this City and vicinity congregated at the Armory of the Seventh Regiment, last evening, for the purpose of aiding the patriotic...
lead_paragraph: A very large and enthusiastic meeting of the firemen and exempt firemen of this City and vicinity congregated at the Armory of the Seventh Regiment, last evening, for the purpose of aiding the patriotic effort to recruit the thinned ranks of the Second Fire Zouaves, or Fourth Regiment, Excelsior Brigade. The audience composed many gentlemen of prominence in the Fire Department. On the stand were Ex-Chief HOWARD, Commissioner WILSON, JOHN S. GILES, Treasurer of the Fire Department, Assistant-Engineer WEST, Chief DECKER, and others of like mote. Previous to the organization the boys amusedthemselves by calling for "HOWARD," "HOTALING," and other gentlemen, whose familiar faces were recognized. Then there were calls for "Music," "SICKLES," "Anybody." A most cordial reception greeted Gen. SICKLES, as he entered the room, about 84 1/4 o'clock, accompanied by Capt. O.H. HART, Assistant Adjutant-General, and Capt. JOHN S. AUSTIN, Brigade Quartermaster, Lieut.-Col. FARNSWORTH, of the Excelsior Brigade, STUART L. WOODFORD, Assistant U.S. District-Attorney, Capts. MAHAN and GENETT, of the First Excelsior, Capt. RAFFERTY, of the Third, and others.

abstract: In a scientific point of view, the present moment is peculiarly favorable for the creation of a systematic and permanent system of harbor defence.
lead_paragraph: In a scientific point of view, the present moment is peculiarly favorable for the creation of a systematic and permanent system of harbor defence. The practical proofs of the respective merits of fixed and floating defences, developed by the present war, have brought new elements into the problem, and thoroughly exploded old notions; the whole subject has been elaborately discussed, both in this country and abroad, and public and professional opinion, after undergoing more than one violent oscillation, has at length found its equilibrium in a principle which may be regarded, if not as a permanent truth, yet as likely to hold good until a total revolution shall come over our present method of attack and defence. The conclusion of the whole matter, then, is simply this, that the best system of harbor protection is that which includes both fixed and floating defences. An incomplete system, which embraces both means, is better than the most complete which consists of but one; and no scheme of harbor protection can possibly be perfect, which does not include both.
headline: {'main': "The Mayor's Message on Our Harbor Defences.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Mayor's Message on Our Harbor Defences.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday a very handsome Festival and Concert again enlivened the beautiful recesses of Jones' Wood. The New-Yorker Sing Academie, assisted and sustained by the New-York Turnverein, the Singing Clubs Arion, Rheinische Saengerbund, Uhlandbund,...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday a very handsome Festival and Concert again enlivened the beautiful recesses of Jones' Wood. The New-Yorker Sing Academie, assisted and sustained by the New-York Turnverein, the Singing Clubs Arion, Rheinische Saengerbund, Uhlandbund, the Turner Liedertafel, the Sing Academie Maennerchor and NOLL's celebrated orchestral band, organized and conducted a file for the benefit of the families of sick and wounded soldiers in the service of the Union which will long be remembered with satisfaction by those who participated in its innocent pleasures. The festival commenced in the afternoon with a series of musical performances by the different clubs whose booths and tents were tastefully decorated with the banners of the Societies, and the American and German Republican national colors. Meanwhile, thousands, in despite of the August sunshine, enjoyed waltzes and guadrilles on the spacious dancing floors. Than followed a succession of amusing sports, sack-races, climbing poles, gymnastic feats by the Turners, &c., and in the evening a superb concert, embracing the following programme: WERER's Jubilee Overture: The Chorus of Houris, from SCHUMANN's "Paradise and the Peri," executed by the ladies of the New-York Sing Academie; a National Quodlibet, by KUNTZE, in which the Rheinische Saengerbund, the Uhlandbund, the Turner Liedertafel, and the Sing Academie Maennerchor united; A Hunting and Harvest Chorus for the Four Seasons, by HADYN, performed by the male and female chorus of the Sing Academie; and the Steuben National March, by KRUEGER, dedicated to the Seventh Regiment, N.Y.S.V., sustained by the entire musical force.

abstract: Editorial speculates on European recognition of South
snippet: Editorial speculates on European recognition of South
lead_paragraph: The Courier de Havre is the Journal of Commerce of the principal seaport of France. It addresses itself, like the latter, to the commercial classes; and is equally sympathetic, while professing indifference, with the rebellion in the South. In a recent number, theCourier gives its views upon the actual crisis in America. The war, it discovers, can never end. The only thing in the circumstances that France or England can do is to acknowledge the independence of the South; the present neutrality being fallacious, inasmuch as it permits the North to draw freely upon Europe for arms and munitions, while the South is excluded from the same advantage.

abstract: The great excitement now in this State is the projected opening of the Nicaragua Transit Route for passengers and freight between New-York and California.
lead_paragraph: The great excitement now in this State is the projected opening of the Nicaragua Transit Route for passengers and freight between New-York and California. The official paper of Costa Rica contains an announcement authorized by Mr. RIOTTE, United States Minister Resident at San Jose, that "Mr. WALTER CAMPBELL has arrived at Corinto with $5,000, for the first payment to the Government for the privilege of the transit," but Mr. RIOTTE does not say that Mr. CAMPBELL paid the money to anybody. Contracts for lumber to build wharves and bridges and for repairing the transit road have been made, (whether bogus ones or not I do not know,) and it is said the route will be reopened in September. Don't believe it!

abstract: Our local reporters give this morning an account of one of the most atrocious riots of modern times, which occurred in Brooklyn yesterday, and in which a mob of four or five ...
lead_paragraph: Our local reporters give this morning an account of one of the most atrocious riots of modern times, which occurred in Brooklyn yesterday, and in which a mob of four or five hundred men, calling themselves Irishmen, assaulted a factory where twenty peaceable colored persons, mostly women and children were at work, attempted to butcher them in cold blood, and subsequently actually set fire to the building with the intent of burning the helpless negroes to death. It was only by the most superhuman exertions of the Police that the lives of the victims were saved, the mob dispersed, and the ringleaders arrested. The assault was entirely unprovoked -- in fact, it was merely because the assaulted parties were negroes -- and was of such a cowardly as well as fiendish nature that there can be found for it neither excuse nor palliation.

abstract: The promptitude with which the City Council has entertained the offer of an additional bounty of fifty dollars to recruits joining regiments already in the field, does credit to the City, and credit to the members of the Boards. There is genuine economy in the offer. If a raw recruit for a raw regiment is worth the Federal and State bounty of $150, the recruit who joins an existing regiment is worth twice as much. In a fresh organization it would take months and hundreds of dollars to convert him into a soldier. In an old regiment he becomes a veteran in half the time, and at a tenth of the expense; so that the special bounty which gives his patriotism that direction saves hundreds of dollars else spent upon his military education. It is clearly a high and inevitable duty for the City authorities to urge this measure. There is no time to be lost. We are not to wait for a draft or any other argument for postponing immediate endeavor. It is now men are wanted, and no price that procures them can be called extravagant.

abstract: Our Washington advices represent army matters as moving on with great harmony and vigor under the new regime. This was to be expected from placing an able and experienced soldier in command of the National forces.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington advices represent army matters as moving on with great harmony and vigor under the new regime. This was to be expected from placing an able and experienced soldier in command of the National forces. Whatever may be his merit in the field, no one doubts Gen. HALLECK's supreme qualification for the organization, combination and general direction of our armies. His present position is precisely the one where his services were the most needed, and where they will be most available. The country may rest assured that whatever troops are placed in the field under his direction, will be used to the best advantage. Their strength will not be frittered away by needless divisions, nor will the jealousies of individual officers, or the rivalries of their political backers, be suffered longer to paralyze the movements of the Union forces.

abstract: The order for a draft has given a great impetus to the enlistment business. Companies that were only recruiting two and three men a day, now obtain six or eight. It is beginning to be understood, that after the 15th of this month, no bounty will be paid, ...
lead_paragraph: The order for a draft has given a great impetus to the enlistment business. Companies that were only recruiting two and three men a day, now obtain six or eight. It is beginning to be understood, that after the 15th of this month, no bounty will be paid, and men to whom the $90 is an object are anxious to join some regiment in time to secure the money. Under this incitement, it is more than likely the first requisition of the President for 300,000 men will be raised by volunteering -- at least the quota required from this City will probably be so.

abstract: The order issued by the War Department directing the drafting of 300,000 men has occasioned no unusual commotion among the people of Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: The order issued by the War Department directing the drafting of 300,000 men has occasioned no unusual commotion among the people of Jersey City. A few have called at the City Clerk's office to find if their names were enrolled and anxious to file their excuses, but aside from this but little interest is manifested. In regard to recruiting, the order for a draft has had no effect in hastening up recruits, no more having been enlisted since it was issued than on any previous day. As yet but sixty-eight men have been enlisted in Jersey City under the former call; of these Capt. BUMSTED has recruited twenty-five men; Capt. BRANIN twenty-three men, and Capt. GRIMES twenty men. The Thirteenth Regiment now numbers about two hundred and fifty men.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held last evening at the County Jail. The report of the Superintendents of the Poor for the year ending July 31 last, embracing reports from the heads of the several Departments, was submitted.
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held last evening at the County Jail. The report of the Superintendents of the Poor for the year ending July 31 last, embracing reports from the heads of the several Departments, was submitted. The Keener of the Almshouse reports: Admitted during the year, 1,587; discharged, 984; eloped, 307; transferred, 400, died, 24. Total 1,732. There were raised on the Alms-house farm 8,000 bushels potatoes; 500 bushels oats; 250 bushels carrots; 725 bushels turnips; 1,300 bushels corn; 5,625 heads baggage; 37 tons hay. Crops growing -- 23 acres potatoes; 7 acres corn; 2 acres cabbage; 4 acres turnips; 1/2 an acre carrots; 30 tons hay was cut the present season.

abstract: We understand from the French Consulate, in regard to the blockade of the Mexican ports of Tampico and Alvarado, that it is not the intention of the French Government to enforce it with the rigor permissible by the provisions of international law. On the contrary, the French cruisers are instructed to offer no obstacle to the entry into either of those ports of either French or neutral vessels, which may have been dispatched thither before the official notification of the blockade, unless necessity should compel different action, they only seeing that such vessels do not carry articles contraband of war, -- Boston Courier.
lead_paragraph: We understand from the French Consulate, in regard to the blockade of the Mexican ports of Tampico and Alvarado, that it is not the intention of the French Government to enforce it with the rigor permissible by the provisions of international law. abstract: NIBLO'S THEATRE. On Monday night, after an absence in Europe, that gymnastic veteran of the pantomimic stage, GABRIEL RAVEL, reappeared at NIBLO's and met with an enthusiastic reception from a large and friendly audience.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's THEATRE. -- On Monday night, after an absence in Europe, that gymnastic veteran of the pantomimic stage, GABRIEL RAVEL, reappeared at NIBLO's and met with an enthusiastic reception from a large and friendly audience. He and his inimitable performances have been the special delight of nearly every Summer for the last quarter of a century; and both he and the performances seem as fresh and elastic as we thought them in the days of our boyhood. He has around him as principal supporters many of his old company, specially popular amongst whom is Madame MARZETTI, who acts with her accustomed intelligence and vivacity, and dances gracefully as ever. She is ably sustained in a difficult pas de deux by Mons. TOPHOFF. After the pantomime a reckless youth, called "Young America," shows a proficiency and daring with the Flying Trapeze, that will make WILLIAM HANLON look to his laurels in a year or two.

abstract: A PRINCIPLE THAT  WILL BEAR EXTENSION. Our City Postmaster, Mr. WAKEMAN, has the employes of his department busy at other work for their country beside the common duties of their office.
lead_paragraph: -- A PRINCIPLE THAT WILL BEAR EXTENSION. -- Our City Postmaster, Mr. WAKEMAN, has the employes of his department busy at other work for their country beside the common duties of their office. Five thousand dollars have been collected from them to aid in filling up the ranks of New-York regiments now in the field; and, beside this, each man in the office is required to "procure the enlistment of at least one person," they themselves being by law exempt from military duty. This is a most excellent movement, and will doubtless be at once initiated in the Custom-house, and the other branches of local Government employ. It might be extended, too, throughout the country, to all the Postmasters and their employee, all the Custom-houses and their employes, and indeed, to all those holding fat or lean offices under Uncle Sam. Let every one of them, on or before the 15th inst., "procure the enlistment of at least one person," and the draft for the July or three-years' muster, may be altogether avoided. It would give us from fifty to a hundred regiments promptly and without much expense. Those who are in the Government service should, in this hour of its peril, do something more for it beside drawing their salary.

abstract: The order authorizing the Governors of States to draft men for the war was the chief topic of conversation among our citizens everywhere yesterday, and the order was variously received.
lead_paragraph: The order authorizing the Governors of States to draft men for the war was the chief topic of conversation among our citizens everywhere yesterday, and the order was variously received. The "Butternuts" declared that it was another Republican "outrage" upon the free people of America, but far the greater portion of the people hailed the order with delight, as indicating that the Government intended for the future to prosecute the war with vigor to a speedy end. It was very generally believed that the draft in this city would call into service about two out of every three men subject to perform military duty; but with most people, going to war had no terrors, now that a vigorous policy was to be adopted. To relieve the minds of the timid, however, we will state, upon competent military authority, that the draft, if one is made at all in this city, will be a very light one -- 4,000 men will be about the quota of Brooklyn -- 2,000 uniformed militia, and about 2,000 of the ununiformed militia -- which will hardly make an appreciable difference in the population. But the place to see the real effect upon the "Butternuts" was at the City Clerk's Office, in the City Hall, where, for the small sum of twenty-five cents, the obliging clerks furnished every man that came along with a sworn statement to the effect that, in the opinion of the affidavit-makers, they are not fit subjects for military duty, and therefore not liable to be drafted. As drowning men are said to catch at straws, so did these poor fellows catch at this sum chance of escaping the fearful drafting ordeal. These certificates are not worth quite so much as the paper they are printed on; nevertheless, they were purchased in large numbers at twenty-five cents each. Hundreds of the "Butternut" tribe assembled in and about the City Hall at an easily hour in the morning, and the moment the Clerk's office was opened, and from that time until 2 o'clock P.M., the Clerk and his assistants were busily engaged in making out the much-coveted "certificates."

abstract: Mr. Samuel M. Harmon, Captain Co. I, Twenty-seventh Regiment N.Y.S.V., Slocum's Division, Franklin's Corps, Army of the Potomac, was wounded in the recent battle of Gaines' Mill, on the Chickshominy. He was wounded in the leg, but refused to leave the field long enough to have his wound dressed.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. Samuel M. Harmon, Captain Co. I, Twenty-seventh Regiment N.Y.S.V., Slocum's Division, Franklin's Corps, Army of the Potomac, was wounded in the recent battle of Gaines' Mill, on the Chickshominy. He was wounded in the leg, but refused to leave the field long enough to have his wound dressed. He was in all the subsequent battles, including that of Malvern Hill. At the battle of Bull Run, last year, Mr. Harmon was First Lieutenant, but his Captain, now Maj. C.C. Gardiner, was sick, and the command of his company, devolved upon him. His regiment was the last to retreat on that memorable occasion. Regiments and companies were scattered, but Mr. S.M. Harmon got his company back to Washington safe and in order. He was in the battles of West Point and Fair Oaks, and his men and superior officers represent that he is a very brave and skillful officer. His company was recruited in Allegany Co., New-York State. As one who has done his duty so nobly, honorable mention is done for public justice, but also to gratify the numerous friends of his company in this State. Army correspondents are apt to overlook the merits of officers as low down as captains, and the official reports of commanders of brigades, corps, &c., wherein company officers are favorably named, seldom meet the public eye.

abstract: We have received intelligence from Europe, one week later, by the arrival off Cape Race of the Cunard steamship Arabia, which left Liverpool on the 26th, and Queenstown on the 27th ult. The English papers are busy in discussing the present condition of affairs in the United States.
lead_paragraph: We have received intelligence from Europe, one week later, by the arrival off Cape Race of the Cunard steamship Arabia, which left Liverpool on the 26th, and Queenstown on the 27th ult. The English papers are busy in discussing the present condition of affairs in the United States. The London Times, of course, is disposed to argue that the cause of the loyal States is lost, but all the papers do not take a view quite so discouraging for us. The Army and Navy Gazette, indeed, is candid enough to admit that the position of the Army of the Potomac is much improved since its movement to the James River, and its position much better for operations against Richmond. The question of putting Canada in a state of defence had again been debated in the House of Commons. I was generally contended that there was no danger of an invasion by the United States. Lord PALMERSTON closed the debate with the announcement that England had sent all the troops to Canada that she could, and that it rested with the Canadians to supply deficiencies. There was rather a general disposition manifested to leave Canada out in the cold. The French Admiral DE LA GRAVIERE, had embarked for Mexico. The rumor that GARIBALDI has in contemplation another expedition is discredited. Cotton, in the Liverpool market, had declined 1/4d.@1/2d., except for American, which was easier, but not quotably lower. Breadstuffs were active and advancing. Provisions quiet and unchanged. Consols closed at 94 1/8@94 1/2.

abstract: A full company of Gen. HEINTZELMAN'S own regiment, the Seventeenth (New) Regular Infantry, was dispatched from the headquarters at Fort Preble, on Friday last, for the National Capital, where they will reinforce the gallant Seventeenth.
lead_paragraph: A full company of Gen. HEINTZELMAN's own regiment, the Seventeenth (New) Regular Infantry, was dispatched from the headquarters at Fort Preble, on Friday last, for the National Capital, where they will reinforce the gallant Seventeenth. They were 125 splendid men, and had the band of the regiment with them. The First Battalion of the Seventeenth is now full, and consists of 800 men. The Second is well under way at Fort Preble, and will be full before the Fall. When the three battalions are in the field, the regiment will number 2,400 men.

abstract: None of President LINCOLN'S admirable proclamations has produced more excitement, or been more generally indorsed among the people, than his last, concerning drafting. There can be little doubt that the North is fully convinced of its necessity.
lead_paragraph: None of President LINCOLN's admirable proclamations has produced more excitement, or been more generally indorsed among the people, than his last, concerning drafting. There can be little doubt that the North is fully convinced of its necessity. Certainly the almost universal sentiment of this City has been developed in support of the measure. Not unnaturally, many men of wealth, or social, domestic and business ties, not to be severed without great personal sacrifice, and enormous self-denial, dread the necessity of such sacrifices, but, that the nation's peril demands the measure, few pretend to doubt.

abstract: Explanation of draft law and exemptions
snippet: Explanation of draft law and exemptions
lead_paragraph: The interest and excitement on the subject of drafting in the City, are still on the increase; and we have received a perfect shower of communications with reference to our article "Concerning Drafting," published in Monday's TIMES. The anxious inquirers have every variety of query to propound touching who are exempt and who are not exempt, who are liable and who are not, and what duty and law require of them under their several individual, civil, social and physical conditions and circumstances. We don't wonder that a great many are puzzled what to do, for there are both National and State laws to consult on the matter, and the latter especially are complex enough. We shall not attempt to answer all the queries propounded to us, for that would require the subtlety of a Mediaeval casuist and the literary lengthiness of a Schoolman. Such, however, as present points of a real practical interest we shall reply to as best we can, and we dare say they will pretty nearly cover the whole ground.

abstract: Editorial on draft
snippet: Editorial on draft
lead_paragraph: The new draft for 300,000 militia is a most hopeful symptom. It not only adds so much to the effective military force of the country in its contest with the rebellion, -- but it shows that the Government is not afraid to throw itself upon the People for support. It indicates a willingness on the part of the President to put forth the power which has been placed in his hands. It indicates a willingness on his part, moreover, to look the worst in the face -- to regard this rebellion as the gigantic and terrible foe it has proved itself to be, and to meet it in its largest and most fearful shape. The Government has a right, legal and moral, to the active services of every able-bodied man in the country, in its contest with this rebellion. Let it use the power thus placed in its hands and the result cannot be doubtful.

abstract: UNITED STATE'S MARSHAL'S SALE. The cargo of the prize steamer Circassian was, by order of JAMES C. CLAPP, United States Marshal for the Southern District of Florida, sold at auction at 11 A.M. yesterday, at the Union Stores of WARD  GOVES, Brooklyn, near the Hamilton-avenue Ferry.
lead_paragraph: UNITED STATE's MARSHAL's SALE. -- The cargo of the prize steamer Circassian was, by order of JAMES C. CLAPP, United States Marshal for the Southern District of Florida, sold at auction at 11 A.M. yesterday, at the Union Stores of WARD & GOVES, Brooklyn, near the Hamilton-avenue Ferry. The sale was conducted by BURDETT, JONES & Co., under the direction of the Marshal. The Circassian was captured in the vicinity of Havana, which port she claimed as her destination, by the United States gunboat Somerset. The papers found on board distinctly proved that her cargo was intended for the port of New-Orleans, then under strict blockade, and it was consequently condemned at Key West by Judge MARVIN, but transferred to New-York as the latter was considered to be much the better market for the goods. The schedule of articles sold is as follows:

abstract: The steamer Continental, of the New-Haven line, went ashore yesterday morning, three miles west of Fort Schuyler, on the northerly shore, in a dense fog. Her bow is hard aground, but is on a good bottom, and she will doubtless come off at the next tide without injury, as she lies without any strain whatever. She is a new boat, and one of the strongest built ones on the Sound.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Continental, of the New-Haven line, went ashore yesterday morning, three miles west of Fort Schuyler, on the northerly shore, in a dense fog. abstract: Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS is certainly doing bad work for the Government and the country. His speech on the anniversary of West India emancipation, of which we publish a full synopsis this morning, is the bitterest and most unpatriotic utterance of which he, or any other man outside of the Southern Confederacy, has ever been guilty. He is furious against the policy of the Government on Slavery -- though it provides for the emancipation of all the slaves of rebels, and looks to the ultimate extinction of Slavery all over the country. He even talks such nonsense as that "the Government rights to preserve Slavery, and therefore it fights in vain." Certainly, such men are hard to please -- so hard that it is not worth while to try to please them at all. The President he calls a turtle, and again he calls him a turtle. Gen. McCLELLAN he does not call a "traitor," but says "he could not have done more to help traitors." The Cabinet, he says, "cease to believe in him." "He looked upon the present war, conducted without a reasonable object, as a total loss of blood and treasure;" but we hope he is incorrectly reported as crying out, "Let this Union be dissolved, in God's name, and the corner-stone of a new one be laid," &c. If Mr. PHILLIPS wishes to air his abusive rhetoric at the expense of the country, he has certainly chosen a most inopportune moment to do it, when every man of every style of opinion is so pressingly needed in the army to uphold and save the Government and the public liberties. He would be of better service if he were drafted into the army.

abstract: In the Philadelphia District Court, on Wednesday, a decision was given in the case of SHOENBERGEN for use vs. MUSSELMAN & WATTS, a brief notice of which, in view of the importance of the point involved, may not be out of place here. The defendants, obligers in a bond dated Nov. 26, 1861, in the penal sum of $56,281 78, conditioned for the payment of $28,155 89, in specie, current gold of the United States of America, on the 1st of May, 1862, with lawful interest in specie, current gold silver money aforesaid, to be paid half yearly for the same in the City of Philadelphia. A warrant of attorney for the same date with the bond to confess judgment was annexed to the bond. Under this warrant a judgment was enterd on the day of the date of the bond, in the Court of Common Pleas of Lancaster County. According to the usual practice, the judgment was entered for the penalty of the bond, and the record sets out the condition also, verbatim. When the day of payment arrived, the obligors tendered to the obligee the debt interest and cost, in full, in the notes of the United States, which, by act of Congress of Feb. 25, 1862, were made a legal tender for all debts, &c. The plaintiff refused to receive them, and had a [???] issued, which the defendants asked to have set aside. The question raised was whether the plaintiff had a right, since the act of Congress of Feb. 25, 1862, to require payment by defendants of gold and silver money, or was bound to accept the notes of the United States, which, by that act, were made a legal tender for notes generally. The Court decided that the tender of United States notes was sufficient answer to the obligation in the bond, and the writ was set aside.

abstract: The special police force of Marshal VANNOSTRAND, on Saturday morning, experienced quite a busy time in arresting rebels. From information received, the force visited the steamer George Weems and arrested thirteen persons, whose purpose was to reach, if possible, the sacred soil of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The special police force of Marshal VANNOSTRAND, on Saturday morning, experienced quite a busy time in arresting rebels. From information received, the force visited the steamer George Weems and arrested thirteen persons, whose purpose was to reach, if possible, the sacred soil of Virginia. The boat was steered for Fort McHenry, and the arrested parties were confronted by the commanding officer of that garrison. Four of the party subscribed to the oath of allegiance, and were released, the balance assuming a muleish disposition, were locked up, and a guard placed over them. The steamer was searched, resulting in the finding of four bales of blue cloth, intended for uniforms for the rebels, silk, spool cotton, thread, needles, pins, and numerous other articles greatly needed by the traitors. The articles were seized and removed to the headquarters of Gen. WOOL. The next steamer boarded was the Mary Washington. She was boarded when off the Seven Foot Knoll. On board of her was found sixteen rank rebels, who had just returned from Dixie. They had in their possession a large mail from Richmond. The whole party were taken to the Fort, they having positively refused to take the path. -- Baltimore Clipper, 4th.

abstract: Editorial calls period when Lincoln was Acting Comdr-of-Army most disastrous of war for Army of Potomac; lauds Halleck appointment
snippet: Editorial calls period when Lincoln was Acting Comdr-of-Army most disastrous of war for Army of Potomac; lauds Halleck appointment
lead_paragraph: To recite the decline of the national military prestige requires only a very few paragraphs. From the time when the principal command of the army was assigned to Gen. MCCLELLAN, June 23, 1861, to January 13, 1862, would constitute the first epoch. Throughout that period there was entire harmony of action between the President, his Secretary of War, and the General-in-Chief; and every energy of the Government was devoted to collecting, drilling and arming troops for campaigns, as yet only planned. It was an era of public patience, of peculation, and unpardonable delays.

abstract: Editorial on rush on NYC City Hall to file draft exemption papers
snippet: Editorial on rush on NYC City Hall to file draft exemption papers
lead_paragraph: BEWARE OF SHYSTERS. -- The rush or persons to the City Hall, for the purpose of filing exemption papers in the County Clerk's Office, has brought a flock of shysters to that locality, who have, for the past few days, driven a thriving business in exploiting the ignorance and credulity of the thousands who are now going on the errand just mentioned. It is fancied by many that every one, whether coming under the conditions that make him liable to military duty or not, is obliged to file exemption papers. Accordingly, hundreds and thousands, who are entirely out of the question of military duty or drafting (such as foreigners, persons under eighteen and over forty-five years of age, etc.,) are, under this false impression, running to the City Hall to do what they imagine to be their duty in the premises. These are eagerly seized by the shysters, who literally by hundreds invest the stairs, passages, subterranean lobbies, halls, rooms, etc., of the City Hall, and are either cajoled or coerced into some corner or chamber, (it is fortunate if the luckless "subject" escape being scrambled for by half-a-dozen of these creatures.) where exemption papers, for which the sharks charge from two to four shillings, are made out for them. They are then referred to the County Clerk's room, where they are swindled out of an additional shilling for a farcical "filing." Three-fourths of the persons who for the past two or three days have visited the City Hall are of this character; that is, persons who are not only "exempt," but not liable for military duty or drafting at all, and who consequently are under no call to file any affidavit whatever it is only those who are technically "exempt" (who these are may be seen in an article on the subject in another column) that are required to do this. As for the others, they need not concern themselves in the least about the matter. Unless they are "able-bodied white male citizens, between the ages of eighteen and forty-five" they do not come within the provisions of the law at all, and even if drafted would immediately be relieved on proving non-liability.
headline: {'main': 'A WORD TO EXEMPTS', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A WORD TO EXEMPTS', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The excitement caused by the first news of a draft being actually arranged has entirely subsided. It is clamly regarded by loyal people as a necessity, and is acquiesced in cheerfully. That adaptability to circumstances that readiness to accept a social or political change (a point of character which may be considered almost peculiar to the people of the United States), was never more strikingly exemplified.
lead_paragraph: The excitement caused by the first news of a draft being actually arranged has entirely subsided. It is clamly regarded by loyal people as a necessity, and is acquiesced in cheerfully. That adaptability to circumstances -- that readiness to accept a social or political change (a point of character which may be considered almost peculiar to the people of the United States), was never more strikingly exemplified. The only excitement openly manifested is by the foreign population. To them -- that is to the British and lush portion of their -- conscription is a sound of dread. Great Britain, in modern times, has never been engaged in a sufficiently important straggle on land, to require a levy en masse of her population, or even a recourse to forced enlistments. She had in the war with France, though, to press men into her naval service -- because it was at sea that she maintained the combat between the two countries. The press-gang is thought of to this day with honor, and the Briton believes his freedom from the conscriptive system of his despised French neighbor, the most conclusive corroboration of the truth of his perpetual assertion that he will 'never, never, never be a slave!" It is with feeling of consternation, therefore, which to the American are inexpressibly ludicrous, that all late or existing subjects of Queen VICTORIA look upon our draft. They, are thoroughly convinced that it is the death warrant of our free institutions, and the sure siga of impending ruin to the country, Nothing can be more amusing than to hear them discuss the matter in their usual places of resort -- especially when this is done under the exciting influence of "half-and-half." Of course we refer only to the Briton of imperfect education. The next most amusing thing is their rush upon their overwhelmed and obliging Consul. Mr. ARCHIBALD's office is besieged from morn till dewy eve. It is really an oppressive revelation to be in the neighborhood of Bowlinggreen, and have to tell every other person you meet that "that is the place he wants; the building there with a portico and two stone lion guarding the front door." There is not the slightest fear that Uncle Sam will kidnap his transatlantic cousins: but the cousins are insanely nervous upon the subject, and insist upon having enough papers to justify Lord PALMERSTON in sending over a fleet to blow New-York out of the water, if a single one of them suffers even the outrage of being called upon by Major PINCKNEY. Mr. ARCHIBALD has endeavored to [???] the overwhelming responsibilities of his position, by putting up outside his office a notice to the effect that British subjects who have never been naturalized abroad, are required by law to deposit the proof of their normality with the Country Clerk at the City Hall, and that thin will render them exempt from military service. No certificate of any kind from the Consul is required by law.

abstract: ARREST AND DISCHARGE OF MOCK-AUCTIONEERS. -- VALENTINE R. VAN SECELES, WM. H. STEPHENSand JOHN LEVY, whom the police characterize as mock-auctioneers, were arrested by officer FARRELL, of the Second Precinct, on a charge of fraud. Capt. SQUIRES makes the following report of the matter to General Superintendent KENNEDY: The above prisoners are mock-auctioneers, keeping Peter Funk shops at No. 1 Park Row, and in Chatham-street, where they daily swindle country people and unsuspecting persons who can be inveigled into their dens. They, yesterday, got hold of two soldiers who had recently been paid off, and filched about $25 out of them for brass watches, representing them to be gold, after which a sympathizing friend stepped up, told them they had been cheated and induced them to go to another Funk shop, where the watches were resold, and the poor soldiers were left minus money and watches. Justice BRENNAN, however, compelled them to disgorge their plunder, with the remarks, "It is my intention to break up these rascally dens, if possible." The "Peters" were discharged by the magistrate after refunding the money to their victims, whose names are JOHN S.

abstract: An overflowing house at Winter Garden, last evening, testified alike to the public interest in the Sickles Brigade, and the estimation of the splendid bill which Mr. FLEMING offered on the occasion. The "Hunchback," with Miss JANE COOMBS as Julia, Mr. FLEMING as Master Walter, and Miss EMILY THORNE as Helen, was a sufficient attraction of itself. The play was well received, as well as the excellent singing which succeeded it, and the dancing of the lady of the Cremorne Gardens.

abstract: Information received at headquarters states that Gen. ARMSTRONG, with the cavalry of the Army of the West, has taken Courtland, Alabama, capturing one hundred and fifty-nine prisoners and six cars. Our loss was two killed and eight wounded. The citizens of Courtland are frantic with delight at our appearance. Our next destination is Chattanooga.

abstract: In the original plan of the Southern insurrection, corresponding insurrections throughout the North formed a conspicuous part of the programme. Some of the Democratic leaders in the Free States were in close alliance with the plotters. They declared the democratic masses would never permit the Government to make war upon the rebellion; or, to use the language of a now repentant adherent of the party, "any regiment moving down Broadway to wage war upon the South would be mobbed and destroyed by the people." It is a matter of evidence that the details of this universal outbreak of violence were arranged, so far as this City was concerned. Men were enrolled, the officers selected, methods of secret communication established, and, but for the irresistible popular reaction, occasioned by the rebel blunder in attacking Fort Sumter, MANSFIELD LOVELL would have led the mob of New-York to the plunder of Wall-street, and the sack of Fifth-avenue. The accomplices of that ingrate were overawed by the great patriotic uprising and constrained to silence and inactivity.
lead_paragraph: In the original plan of the Southern insurrection, corresponding insurrections throughout the North formed a conspicuous part of the programme. Men were enrolled, the officers selected, methods of secret communication established, and, but for the irresistible popular reaction, occasioned by the rebel blunder in attacking Fort Sumter, MANSFIELD LOVELL would have led the mob of New-York to the plunder of Wall-street, and the sack of Fifth-avenue. abstract: GENERAL ORDER NO. 5. In order to maintain peace and quiet and protect persons and property from molestation or injury in this District, it will be necessary to occupy this place with a small force until the close of our national difficulties. abstract: On Wednesday evening,July 30, a band, under the lead of JOE THOMPSON, (many of whom had taken the oath and given bond,) entered Paris, cut down the flag pole, took the Sheriff and the clerks of the Circuit and County Courts prisoners, forced the keys of the jail from the jailor, set at liberty a man who was muleted for murder in the first degree, demanded of the Sheriff the warrant of commitment and all the money which he had collected for taxes, (but he having disposed of it, they got none.) They took the two clerks to the jail, in a room of which was the Clerk's office, and forced the Clerk of of the Circuit Court to deliver such indictments as JOE THOMPSON wanted. They took from some of the stores such goods as suited them, amounting to hundreds of dollars, pressed a wagon, and then loaded it and drove it off, forced the people to deliver their money, furnished them supper, &c. About night some four hundred joined them, also taking supper. After dark they left, taking off one prisoner. Next morning MCNEIL, with several hundred men, entered town about daylight, having marched all night. He had a battery of three pieces, and his men were well equipped. At night, having learned that PORTER, with a large force, was skedaddling north through the county, Col. MCNEIL left about dark in pursuit. PORTER's gang, as they passed through, took a great many horses, bridles and saddles. Major CALBWELL, and others, with a heavy force, battery, &c., were in pursuit.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening,July 30, a band, under the lead of JOE THOMPSON, (many of whom had taken the oath and given bond,) entered Paris, cut down the flag pole, took the Sheriff and the clerks of the Circuit and County Courts prisoners, forced the keys of the jail from the jailor, set at liberty a man who was muleted for murder in the first degree, demanded of the Sheriff the warrant of commitment and all the money which he had collected for taxes, (but he having disposed of it, they got none.) About night some four hundred joined them, also taking supper. After dark they left, taking off one prisoner.
