abstract: The abstract of the late debate in the House of Commons, on the subject of Canada, published by us yesterday, can hardly have failed to take, our readers by surprise, as we confess it did ourselves. We were not ignorant, indeed, of the fact that there is a considerable and growing party in England that favors not only allowing, but encouraging, the colonies to separate from the mother country, and set up for themselves whenever they feel so disposed. But we had supposed that this viewwas confined exclusively to a set of historical and political doctrinaires, and never for a moment entered the heads of practical statesmen. But it seems that the doctrine is not confined to historical philosophers, like Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH, or economists, like COBDEN or BRIGHT, but is shared by the leaders of English politics, Tory as well as Liberal. The War Minister, Sir CORNWALL LEWIS, frankly avowed that with regard to the future relations of Canada and Great Britain, he "looked forward without apprehension or regret to the period when she might become an independent State." Mr. ROEBUCK said that "the Canadian people had been induced to believe that the maintenance of their independence was of the greatest importance to England; we ought," he tartly added, "to show them that we do not care a farthing about their adherence to England."
lead_paragraph: The abstract of the late debate in the House of Commons, on the subject of Canada, published by us yesterday, can hardly have failed to take, our readers by surprise, as we confess it did ourselves. We were not ignorant, indeed, of the fact that there is a considerable and growing party in England that favors not only allowing, but encouraging, the colonies to separate from the mother country, and set up for themselves whenever they feel so disposed. But we had supposed that this viewwas confined exclusively to a set of historical and political doctrinaires, and never for a moment entered the heads of practical statesmen. But it seems that the doctrine is not confined to historical philosophers, like Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH, or economists, like COBDEN or BRIGHT, but is shared by the leaders of English politics, Tory as well as Liberal. The War Minister, Sir CORNWALL LEWIS, frankly avowed that with regard to the future relations of Canada and Great Britain, he "looked forward without apprehension or regret to the period when she might become an independent State." Mr. ROEBUCK said that "the Canadian people had been induced to believe that the maintenance of their independence was of the greatest importance to England; we ought," he tartly added, "to show them that we do not care a farthing about their adherence to England."
headline: {'main': 'Canada Gets the Cold Shoulder.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Canada Gets the Cold Shoulder.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: These Clubs played a match at Hoboken yesterday afternoon, and the once famous Empires were badly beaten by the rising Henry Eckfords. It is but just to say that several of the Empire's best men have left them for other organizations, notwithstanding which disadvantage they batted pretty pluckily for their score. The Henry Eckfords did some of the tallest kind of batting, but were missed a number of times. Dr. BELL not only pitched well, but also made a home run.

abstract: -- We are glad to learn that recruiting for the July call has improved so rapidly in this City, and throughout the State and country within the last ten days. This week, in New-York, it has been particularly brisk. If it goes on increasing for the next eight days, as it has done for the last eight, we shall have our State quota in the field before the 15th, and drafting for the three years' men will not need to be resorted to. We hope this will be the case.

lead_paragraph: Upon no class of our fellow-citizens has the draft produced a livelier effect than upon the Germans of this City and neighborhood. The German papers, one and all, approve of the measure, only wishing that it had been adopted long ago, before the armed force of the rebellion had acquired such de- velopment. The radical German papers do not let slip the occasion to urge that the President shall at once give to the war the utmost latitude of operation in reference to freeing and arming the slaves in the South. The conservative papers are less violent, yet they [???] with their contemporaries in making [???] appeals to the Germans in America to give [???] proofs of their attachment to that Government for which, within the past 16 months, they have so freely shed their blood on every battle-field of the war. These appeals, the certainty of speedy drafting, and the [???] of securing the [???] the [???] to their [???] by [???] volunteering, have given a [???] and [???] to [???] among the Germans.

abstract: The news we have had from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army, the last three or four days, shows a more cheering and hopeful condition of affairs than has existed since the battles of June. The vigor which Gen. HALLECK has brought to the conduct of the war is beginning to give forth its first fruits. The army is represented as being in as good condition and spirit now as ever it was. The men do not seem to be at all affected by the depression of feeling which has prevailed so extensively in the North; and their devotionto, and faith in their commander is as great as ever it was -- if we may credit the all but unanimous testimony of correspondents. The army's confidence and courage has doubtless also by this time been vastly augmented by the news of the prodigious musters of troops called for by the President, and by the way in which these calls are being responded to by the people. Our gallant soldiers will now sec that they are not to be left to wage hopeless battles with an enemy whose strength is twice or thrice as great as theirs; but that hundreds of thousands of comrades are hastening forward to stand by them shoulder to shoulder in their future contests. The order of the War Department peremptorily commanding all absentees who are capable of duty to return at once to field service, has already added to their strength hundreds of officers and thousands of men; and has had the best effect upon them. The employment of blacks as laborers has relieved them from a good deal of the excessive fatigue duty to which they have heretofore been subjected; and they sec that it is only the beginning of a policy which will relieve them from unendurable labors, and save to thousands of them life and health. Their sanitary condition is greatly improving, owing to their healthier location, the addition of vegetables and fresh meals to their diet, and the general improvement in spirits and prospect of active service. They see also that the large and splendid army of Gen. [???], or soon will be, in a position where it can act as a cooperating force; and that his movements forbid that they should be compelled to lie much longer on the sultry banks of the [???], watching against the as adults of a desperate and overpowering foe. More than all these in their good effects upon the soldiers, have been the daring and successful reconnaissance's made by detachments of the army within the past week. The first expedition toward the rebel line since Gen. MCCLELLAN reached the James, was mode a week ago to-day, when a force was sent northward, crossed the Chickahominy, penetrated as far as Gaines Hill, and found that, in that direction, there was no enemy for a distance of nearly twenty miles. This was followed, on the next day, by the expedition to the south side of the James River, which was altogether successful, and has resulted in the occupation, by Gen. PORTER's Division, of the high grounds on the south bank, from which the enemy menaced our encampment, and in the discovery that the rebels had no great force south of the Appomattox. Again, this morning, we learn of a series of reconnoissances, under the immediate direction of Gen. MCCLELLAN, made on Monday and Tuesday of this week, in the direction of Richmond, reaching to within ten miles of that city, and, after a series of brisk skirmishes, ending by the encamping of the reconnoitering parties upon Malvern Hill. The telegraph jubilantly announces that "the Army of the Potomac has again assumed the offensive;" and though as yet it necessarily does this on a small scale, it is sufficient to greatly encourage the troops, while the results and the discoveries made are highly gratifying to the country. The army is now all ready, in case the enemy should attempt to make an attack; and is eager for sufficient reinforcements, so as to be at once the attacking party.

abstract: At 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the basement of the Rainbow Hotel, at Nos. 31 and 33 Beekman-street, occupied by WM. J. HOWELL The flames spread rapidly, and the whole building was very soon enveloped in flames. The three upper floors of the building were occupied by CHARLES W BAKER, envelope manufacturer. Building No. 29 Beekman-street took fire and was totally destroyed, as well as the hotel, together with a three-story brick building in the rear of No. 61 Ann-street, and the four-story brown-stone building No. 165 Williamstreet A number of the buildings adjoining werebadly damaged by the fire, but were not totally destroyed. The firemen were busily engaged throughout the day in extinguishing the fire and cleaning away the debris. The losses and insurances have not been fully ascertained, but the former, it is estimated, will not fall short of $150,000.

abstract: The busy days of July have been succeeded by very dull ones, so far as the Warehouse Department is concerned. The efforts of importers owning [???] goods, thanks to the Collector, were successful, and few of the old entries now remain in store. The difference between the rates levied by the acts of 1857 and 1861 and those imposed by that of July, 1862, was too great to admit of delay, in withdrawing old entries and a consequent risk to importers of being compelled to pay the new rates required by the new act. A few only of the owners of merchandise bonded before the act of August, 1861, took effect, were unable to pay duty, and gain possession thereof, and these few, through their neglect, lost consideration money. The receipts for July were nearly $7,200,000.

abstract: It is no fault of Lord PALMERSTON that intervention has not long ago beoome the policy of the British Government. Some shortsighted persons in Europe, as in this country, may have been induced to believe, from the English Premier's speech on Mr. LINDSAY'S motion for Southern recognition, that his Lordship's opinions have undergone a change; but it must not be overlooked that in temporarily shelving that motion, Mr. FORSTER'S amendment was purposely overslaughed ...
lead_paragraph: It is no fault of Lord PALMERSTON that intervention has not long ago become the policy of the British Government. Some shortsighted persons in Europe, as in this country, may have been induced to believe, from the English Premier's speech on Mr. LINDSAY's motion for Southern recognition, that his Lordship's opinions have undergone a change; but it must not be overlooked that in temporarily shelving that motion, Mr. FORSTER's amendment was purposely overslaughed -- an amendment, in fact, pledging the Government to an honest and strict neutrality. During the remainder of the Parliamentary session, we may be safe from the assaults of such Southern sympathizers as LINDSAY and GREGORY, but we are perfectly justified in fearing the worst when the adjournment shall have left the question in the hands of Her Majesty's advisers, uncontroled, as they will then be, by their Parliamentary supporters.

abstract: The Produce Merchants held a second recruiting meeting, yesterday, at the Produce Exchange. Speeches were made by Gen. MEAGHER, Gen. SICKLES, STEWART L. WOODFORD, Esq., JOSEPH HOXIE, Esq., Hon. MOSES F. ODELL, and a large addition to the subscription list of $10,000 was made on the spot. The spirit of the meeting was decidedly up to the war standard, and the utmost willingness manifested to sustain the Government, fill up the old regiments, and do all in their power to put down the unholy rebellion.

abstract: At an adjourned special meeting of this Board, yesterday, after the reading of the minutes, Aldermen BCOZE moved to suspend the regular order of  business for the purpose of taking up the ...
lead_paragraph: At an adjourned special meeting of this Board, yesterday, after the reading of the minutes, Alderman BOOLE moved to suspend the regular order of business for the purpose of taking up the preamble and resolutions, presented by him at the last meeting, offering an extra bounty of $50 to any volunteer who should enlist in either of the regiments raised in this City and now in the field. The motion having been carried, Alderman BOOLE moved an amendment to the last of his resolutions, adding to the Committee to promote enlistments, the Republican Central Committees, both American and German. The amendment was adopted without opposition, and a motion to adopt the resolutions, as amended, being made. Alderman DAYTON wished to know how the mover of the resolutions, or the Chairman of the Committee on National Affairs, reconciled these resolutions with the report made by that Committee a few days since, in which they state that the inducements already held out to volunteers by the State and National Government was amply sufficient, and all that could be desired by any reasonable man. He proceeded to read extracts from said report, but was repeatedly called to order, the point being that he was discussing a matter not before the Board. The points of order being overruled by the Chair, Alderman DAYTON proceeded to state that at the time the report alluded to was made he was in favor of giving a bounty of one hundred dollars, to al recruits for this City; he was still in favor of giving such bounty, and be contended that volunteers for new regiments would undergo equal hardships, and were as much entitle to the bounty as recruits for the old regiments. He was also in favor of granting the bounty to soldiers now serving in the old regiments an well as to new recruits. He closed by moving, as an amendment, that the bounty of $50 be also given to members of the old regiments now serving in the field.

abstract: Considerable damage was done by the severe storm on Tuesday evening, in this city and vicinity. A number of small crafts were wrecked in Gowanus Bay, and vessels were forced from their fastenings along the docks, on the river front, by the violence of the wind, and several small frame buildings in the outskirts of the city, together with fences and outhouses, were more or less injured. So far as known, ...
lead_paragraph: Considerable damage was done by the severe storm on Tuesday evening, in this city and vicinity. A number of small crafts were wrecked in Gowanus Bay, and vessels were forced from their fastenings along the docks, on the river front, by the violence of the wind, and several small frame buildings in the outskirts of the city, together with fences and outhouses, were more or less injured. So far as known, the lightning did not strike any building within the city limits, but, just beyond, considerable damage was done to buildings and other property. The bright light seen from the city in the direction of Bedford, at about 9 1/2 o'clock, was caused by the burning of a large barn belonging to ISAAC C. SCHENCK, Esq., on the Jamaica Plank Road, in the town of New Lotts. It was struck by lightning and entirely destroyed by fire, together with the contents, consisting of hay and grain, nine cows and one horse. It was occupied by DANIEL BARKER. In an instant after the subtle fluid had struck the building the whole premises were enveloped in a sheet of flame as if it had been fired simultaneously at all points, and all attempts to save the live stock were abortive. The loss is estimated at $5,000. A building was struck at Rockaway, (said to be the Pavilion Hotel,) and also destroyed by fire -- the particulars of which have not been ascertained.

abstract: Mr. Edson B. Olds, who a few days ago, used language in the course of an address to the citizens of Bern Township, Ohio, which sounded amazingly like treason, has seen fit to explain his position, and in doing so, does not better matters much. He says:
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. Edson B. Olds, who a few days ago, used language in the course of an address to the citizens of Bern Township, Ohio, which sounded amazingly like treason, has seen fit to explain his position, and in doing so, does not better matters much. He says: "What I said was substantially this: That whilst this war was prosecuted for the putting down of rebellion, and the maintenance of the Constitution as it is and the Union as it was,' the Democracy would freely shed their blood, and liberally give their money, but so soon as it ceased to be a war for the suppression of rebellion, and became an Abolition war, no Democrat would be found willing to volunteer. I further remarked that the Government in all probability would make a draft for soldiers, and that that drafting would be in the hands of Republicans; that the party would want to keep Republicans at home to vote, and want to send Democrats away so that they could not vote, and that no fair draft would be made; and that if any Democrat believed that he had been fraudulently drafted, he would refuse to go, and that then a file of soldiers would be sent after him, and that under such circumstances he would resist, even at the point of the bayonet, and that in this way civil war would be brought upon us in Ohio. Not one word was said as advising resistance, but all was told as a vision of what would be future events. Now, Mr. Editor, let me repeat, as a warning to the Republicans, that no unfair or fraudulent drafting will be submitted to. A word to the wise should be sufficient."

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 25th inst., Mr. ADDERLEY wished, before the Secretary for War rose to reply to the question that had been put to him, to make a few observations upon a most important subject.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 25th inst., Mr. ADDERLEY wished, before the Secretary for War rose to reply to the question that had been put to him, to make a few observations upon a most important subject. It was most desirable that Parliament should not separate without some distinct statement being made of the intentions of the Government as to the defence of Canada. It was their right and duty, as it was the right and Interest of the Canadians, to know what were the intentions of the Government in view of the possible If not probable dangers of the approaching Winter. In the first place, he would wish to know whether the Government considered that Canada was exposed to any danger. If not, why were 12,000 British troops retained in that colony; and if there was danger, to what did they look for defence against that danger? The noble lord at the head of the Government had urged upon the House the duty of protecting the country against invasion, but in respect of Canada, which was more vulnerable, he had not urged any precautions either in this country or in the colony. At the commencement of last Winter, 12,000 British troops were sent out in great haste to meet an apprehended danger, and to enable Canada to prepare her means for self-defence. There was no Quixotic intention to defend Canada by means of forces sent from this country, nor to exempt the Canadians from military service; but the aid was sent to assist and to encourage them in preparing their own means of defence.

abstract: Editorial on current lull in war
snippet: Editorial on current lull in war
lead_paragraph: "A peerage or Westminster Abbey," said NELSON, when he first descried the French fleet at anchor in the Bay of Aboukir. Fate was propitious this time, and the brave Admiral won the title which he bore till the fatal day of Trafalgar. But valued as was the distinction bestowed by his grateful country, it was probably not more highly prized by NELSON than was the simple copper medal, bestowed in acknowledgement of surpassing courage and devotion, by certain sailors and marines who helped to win the Battle of the Nile. Prize money is a capital thing in its way, and few honest tars object to receiving it; but the indestructible token of a nation's gratitude, which they may carry through life, and bequeath to their children, is a prize which money cannot buy, and which, to some natures, is the more powerful incentive. It is a silent but perpetual witness in favor of the character and worth of the wearer; and long after the prize money is scattered to the winds, its appeal has gained aid and asylum for the veteran, when decrepid age has left him no other resource.

abstract: The loss of that splendid steamship, the Golden Gate, accompanied by the sacrifice of a hundred and eighty lives, falls upon the community, used as it is to the waste of life, ...
lead_paragraph: The loss of that splendid steamship, the Golden Gate, accompanied by the sacrifice of a hundred and eighty lives, falls upon the community, used as it is to the waste of life, as a fearful shock and calamity. The disaster was wholly unexpected. In the Eastern Pacific half the terrors of sea travel are disarmed. In July there are no frightful gales and tremendous seas to imperil the strength of the vessel. Unless the pilot wander from a well-defined course, there are no reefs and shoals where he may be suddenly sunk. So plain and secure has been the journey from San Francisco to Panama, that the voyager has come to regard it as less formidable than the crossing of an inland ferry.

abstract: Telegrams received in this City yesterday announced the loss of the steamer Golden Gate, which left San Francisco on the 21st of July for Panama, with 230 passengers, $1,114,000 in treasure for this City, and $270,000 for England.
lead_paragraph: Telegrams received in this City yesterday announced the loss of the steamer Golden Gate, which left San Francisco on the 21st of July for Panama, with 230 passengers, $1,114,000 in treasure for this City, and $270,000 for England. She was burnt at sea, near Manzanillo, on the coast of Mexico, on the 27th of July, and one hundred and eighty of her passengers and twenty of her crew lost. There appears to be some doubt about the loss of the treasure, as some of the dispatches received express the belief that it might be saved -- the ship being beached. Full particulars are delayed by an interruption of telegraphic communication.

abstract: -The present is a moment of great quietude all over the field of military operations. Doubtless, if the rebel leaders intend to attack any of our armies, or to attempt an advance anywhere, they will do it soon. They have got the news before now that by the 15th of this month, or shortly thereafter, the three hundred thousand three-years' troops will be in the field, and about the same time the three hundred thousand nine-months' men -- a grand army six hundred thousand strong -- will have been enlisted. It cannot be that they are waiting till we get our full million of soldiers all under arms before they try the issue of battle. That will certainly be at least twice the number of men that JEFF DAVIS has in his service. They know that while at present their army may outnumber ours, by the end of this month ours will vastly outnumber theirs. In Virginia alone we shall probably concentrate a half million men, before September. They know that now is the most favorable opportunity they will ever have to make a bold and desperate stroke at MCCLELLAN, or at POPE, or at Washington. There are signs that they are again preparing to attack Gen. MCCLELLAN; and the telegraph this morning announces that they are advancing in force toward Malvern Hill, which our troops occupied on Tuesday last, and which it is said to be the intention of Gen. MCCLELLAN to hold. We are glad to learn that Gen. MCCLELLAN's position has been greatly strengthened, that he can be aided by the gunboats and mortar fleet, and that, though the rebels may think this is our weakest time, we may yet be much stronger than they know of.

abstract: The  Annual Commencement of this Institution, at Hamilton, N.Y., will open on Sunday evening, Aug. 17, by a sermon before the Society for Inquiry, by Rev. Dr. EVERTS, of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: -- The Annual Commencement of this Institution, at Hamilton, N.Y., will open on Sunday evening, Aug. 17, by a sermon before the Society for Inquiry, by Rev. Dr. EVERTS, of Chicago. On Monday evening following, will occur the Anniversary of the AEonian and Adelphian Societies. The Oration will be by the distinguished author and lecturer, GEO. WM. CURTIS, Esq.. The Poem will be given by BENJAMIN F. TAYLOR, A.M., formerly editor of the Chicago Journal. Addresses and Reports before the Education Society will be delivered on Tuesday. The Sermon will be by Rev. Dr. WESTON, of this City. The Oration before the "Alumni and Friends" will be delivered on the same evening, by Rev. REUBEN JEFFREY, D.D., of Philadelphia.

abstract: The recent debate in the English Parliament on Canadian affairs, an extended report of which may be found on another page, has no parallel in the history of the British Empire.
lead_paragraph: The recent debate in the English Parliament on Canadian affairs, an extended report of which may be found on another page, has no parallel in the history of the British Empire. The people of Canada are pointedly told that it is of no sort of consequence to the English Government whether they remain a component part of the Kingdom or not. Now, Canada is one of the largest dependencies of the English Crown. It has cost the mother country many millions of pounds to hold and fortify it. It has cost many millions more to build railroads and canals, and immense bridges, to develop it. It has cost larger sums still to guard it against apprehensions of American cupidity, and to settle international quarrels growing out of the Northeastern boundary, the burning of the steamer Caroline, and the capture of the Confederate envoys by Capt. WILKES. Canada, from having been a poor and sparsely settled Province, has grown to be a respectable and comparatively prosperous country. It has never been of any pecuniary value to the British Government, but now is in a fair way to become so, if the population has intelligence and energy to make available the vast improvements that British wealth has introduced among them. It is just at this moment that English statesmen declare to the world that the retention of Canada is not an object of their desire, and that the people of Canada may assume their independence whenever they think proper to do so.

abstract: A NEW METRE An ingenious individual has invented a new water metre, which has been satisfactorily tested by the authorities of Brooklyn, and is approved by the Water Commissioners of that city.
lead_paragraph: A NEW METRE. -- An ingenious individual has invented a new water metre, which has been satisfactorily tested by the authorities of Brooklyn, and is approved by the Water Commissioners of that city. The metre is readily attached to the service pipe, occupying but a trifling additional space, and may be placed in any position required. The peculiar advantages claimed in this invention are simplicity of construction and action, perfect accuracy in measurement, having no close compartments, it is self-cleaning, will not become foul, or get out of order, the sediment of the water not being retained, as in other metres of water-tight compartments. Also in affecting a great reduction of the expense, being furnished at about half the cost of any other metre now in use, and the friction being reduced to the smallest possible extent, the wear of the metre to one point or axle, which can be replaced at trifling cost. The metre was tested in every manner with the most satisfactory results to the gentlemen present, and was found to work with unerring accuracy under all circumstances.

abstract: All the men raised under the President's requisition for three hundred thousand men for three years  or the war, that can be so used legitimately, will be used to fill up the depleted ranks of the old regiments now in the field. Faith will of course be kept with new regiments which can quite or nearly complete their organization by the 15th inst., but there is little...
lead_paragraph: All the men raised under the President's requisition for three hundred thousand men for three years or the war, that can be so used legitimately, will be used to fill up the depleted ranks of the old regiments now in the field. Faith will of course be kept with new regiments which can quite or nearly complete their organization by the 15th inst., but there is little doubt that all bodies of recruits existing in a fragmentary condition on that date, will be rendered available in the readiest way that offers. It is calculated that this three hundred thousand -- all of whom are confidently expected to come on voluntarily -- will be sufficient to carry into effect the military measures immediately resolved upon at Washington. The second three hundred thousand, which are to be raised by a prompt draft of the enrolled militia, will probably not be called into active service -- not the whole of them, at any rate. They will more likely be used for garrison duty, and, to some extent, as a reserve from which occasional detachments can be drawn to strengthen any given point or army. Until the early part of Winter they will, it is said, be retained hard at work in camps of instruction, there to be thoroughly disciplined in their school of the soldier, and made fit, by the and of their term, to form the commissioned and non-commissioned nucleii for fresh drafts for active and reserve duty.

abstract: editorial on Lincoln speech
snippet: editorial on Lincoln speech
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN did an honor to himself in doing justice to Secretary STANTON, in the brief speech he delivered at the war meeting in Washington, on Wednesday afternoon. He declared that the Secretary of War had, at no time, withheld anything from Gen. MCCLELLAN that it was in the President's power to give him. And he further asserted that the supposed quarrel between STANTON and MCCLELLAN had less existence between them than between some of those presuming to be their friends.

snippet: Editorial on report Rhode Island has called for Negro regiment under state's rights theory
lead_paragraph: The Tribune shouts "Eureka" over a startling discovery it has just made. It has found out an ingenious solution of the problem of employing negro regiments. "State Rights" is the Open Sesame that is to unlock the desperate puzzle. Gov. SPRAGUE has called for a negro regiment, as part of the quota of Rhode Island. The Constitution and laws of Rhode Island treat whites and blacks alike, entitling the latter to vote on the same terms as the former; and therefore, it argues, "Rhode Island has a clear right to the service of all, whenever their service is needed." From these premises the Tribune proceeds thus to expatiate :

abstract: RELIGIOUS SERVICES IN THE JERSEY CITY ALMSHOUSE. The question of dividing the religious services in the Jersey City Almshouse under two distinct forms Protestant and Catholic which is ...
lead_paragraph: RELIGIOUS SERVICES IN THE JERSEY CITY ALMSHOUSE. -- The question of dividing the religious services in the Jersey City Almshouse under two distinct forms -- Protestant and Catholic -- which is brought before each succeeding Common Council, was again revived at the meeting of the Board on Tuesday evening. Alderman KANE offered a resolution directing that the same privileges be granted to Catholic ladies to teach children in the Almshouse as are extended to ladies of other denominations. Considerable discussion ensued, when the whole matter was laid over for future consideration. The object of this resolution is to divide the children into two classes, those of Catholic parentage to be taught exclusively by Catholic teachers, and those of Protestant birth to be taught by Protestants, instead of being taught together alternately by Protestants and Catholics, as at present.

abstract: -- It will be noticed that the Metropolitan Police force has been invited by the President of the Police Board to volunteer for the military service of their country. We think that those who do not enlist themselves, should, like the employes of the City Post-office, be required to furnish at least one recruit for the army. The Police force comprises twenty-three hundred able-bodied men in the prime of life; and, if each of these men who does not enlist himself wen to furnish a substitute, it would give us at once three regiments of 750 men each. The volunteering closes next week, and there must be no time lost.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are again important this morning. We have a dispatch dated yesterday, and a letter from out special correspondent dated the day before, giving ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are again important this morning. We have a dispatch dated yesterday, and a letter from out special correspondent dated the day before, giving details of the expedition to Malvern Hill, with the announcement that it is the intention of Gen. MCCLELLAN to hold that position. The General proceeded there on Tuesday afternoon, and remained through the night, and COUCH's Division was sent up to reinforce HOOKER, who had already a considerable force there. It was rumored also that another division was to be sent up on Wednesday morning -- a proceeding probably rendered necessary by the movement of a considerable rebel force from Richmond, with the intention of recapturing their lost position. That they entertain such an intention is believed from the reports of deserters and contrabands, who reached headquarters on Wednesday night. At Malvern Hill, however, our forces can have the cooperation of Commodore WILKES' gunboats, the acquaintance of which the rebels will not care about renewing at short range. Three thousand of our men, exchanged prisoners, arrived from Richmond on Wednesday afternoon. These lit to do duty were immediately sent to their regiments.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, at Chambers, before Justice BARNARD, A.A. SELOVER and Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT were sued by JOHN S. GILES, as the maker and indorser of a promissory note for $2,000, in which ...
lead_paragraph: In the Supreme Court, at Chambers, before Justice BARNARD, A.A. SELOVER and Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT were sued by JOHN S. GILES, as the maker and indorser of a promissory note for $2,000, in which judgment resulted against them for that amount with costs. Execution being issued and returned by the Sheriff unsatisfied, plaintiff's attorney obtained an order for examining defendants on supplementary proceedings, returnable Aug. 7. Gen. FREMONT failing to appear and submit to an examination, the attorney for plaintiff, yesterday, applied for an order to arrest the General for contempt of Court.

abstract: Steamship Golden Gate destroyed by fire en route from San Francisco to Panama; 180 dead
snippet: Steamship Golden Gate destroyed by fire en route from San Francisco to Panama; 180 dead
lead_paragraph: Dispatches reached this City yesterday announcing the destruction of the steamship Golden Gate by five. She left San Francisco, July 21, for Panama, with two hundred and thirty passengers, $1,114,000 in treasure for New-York, and $270,000 for England. She was burnt at sea July 27, and one hundred and eighty passengers, twenty of her crew, and all the treasure lost.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF A STAB ESCAPE OF THE PERPETRATOR. JOHN MAGNIN, the man who was stabbed late on Monday night last, during a fight which took place at the corner of Catharine and ...
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF A STAB -- ESCAPE OF THE PERPETRATOR. -- JOHN MAGNIN, the man who was stabbed late on Monday night last, during a fight which took place at the corner of Catharine and Cherry streets, died in the New-York Hospital, yesterday afternoon. The friends of deceased allege that, seeing an altercation on the corner, he ran to quell it, or otherwise interfered, when some man at present unknown, stabbed him in the pit of the stomach with a knife, and ran away. A sailor's boarding-house runner, well known in Water-street, is strongly suspected as being the assailant, and the Fourth Ward Police are in search of him. Coroner COLIN was notified, and will hold an inquest on the body to-day. Deceased was a single man, about 40 years of age. He lived within a few doors of where his death-blow was received.

abstract: We have received our usual early copy of the Annual Report of the British Board of Trade, which will be found very suggestive at the present moment. One of the most striking features of this report is, that while the ...
lead_paragraph: We have received our usual early copy of the Annual Report of the British Board of Trade, which will be found very suggestive at the present moment. One of the most striking features of this report is, that while the British exports have been enormously diminished, the imports, especially from this country, have been much increased. The value of the manufactured products which England sent abroad in 1861, was nearly eleven million sterling less than were exported in the preceding year. Of this serious decrease, more than nine-tenths was due to the falling off in the trade with the United States. For, in 1860, the total value of the British products entered at our ports, amounted to twenty-one and a half millions, while last year it declined to nine millions, showing a diminution of upwards of twelve million, or nearly sixty percent.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Jura off Cape Race yesterday morning, we receive intelligence from Europe to the 1st inst. five days later. The United States steam-frigate Tuscarora had ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Jura off Cape Race yesterday morning, we receive intelligence from Europe to the 1st inst. -- five days later. The United States steam-frigate Tuscarora had left Southampton, and it was supposed she was in chase of the steamer Merrimac, which had sailed on the day previous from Plymouth, having on board a large cargo of ammunition, etc., for the rebels. Cotton had advanced again in the Liverpool market, and the tendency was still upward. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 94, for money.

abstract: The keel of Mr. ROWLAND'S fourth vessel was laid yesterday at Greenpoint. She is to be exclusively iron, and will be of extraordinary strength. A large number of persons was present on the occasion, and the foreman who has the supervision of the work ...
lead_paragraph: The keel of Mr. ROWLAND's fourth vessel was laid yesterday at Greenpoint. She is to be exclusively iron, and will be of extraordinary strength. A large number of persons was present on the occasion, and the foreman who has the supervision of the work mustered all the employes to participate in the act. She will be 226 feet long, 48 feet wide, and 13 feet deep. She will have two turrets, and be finished in a few months. Her tonnage will be over 1,000. The machinery is to be built at the Morgan Iron Works in this City.

abstract: Our special Correspondents with the army and navy on the coast of South Carolina and Georgia, send us highly exciting accounts, which we print this morning, of the extreme peril of our troops and slips under command of Gen. HUNTER and Admiral DUPONT.
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondents with the army and navy on the coast of South Carolina and Georgia, send us highly exciting accounts, which we print this morning, of the extreme peril of our troops and slips under command of Gen. HUNTER and Admiral DUPONT. It seems that the great ram at Savannah, on which the rebels have been at work for a long time, is completed, and has of late been frequently in sight from the walls of Fort Pulaski, moving about under an easy head of steam; she threatens to come down, run past Fort Pulaski, destroy our fleet at Hilton Head and thereabouts, and operate against our works and our troops on the sea-islands. If she succeeds in crushing our wooden gunboats -- as all our past experience with iron-clad rebel rams shows she is likely enough to do -- the rebels will have obtained an unmolested crossing for the rafts which they are known to have been busily building of late in every creek and bayou along the shore; and our well-posted correspondent thinks they will in all human probability be enabled to wrest back from us every foot of ground now under the Union flag in South Carolina and Georgia. It is the opinion of those best informed that the Savannah ram is only delaying the beginning of her work until the large rebel land force, massed on the railroad at points not far distant from Hilton Head, is in readiness to cross over and cooperate with her.

abstract: President HOPKINS opened the exercises of Commencement week at Williams College, on Sunday last, with the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class. He took his textfrom Peter II., 4-5: ...
lead_paragraph: President HOPKINS opened the exercises of Commencement week at Williams College, on Sunday last, with the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class. He took his textfrom Peter ii., 4-5: "To whom coming as unto a living stone, disallowed indeed of men, but chosen of God and precious, ye also as lively stones are built up a spiritual house." In the evening the address before the Mills Theological Society was delivered by Rev. DWIGHT W. MARSH, lately a missionary at Mosul. He opened his address with a reference to the condition of the country, and acknowledged the necessity of every young man devoting himself to her service, but considered it wrong, even under these circumstances, to neglect the missionary cause, in behalf of which he spoke. The missionary life is desirable because it causes those who follow it to become like Christ. To prove this was the object of his remarks. The speaker was instructive and at times eloquent, and those were fully repaid for their attendance who heard him.

abstract: Current scene
snippet: Current scene
lead_paragraph: The accounts of GARIBALDI's visit to Marsala record an extraordinary scene of patriotic excitement. GARIBALDI, in the course of his speech, several times made use of the phrase "Rome or death," to which the people responded each time, "Yes, Rome or death!" He spoke in violent terms of NAPOLEON, and said: "We have given Nice and Savoy, and he wishes for something more. Yes, I know he has one Prince ready for Rome, and another for Naples, and soon I know it."

abstract: Lorenzo Seus vs. Joseph Buisson. -- An order was granted under section 153 of the Code, as amended by the Laws of 1860, that the plaintiff's reply to certain new matter set up in the answer, which was a defence by way of avoidance. The order was grant-by Justice Clerke ex parte. An order was then made to show cause why that order should not be set aside, on the ground that it was granted ex parte, the counsel for plaintiff contending that notice should have been given. Defendant's counsel contended, in opposition, that as the granting of the order was in the discretion of the judge, to be exercised only on the inspection of the pleadings, no notice was necessary. The Judge took the papers.

abstract: -- The London Times, speaking of the draft of soldiers for the Union cause, says "the scheme of a forcible levy of troops in a republic to subjugate and hold down another republic is one that will hardly be seriously proposed even by the more fanatical of Mr. LINCOLN's advisers." But the scheme of a forcible levy of troops in one part of the republic to put down and destroy the Government, encountered no such protest from the London Times. That scheme was quite in keeping with its notions of propriety. JEFF. DAVIS is cheered at Oxford for it. Everything in John Bull's eyes is quite lawful and proper which aims at destroying the Government of the United States: nothing which aims to preserve it can be tolerated. John will see the result of his teachings on the subject by-and-by.

abstract: Editorial says Phillips speaks against Adm
snippet: Editorial says Phillips speaks against Adm
lead_paragraph: -- WENDELL PHILLIPS is stumping Massachusetts against the Administration. He objects to its method of carrying on the war, and denounces the President, the Cabinet, Gen. MCCLELLAN and everybody else connected with the Government. He speaks of Gen. MCCLELLAN as no better than a "traitor." Now we should like to know what Mr. PHILLIPS means by "treason." A year or two ago, in a public lecture at Brooklyn, he declared that he was not an American citizen -- that he had never taken the oath of allegiance to the Constitution -- that he never voted or took any part in public affairs, and that he never would do so, as long as the Constitution tolerated the existence of Slavery.

abstract: Editorial on rush of men seeking exemption from draft
snippet: Editorial on rush of men seeking exemption from draft
lead_paragraph: -- The rush for certificates of exemption from military duty is an incident worth remembering. The names of these patriots who are so anxious not to serve their country should be perpetuated. We have heard of some very extraordinary steps taken by individuals to disable themselves for service. We know of one young man, robust, vigorous, and supposed to be of average respectability, who cut off the forefinger of his right hand to escape the draft. Such heroism ought to be held in everlasting remembrance. We intend to collect material for a history of all such cases. We shall be greatly obliged for authentic reports of every such incident. Our readers in all parts of the country will confer a favor by sending us accounts of them. The memory of these cowardly sneaks ought not to perish.

abstract: The Petersburgh Express learns from gentlemen who made observations from Coggin's Point, last Wednesday, that the Federal fleet then comprised 150 vessels, among which the names of the Vanderbilt, the Metanora, and ten other large steamers, were legible by the aid of a telescope. During Wednesday four large transports, loaded with troops, came up the river. The number of tents at Berkeley seemed less than on the week before. This may have been owing to a removal to the forests back of Berkeley. Persons in the neighborhood think MCCLELLAN's force has been reduced, but are not positive, on that point. A balloon yelept "The Intrepid," containing two persons, made an ascension, and hovered for two hours over MCCLELLAN's camp.

abstract: No locality in this City has had the name of being more thoroughly loyal, since the rebellion broke out, than Washington Market. The boys who do business there will not tolerate anything that has the least squinting toward secesh, and they have a ...
lead_paragraph: No locality in this City has had the name of being more thoroughly loyal, since the rebellion broke out, than Washington Market. The boys who do business there will not tolerate anything that has the least squinting toward secesh, and they have a way of treating sympathizers with treason, which, though not quite so barbarous as the treatment dealt out to Union men by the rebels, has nevertheless proved quite effectual hitherto. Whenever a secession blower appears among them, they immediately chuck him into a barrel that has been used for keeping fish, and put another barrel of the same kind over his head. If the weather is warm, the fellow generally comes out a good Union man, in about five minutes; if it is cool, it sometimes takes longer, but never more than half an hour. Yesterday, a gray-headed butcher, named DIEBOLD MILLMAN, who has got himself rich by selling meat to loyal citizens, took it into his head to turn traitor, and began cursing the Government in the most approved secesh style. He "would see them (the Government) d -- d, before he would allow his sons to join their d -- d Union army." He soon had a large crowd of listeners around him, which only appeared to exasperate him still more, until finally his harangue became so violent and outrageous that the boys considered his case beyond the fish-barrel treatment, and began to talk seriously about hanging the old rascal. At this juncture, a policeman made his appearance, and, to save further trouble, arrested the speaker, and took him to the United States Marshal's Office, whither he was followed by about 50 persons, all ready to swear to his treasonable utterances. The Marshal being absent at Washington, the prisoner was taken to the Police Headquarters, and after remaining a short time in custody, he expressed his willingness to take the oath of allegiance, and denied that he was any other than a good Union man. As for his sons, whom he was charged with swearing that he would not allow to enlist, he said they had already enlisted in the Eighth Regiment. In view of these facts, and the apparent sincerity of his penitence, he was conducted before Commissioner WILMOT, when he took the oath of allegiance, and was allowed to depart. Whether the market boys will let him off so easily is uncertain, but should his secesh ever break out in a new spot, it is believed that the fish-barrel remedy will prove a "ready relief."
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; A Washington Market Butcher Blows Secesh, and Takes the Oath of Allegiance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; A Washington Market Butcher Blows Secesh, and Takes the Oath of Allegiance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The National Government has taken a vigorous step to prevent evasions of the draft. All males of the liable age, proposing to pass the frontier either toward Canada or Europe,...
lead_paragraph: The National Government has taken a vigorous step to prevent evasions of the draft. All males of the liable age, proposing to pass the frontier either toward Canada or Europe, are obliged to give a satisfactory account of their motives and objects, and, we presume, furnish evidence of having provided a substitute in case the chance of the draft fall to their names. Only when these conditions have been fulfilled, can the National writ ne exeant be suspended in their favor. The prohibition is, of course, but temporary. Before the close of the mouth the drafted troops will all be in service, and they who choose to expatriate themselves may then do so at pleasure.

abstract: THE RECENT HOMICIDE IN THE FOURTH WARD  ARREST OF THE ALLEGED PERPETRATOR. Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of JOHN MAGNER, who died from the ...
lead_paragraph: THE RECENT HOMICIDE IN THE FOURTH WARD -- ARREST OF THE ALLEGED PERPETRATOR. -- Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of JOHN MAGNER, who died from the effects of a stab in the abdomen, received during a fight corner of Cherry and Catharine streets, late last Monday night. The testimony adduced went to show that JOSEPH BARROW, alias Welsh, but familiarly known as "Tipperary," a sailor belonging to the ship Dreadnaught, the deceased, and 'one or two other men, got into a right while partially intoxicated, and during the altercation MAGNER was stabbed. Directly after the fight, BARROW said to JAMES COLLINS, of No. 50 Oliver-street, then standing near, "Let's get out of this -- I stabbed that man," and at that time COLLINS saw BARROW take a knife and put it into his pocket. BARROW then left, and at 3 o'clock the following morning applied for admission to the house of CHARLES MILLER. Being impatient, he burst in the door, and violently assaulted Mrs. MILLER. He then said, "I have cut one man to-night, and will cut another before I leave this house." At that time, Sergeant DE VOURSNEY, of the Fourth Precinct, came up and accosted BARROW, and took a sheath-knife from him. The prisoner was subsequently sent to Blackwell's Island for the assault on Mrs. MILLER, and after the death of his victim, Sergeant DE VOURSNEY, by order of Coroner COLLIN, proceeded to the Penitentiary and brought him down to await the result of the inquisition. The testimony pointed strongly toward the prisoner, and to no one else, as being the man who stabbed the deceased, and the jury, after a short deliberation, rendered the following verdict:

abstract: Editorial decries practice of conferring high military commands on civilians
snippet: Editorial decries practice of conferring high military commands on civilians
lead_paragraph: -- AN INJUSTICE TO OUR SOLDIERS. -- We are sorry to see the practice so largely continued of conferring high military commands on civilians, who know nothing whatever of military affairs, and who have not had even an hour's experience in the battle-field. Our past experience ought to have warned the Government against the fatal consequences of such a course, and there is less excuse for it now than ever before. There are scores and hundreds of subordinate officers in the Army, Colonels, Lieutenant-Colonels, Majors, Captains, Lieutenants, Corporals and Sergeants, who have won distinction by actual service in the field, --- who have led their men into the hottest of the fight, and done their duty with noble and conspicuous valor. These men are entitled to promotion, and the good of the service demands that they should receive it. Nothing can be more discouraging to such men than to see others put over them in high command, who have done nothing whatever to earn it, and nothing whatever to show their fitness for it. This system of political favoritism has been the bane of armies at all times, and has done enough already toward ruining ours to have arrested the attention of the military authorities. Gen. HALLECK ought to put a stop to it. A judicious and careful system of just promotions, not confined to the higher grade of officers, but carried all through the army and into the ranks, would do more than anything else to infuse military ardor into our troops, and make our armies formidable and effective.
headline: {'main': 'CIVILIAN COMMANDERS', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CIVILIAN COMMANDERS', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We are glad to see that Superintendent KENNEDY is causing a rigid examination to be made into the late disgraceful riot in Brooklyn, and that he is determined to brand official delinquency with its deserved punishment. So far as the head of the Police Department is concerned, every precaution that vigilance suggests appears to have been taken to prevent disturbance and protect the negro laborers in their peaceful avocation. Nor do the body of the police appear to be deserving of any blame, for they seem to have done their duty well after they arrived on the scene. The blame of their not arriving sooner and preventing the outrage rests on certain of the local officials, and Superintendent KENNEDY does well to bring these delinquents to prompt trial.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to see that Superintendent KENNEDY is causing a rigid examination to be made into the late disgraceful riot in Brooklyn, and that he is determined to brand official delinquency with its deserved punishment. abstract: Capt. LARNED had his hands full yesterday. Recruits absolutely poured in upon him, and he and the inspecting officers had very little leisure from early morning until late in the afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Capt. LARNED had his hands full yesterday. Recruits absolutely poured in upon him, and he and the inspecting officers had very little leisure from early morning until late in the afternoon. The old regiments mostly claimed his attention, Duryee's Zouaves in particular. Capt. abstract: The rebel  assassination of Gen. McCook is one of the most melancholy and disastrous events of the war. There is not a single circumstance to ...
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel assassination of Gen. MCCOOK is one of the most melancholy and disastrous events of the war. There is not a single circumstance to redeem it from classification among the most wanton and savage butcheries that ever occurred in a civilized country. The General was a helpless invalid -- moving in an ambulance painfully along a highway. He came to a place of refreshing shade and cooling springs, and rested awhile to alleviate his sufferings. His name and rank became known to those who witnessed his stopping, and when he moved again it was soon found that his ambulance was followed by a treacherous foe skulking in the woods. They pursued till a place of convenient seclusion was reached, when they rushed upon the defenceless soldier, overturned his conveyance, and shot him as he lay helpless, pleading for life. A more cold-blooded and fiendish murder was never perpetrated by barbarous Indians than these guerrillas of Northern Alabama have been guilty of, and it is not surprising that the most intense excitement is stirred up in the West wherever the facts become known.

abstract: The keel of Mr. ROWLAND'S fourth vessel was laid yesterday at Greenpoint. She is to be exclusively iron, and will be of extraordinary strength.
lead_paragraph: The keel of Mr. ROWLAND's fourth vessel was laid yesterday at Greenpoint. She is to be exclusively iron, and will be of extraordinary strength. A large number of persons was present on the occasion, and the foreman who has the supervision of the work mustered all the employes to participate in the act. She will be 226 feet long, 48 feet wide, and 13 feet deep. She will have two turrets, and be finished in a few months. Her tonnage will be over 1,000. The machinery is to be built at the Morgan Iron Works in this City.

abstract: It is perfectly natural that projects of mediation or interference should from time to time be brought forward in Parliament. The wasteful and sanguinary ...
lead_paragraph: It is perfectly natural that projects of mediation or interference should from time to time be brought forward in Parliament. The wasteful and sanguinary contest in America is generally regarded with angry impatience, for the suicidal folly of the Federalists is almost as provoking as the wanton injury which their policy inflicts on neutral foreigners. The respect which is due to heroic resolution and warlike aptitude has by degrees induced the great majority of Englishmen to withdraw their active sympathy from the baffled invaders, and at least to admire the indomitable resistance of the South. The dissentients apologize for their favorite Democracy on the ground that, in its extremest need, it has been unable to secure the services of a statesman, a general, or even of an honest man; but impartial observers cannot but suspect that there must be something wrong in the constitution of a society which deliberately submits itself to the authority of swindlers, of bullies and of charlatans. In the beginning, both parties had a plausible ground of quarrel, and bystanders are consequently influenced rather by the character and conduct of the disputants than by the merits of the original controversy. The Federalists have, from the first, had the questionable advantage of telling their own story, and of suppressing the statements and arguments of their opponents. The result is, that they have convinced all Europe of the incapacity of their Government, and of the hopelessness of their enterprise. By excluding foreign imports and by preventing the export of cotton they have, to the utmost of their power, identified the interests of England and France with the establishment of Southern independence; and in tolerating Gen. BUTLER's extravagant proceedings they have gone far to make recognition a point of honor as well as a measure of apparent expediency. Nevertheless, Mr. LINDSAY's motion was properly rejected by the House of Commons as unadvisable or premature. There is no room for simple mediation as long as the belligerents have no common basis of agreement. The South will only treat on the assumption of independence, and if the Federal Government were willing to concede the indispensable condition, peace would already be made. It would be idle to propose to the seceding States a mere revision of the Constitution; and the North, if it were prepared to accept separation and the frontier of the Ohio, would require no umpire to settle the terms of the unpalatable arrangement. The use of mediators is to save the honor of litigants who desire an adjustment, and not to enforce the abandoment of incompatible pretensions.

abstract: Caroline Mathieu vs. A. Harcq -- J. Wietoff vs. Same. -- The defendant, Harcq, is a Frenchman who has an eye to business. His business, as is alleged, is to purchase or beg old claims, which he proposes to collect for a reasonable percentage on the amount. His manner of doing this, it is said, is to present the claim to the debtor, with the information that unless the same is paid, he will advertise the claim for sale in the columns of the Creditors' Reporter, of which Harcq is editor and proprietor. This paper, it is stated in the prospectus, will be distributed in barrooms, lager-bier saloons and public houses, and will be mailed to the leading men of the City; but that no claims will be advertised which were not fraudulently contracted. That the failure of American law to attain justice compels creditors to resort to such means to expose fraudulent debtors, &c. A claim of this nature against the plaintiffs being advertised in this paper, an action for libel was commenced against Harcq, and Tallent & Averill, counsel for plaintiffs, now applied for an order to arrest the defendant.

abstract: Editorial on need to strengthen Union forces immediately
snippet: Editorial on need to strengthen Union forces immediately
lead_paragraph: There are a great many things which must be done before this rebellion can be crushed and peace restored. But the one thing to be done now, -- before all others, and to the exclusion of everything else for the time being, -- is to gather up the greatest possible military strength of the nation, and hurl it with resistless force upon the rebel army. Everything else can be postponed; -- this cannot. How to employ negroes; -- what to do with rebel property; -- whether to set slaves free or not; -- all these and scores of other questions of the utmost importance, and which must be settled at some time or other, can be safely and wisely postponed. But this task admits of no delay. The rebel armies in the field must be beaten. The military power of the rebellion must be broken. That is an indispensable preliminary to everything else. Until that is done, nothing else can even be attempted with any prospect of success. After it is done, the chances of doing everything else that the case requires will be increased tenfold.
headline: {'main': 'The One Thing Needful.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The One Thing Needful.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We give a sensible and intelligible article from the London Saturday Review showing the impolicy of England's mediation or intervention between the American belligerents. This hebdomadal, as our readers know, has been one of our most malignant foes from the beginning, but has treated the aspect and progress of affairs here with somewhat more intelligence than the vulgar herd of English writers have exhibited. It sees now that there is no possible room for mediation, that mediation involves contingent war, and that war would not pay. We are glad that these ideas are at last penetrating the English cranium; and we are glad that they are beginning to exhibit a certain sense of international justice and right, as well as a prudent regard for home economy. Since Parliament took ground against interference in our affairs, we are happy to see the position finds such a respectable following in the Press.
lead_paragraph: -- We give a sensible and intelligible article from the London Saturday Review showing the impolicy of England's mediation or intervention between the American belligerents. abstract: The accounts of GARIBALDI's visit to Marsala record an extraordinary scene of patriotic excitement GARIBALDI in the course of his speech, several times made use of the phrase "Rome or death," to which the people responded each time, "Yes, Rome or death" He spoke in violent terms of NAPOLEON, and said: "We have given Nice and Savoy, and he wishes for something more. Yes, I know he has one Prince ready for Rome, and another for Naples, and soon I know it."

abstract: An important order has been issued by the War Department, which will seriously interfere with the plans of those who have calculated to escape the coming draft by changing their locality.
lead_paragraph: An important order has been issued by the War Department, which will seriously interfere with the plans of those who have calculated to escape the coming draft by changing their locality. It directs that until further orders no citizen liable to be drafted shall be allowed to go to a foreign country, and all Marshals, Deputy Marshals, military officers and Police authorities are instructed to see the order carried into effect. It also directs that any person liable to draft, who shall absent himself from his county or State before the draft is made, shall be arrested wherever he may be found within the jurisdiction of the United States, conveyed to the nearest military post or depot, and placed on military duty for the term of the draft. The order also suspends the writ of habeas corpus with respect to all persons so arrested, and in respect to all persons arrested for disloyal practices.

abstract: JAMES GORDON BENNETT, ESQ. Sir: A few days before the close of Congress my attention was called to an article in your journal, in which it was stated that I had declared that we had one hundred and fifty thousand more men than we needed, and ...
lead_paragraph: JAMES GORDON BENNETT, ESQ. -- Sir: A few days before the close of Congress my attention was called to an article in your journal, in which it was stated that I had declared that we had one hundred and fifty thousand more men than we needed, and that I must be held personally responsible for the present want of men. Conscious that I had ever been swift to obey the wishes of the Government and of our Generals in the field -- conscious, too, that the nation had not a single battalion the less through any word or act of mine -- I could not but feel deeply the cruel injustice of this attempt to hold me now responsible for a want of men, caused by events no one foresaw.

abstract: -- Com. Vanderbilt has purchased of Mr. George Ebbet, for $4,721 75, about eight and a half acres of land adjoining the land of the Moravian Church, New-Dorp, Staten Island. Upon this, it is understood, he intends erecting large and substantial buildings, in which to educate the youth of both sexes, somewhat after the fashion of the celebrated schools of Bethlehem, Penn. He will endow the schools in such a manner that their support will always be insured.

abstract: Whatever may be the varied emotions occasioned in peaceful Northern communities by the recent draft of 300,000 by the Government, it is very certain that in one quarter it is hailed with unanimous and unalloyed delight. The letters now coming from the Army of the Potomac show that the feeling kindled in the thinned ranks of the Union soldiers by the news of the draft, is exultant and enthusiastic. The reassured hope it brings makes them equal to double the daring and endurance of the recent past, for now they know they must and will conquer.
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the varied emotions occasioned in peaceful Northern communities by the recent draft of 300,000 by the Government, it is very certain that in one quarter it is hailed with unanimous and unalloyed delight. The letters now coming from the Army of the Potomac show that the feeling kindled in the thinned ranks of the Union soldiers by the news of the draft, is exultant and enthusiastic. abstract: The United States war-steamer Quaker City, (nine guns,) Commander J.M. FRAILEY, United States Navy, has arrived at the Philadelphia Navy-yard. Officers and crew all well. It will be remembered that this vessel was almost the first one taken by the Government on the breaking out of the war.
lead_paragraph: The United States war-steamer Quaker City, (nine guns,) Commander J.M. FRAILEY, United States Navy, has arrived at the Philadelphia Navy-yard. Officers and crew all well. It will be remembered that this vessel was almost the first one taken by the Government on the breaking out of the war. On account of her great speed and adaptability, she was taken by Gen. WOOL, and sent with munitions of war to reinforce Fortress Monroe. After that, and during the greater part of last year, she was employed blockading the Chesapeake, which she did with an efficiency which excited much notice and commendation.

abstract: A deserter who made his appearance at Suffolk, Va., on Monday last [???] that the rations the rebel soldiers now receive [???] is one-half pound of meat, eighteen [???] of flour, and a little salt. The men are getting very tired of this kind of fare, and he thinks by October next they will be completely starved out. Flesh and blood, he says, cannot stand it much longer, no matter how patriotic.

abstract: -Communications have, for the past three or four days, continued to pour in upon us containing queries regarding the regulations of drafting, exempts, non-liables, &c. As we have already discussed these matters very fully, we do not think it worth while to occupy our space with further explanation thereon. These queries, indeed, belong to two classes -- first, those we have already answered, and secondly, those we can't answer. The latter have reference to cases on which no official utterance has yet been made. These can only be determined by the Secretary of War, who will, in a few days, publish rules and regulations for drafting throughout all the States. These will, it is understood, supersede, in some particulars, the State law. Till the order from the War Department is made public accordingly, our anxious inquirers will have to wait as patiently as they can. If they can't do that let them enlist immediately, which is better still.

abstract: The Monroe County Regiment is now nearly full, and the Military Committee have commenced the work of recruiting for the Thirteenth. They have already commissioned three officers to recruit companies for the Thirteenth, and another officer will probably be commissioned at once for the same purpose -- making four full companies to be recruited for this regiment. The Thirteenth was one of the earliest of the two years volunteer regiments to take the field. They have been in severe battles, and have been much reduced by death, sickness and resignations.

abstract: Editorial on how political actions of past have led to institution of slavery; Editorial on political actions of past that led to institution of slavery
snippet: Editorial on how political actions of past have led to institution of slavery; Editorial on political actions of past that led to institution of slavery
lead_paragraph: That obstinacy which is the virtue of little minds, still characterizes what remains of the Northern Pro-Slavery faction -- the faction which rates interest as more precious than principle, and which hates the black man more than it loves the Union. It is truly surprising to see with what tenacious perversity these men cling to an alliance at best only founded on a corrupt expediency, and continue to glorify as an indispensable good the institution which no one of average intelligence and honesty could ever regard as better than a necessary evil. This alliance between the Slaveholders of the South and a clique of greedy demagogues at the North, has had full sway for a great many years, and we are now reaping its legitimate fruits. It can never exist again, for the storm which these men have evoked will not subside but with the utter destruction of the Republic, or the immolation of Slavery as a political power. We pronounce it, therefore, surprising, that politicians who, however low their moral and intellectual calibre, have been ever conspicuous for a keen appreciation, of self-interest, should continue to call upon their gods in the tempest, when those gods are shivered, and can aid and comfort them no longer.

abstract: The Boston newspaper give  blowing accounts of the patriotic and military ardor of that city at the present time. All classes of people are thoroughly aroused. Business is a secondary matter. The most eloquent men address ward meetings and
lead_paragraph: -- The Boston newspaper give blowing accounts of the patriotic and military ardor of that city at the present time. All classes of people are thoroughly aroused. Business is a secondary matter. The most eloquent men address ward meetings -- and enlist. The most polished scholars mingle with the rude democracy in their warlike gatherings, excite them to heroism and self-denial by their example -- and with them join the army. Rich and heavy merchants march through the streets, bearing aloft the Star-spangled Banner, with their clerks and employes following in their wake; and after contributing lavishly of their wealth to the cause, enter the ranks. All party issues are forgotten -- all classes are fused together -- all interests are made to give way before the one overshadowing interest. Not even at any period of the first Revolution were the citizens so completely united, so filled with military enthusiasm, and so devoted to the great American idea of Liberty. And as it is in Boston, so it is all over Massachusetts.

abstract: Our special tele  graphic correspondence this morning makes it appear as if there may have been important work in POPE'S Department, on the Rapidan River. His pickets were driven across the
lead_paragraph: -- Our special telegraphic correspondence this morning makes it appear as if there may have been important work in POPE's Department, on the Rapidan River. His pickets were driven across the stream on Friday morning, and by the evening of the same day, the corps of Gen. BANKS and that of Gen. MCDOWELL had been hastened forward to the scene of danger; and the telegraph says that "heavy firing" had been heard in that direction. It may be that this was only artillery practice to prepare the way to cross over, and it may be that the rebels disputed the passage of our troops. We shall doubtless have the facts in the case by to-morrow.

abstract: Mr. COBDEN'S speech in the House of Commons, which we published yesterday, was admirably adapted to the object this eminent statesman had in view.
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN's speech in the House of Commons, which we published yesterday, was admirably adapted to the object this eminent statesman had in view. For he wished to show that the existing cotton difficulties are in their nature exceptional, and in duration will be temporary; and that, consequently, the distress they entail might confidently be met by an exceptional and a temporary remedy. In a national point of view, however, the wider and more important inquiry is suggested, how far a people like the English, so rich in fertile territory, under every condition of climate and soil, so abounding in industrial enterprise, in accumulated capital, and in everything which confers material prosperity, quickens growth, and consolidates power, are justified in acquiescing in a state of things so pregnant with mischief as that Mr. COBDEN has portrayed.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Cobden on the Cotton Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Cobden on the Cotton Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Advices from Europe two days later are received by the arrival of the Scolia off Cape Race. An important item of the news is the announce
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe two days later are received by the arrival of the Scolia off Cape Race. An important item of the news is the announcement that Earl RUSSELL justifies the vigilance of our cruisers at the Bahamas. The gunboat Tuscarora was at Queenstown, watching for a rebel steamer which had left Liverpool, (or Plymouth,) but which had put back to Holyead, where she lost all of her men. The news of cotton movements is no later. Breadstuffs had a declining tendency and Provisions were dull. Consols unchanged.

abstract: President HOPKINS opened the exercises of Commencement week at Williams College, on Sunday last, with the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class. He took his textfrom Peter ii., 4-5: "To whom coming as unto a living stone, disallowed indeed of men, but chosen of God and precious, ye also ...
lead_paragraph: President HOPKINS opened the exercises of Commencement week at Williams College, on Sunday last, with the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class. He took his textfrom Peter ii., 4-5: "To whom coming as unto a living stone, disallowed indeed of men, but chosen of God and precious, ye also as lively stones are built up a spiritual house." In the evening the address before the Mills Theological Society was delivered by Rev. DWIGHT W. MARSH, lately a missionary at Mosul. He opened his address with a reference to the condition of the country, and acknowledged the necessity of every young man devoting himself to her service, but considered it wrong, even under these circumstances, to neglect the missionary cause, in behalf of which he spoke. The missionary life is desirable because it causes those who follow it to become like Christ. To prove this was the object of his remarks. The speaker was instructive and at times eloquent, and those were fully repaid for their attendance who heard him.
