abstract: Democratic state convention proceedings; Editorial on Mr. Wickliffe speech, Democratic state convention, Indiana, attacking Republican attitudes on war
snippet: Democratic state convention proceedings; Editorial on Mr. Wickliffe speech, Democratic state convention, Indiana, attacking Republican attitudes on war
lead_paragraph: The Indiana Democratic State Convention was a remarkable affair. The speeches which were made before it were, not very creditable to those that made them, or to those that heard them and applauded. The whole thing indicates a reawakening of the old party spirit which can see no good in any one who has not the Democratic ear-mark; which is willing to see the country ruined, unless it shall be saved in ways which suit party leaders, and by Democrats instead of Republicans. We do not believe that the spirit which prevailed there will commend itself to the country.
headline: {'main': "Some of Wickliffe'e Heresies.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Some of Wickliffe'e Heresies.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This war for the Union is the People's war -- the people fighting for National integrity, for public justice, for the perpetuity of freedom, for the honor and glory of the flag and all that it represents. Every one who has enjoyed the blessings of Republican Government and of the Union should do his part to sustain them. Now is the moment he can be of service. By encouraging words, by contributions in money, by stimulating volunteering, by working for the soldiers in the field, and by labors for those who are sick or wounded -- in these and other ways, every man, woman and child can do service to their country -- a service which in after years will be looked back upon with joy and spoken of with pride, and which cannot fail of its reward. The special work of this week for every one is to do all in his power to forward the work of enlistment. Soldiers are the one thing needful. If every one who reads the TIMES this morning were to make a resolve that before the week is over he (or she) would procure one soldier for the country's service, there would need to be no drafting for three-years' men in New-York. Resolution and effort are all that are needed for success in the work. Let every one see that he does his duty before it is too late -- so that the glories of the past may be revived, and the blessings of the Constitution conserved for posterity.

abstract: JOHN B. THOMPSON, of the Southern Literary Messenger, who writes for the Appeal over the signature of "Dixie," says: "Lord EDWARD ST. MAUR left Richmond to proceed to New-York by way of Fortress Monroe. That young gentleman went down to Berkeley yesterday, and returned to-day by flag of truce. He is the son of the Duke of Somerset, and has been in America but a few weeks. His purpose was to make a rapid tour of the Yankee States, and take steamer at New-York for Liverpool. On arriving at the lines he made application to MCCLELLAN for leave to pass, and met  with a prompt refusal. The reasons, as stated by Lord ST. MAUR, were that he had violated the Queen's proclamation concerning the neutrality of her subjects, and SEWARD's proclamation of non-intercourse between the loyal and rebel States, and that he had there by forfeited his right as an English citizen. Lord ST. MAUR was at Richmond during the late fight, and had been an eye-witness from a most favorable point of observation of all the battles down to the retreat of MCCLELLAN to his gunboats. The incivility did not stop with sending him back to Richmond . His baggage remained all night on the steamer, and thus the Duke of Somerset's son was packed off without a chance linen, under the assurance that his baggage would be sent up by flag of truce. Doubtless it will be when it has been thoroughly searched for treasonable matters to compromise its owner."

abstract: There is no maxim better settled than that an impossible law is void. The order of Mr. STANTON, suspending travel in view of the draft, is practically impossible. Not only shall the outgo of foreign travel be stopped, ...
lead_paragraph: There is no maxim better settled than that an impossible law is void. The order of Mr. STANTON, suspending travel in view of the draft, is practically impossible. Not only shall the outgo of foreign travel be stopped, but all intercourse between immediate neighborhoods is prohibited, and the existence of an invisible boundary line, between counties and States, is an insurmountable barrier to communication. We need hardly refer to the dweller in that anomalous house, which standing where the boundaries of New-York, Massachusetts and Connecticut converge, is in three States at once, and of which the owner cannot go from his dining-room to his parlor without incurring the Stantonian penalties. It is sufficient to name Mr. A., whose residence is in Jersey City, and whose place of business is in New-York, and who cannot pass from one to the other without liability to arrest; or Mr. B., who must pine in the solitudes of Brooklyn, because to visit his office in Wall or Water-street is exposure to untold punishments. With these daily duties the Secretary of War blunderingly interferes. Men who see the greedy Tax bill in the future, and groan at the probable effects of the tariff; men who have the possibility of a draft drawing them away for nine months from the thrifty prosecution of their vocation, are suddenly stopped from those pursuits upon which their uncertain future is intimately dependent. Such prohibition is not only senseless, but so nearly impossible of observance as to be fairly within the legal axiom. The restriction is void because impracticable.

abstract: Operations of importance appear to have commenced in Gen. POPE'S Department, and the Army of Virginia is likely soon to have an opportunity to distinguish itself.
lead_paragraph: Operations of importance appear to have commenced in Gen. POPE's Department, and the Army of Virginia is likely soon to have an opportunity to distinguish itself. Early on Friday morning, our pickets, which had been thrown out on the south bank of the Rapidan River, were attacked by the enemy in superior force, and driven across the river. When information of the fact reached Culpepper Court-House, then the headquarters of Gen. POPE, MCDOWELL's corps was ordered forward, and was soon followed by BANKS' corps, both making directly toward the point at which our pickets had been driven across the Rapidan, only about ten or twelve miles from Gordonsville. At Culpepper Court-House, late in the afternoon of Friday, heavy firing was heard in the direction of the Rapidan, and it was conjectured that a severe engagement was proceeding. It is more probable, however, that the firing was a mere artillery duel across the river. Gen. POPE is understood to be now personally directing movements.

abstract: It is be regretted that in writing Ravenshoe Mr. HENRY KINGSLEY had so much time and paper at his disposal. For had he less of either, or simply a sufficiency of both, he would have made a better book.
lead_paragraph: It is be regretted that in writing Ravenshoe Mr. HENRY KINGSLEY had so much time and paper at his disposal. For had he less of either, or simply a sufficiency of both, he would have made a better book. The story is well told, but theteller forgets that his hearers are not immortal, and have other duties to perform in life besides listening. And so he talks on against time, very much to his own amusement, undoubtedly, but greatly to the weariness of the reader. As the story progresses the plot becomes so complicated that one rather fears the author himself will not be able to untangle it. And gradually, too, the situations become so improbable, that we fancy the author is endeavoring to practice on our credulity; this very naturally begets a feeling of intense indignation on the part of the reader -- a feeling, however, which turns rather to the author's advantage than otherwise, as it keeps one from going to sleep at this prolix juncture, despite the many persuasions to slumber. The hero, Charles, is introduced to us in the first place as a sensible young man, full of life and spirit, and we like him. But subsequently he reveals himself as a complete muff, an incorrigible ninny. The moment that trouble comes upon him he sinks down into his shoes, as though his spine were of jelly instead of bone, and with the instincts and education of a gentleman persuades himself that his destiny in life is to be a groom; that, because birth did not bring his talents in a damask napkin, nothing remains for him but to bury them under a dunghill. But he isn't unfortunate, after all, if he only know it. By a double-shuffle-and-cut of the cards the author turns up his hero as trump, and the rightful heir of Ravenshoe after all. A pretty loving wife, and a fortune, await Charles if he can only be found. But he wont be. He hides himself under all manner of disguises, and in all corners of the kingdom, and Mr. KINGSLEY comes to his aid, prestidigitating him about in the most remarkable way. The young man is a pea, and Mr. KINGSLEY plays the part of a thimbie-rigger -- nowhere is the little joker to be found. Detectives are put on his truck, but fail to find him; little boot-blacks almost betray him, but not quite; and, finally, when discovery seems inevitable, he is whistled away to the Crimes to figure as one of the Light Brigade in the charge of Balaklava. It is coming this prestidigitorial display that the render's wrath becomes excited, and not his curiosity. All participating in this game of Hide and Seek behave so like consummate fools that one's only desire is to catch Charles and his friends -- the author included -- and knock their beads together until they become sensible, and go to work in a rational way. The perpetual game of cross purposes that is played provokes one. The excellence of the story in other respects [???] that the plot had not been simplifies and the hero permitted to fail into the open arms of his friends earlier in its course. [???] to pronounce Ravenshoe a book that would be good if it were not so long, long if it were not so good. It is published by TICKNOR & FIELDS.

abstract: Mr.Wesley Johnston, in a note dated Polo, Ill., claps another extinguisher on the "Rev." C. H. Clark. He says: "I resided in Austin, Texas, three years prior to the commencement of the present war, doing a mercantile business as a one of the firm of Phelps  Johnston.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr.Wesley Johnston, in a note dated Polo, Ill., claps another extinguisher on the "Rev." C.H. Clark. He says: "I resided in Austin, Texas, three years prior to the commencement of the present war, doing a mercantile business as a one of the firm of Phelps & Johnston. Being intimately acquainted with Gov. Clark while acting a Lieutenant-Governor, also intimate with his family, I can positively assert that his oldest son is not over thirteen years old at the present time. I am also acquainted with the Hero of San Jacinto (Sam Houston.) His oldest daughter at this time is not more than fourteen or fifteen years old, and, at the time of the secession of the State, was not married. He states that Sam Houston was brought before the Legislature on a charge of treason, and that he made a speech against them and secession. "The Secessionist rose and gathered about him, and for a while nothing was heard but pistols shots are the clanking of knives? This statement above is all false. At the time the Governor was deposed of his office, there was a meeting held on the grounds of the Governor's mansion. The Governor, also Gen. Hamilton, member of Congress, made very violent speeches against Secessionist and traitors. Hamilton, pointing to the Capitol said, 'There you will find the traitors,' upon which dozens of pistols were drawn, but not a shot was fired, nor was the 'clanking of knives' heard. This was the only time during the sitting of the Legislature and Convention that there was any extra excitement. The wound this Rev. C.H. Clark alludes to having received must have been invented for the occasion of making money out of the audience he was then addressing. I suppose he thought that, in consequence of the Reverend attached to his cognomen, his audience would take what he said without question."

abstract: DEATHS FROM THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT.  PATRICK KELEHER, a laborer employed in loading freight cars on the Erie Railroad at Long Dock, Jersey City, was prostrated on Saturday afternoon by the excessive heat, and was taken to the City Hospital, where he died during the night.
lead_paragraph: DEATHS FROM THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT. -- PATRICK KELEHER, a laborer employed in loading freight cars on the Erie Railroad at Long Dock, Jersey City, was prostrated on Saturday afternoon by the excessive heat, and was taken to the City Hospital, where he died during the night. Deceased was about twenty-six years of age, and had been in this country only ten day....A man named JOHN BURKE, of intemperate habits, died suddenly on Saturday evening at No. 17 Prospect-street, from the effects of the heat, superinduced by intemperance. Deceased entered a grocery while under the effects of liquor, about an hour previous to his death, and, destroying some goods, was put out by the proprietor. His friends, hearing of this, created considerable excitement by stating that his death resulted from violence at the hands of the latter. The evidence, however, elicited on the inquest held by Coroner GAFNEY, entirely disproved this, and showed that death was caused by heat and intemperance, in both of the above cases a verdict was rendered in accordance with the facts as stated.

abstract: Sewell, William Grant; NY Times editorial writer
snippet: Sewell, William Grant; NY Times editorial writer
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. WILLIAM GRANT SEWELL for nearly ten years a member of the New-York Press, died in Quebec, on Saturday morning, 9th inst., after a lingering illness -- from pulmonary consumption -- in the 33d year of his age. Mr. S. was a native of Quebec, grandson of Chief Justice SEWELL, of Canada, and was educated for the bar, but having little taste for the profession, he soon turned his thorough literary training to account in the more congenial pursuits of journalistic life. He came to New-York in 1853, and after a brief employment elsewhere was permanently engaged on the editorial staff of the NEW-YORK TIMES, where his good service, sound judgment and varied accomplishments were ever appreciated; though, from his weak health, for some years past they could only be availed of in the shape of correspondence from the British West India Islands. His contributions to the TIMES from that quarter were exceedingly valuable both for their originality and entire spirit of fairness on the West India emancipation system and its practical working, as thoroughly investigated by him, in Jamaica, Barbados, etc. These letters, attracting universal attention both at home and abroad, were subsequently republished in book form, and, besides extending the reputation of the author, won for him the highest commendation from official sources in the Islands which he had so carefully surveyed and conscientiously treated of.

abstract: In another culumn Mr. M.O. ROBERTS announces the intended reopening of the California route by the way of Nicaragua. The first steamer, a new and splendid vessel named the America, will sail on the 25th of October, connecting with the Moses Taylor on the other side. Mr. ROBERTS gives assurance that other vessels will at once be put in service to increase the frequency of the trips; and what is more to the purpose, pledges himself that the line is not put on simply to be bought off, but that it is to be maintained permanently. The rates of fare, it is stated will be much lower than those of the actual line, while the time will be shorter. The enterprise merits success.

abstract: attacking Confederates for not including officers in prisoner exchange
snippet: attacking Confederates for not including officers in prisoner exchange
lead_paragraph: Operations of the first importance have commenced in Gen. POPE's Department. Early on Friday morning, our pickets, which had been thrown out on the south bank of the Rapidan River, were attacked by the enemy in superior force, and driven across the river. When information of the fact reached Culpepper Court-House, then the headquarters of Gen. POPE, MCDOWELL's corps was ordered forward, and was soon followed by BANKS' and SIGEL's corps, all making directly toward the point at which our pickets had been driven across the Rapidan, only about ten or twelve miles from Gordonsville. Our dispatches, received late last night, report a desperate battle between Stonewall JACKSON and Gen. BANKS, with no definite results. The battle was likely to be renewed at any moment. Two trains of cars left Alexandria yesterday morning to bring in wounded men.

abstract: Editorials speculating on next Confederate move in Virginia
snippet: Editorials speculating on next Confederate move in Virginia
lead_paragraph: The military policy of the rebels is as puzzling as our own has been. It is impossible to tell what a day may bring forth; yet we know perfectly well that no future day is likely to have in its womb as many hopeful chances of rebel success as has been contained in every one of the last forty days. Within that time our strength has gradually been growing, until now it is double what it was at the opening of last month. Our army in Virginia -- taken as a whole and in its different Departments -- has been enabled to plant it-itself in far more favorable positions, as may be seen by observing the movements of POPE and BURNSIDE, to say nothing of MCCLELLAN; the cooperation, if not concentration, of separated columns, has been rendered practicable; the spirit of our troops has been improved; and our naval force has been greatly strengthened. At this moment, we may safely say, that in numbers, position and morale, our Virginia armies are already fully twice as strong as at the close of the week of battles. Of course it was not in the programme of JEFF. DAVIS, or Gen. LEE, or Stonewall JACKSON, to give us opportunity to acquire such gains and achieve such advantages as these, if it had been in their power to prevent it.

abstract: The rebel ram Arkansas, which made so brilliant a debut on the Mississippi a few weeks ago, has closed its career in precisely the same manner as the Merrimac did  namely, by an act of suicide.
lead_paragraph: The rebel ram Arkansas, which made so brilliant a debut on the Mississippi a few weeks ago, has closed its career in precisely the same manner as the Merrimac did -- namely, by an act of suicide. Rebel rams seem to have an inherent predisposition to felo de se, for the two chief representatives of that type of marine creature have adopted this method of taking off. Each signalized its advent in the most spirited style, each seemed for a while to have things all its own way, and both have finally been hedged around with so many obstructions that a desperate making away with themselves was the only outlet left them.

abstract: Senator WILSON was made to appear, recently, in a very awkward predicament before the public.
lead_paragraph: Senator WILSON was made to appear, recently, in a very awkward predicament before the public. He was accused of having contributed to weaken the Union armies in the field by advocating the policy of stopping enlistments, and by declaring from his seat in the Senate, and as Chairman of the Military Committee, that we had 150,000 more volunteers than the Government knew how to use. When it became apparent lately that the Government was not able to reinforce the shattered Army of the Potomac, and that the National cause was in peril, because of the lack of soldiers, the course of the men whose Congressional action had produced the result, was sharply criticised. Mr. WILSON was specially arraigned for having done the chief work of reducing the army by the influence of his speech above referred to.

abstract: We fear that Gen. Richardson's conscience accuses him. A few days since the telegraph distorted a dispatch stating that Maj. Richardson had been dismissed from the service, with an announcement that this penalty had been visited upon the gallant Brigadier-General of that name. Some papers ventured to correct the blunder, but the Detroit Tribune at Friday says: "We are informed that the telegraph report of the dismissal of Gen. I.B. Richardson, of this State, from the service is probably true, although based upon misinformation. Gen. Richardson, who had been on continuous active duty for more than a year, applied for a short furlough, First to Gen. Sumner and then to Gen. McClellan, but was refused. He finally, however, obtained leave to wish Fortress Monroe two days, and while there obtained a prolongation of furlough for twelve days from Gen. [???]. This latter fact is not probably known in Gen. McClellan's army, where the powers that [???] are not very favorable to an up-and-down fighting man like our Gen. 'Dick,' who cannot be spared from the army at this time upon any consideration whatever."

abstract: By the steamship Scotia, which passed Cape Race on Saturday forenoon, we received advices from Europe to the 3d inst., two days later than by the Jura. Among the passengers is His Grace Archbishop HUGHES.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Scotia, which passed Cape Race on Saturday forenoon, we received advices from Europe to the 3d inst., two days later than by the Jura. Among the passengers is His Grace Archbishop HUGHES. The gunboat Tuscarora had been at Queenstown several days, supposed to be watching the movements of a rebel vessel, but she left on the evening of the 1st -- destination unknown. Various rumors were again current, especially on the Continent, with regard to intervention or mediation in American affairs, but none of them are regarded as worthy of serious attention. In reply to a memorial of forty merchants and shipowners of Liverpool, relative to the alleged violation of international law by the National cruisers in the Bahama waters. Earl RUSSELL, through Mr. LAYARD, had in effect justified the proceedings of our cruisers, in consequence of the practice of sending vessels to the Bahamas for the purpose of running the blockade. He further recommended strict attention to the Queen's neutrality proclamation. Gen. POPE's recent orders relative to the subsistence of his army had provided some unfavorable comment, under the construction that they were intended to inaugurate a system of rapine. The embarkation of French troops for Mexico was proceeding briskly. Gen. FOREY left Cherbourg on the 29th ult., for Vera Cruz. GARIBALDI is about to commence operations again. He has issued a proclamation to volunteers to assemble at Sicily, announcing that the time for action had arrived. His intentions are at present unknown. The news of cotton movements is no later. Breadstuffs had a declining tendency and Provisions were dull. Consols unchanged.

abstract: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning the ferryboat Nebraska, while proceeding to Williamsburgh, came in collision with the Sound steamer City of New-York. The ferryboat was running quite close to the NewYork shore, a short distance below Grand-street, and the City of New-York was coming down the river on the same side.
lead_paragraph: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning the ferryboat Nebraska, while proceeding to Williamsburgh, came in collision with the Sound steamer City of New-York. The ferryboat was running quite close to the New-York shore, a short distance below Grand-street, and the City of New-York was coming down the river on the same side. The steamer gave the signal for the ferryboat to go to the right, which, it appears, was disregarded, or misunderstood, and an opposite direction was taken. The pilot of the City of New-York, as soon us he saw the direction taken, stopped his vessel, but not in time to prevent a collision -- the bow of the City of New-York striking the Nebraska just forward of the wheel-house.

abstract: We publish to-day the official report of Brig.-Gen. H.M. NAGLEE, commanding First Brigade, CASEY's Division, Army of the Potomac, of the part taken by his brigade in the battle of the "Seven Pines," May 31, 1862. It is a straightforward, manly document, in defence of brave men suffering from undeserved censure. Gen. NAGLEE has been at pains to make a most thorough examination into all the facts relating to the conduct of his brigade on that unfortunate day, when Gen. CASEY's Division suffered so severely from the attack of a superior force, and the circumstantial account he gives of their movements during the battle of the Seven Pines, places their reputation beyond a question of doubt. No General in the army has labored more indefatigably than has Gen.NAGLEE to bring his brigade up to the highest point of efficiency, and it is not strange that he should be jealous of its reputation. His statements in regard to its actions form a portion of the history of the Peninsula campaign which cannot be ignored. It is to be regretted that we should be even temporarily deprived of the services of so valuable an officer as Gen. NAGLEE, on account of ill-health, which has compelled him to withdraw for a time from his command.

abstract: As the Summer season draws toward a close, the experimental managers who, at the heated period of the year, launch their little ventures on the sea of metropolitan favor, drop off, one by one, leaving the theatres they have transiently occupied to solitude and "renovation."
lead_paragraph: As the Summer season draws toward a close, the experimental managers who, at the heated period of the year, launch their little ventures on the sea of metropolitan favor, drop off, one by one, leaving the theatres they have transiently occupied to solitude and "renovation." In a week or two, freshly furbished walls will echo to the voices of the regular people, who are to delight or bore us through the Fall and Winter; and the ephemeral speculators, who have done their best to help us through the oppressive evenings of the past two months, will know us no more until next June.

abstract: official report on death; Article on press of Great Britain
snippet: official report on death; Article on press of Great Britain
lead_paragraph: It is not an easy matter to decide how far the newspaper Press of any country represents the national feeling. Journalism in France, if not inspire, is, to a great extent, coerced by a rigid censorship, while, in most other European nations, public opinion is either too feeble to find expression through such a channel, or the Governments are too powerful and despotic to brook its inevitable opposition. But we must look to Great Britain to discover how far it is possible to distort journalism so as to rob it almost entirely of independence while still retaining the mask of free thought and free expression. Cliquism and caste are the controlling influences of the English Press, the almost sole exception to this rule being the "kept" papers -- an expression used in England to define the status of those journals which are supported, not by an honest circulation, but by this or that designing politician, and used, necessarily, to further his own immoral purposes. Nor is it difficult to account for the existence of such a state of things; indeed, it would be hard to show how it could be otherwise. Education, even of the commonest description, is there confined to the few, and intelligence can be claimed but by the "upper classes" of the nation. The English people know nothing of what is passing in the outside world unless it be through reports of occasional debates in Parliament, which they seldom if ever read, or the foreign correspondence of their papers, which possesses no interest for them. The newspaper Press of Great Britain is written for and sustained by the aristocracy and the upper portion of the middle classes, and, most naturally, it chimes in with their opinions and prejudices, however inconsistent may be its facts and deductions. Of late years, however, the progress of enlightenment, and, above all, the enormous increase of taxation, have awakened Englishmen to the necessity of reliable information upon passing events; the penny papers have started into being, and, within half a dozen years, have gone far toward reforming public sentiment on most questions. These papers may now be numbered by scores, and it bodes nothing but good to England and her people that the politics of these journals are progressively democratic. No wonder that the House of Lords long refused to consent to the repeal of the tyrannical Paper Duties; without such repeal the English oligarchy knew full well that penny papers were an impossibility, whilst the removal of the impost presaged indubitably a continued agitation of reform, and an increasing contraction of the usurped privileges of the aristocracy.

abstract: All through the past week the eagerness universally manifested to join the army has equaled, if it has not exceeded in enthusiasm, the great uprising of a year ago.
lead_paragraph: All through the past week the eagerness universally manifested to join the army has equaled, if it has not exceeded in enthusiasm, the great uprising of a year ago. In this City nearly twelve hundred men have been enlisted in five days, a majority of them electing to serve in the old regiments; but a goodly number preferring to take their chances of winning glory and advancement in the new. About 150 were mustered into the service at the White-street office on Saturday, and as many more were taken up to the various encampments in the neighborhood of New-York for enrollment. The whole available population, of young men seems to be at last in earnest about the matter. There is evidence of a real appreciation of the emergency which the country is called upon to meet; and, so far as the Empire City is concerned, there will be few attempts made to shirk the responsibility. At the rate at which enlistments are thus progressing, there can be no doubt that, before the period arrives for drafting, the full quota of the State will have, volunteered; that is the quota the State is expected to furnish of the 300,000 men required by the President for use during three years or the war. The City, which at first rather slowly strove to do its dutry in the premises, is now -- being fairly aroused -- outstripping the [???] districts in determination to accomplish more than the share demanded of it.

abstract: MORE CASES OF SUNSTROKE. Coroner RANNEY was yesterday notified to hold inquests at Bellevue Hospital on the remains of the following named persons who had died there from the effects of the heat.
lead_paragraph: MORE CASES OF SUNSTROKE. -- Coroner RANNEY was yesterday notified to hold inquests at Bellevue Hospital on the remains of the following named persons who had died there from the effects of the heat. All of the deceased parties appeared to have been laborers: C.C. CONNOR, found in First-avenue, near Seventeenth-street; JACOB BAKER, found in University-place; WM. C. CONNOR, a man named MURPHY, THOMAS MCKINDY....Coroner RANNEY was called to the house No. 642 Greenwich-street, to hold an inquest on the body of THOMAS MULHISEN, who died from the effects of the heat....The same Coroner held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of an unknown laborer, who was sunstruck on Saturday and died soon afterward. Deceased was about 23 years of age, and apparently a native of Ireland....Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on board the steamship Etna, lying at Pier 44, North River, on the body of EDWARD DOYLE, a passenger, who was going to Liverpool. Deceased was sunstruck on Saturday. He was 35 years of age and a native of Baltimore....Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at No. 31 1/2 Whitehall-street on the body of MARY RILEY, an Irish woman, 30 years of age, who died from the effects of the excessive heat ...THOMAS CARLIN, who recently arrived from Europe, died at No. 135 Liberty-street, from a sunstroke. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on the body. Deceased was 33 years of age and a native of Ireland....JOSEPH LUCE, a native of Ireland, 31 years of age, died suddenly at his late residence No. 4 Caroline-street, from the effects of the heat. An inquest was held on the body by Coroner WILDEY.

abstract: Alden typesetter and distributor described
snippet: Alden typesetter and distributor described
lead_paragraph: The most valuable compositor in the employ of a newspaper is that one who possesses the greatest facility of rapid and exact manipulation of type. The best compositor is liable to error, and the strongest may be compelled to succumb under the pressure of long-continued work. Hence any invention which can insure absolute accuracy, combined with expedition and endurance, must of necessity be the ne plus ultra of desiderata in the composing-room.

abstract: Sir Alan Napier McNab, the well-known Canadian statesman, died on Friday, at his residence, near Hamilton, in the 64th year of his age. He was born in Canada, and participated as an infantry officer in the War of 1812. He then studied law, and entered upon practice at Hamilton. In 1829 he was chosen member of Parliament. He served three terms, and was once Speaker. After the "patriot war" of 1837, he was knighted for distinguished services against the insurgents. After the union of the two Provinces he was Speaker of the new Legislature; and in 1854 was Prime Minister under the Earl of Elgin. In 1859 he was a candidate for the British Parliament from Brighton, but was not elected. He was made an Aid-de-Camp to the Queen in 1860, and received the honorary rank of Colonel. Sir Alan McNab was made a baronet after his retirement from the Cabinet of the Earl of Elgin. He had for many years lived at a splendid residence, known as Dundurn, a short distance from Hamilton. Sir Alan suffered a considerable shock to his constitution last Fall, while on his way to England on board the steamer North Briton, which ran on the rocks in the Lower St. Lawrence. He has not for many years enjoyed good health, having been greatly afflicted with gout.

abstract: The city authorities, desiring to signify their appreciation of the distinguished services of Brig.Gen. SWEENEY, at the last meeting of that body adopted a series of resolutions publicly thanking that officer for his services, and inviting him to accept the congratulations of the citizens.
lead_paragraph: The city authorities, desiring to signify their appreciation of the distinguished services of Brig.-Gen. SWEENEY, at the last meeting of that body adopted a series of resolutions publicly thanking that officer for his services, and inviting him to accept the congratulations of the citizens. The Committee appointed to carry the resolutions into effect decided upon presenting Gen. SWEENEY with a sword on the occasion of his public reception, and accordingly purchased one for $175, of Messrs. TIFFANY & Co. It is a beautiful as well as a serviceable weapon. The scabbard is made of gold, lined with steel, and ornamented in the best manner. The handle is of solid silver, mounted by a golden head of Minerva, as she sprang from the brain of Jupiter. The shield is silver, and contains the following inscription:

abstract: Editorial gives advice to draft evaders
snippet: Editorial gives advice to draft evaders
lead_paragraph: -- We do not wish to tantalize the unhappy part of our male population who have been prevented by Secretary STANTON's order, from evading the operation of the forthcoming draft. If they were about to run away, they were about to do a very silly thing; but as the public did not know their purpose, they may easily make a virtue of necessity. They may safely and loudly pronounce every man a poltroon who is not willing to do his part in defending the Government that our Revolutionary Fathers founded. We advise them to take this course. They will feel better after having made up their minds to it, for patriotism is a virtue quite susceptible of cultivation.

abstract: Editorial on states which prefer to rely on volunteering to raise military quota
snippet: Editorial on states which prefer to rely on volunteering to raise military quota
lead_paragraph: There is a strong disposition throughout the whole North, but especially in the Middle and Eastern States, to avoid drafting, and trust to volunteering to raise both the three hundred thousand troops under the former call, and the three hundred thousand called for by draft. This desire seems to be especially felt by the Governors of the States. They are tender on the subject of drafting, and loath to resort to it. We understand that some of them are using their influence at Washington with a view to have the draft postponed or rescinded altogether. The Governors of several of the States have requested to be allowed to fill their quota with volunteers within a given time, and to order a draft only in such localities as may be backward in filling their quota. It is intimated that the President is moved by these influential representations, and is disposed to consent to this arrangement.

abstract: The first really cheering news the country has had from Missouri, for some time, is the report of the fight at Kirksville, in Adair County, between Col. MCNEIL's Union forces, 1,000 strong, and the guerrilla band of PORTER, estimated at 2,500. The latter are said to have lost 128 killed, and if so, they must have had a much larger number wounded. They disbanded and fled in confusion, and at last accounts were still pursued and captured in squads by Col. MCNEIL's troops. The chastisement and disorganization of this guerrilla horde which had grown to formidable dimensions in Northern Missouri, seem to be complete, and will probably clear that portion of the State of rebels, and render Missouri a much less attractive field for marauding operations.
lead_paragraph: The first really cheering news the country has had from Missouri, for some time, is the report of the fight at Kirksville, in Adair County, between Col. abstract: The intima  tions from Italy are big with events. The man whose sword is the oriflamme of Italian freedom again raises that sword on high.
lead_paragraph: The intimations from Italy are big with events. The man whose sword is the oriflamme of Italian freedom again raises that sword on high. GARIBALDI has given the word that the time has some for the redemption of Rome and Venice, and his thousands of enthusiastic followers are flocking to his standard. As the steel particles fly from all directions to the magnet, so the the lovers of Italian freedom, and the haters of oppression, wherever scattered, are rushing to join the red-shirted hero, who is again ready to lead them to glorious fields. Even from America, numbers of Garibaldini are obeying the summons; and valuable though the services of these might be to our cause, we would not have them stay, if a cause to them still more dear calls them to Italian soil. GARIBALDI is now in Sicily, where he has, for some time, been maturing his plans and preparing his expedition, and any steamer now may bring us word of the landing of his men somewhere on the Adriatic coast, and announce that anew blow has been struck for Italian unity and independence.

abstract: A very convenient and admirable method of aiding the families and watching over the persons of those who may be drafted into the army, has been put in practice to some extent in this City. It is for the workmen or employes in any large establishment or manufactory, or workshop of any kind, to club together and mutually agree to pay to the families of any one or more of their number who may be drafted, a certain sum per week, and to watch over the interests of the drafted persons, tend them in sickness, bring them home if wounded, &c. The Associations are being formed of about fifty persons each, which is found to be the most convenient number. Any fifty persons, friends, fellow-workmen, acquaintances or otherwise, may thus club, and the beneficial workings of the system will at once be seen. Such an association (fifty strong) has already been formed among the printers of the TIMES establishment; and we hear that they are also being formed elsewhere. The plan, we believe, will work admirably, and greatly encourage those who may be drafted.

abstract: The fuller reports which we publish this morning of the battle fought beyond Culpepper, on Saturday, between Gen. BANKS and Stonewall JACKSON, prove it to have been one of the hottest of the war.
lead_paragraph: The fuller reports which we publish this morning of the battle fought beyond Culpepper, on Saturday, between Gen. BANKS and Stonewall JACKSON, prove it to have been one of the hottest of the war. Although our forces suffered severely, proofs are not wanting that the enemy suffered much more heavily; and the most significant of these proofs is the fact that they yesterday morning sent a flag of truce to our lines, asking permission to bury their dead. This will be accepted as showing that they were too badly cut up to maintain their position, and that their falling back on Sunday, as noticed in our dispatches, was from necessity, and not from choice. The force of the enemy engaged is estimated at 20,000, while our own, exclusive of cavalry and artillery, did not exceed 7,000 -- about the usual odds at which we seem necessitated for some reason to fight the rebels.

abstract: From two English citizens who returned to this city recently from Richmond, after a sojourn there of five months, we learn several interesting items of news, which have never yet been published.
lead_paragraph: From two English citizens who returned to this city recently from Richmond, after a sojourn there of five months, we learn several interesting items of news, which have never yet been published. They received passports from the British Consul on the 26th ult., at Richmond, and went to Petersburgh, where they waited for a flag of truce which was to carry some Northern prisoners through their lines, but after waiting some three days they were disappointed, as Gen. LEE sent word that the roads were out of order for travel. The true reason, however, was that the rebels were busy in sending away their own troops to make an attack on Gen. MCCLELLAN's camp, which they were very anxious to conceal.

abstract: The battle of Saturday wears a more favorable aspect than was given it by some of the telegraphic details published yesterday. It is clear that though Gen. BANKS' command suffered ...
lead_paragraph: The battle of Saturday wears a more favorable aspect than was given it by some of the telegraphic details published yesterday. It is clear that though Gen. BANKS' command suffered heavy loss, and though he was outmanoeuvred by JACKSON in the early part of the action, yet he maintained his position with persistency and valor, and inflicted upon the rebels at least equal damage to what he himself suffered; while the fact that the enemy yesterday sent a flag of truce to our lines, asking permission to bury their dead, shows that our forces, at the conclusion of the engagement, held the field of battle. Our troops, as usual, showed their indomitable and heroic fighting qualities, and only one regiment, for lack of experience, is accused of flinching under fire. The rebels, most certainly, have nothing to boast of in this engagement.

abstract: The Government has given authority to Col. SWAIN to increase his regiment of cavalry to the maximum number of twelve companies of 100 each. This regiment is now in active service, under Gen. WADSWORTH, and is the mounted Provost-Guard of Washington. It is most splendidly equipped and mounted, and being the only United States volunteer cavalry regiment, it enjoys more advantages than any other in the service. Capt. ORNE and Lieut. BOGARDUS have a recruiting tent in the Park, from whence recruits are daily sent to the regiment in the field. Recruits are mustered into the service at once, and paid bounty, clothed, equipped and mounted -- so that they are at once in the receipt of their pay.

abstract: On Saturday last there was published in the TIMES a synopsis of the report of the Congressional Committee upon Contracts, the topic in this instance conspicuously reported upon being the railroad jobbery antecedent to the retirement of Mr. CAMERON from the War Office. The evidence is not complimentary to the Minister to Russia; nor is it so to Col. THOMAS SCOTT, Ex-Assistant Secretary of State and Manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It is quite possible the Committee have failed to affix the stigna of guilt to either of these worthies; but if, after examining the testimony, the reader has any hesitation in believing the two conspired to make the public service subsidiary to their private advantage, his incredulty will be incredible.

abstract: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a report  was presented by the Committee on National Affairs, and laid over under the rule, offering a ...
lead_paragraph: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a report was presented by the Committee on National Affairs, and laid over under the rule, offering a bounty of $10,000 to each of the organized militia regiments of this City which shall volunteer for the nine months' service under the last call for 300,000 troops. The Joint Committee on National Affairs also presented a report and ordinance appropriating $1,000,000 for the defence of New-York harbor, the money to be expended under the direction of six Harbor Defence Commissioners, four of whom are to be appointed by the Board of Aldermen, and the Mayor and Comptroller to constitute the other two. This report was also laid over under the rule, till the next meeting, which takes place to-morrow evening.

abstract: All leaves of absence, unless granted directly by the War Department, expired yesterday. On Monday next the rolls will be called in every regiment of the army, and all absentees, whether officers or privates, will, unless detained away by sickness disqualifying them for service, be stricken from the payroll, and regarded and treated as deserters. The warning, as given in the General Order of July 31, we thus repeat for the benefit of all concerned.
lead_paragraph: All leaves of absence, unless granted directly by the War Department, expired yesterday. The warning, as given in the General Order of July 31, we thus repeat for the benefit of all concerned.

abstract: At a regular meeting of the Board yesterday, after the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting, Alderman ---------- moved a suspension of the regular order of business for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee on National Affairs, relative to offering a bonus to the organized militia regiments of the City which should fill up their ranks and enlist for nine months in the United States service, in compliance with the last call for 300,000 militia. The report (see official) offers a bonus of $10,000 to each regiment so enlisting. It was laid over under the rule.

abstract: PICKPOCKET ON A STEAMBOAT. On Sunday, TIMOTHY CLEARY, of No. 27 Whitehall-street, was returning from Staten Island, and during the passage up he caught an unknown young man in the act of rifling his pantaloons pocket of a wallet containing $390.75 in British, German and Mexican silver coins, and a promissory note for $390.
lead_paragraph: PICKPOCKET ON A STEAMBOAT. -- On Sunday, TIMOTHY CLEARY, of No. 27 Whitehall-street, was returning from Staten Island, and during the passage up he caught an unknown young man in the act of rifling his pantaloons pocket of a wallet containing $390.75 in British, German and Mexican silver coins, and a promissory note for $390. As CLEARY turned to seize the thief, a fellow, giving his name as WILLIAM SMITH, stepped up and aided the rascal to escape, by striking CLEARY a heavy blow in the face, and knocking him down. During the excitement which prevailed, the man with the plunder escaped in the crowd and successfully secreted himself. SMITH, however, was taken for the assault, and also as being accessory to the theft, and when the boat arrived in her dock he was taken into custody by Officer BURNS, of the Fourth Ward. Yesterday afternoon SMITH was arraigned before Justice CONNOLLY, and committed to the Tombs for examination. The stolen property was not recovered.

abstract: Outside of Kings County on Long Island excepting Flushing and one or two more villages but little has been done in the way of volunteering under the last call for 300,000 volunteers, and there is little better prospect of anything better in the future.
lead_paragraph: Outside of Kings County on Long Island -- excepting Flushing and one or two more villages -- but little has been done in the way of volunteering under the last call for 300,000 volunteers, and there is little better prospect of anything better in the future. The able-bodied patriots who can possibly leave for the war, are already in the field of action, and have thus far everywhere rendered a creditable account of themselves. There are hundreds of subjects of a draft yet, who remain behind loitering their time away, for the most part in idleness and utter indifference to the demands of their country. The firder for a "draft," as might have been anticipated, has created among the latter class quite a panic, and for the first time since the rebellion commenced, they begin to realize not only that their country is at war, but that the Government is in earnest, and points significantly to them for that assistance which they so justly owe it. Quite a number of these lukewarm youths have already left their accustomed haunts for a more congenial climate, taking the North Star as their guide, and some of them have been so fearful of being caught that they have deemed it expedient to leave between two days, as for instance, a young gentleman left Blue Point the other day, much to the gratification of a fellow whose loyalty is frequently questioned by those who knew him best, but to the utter disgust of his loyal friends and relatives. But it is believed that such cases of skeddadling are rare even in Suffolk County. The stronger nerved intend to brave it out, and there is quite a numerous class, also, who are watching their pockets. This class is composed of hardy young farmers, too young to be subject to a draft, but nevertheless possessing more nerve and muscle than many who are several years older. These chaps are awaiting the demand for substitutes, when they expect to make their weak kneed neighbors' blead handsomely. They now ask $1,000 to go as substitutes, and threaten to raise their price, if not accepted and the money paid over before the 15th inst.

abstract: The Government appears determined upon sensations. The general supposition was that the mos stringent precautions had already been taken to pret vent the spontaneous flight of a very large proportion of the community subject to draft, or believing they were which is pretty much the same thing.
lead_paragraph: The Government appears determined upon sensations. The general supposition was that the most stringent precautions had already been taken to prevent the spontaneous flight of a very large proportion of the community subject to draft, or believing they were -- which is pretty much the same thing. We believed that those extremely patriotic and astute citizens who contemplated escape via Canada, Europe, and anywhere else, were effectually cornered, cabined, cribbed and confined, and we who were subject to the draft, and didn't propose to run away, were glad of it, for it lessened our chance while it did not detract from our patriotism. But it seems there was a loophole left, after all. Mr. KENNEDY, our amiable Superintendent of Police, had, in the kindness of his heart, construed the order prohibiting skedaddling, as not interfering with the regular California trade. He was aware of the geographical necessity for passing through a foreign country to get to California, but in the kindness of his heart, as hereinbefore mentioned, determined upon a liberal construction of the order, and had about made up his mind to let the passengers go in peace. Indeed, as late as 10 o'clock A.M., the steamer being about to sail at 12 M., precisely, the worthy Superintendent declared that the passengers might go, nem. con., and accordingly they packed on board, bag and baggage, lug and luggage, tickets in hand, and supposing all was right. But a change came o'er the spirit of their day-dreams, in the shape of a posse of police, who without ceremony cleared the ship from stem to stern, of every man not an employe, who had not a passport. Of course, nobody had a passport. They had many of them inquired before purchasing tickets, and had been informed that there would be no detention. Ono passenger averred that he had a telegram from Secretary SEWARD to that effect. The discomfiture was general and the indignation universal; but what could not be cured had to be endured -- if not with a good grace, certainly with a bad one. Mr. KENNEDY's policemen were inexorable, and the passengers had no alternative but to vacate the premises, excepting the few women and children and old men exempted.

abstract: At a regular meeting of the Board yesterday, after the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting, Alderman ---------- moved a suspension of the regular order of business for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee on National Affairs, relative to offering a bonus to the organized militia regiments of the City which should fill up their ranks and enlist for nine months in the United States service, in compliance with the last call for 300,000 militia. The report (see official) offers a bonus of $10,000 to each regiment so enlisting. It was laid over under the rule.

abstract: Among the throngs who, during Saturday and Monday, were examined and detained by the Provost Guard at the different European and California steamer wharves, was no small represention of the German element of our community.
lead_paragraph: Among the throngs who, during Saturday and Monday, were examined and detained by the Provost Guard at the different European and California steamer wharves, was no small represention of the German element of our community. On the Hamburg steamers they greatly outnumbered any and every other nationality. Some of these were naturalized citizens, who were departing on bona fide trips of business or pleasure in the Old World. Many were attracted by the peculiarly interesting state of affairs in Europe, and others were going out to look after matters connected with the great Rifle Shooting Festival at Frankfort-on-the-Main. But a large majority of the proposed voyagers was made up of a class of petty speculators, fourth-rate traveling dry goods clerks, speculators in wine, cigars, and the various other commodities which Europe supplies. Another set consisted of men who, neither professing nor desiring to owe allegiance to the country, have yet been perfectly willing to seek shelter here, where they could pursue their avocations at great profit to themselves, and often to the great loss of more patriotic residents. These were among the men who have speculated in "panics," and have materially assisted in depreciating our markets, running up the price of specie and running down the value of Government stuck. They and the class previously mentioned have everywhere, even among their own countrymen, been noted for their high-backed sneering at everything in the country they were robbing, and scornful denunciations of American military affairs. Yet now, when their exalted wisdom might find a chance for our enlightenment, they, with as much cruelty as alacrity, leave us in the lurch. There is, too, quite a large contingent of mock-revolutionist among these strategists for a retreat. Coming to us with an immense outcry of wonderful deeds performed on the barricades and in the fields of Europe, they

abstract: A Washington dispatch says that CASSIUS M. CLAY, of Kentucky, our returned Minister from Russia, has not accepted his commission of Major-General of Volunteers, tendered him by the President, and that it is not at all certain that he will accept.
lead_paragraph: A Washington dispatch says that CASSIUS M. CLAY, of Kentucky, our returned Minister from Russia, has not accepted his commission of Major-General of Volunteers, tendered him by the President, and that it is not at all certain that he will accept. It is further added that Mr. CLAY thinks the nation has already more generals in the field than it needs, quality being considered; and that as they all have one year the start of him in experience, he will not try to compete with them, but will seek to serve the nation again in the field-diplomatic. Indeed, it is broadly asserted in this same dispatch, that inasmuch as Mr. CAMERON is evidently unpopular at the Court of St. Petersburgh, and Mr. CLAY has the full confidence of the European Powers, among whom he has spent the past year, it is not impossible, nor improbable even, that he (Mr. CLAY) will return to Russia at an early day, as Minister.

abstract: The numerous recruiting offices around the City did, a thriving business yesterday. Volunteers came in freely, and the prospects of quickly filling up the ranks of regiments in the field, and of completing the new regiments to the regulation standard, without resorting to drafting, seemed brighter than ever. It is to be hoped, though, that the probability of doing this will not render those who are able to join the army indifferent and supine. The quota of the State is not full [???]. Several thousand men are wanted to reinforce the veteran regiments to their original strength, and to prevent the new organizations from being consolidated. Only about a week remains wherein volunteering will avail to secure the liberal bounties offered by the State and United States authorities -- so all who desire to obtain these pecuniary aids, and at the same time avoid conscription, had better hurry up and enroll their names at once.

abstract: The final preparations for the sending on active service of the frigate New Ironsides are in course of completion. Orders have been received at the Brooklyn Navy-yard to dispatch at once to Philadelhia a ...
lead_paragraph: The final preparations for the sending on active service of the frigate New Ironsides are in course of completion. Orders have been received at the Brooklyn Navy-yard to dispatch at once to Philadelphia a guard of marines and 150 sailors to make up the quantum of the vessel. The marines are in charge of Sergeant JOHN GOTTENNEYER, who has been specially selected as "Chief of Police" of the first iron-clad frigate ever commissioned under the American flag. Master's Mate JOHN BURNS, who received his appointment yesterday in the Navy, is to convert the blue jackets to their new home.

abstract: -- Theseventh annual exhibition of the New-Jersey Agricultural Society will be held at Newton in September. Premiums are offered ranging from $3 to $10 for the best specimens of bulls, cows and heifers, of the following breeds: Darbons, Devons, Herefords, Ayrshires and Alderneys; also, for the best cattle without regard to blood. The best sample of milch cow will be awarded $15. Working oxen and steers, also, are to receive an award varying from $3 to $10. Horses, mules and jacks, come in the second class, and the best stallions of two, three, four, five, six years, and older, up to twelve, the best teams of geldings, and mares of similar ages, trotting horses, will receive a reward of $10; others, possessing merit, less amounts, from $5 to $8. The best lots of fat sheep, long-wooled and middle-wooled, and best native blacks, receive the award of $10; second best, generally $5 each. Swine -- the best, $8; second best, $5. The different varieties of poultry are offered $3; second-class, $2. Turkeys, ducks, geese, Guinea fowls, pea fowls, pigeons and rabbits, are included in a similar category.

abstract: editorial on campaign
snippet: editorial on campaign
lead_paragraph: Some weeks ago a little cloud appeared on the Southern horizon no larger than a man's hand. It was the nomination of rival candidates for the office of Governor of the State of North Carolina. As the canvass progressed the cloud grew larger, until it not only overshadowed the State, but casts its gloom even toward Richmond. One JOHNSON, a politician of the South Carolina school, an aristocrat and fire-eater, became the candidate of the original Secessionists of the old North State. He was opposed by Col. ZEBULON B. VANCE, a Union member of Congress two years ago. But VANCE, though a Unionist up to the date when North Carolina was dragged out of the Union, seems to have yielded to the heresy of the times, and "followed his State" into the ranks of treason, for he raised a regiment of volunteers, and is now serving in the Confederate army near Richmond.

abstract: The funeral of this gallant young officer took place at St. George's Church, in Astoria, yesterday afternoon, and was attended by a large concourse of people from that village and from this City. The services were conducted in the Episcopal form by the Pastor of the church, Rev. Dr. HARRIS, assisted by Rev. Mr. SAYRES, of Ravenswood.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of this gallant young officer took place at St. George's Church, in Astoria, yesterday afternoon, and was attended by a large concourse of people from that village and from this City. The services were conducted in the Episcopal form by the Pastor of the church, Rev. Dr. HARRIS, assisted by Rev. Mr. SAYRES, of Ravenswood. After reading appropriate passages from Scripture, the Pastor briefly addressed the congregation, and spoke of the deceased as one who had fallen in the glorious cause of defending law, justice, truth and government. No man could come to a more honorable end than in the defence of a cause such as our Government was now engaged in, and the highest teachings of Christianity authorized us to say of a man who gave up his life to such a cause that he died virtuously. There was not a man among us who should not willingly surrender his life, if need be, in defence of those great principles of law, justice and good government, for which we were now contending.

abstract: The Government may easily put a stop to the exodus of poltroons and semi-Secessionists by causing all those caught in flagrante delicto, to be immediately mustered into service under the President's second call for 300,000 men. The small chance of escape to Canada or Europe would not be likely to influence such men so much as the almost certainty of their apprehension by our active Provost-Marshals.
lead_paragraph: The Government may easily put a stop to the exodus of poltroons and semi-Secessionists by causing all those caught in flagrante delicto, to be immediately mustered into service under the President's second call for 300,000 men. abstract: The Parliamentary [???] Association of Paisley, representing the industrial classes of that great manufacturing city, has forwarded an address to the authorities of this country, which is very different in its tone from the utterances of the aristocracy and snobocracy of England. It recognizes that the present struggle of the North is one for the equal rights of man, and gives warm utterance to the sympathies and prayers of the working-classes for our success. Coming after the recent remarkable demonstration of the unfortunate laborers of Manchester, it gives proof that we have friends in Great Britain, and that these friends are those who suffer most terribly by the war, but who see in it an object, which consecrates even their own sorrows. No European city has suffered more from the stoppage of the cotton supply than the people of the Scottish town of Paisley; but those disfranchised and ground-down workers, who have no voice in Press or Parliament, recognize in our success the dawn of a better day for the whole world and for themselves. When once they get to the top, we shall have fewer insults from England.

abstract: SIDNEY SMITH used to tell a good story of a friend of his who, when Finchley Common the favorite preserve of highwaymen) came, in the progress of improvement, to be inclosed, and the footpads lost the opportunity of exercising their gallant vocation, proposed to draw up for them a petition to the House of ...
lead_paragraph: SIDNEY SMITH used to tell a good story of a friend of his who, when Finchley Common the favorite preserve of highwaymen) came, in the progress of improvement, to be inclosed, and the footpads lost the opportunity of exercising their gallant vocation, proposed to draw up for them a petition to the House of Commons, running somewhat after this wise: "We, your loyal highwaymen of Finchley Common and its neighborhood, having, at great expense, laid in a stock of blunderbusses, pistols and other instruments for plundering the public, and finding ourselves impeded in the exercise of our calling by the said inclosure of the said Common of Finchley, humbly petition your honorable House will be pleased to assign to us such compensation as your honorable House in its wisdom and justice may think fit."

abstract: The War Department, in answer to an inquiry from Gov. MORGAN, has telegraphed that the Department will receive volunteers for the old regiments until the draft is made. As the draft can not be made before the 1st of September, volunteering for the old regiments will therefore be in order until that time.

abstract: Lieut. C. Stuart Webster, of the Fifteenth NewYork Volunteers, who died at New-Haven on Saturday, was well known in this City, where he was engaged in the insurance agency business at the time the war broke out. He was a grandson of the great lexicographer, Noah Webster, and a great grandson, ...
lead_paragraph: Lieut. C. Stuart Webster, of the Fifteenth New-York Volunteers, who died at New-Haven on Saturday, was well known in this City, where he was engaged in the insurance agency business at the time the war broke out. He was a grandson of the great lexicographer, Noah Webster, and a great grandson, through his mother, who was a Custis, of Martha Washington. One who knew him well, describes Lieut. Webster as having been a man of fine attainments, of great energy of character, brave almost to recklessness, and yet in his social habits as gentle and winning as a child. His qualifications as a civil engineer were of a superior grade, and it was largely owing to his skill and sleepless energy that the Chickahominy was spanned by these half dozen bridges over which our army passed on their way toward Richmond. In all the land engineering work that preceded the famous seven days' battle, as well as in the terrible work of the battle itself, Lieut. WEBSTER sustained his full share, and, although he escaped wounds on the field, he, nevertheless, through constant exposure, night and day, on that field, contracted the disease which resulted in his death.

abstract: The Police Commissioners yesterday concluded the reception of evidence in the case of Inspector FOLK and Capt. HOLBROOK, charged with neglect of duty with reference to the late riot at the tobacco factory in Brooklyn, Wm. EGNER, foreman in the adjoining building for Mr. LORILLARD, testified that as early as 8 o'clock in the morning he thought there would be a little row.
lead_paragraph: The Police Commissioners yesterday concluded the reception of evidence in the case of Inspector FOLK and Capt. HOLBROOK, charged with neglect of duty with reference to the late riot at the tobacco factory in Brooklyn, Wm. EGNER, foreman in the adjoining building for Mr. LORILLARD, testified that as early as 8 o'clock in the morning he thought there would be a little row. He had no expectation of a riot. Saw young men hanging about the corners, and thought they wanted to make a disturbance with the colored people on account of the fight with the colored people on the Friday previous; did not apprehend any extended difficulty; took measures as early as 10 o'clock to protect his factory; notified Mr. LORILLARD, Mr. WATSON and Mr. KELSEY; they went off, saying they would notify the police, about 10 o'clock; they went to the New-York station; the Brooklyn police knew nothing of the affair at that time; there was no want of vigilance on the part of the police, who did a great deal better than he expected so few men could do with so large a crowd; heard no threats that there was to be an outbreak.

abstract: A gentleman up town, who, the other day, missed his "boy," learned that the lad was at Carrollton. He at once repaired to the headquarters of Gen. PHELPS, and stated his case -- that he was in search of a runaway negro. "You have lost a man, have you?" observed the General, inquiringly and dryly. "Yes, Sir," responded the other. "Very well," said the General, "the negroes are over yonder; if your boy is there, he can go with you, if he wishes." The gentleman asked, further, that a guide might be sent with him, as he did not know the road and paths. "Certainly," said the General -- "Orderly, call Maj. SCOTT." Presently the Major presented himself, and the General instructed him to conduct the gentleman to the negro camp, and assist him in finding his "boy," and to say to the "boy" that he had his (the General's) permission to return with his master. Thereupon the Minor spoke: "General, I am the 'boy' the gentleman is in search of. I do not want to return." "This is all I can do," observed the General. The droll part of this incident is, that the General was ignorant of the fact that the gentleman was SCOTT's master. The "Major" has nitherto been known in darkey circles as a great orator; he is now known as "Maj. SCOTT, of the Black Guards." Queer things have come out of secession.

abstract: -- DEATH OF CAPT. BLUNCK. -- Capt. MARCUS B. MUNCK, the gentleman who was so severely burned by the burning of the Rainbow Hotel, corner of William and Beekman streets, on the 6th inst., died on Monday in the New-York Hospital. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, and averdict of death from burns accidentally received was returned by the jury. Deceased was 30 years of age, and a native of Ireland. The funeral will take place to-day from the City Hospital at 1 P.M. His remains will be deposited in Greenwood, and will be attended thither by two companies of the Stanton Legion.

abstract: SHOOTING AFFRAY IN GRAND-STREET -- A POLITICAL DISCUSSION ENDS IN BLOOD -- ARREST OF THE GUILTY PARTY. -- Mr. JOHN BENNETT, proprietor of a drinking saloon on the corner of Green and Grand streets, was shot in his own house, about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by a man named JOHN VARIAN. The latter was in the saloon, and had been drinking. A discussion arose relative to the conduct of the war, and was carried on between VARIAN and a man named VALES, when the former was forcibly ejected from the saloon. Upon getting outside he drew his pistol and fired twice, evidently with the intention of shooting Mr. VALES. The first shot passed through the door and lodged in the floor. The second took effect in the head of Mr. BENNETT, who had just come from behind the bar, and was proceeding toward the door. The ball entered first above the right temple, and passed out at the top of the head. The wounded man fell to the floor, from whence he was taken up stairs, and three physicians sent for. The physicians pronounce the wound a highly dangerous one, but think there is a probability that it may not prove fatal. Detective KING, who was passing on Broadway heard the report of the pistol, and immediately ran down Grand-street. VARIAN stood in the street, and upon seeing the officer coming toward him, took deliberate aim, but before he could fire the detective was upon him, and had wrenched the pistol from his grasp. The weapon is a revolver of the largest size -- six-barreled and self-cocking. VARIAN was taken to headquarters. He states that he was a member of the First Fire Zouaves, and that he took this pistol from a member of the Black Horse Cavalry, at the battle of Bull Run. He says he is 27 years of age, a native of New-York, and that he is a single man. He is locked up at headquarters. The Police know him well, and say he is a pickpocket. Mr. BENNETT is a man well known in the Eight Ward, and is highly esteemed. He is about 57 years of age.

abstract: -- Those rival Lilliputian Gen. TOM THUMB and Commodore NUTT, are creating an immense sensation at the Museum. The idea of uniting these competitive attractions could have entered the head of none other than the great showman, or, had any one else thought of the plan, none other would have had enterprise enough to put it into execution. The General and Commodore engage in a grand and comprehensive trial of skill in all those performances  for which both of them have been justly celebrated. They each appear in a wide range of characters, in songs, dances and statuesque tableaux, and whichever excels the other in the long run is to receive a prize of $1,000. At present neither seems to be ahead, and they will no doubt have to contend for several weeks to come, especially if the public continues to rush in such crowds to see them.

abstract: A MAN ARRESTED FOR MURDERING HIS OWN SON SINGULAR CASE. -- A German named DRESSLER was arrested yesterday by the Ninth Precinct Police, on a charge of killing his own son, a lad about 12 years old, by thursting a pitchfork into his brain. The prisoner resides at the corner of Lott's-lane and Lafayette-avenue. On Monday the accused was loading a wagon with hay, assisted by the deceased, when, under some slight provocation the father made a thrust at his son with a pitchfork, killing him instantly. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest on the body, when all the testimony that could be obtained was that of the father, who swore that the killing was accidental, and the jury rendered a verdict accordingly to that effect. Subsequently the Police discovered a man who witnessed the whole transaction, and he swears that the use of the pitchfork was a deliberate act of malice. DRESSLER was arrested yesterday, while attending the funeral, and, with the witness, was locked up, until the case can be more fully investigated.

abstract: JOHN MORGAN, with 1,800 cavalry, and four pieces of artillery, entered Gallatin, Tenn., early this morning, and captured Col. BOONE, commanding the post, without about 300 men of the Twenty-eighth Kentucky, and a Federal freight train, containing 60 horses, and a lot of oats and corn. There was no fight. MORGAN was still in possesion at noon today.

abstract: Such an exodus of numbers as might have taken place, may be imagined from the crowds who are compelled to stay at home under the orders of Secretary STANTON. A spontaneous resolve upon travel appears to have seized the masses of those who had the shadow of a shade of pretext for denying that they are citizens of the United States. Hearty, robust, stalwart men, who have lived here, made money here, and been protected here for five, ten or more years, daily present themselves for passports to leave the country, avowedly because they, though not liable, are afraid of being drafted. Such is the combination of ignorance and cowardice which has seized some men. So far as at present developed, nobody manifests any reluctance to let such men go, and many say "good riddance."

abstract: editorial speculates on Jackson's movements
snippet: editorial speculates on Jackson's movements
lead_paragraph: -- Now that under cover of the darkness of Monday night. Stonewall JACKSON has suddenly retreated and recrossed the Rapidan, the purpose of his passage over the stream and advance in a northerly direction, giving battle to BANKS' corps on Saturday last, appears evident. He wished simply to get a blow at part of Gen. POPE's force before the whole of it was concentrated, and cripple it as much as was in his power. He threw forward 20,000 men against one-half that number of Union troops, fought a battle, which was not as successful, perhaps, as he anticipated, and went back. He may have made the retrograde movement, perhaps, quicker than he intended, because of the reported approach of Gen. BURNSIDE in his rear, and the sudden massing of troops by POPE in his front. But he escaped, it seems, in time to save himself, and has succeeded in placing himself in a position where reinforcements are much easier got than they would have been at Cedar Mountain. It is a misfortune that he has effected his escape -- a still greater misfortune than it was that he was permitted to come and bring on a battle. But there is good chance still that he may yet be cornered by the combined efforts of POPE and BURNSIDE. While it is important to prevent any great reinforcements reaching him from Richmond, it is still more important that he be not permitted, in case of any sudden emergency on the Peninsula, to rush back with any part of his force to Richmond. The operations in Gen. POPE's Department at the present time are of vital significance. The stake is greater than appears on its surface; the forces on both sides are large, and the commanders among the ablest in either service. We have POPE, SIGEL, BURNSIDE, BANKS and MCDOWELL, with a large number of the most dashing inferior officers; while the rebels have JACKSON, HILL, EWELL and others. From the character of the men in command on either side it is not likely that there will be any long period of delay or inaction. We hope that it will be possible for our army next time to be the attacking party, and with superior numbers, and not give the rebels the advantage in both particulars, as has generally been the case in Virginia.

abstract: The Summer sojourners at Rockaway are rejoicing in the performances of a very superior quartette of musicians, who make the evening concerts at the Pavilion much more attractive than those at watering places usually are. BERGMANN, of the Philharmonic Society, has been there through the season with his violincello, and EREN with his flute. In addition to the daily afternoon and evening performances they have given two or three serenades, at which one or two additional instruments have been brought down from the City. MATZKA presides at the piano, and SCHNEIDER plays the violin. Their annual concert takes place on Saturday evening next, Aug. 16. The Pavilion is unusually crowded this year.

abstract: -- Among the items of European news is a report that a marriage is on the tapis for our late guest, the Prince of Wales; that two ladies, one of Denmark and the other of Prussia, are mentioned for him, and "the King of the Belgians, it is said, inclines to the former." The King of the Belgians is a very old and experienced bird in this matter of royal marriages, and his inclinations are very likely to settle the case; but we should really like to know which of the two girls the Prince of Wales inclines to, or whether he inclines to either of them. The case is a hard one -- that the young English kingling's bedfellow should be picked out for him by the withered old diplomat of Belgium.
