abstract: Col. Weir, of the Indian Expedition, who was put under arrest by his junior, Col. Salomon, publishes a card in the Western papers defending himself. He says: "Until interrupted by Col. Salomon's munity, I had not only succeeded in capturing Col. Clarkson, and breaking up his regiment, commissioned by Gen. Van Dorn to destroy the Santa Fe trade; driven Rains from his position threatening Southwest Missouri; reduced the whole Cherokee Nation to a restoration ...
lead_paragraph: -- Col. Weir, of the Indian Expedition, who was put under arrest by his junior, Col. Salomon, publishes a card in the Western papers defending himself. He says: "Until interrupted by Col. Salomon's munity, I had not only succeeded in capturing Col. Clarkson, and breaking up his regiment, commissioned by Gen. Van Dorn to destroy the Santa Fe trade; driven Rains from his position threatening Southwest Missouri; reduced the whole Cherokee Nation to a restoration of their treaty relations with the United States; conquered the country to the Arkansas River; but was in the act of destroying the rebel force south of that river, under Gen. Cooper. Had I not been been interrupted, there would at this moment have been no respectable body of the enemy north of Red River, except the army of Hindman. The results of such successes must be apparent. The trade of the Indian Country, hitherto diverted to Fort Smith, would have been brought here and to St. Louis. Arkansas and Texas would have been threatened on their frontier, and the [???] now being used to reinforce Hindman effectually checked, while the Indians would have been converted from enemies into friends. Salomon's plan, forever was to run, -- mine to attack. A court-martial will determine which was the most proper; but, in the breaktime, I would respectfully request that the results to flow from the advance of our arms to Red River be not undervalued."

abstract: scriptively necessary for budding royalty. This schooling, owing to the anomalous position of the family in the European political system, was not to be had in Europe. Civil war opportunely broke out in America. Hither, with the Prince of Joinville as their Mentor, the Princelings came; selected the side to fight upon, with, we suspect, far less regard to the merits of the contest than the convenience of the National headquarters, and the facilities of departure in case of disgust; and served their year with commendable subordination and good humor. A serious reverse befel the National arms. The army, to the staff of which they were attached, was beaten from its chosen position; and after a conflict reflecting eternal credit upon our gallant fellows, reached the banks of the James several miles further from Richmond than the scene of the curliest strife. At this moment of gloom and prostration, the Princes announced their determination to return to Europe; and the determination was at once put in practice.

abstract: The near approach of the 15th, when drafting, it is stated, will positively be commenced, has materially accelerated recruiting for the last two days, in Brooklyn. Persons liable to be drafted are beginning to feel that there is but a short time for them to decide whether they will accept the liberal bounty offered, and come forward to aid the country in an honorable manner, or take the other alternative, and be forced to discharge their duty, without bounty or other pecuniary reward.

abstract: The prospects of filling up the quota of this State before the 15th inst look brighter than ever. Yesterday all the recruiting offices were maintained in a healthy condition of excitement -- men coming in fast and steadily from quite early in the morning until near 5 o'clock. In the belief that there will be no necessity to resort to drafting to fill up the requisition for 300,000 for three years or the war, Gov. MORGAN has telegraphed to the War Department requesting an extension of ten days to enable New-York to voluntarily fulfill her duty. It is even thought that by the 1st week in September the second (militia) 300,000 could be obtained by volunteering. Deputations from almost every county in the State were in consultation with the Governor on the subject on Monday.

abstract: -- Capt. DAVIS, of the Western Flotilla, has been subjected to frequent attack by a portion of the public Press on account of his failure to take Vicksburgh. There are two facts that should be known before a judgment is pronounced. 1. It was wholly impossible to capture the place without the aid of land forces. This cooperation he repeatedly requested, but never obtained. 2. At the time of his withdrawal from Vicksburgh and retirement up the Mississippi, full one-half of his men were prostrated by sickness. Any verdict which did not take these circumstances into account would necessarily be imperfect.
lead_paragraph: -- Capt. DAVIS, of the Western Flotilla, has been subjected to frequent attack by a portion of the public Press on account of his failure to take Vicksburgh. Any verdict which did not take these circumstances into account would necessarily be imperfect.

abstract: The skedaddling mania subsided to a great extent yesterday, partly because there were no cheap steamers sailing, and partly on account of the vigorous efforts of the Government to keep the prospective conscripts home.
lead_paragraph: The skedaddling mania subsided to a great extent yesterday, partly because there were no cheap steamers sailing, and partly on account of the vigorous efforts of the Government to keep the prospective conscripts home. The moral effect of Secretary STANTON's order was great, hut, the physical persuasion of the Provost-Marshal and his Deputies is also great. There were, however, three or four more added to the skedaddaler's brigade, and none of them furnished the required bonds to serve if drafted. There were less than the usual number of passports presented, those for the Emerald Isle Comprising by far the largest number. Not a few apparently respectable and intelligent citizens applied to know whether they were at liberty to travel north, south or east, or the watering [???]. The Deputy Marshals were [???] to [???] -- for the [???] don't take the [???] or [???] them, [???] want they read -- that [???] travel.

abstract: -- The Government has done itself the honor of conferring the rank of Major-General of Volunteers upon Gen. PHILIP KEARNEY. No officer in the service has more thorough knowledge of military science, and no one has had half the experience, Gen. KEARNEY has served in Mexico, Algeria, and in Italy. Wherever he has served he has won universal applause for daring intrepidity. He is just the man to cope with [???] and the authorities could do no more sensible thing than to organize a flying column, similar to that of the rebel leader, and give the command to KEARNEY. So furnished, and with ample discretion, he would soon give a splendid account of himself.

abstract: The following choice pieces of intercepted letter-writing were handed to our correspondent in Suffolk, by an officer of high rank residing there, and is quite genuine. It will be found interesting, as illustrating the dread which the rebels entertain of our ...
lead_paragraph: The following choice pieces of intercepted letter-writing were handed to our correspondent in Suffolk, by an officer of high rank residing there, and is quite genuine. It will be found interesting, as illustrating the dread which the rebels entertain of our Yankee boys carrying away the hearts of the secesh girls, their great education, and also as proving how nicely these people manage to keep up a correspondence between Suffolk and Richmond -- a letter having been evidently received at the camp near Richmond and replied to on the same day -- the 19th of July, 1862. We give the letter verbatim et literatum from the original:

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION, At a regular meeting of this Board, yesterday, President VERILANCK in the chair, a communication was presented by the General Agent from an Englishman named HENRY HASLAM, in which he states that he was persuaded to leave England for Utah by the Mormons, and after paying  3 16s, passage for each member of his family, ...
lead_paragraph: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION. -- At a regular meeting of this Board, yesterday, President VERILANCK in the chair, a communication was presented by the General Agent from an Englishman named HENRY HASLAM, in which he states that he was persuaded to leave England for Utah by the Mormons, and after paying 3 16s, passage for each member of his family, he was induced by Mormon Elders to pay 118, for other passengers not belonging to his family. When he got as far as Florence, in Nebraska Territory, he discovered that the Mormon Elders were trying to persuade his wife to abandon him. This opened his eyes to the beauties of Mormonism, and he took the back track, arriving here [???] and is now at Castle Garden awaiting a remittance from England to enable him to return home. The communication was placed on file. Little other [???] was transacted by the Board. The following is the weekly statement: Emigrants arrived during the past week, 703, making a total of 46,646 since first of January [???]. The number arrived during the same period last year was 51,862. Number of inmates in the institution on Ward's Island, 641. The receipt into be he treasury of the Commission during the past week has been $2846 55. Total since Jan. 1, [???]. Balance on hand at date, $14,674.

abstract: The People ex rel. Charles H. Combes vs. Col. Warner and Capt. Carr. -- The respondents are the Colonel and a Captain of the Fifth Regiment. New-York Volunteers, better known as Duryee's Zouaves, which is now recruiting in this City. A writ of habeas corpus was issued to Col. Warner and Capt. Carr to produce the body of the relator's minor son, who, it is alledged, was induced to enlist in the Fifth Regiment, and to make oath that he was over eighteen years of age. Capt. Carr appeared on the return day, with the alledged minor, and stated that he knew nothing of the circumstances of the enlistment, except that relator's son applied at the recruiting office of the regiment, on Broadway and was regularly sworn as to his age, &c.

abstract: Events which have transpired since the battle of Cedar Mountain lead to the conclusion that the rebels were terribly defeated, and that their retreat across the Rapidan was a positive necessity, owing to their crippled condition.
lead_paragraph: Events which have transpired since the battle of Cedar Mountain lead to the conclusion that the rebels were terribly defeated, and that their retreat across the Rapidan was a positive necessity, owing to their crippled condition. There appears to be no doubt that had Gen. POPE's forces been sufficiently concentrated to have moved forward on Sunday, the defeat of Stonewall JACKSON would have been most complete. A dispatch from Gen. BUFORD, forwarded to Gen. HALLECK. by Gen. POPE, sufficiently proves this. Gen. BUFORD commanded a cavalry reconnoissance on Tuesday, down the Orange. Court-house road, in the track of the flying enemy. He reports that the flight of the enemy after the fight was must precipitate, and in great commission. The [???] descried by them was strewn with dead men horses and arms, and all along the route pursued by our cavalry were found wounded men, among whom was no less a [???] than Major ANDREWS, JACKSON's Chief of [???]. JACKSON's flag of [???] on Monday, asking permission to bury his dead, gave him more time for escape, ad now he has the [???] swollen [???] consequent upon a heavy rain which fell in theregion beyond Cedar Mountain on Tuesday.

abstract: A trotting-match took place on Tuesday on the Union Course, for which there were ten entries and six starters; it being for a purse of $50 and the entrance money; mile and repeat, and to go as they pleased. The horse that trotted nearest to three minutes to win the purse. The following started: Mr. R. WALTER's sorrel stallion (pacer), who won the first heat; Mr. HOWE's sorrel mare, who won the second heat; HIRAM WOODRUFF's brown gelding, who, with Mr. WALTER's pacer, ran a dead heat in the third heat; Mr. P. DUBOIS' sorrel mare, who won the fourth and fifth heats, and the race; and a brown stallion, which was drawn after the fourth heat, and D. PFIFER's gray gelding, which did not win either of the five heals. The heats were so well contested that in neither of them was there a difference of two seconds between the horses. The nicety with which the drivers managed not to get over or under the three minutes, was very amusing as well as exciting, and the whole affair created a vast amount of good humor and fun among the comparatively small number of spectators who had ventured to the course, notwithstanding the threatening state of the weather.

abstract: The correspondence, published this morning, between the rebel Gen. LEE and Gen. HALLECK, in relation to our mode of dealing with traitors, ends very abruptly. LEE is not only [???] in his statements but insulting in his language. He evidently only desires an opportunity of concealing the past [???] of the rebel leaders, and continuing them in future. The rebels have hung Unionists in East Tennessee by the score, and butchered them all over the South by the hundred. And not into a single one of these cases has one Government made inquiry, or in any instance attempted retaliation. The blood of Gen. MCCOOK, brutally murdered by the guerrillas whom JEFF. DAVIS has authorized and defended, was hardly cold when LEE was writing his insulting letter. And BECKNER and half a dozen other rebel Generals had just arrived in Richmond, for whom the Secessionists had promised an exchange, but were even then in the act of swindling us about. There is nothing whatever, no reason and no argument, that will have any effect with these bad men but the quick crushing out of their bloody rebellion.

abstract: It will be observed that Gov. ANDREW in the instructions (published elsewhere,) which he has issued for the enrollment of the militia of Massachusetts, preparatory to drafting, commands that "all [italics his,] citizens, white ...
lead_paragraph: -- It will be observed that Gov. ANDREW in the instructions (published elsewhere,) which he has issued for the enrollment of the militia of Massachusetts, preparatory to drafting, commands that "all [italics his,] citizens, white or colored, who, at the date of the order were between the ages of eighteen and forty-five," shall be included. We must say this strikes us as a bit of very artful dodging. The Order of the War Department furnishing the Governors with regulations for drafting, and in obedience to which Order, Gov. ANDREW issues his instructions, provides that the enrollment shall embrace "all able-bodied citizens," etc., without any qualification of white or black, and this for the simple reason that blacks are not citizens of the United States. They may, however, be citizens of the individual States, (they are so in Massachusetts,) and hence, to avoid all ambiguity, the law on the national statute-book concerning drafting, expressly limits it to "able-bodied white male citizens." We observe, however, that, by a clerical error in the late order of instructions to the Governors, the adjective "white" is omitted.

abstract: For some considerable time an ill-feeling has existed between JOSEPH COBURN, the noted pugilist, and ANDREW HINES, alias "Figsey," the keeper of a resort for sporting characters in West Houston-street. It appears that on the 7th inst. these parties accidentally met on the Fashion Association race track, ...
lead_paragraph: For some considerable time an ill-feeling has existed between JOSEPH COBURN, the noted pugilist, and ANDREW HINES, alias "Figsey," the keeper of a resort for sporting characters in West Houston-street. It appears that on the 7th inst. these parties accidentally met on the Fashion Association race track, on Long Island, and entered into a dispute over an affair existing between JIM IRVING and COBURN. High words ensued, and COBURN, so it is alleged, threatened to punish HINES for his interference in the matter. HINES approached COBURN and the two came to blows, but which was the aggressive party first in this scene has not satisfactorily appeared. COBURN was knocked down and dreadfully beaten. Both of his eyes were gouged out and laid upon his cheeks while his arms were fairly pinioned, but by [???] physical strength he succeeded in loosing himself, and shoved his eyes back into their place. He was also cut in the nose with a chisel. Through the interference of a large number of spectators of this brutal scene, the parties were separated.

abstract: The letter  VOLUNTEERING VS. INTERVENTION. The letter  of our London correspondent, published yesterday, in allusion to the mutterings of intervention, said: "If the 300,000 volunteers  called for by the Government are promptly ...
lead_paragraph: -- The letter of our London correspondent, published yesterday, in allusion to the mutterings of intervention, said: "If the 300,000 volunteers called for by the Government are promptly raised, intervention will be indefinitely postponed. Or if the Government gives a demonstration of its power by a successful conscription, it will have the same effect." That the opinion of our English critics was that we would not be able to make these demonstrations of our power, is placed beyond a doubt by the subjoined, from a leader in the London Times, which we may regard as the latest and choicest of all its prophecies:

abstract: A large and enthusiastic war meeting was held at Mamaroneck. Westchester County, on Tuesday evening. Spirited speeches were made by Mr. MORSE, Rev. W.F. WATKINS and others. Two gentlemen each offered twenty dollars in addition to the State and United States bounties to every man in the town who would enlist. Several volunteered on the spot and a number of others will follow in a few days.

abstract: Wehave ascertained on good authority that the statement which appeared in several papers, that the Santec and other vessels of the blockading squadron off Galveston, were not supplied properly with fresh provisions, is totally unfounded. It was also reported that the supply streamers have been loaded with sutlers' goods, to the exclusion of articles needed by the men, which were sold at exorbitant prices. This statement will at once appear incorrect, when it is remembered that no sutler is allowed to sell anything to the seamen or marines, and the goods which he has in charge is exclusively intended for officers.
lead_paragraph: Wehave ascertained on good authority that the statement which appeared in several papers, that the Santec and other vessels of the blockading squadron off Galveston, were not supplied properly with fresh provisions, is totally unfounded. It was also reported that the supply streamers have been loaded with sutlers' goods, to the exclusion of articles needed by the men, which were sold at exorbitant prices. This statement will at once appear incorrect, when it is remembered that no sutler is allowed to sell anything to the seamen or marines, and the goods which he has in charge is exclusively intended for officers.

abstract: Editorial notes all Union victories are in cooler months while Confederates are more successful in summer; sees brighter prospects in coming fall and winter
snippet: Editorial notes all Union victories are in cooler months while Confederates are more successful in summer; sees brighter prospects in coming fall and winter
lead_paragraph: About a month ago, we gave an article from a Richmond paper which argued that in this war the rebels had achieved all their principal successes in the Summer months, and urged the Southern military leaders to push on the campaign everywhere while the hot weather lasted. Per contra, it argued that the Unionists had gained all their victories in the Winter months, and that our armies were best adapted to action during the cold term. In proof of the first proposition, Bull Run and Wilson's Creek last Summer, and the battles in the Shenandoah Valley and on the Peninsula this Summer, furnished evidence; while the score of great victories that glorified our arms last Winter and Spring, from Mill Spring down to the time of the destruction of BEAUREGARD's army and the capture of New-Orleans, gave proof that our fortunate months were those in which the mercury in the thermometer was low. The war has not lasted long enough yet, and we hope it will not last long enough, to establish a fixed principle upon these facts. But it seemed plausible enough to suit a rebel's logic.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic mass meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall last evening, and organized by the appointment of Aldermen MAIRES, President of the Common Council, Chairman. Eloquent addresses ...
lead_paragraph: A large and enthusiastic mass meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall last evening, and organized by the appointment of Aldermen MAIRES, President of the Common Council, Chairman. Eloquent addresses were delivered by Gen. Walbridge, Gen. Sickles, Judge Whiting, Charles H. Winfield, of Jersey City, Col. Farnum, H.F. Perkens, and Conrad Swackhammer. During the remarks of Judge WHITING, Col. FARNUM took exceptions to a portion of his speech, and, interrupting him, threatened him with arrest for treason. The audience dividing in favor of the two speakers, considerable disturbance ensued, and at one time a row seemed imminent. The difficulty, however, was soon quieted and the speakers proceeded. Several hundred persons were present. No doubt the obtaining of many recruits will be the result.

abstract: As compared with other portions of the State, recruiting is dull in Brooklyn at this time. No public meeting has been held to raise money and encourage recruiting, and, according to present appearances, the deficiency to be made up by drafting will be a large one unless the 15,000 men already sent to the war from the city are considered when the order for drafting is made out.
lead_paragraph: As compared with other portions of the State, recruiting is dull in Brooklyn at this time. No public meeting has been held to raise money and encourage recruiting, and, according to present appearances, the deficiency to be made up by drafting will be a large one unless the 15,000 men already sent to the war from the city are considered when the order for drafting is made out. Kings County has sent twice as many men to the war in proportion to the population as any other county in the State, excepting only New-York. The quota for Suffolk County under the drafting order will be about 1,085, but as only a few men have heretofore volunteered in that county, it is supposed that she will be called upon under the draft for 2,000 men. Queens County has been much more patriotic than Suffolk, the little village of Flushing alone having furnished 325 men.

abstract: C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, made a speech, at Dayton, in which he held that the rebellion was the sole work of the "Abolitionists;" that it never could be suppressed by arms; and that the debt we were incurring in the war would crush the nation.
lead_paragraph: C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, made a speech, at Dayton, in which he held that the rebellion was the sole work of the "Abolitionists;" that it never could be suppressed by arms; and that the debt we were incurring in the war would crush the nation. In all of his proposition and arguments he held a tone very unfriendly to the Government in power, invoked the people to turn them out and put other men in office, and advised all men who preferred to stay at borne and "suppress Abolitionism" to do so. Upon this record the Tribune demanded why VALLANDIGHAM should not be made to speak hereafter "behind prison bars."

abstract: -GEORGE GILLINSand FRANK KREILER were arrested in the Ninth Ward, yesterday, by Officer LEICH, for attempting to escape from the county to avoid being drafted. They were taken before Superintendent KENNEDY, when GILLINS was duly enlisted and KREILER promises to do so. Officer BYRNES, of the Forty-third Precinct, yesterday arrested a fellow named FRANCIS RILEY, at the foot of Harrison-street, who was railing against the Government in the presence of an admiring crowd, He hoped "that every man who went to fight against the South would get shot." and said "that if any man came to draft him he would shoot him." RILEY represents a numerous class in this city, but does not exercise so much discretion as many others. He was taken before the Provost Marshal.

abstract: Conscience may become so blunted in a city like New-York, that internal views of our own case might develop sometimes certain belongings which we loudly condemn in others. Who stops to consider the over-taxed muscles of the jaded stage or carhorse, when he is in a hurry to get up town to wife ...
lead_paragraph: Conscience may become so blunted in a city like New-York, that internal views of our own case might develop sometimes certain belongings which we loudly condemn in others. Who stops to consider the over-taxed muscles of the jaded stage or carhorse, when he is in a hurry to get up town to wife and the babies, and the cheerful home circle? Yet, he turns with disgust, and blames without reserve the teamster who goads with whip and curse his over-loaded beast. The humane, law providing against cruelty to animals, surely should be broad enough to make a limit to the carrying capacity of omnibuses and horse-cars. Passing over the many shocking sights one necessarily meets with in traversing our great thoroughfares of commerce, where bone and muscle must needs be used and abused with unfeeling indifference, we come to a stand-point beyond which indifference becomes a sin. The meat we eat is something which nearly concerns us.

abstract: -- Gen. POPE's official report of the engagement of last Saturday is as neat and lucid a military document as we have yet had. It clears up many of the difficulties and contradictions that hung around the first authorized telegraphic account of the affair. The object and the plan of operations, and the substantial victory that resulted from them, are stated in such a way that neither note nor emendation is required. The only point that is somewhat obscure is the failure of Gen. POPE to have the withheld regiments of Gen. MCDOWELL's column, and the column of Gen. SIGEL, within supporting distance before the battle was accepted. It would seem that Gen. BANKS was too eager to open the action. It appears that it was really POPE's intention to have all his different corps massed as soon as possible. The issue of the battle, however, it is evident, was very much more favorable to us than appeared on Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. POPE's official report of the engagement of last Saturday is as neat and lucid a military document as we have yet had. abstract: Applications continue to be made at the United States Marshal's office for passes to go to this and that place. To save further annoyance of this kind, the Marshal desires a repetition of the information, which has already been repeatedly published, that no passes are required for traveling to any part of the United States with the exception of California. Beyond these limits, which are large enough to satisfy any reasonable traveler, a passport will be required; if the applicant is a foreigner it can be obtained from the British Consul, and will be vised by the United States Marshal to establish the fact whether the applicant is a citizen or not. A declaration of intention to become a citizen, even though the person has not been naturalized, will prevent his leaving the country. About thirty passports, issued by the British Consul, were vised by the Marshal yesterday. It may be of interest to state that the Consul, yesterday, raised the price of passports from $2 to $3.

abstract: On Thursday morning the enemy crossed the Rapidan at Barnett's Ford, in heavy force, and advanced strong on the road to Culpepper and Madison Court-house. I had established my whole force on the turnpike between Culpepper and Sperryville, ready to concentrate at either place, as soon as the enemy's plans were developed.

abstract: The President yesterday gave audience at the White House to a Committee of colored men, for the discussion of the matter of colonization, as proposed by the last Congress.
lead_paragraph: The President yesterday gave audience at the White House to a Committee of colored men, for the discussion of the matter of colonization, as proposed by the last Congress. Mr. LINCOLN made a speech of length, in which he urged colonization as the best thing for the colored race, and stated that a place in Central America had been decided upon for the experiment. He asked the delegation to give the matter thorough consideration, and to give him an answer at their pleasure. They promised to do so, and then retired.

abstract: An immense war meeting was held in Cincinnati, of which you have the particulars. Nay, any such thing is literally impossible.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury publishes the official correspondence "between Gov. PICKENS and Gen. JENKINS (late Colonel of the Palmetto Sharpshooters) in relation to the flag of the Sixteenth Michigan Regiment, captured in the battle of Gaines' Mills, in ...
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury publishes the official correspondence "between Gov. PICKENS and Gen. JENKINS (late Colonel of the Palmetto Sharpshooters) in relation to the flag of the Sixteenth Michigan Regiment, captured in the battle of Gaines' Mills, in which the Yankee regiment was nearly annilated by the withering fire of our expert riflemen. The flag is of blue silk, six feet by four, with a gold fringe, and mounnted on a staff which has lost its spear head in the fight. One side exhibits the Goddess of Liberty and the inscription: 'Stand by the Constitution and the Union;' the other shows the State Arms of Michigan and the name, 'Stockton's Regiment.'"

abstract: We have definite news this morning, from our correspondents with the Army of the Potomac, of the entire withdrawal of Gen. McCLELLAN'S army from its recent camp at Harrison's Landing.
lead_paragraph: We have definite news this morning, from our correspondents with the Army of the Potomac, of the entire withdrawal of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army from its recent camp at Harrison's Landing. At the time our letters were written, the evacuation was in full progress; and as the time has elapsed within which the first march was to be accomplished, from the late camp to the vicinity of Williamsburgh, and as no news has been had up to the moment of the present writing of any interference with Gen. MCCLELLAN's movement on the part of the enemy, we may assume that it has been entirely successful, and that all possibility of hostile injury to that still great army, isolated and ineffectual where it was, is at an end.

abstract: Our enemies have listed the last of those among them who were willing to fight us for the love of it. At first they all supposed that it would be a short and easy task to conquer us; and there was accordingly a considerable rush of volunteers for the "glory" thus cheaply to be obtained.

abstract: The sanitary steamer and transport Daniel Webster, Capt. BLETHEN, arrived here this evening, bringing a large company of nurses, and a cargo of 2,000 barrels of potatoes and onions. The soldiers will welcome her with tears in their eyes.

abstract: Lieut. C.H. GREENE, of the Crusader, which arrived here from Port Royal yesterday, brought under his charge twenty-four persons, composing the crew of the prize steamer Ladona, which was sent to Philadelphia. The arrival of the prisoners was reported to the United States Marshal, who will take them from the Crusader this morning and forward them to Philadelphia.

abstract: -- DANIEL CUNNINGHAM, a well-known "sport" of this City, went yesterday with a female friend into TAYLOR's saloon, on Broadway, for the purpose of ordering some refreshments. While quietly seated at a table, a pistol fell from one of CUNNINGHAM's pockets and exploded, the contents entering the woman's arm and badly lacerating it. Consternation seized all in the saloon, but as it was an evident accident no arrest was made. A physician was called, the wound was dressed, and the crowd dispersed.
lead_paragraph: -- DANIEL CUNNINGHAM, a well-known "sport" of this City, went yesterday with a female friend into TAYLOR's saloon, on Broadway, for the purpose of ordering some refreshments. While quietly seated at a table, a pistol fell from one of CUNNINGHAM's pockets and exploded, the contents entering the woman's arm and badly lacerating it. Consternation seized all in the saloon, but as it was an evident accident no arrest was made. A physician was called, the wound was dressed, and the crowd dispersed.

abstract: -- Twenty-five citizens of Manchester, N.H., set all from  Portsmouth on Monday [???], in a yacth, intending to have a fighting excursion on the Coast of Maine. Some of them [???] who could not go with them, [???] have a [???] at to [???] by telegraphed to the United States authorities at [???] for a [???] about leaving that [???]. As the yatch was [???] merely [???] McCleary, it was brought to [???] a shot across its bows, and a boat, with an armed crew, put out and brought the whole party ashore. For a time there was any amount of sweating, although the oath of allegiance was not taken, and several of the gentlemen became so obstreperous at the suspicious cast upon their loyalty, that it was found necessary to order them under close confinement. The champagne bottles had to suffer when the joke was explained, but the officers of the fort would not release their prisoners until they had furnished $1,000 bonds for their appearance.

abstract: The United States vs. Steamer Memphis. -- An order having been made to show cause why a previous order should not be set aside, granting the Captain of the prize steamer Memphis permission to remove certain articles, claimed as his personal effects, from the steamer (a report of which appeared in yesterday's [???]. abstract: Effectiveness of "dead letter" office discussed
snippet: Effectiveness of "dead letter" office discussed
lead_paragraph: From the very satisfactory report which appeared yesterday in our columns, as to the first half-year's operation of the new postal law of Jan. 21 relative to dead letters, it will be seen that the predictions of the advocates of the measure have been fully realized. The additional postage of six cents charged on the letters when returned to the writers has not only paid all the salaries of the clerks employed in this special work, with the extra commission of fifty per cent. to the respective Postmasters, but has left a net profit to the National revenue of $1,991 on the half year.
headline: {'main': 'The Dead-Letter Office.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Dead-Letter Office.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In conformity with an elaborate programme, the Academy of Music was beautifully decorated with flowers, gaily hung with flags and banners, and mythologically adorned with busts, statues and statuettes. The advertisement promised a feast of fat things in the floral, theatrical, poetical and musical veins, the proceeds pecuniary of which were to be given to the Union Home and School at the corner of Seventy-fifth-street and Eleventh-avenue, where the children of our dead soldiers are tutored and maintained. A very fair audience gathered to witness the performances, which being almost entirely unprofessional, were interesting and instructive to the old and young.
lead_paragraph: In conformity with an elaborate programme, the Academy of Music was beautifully decorated with flowers, gaily hung with flags and banners, and mythologically adorned with busts, statues and statuettes. A very fair audience gathered to witness the performances, which being almost entirely unprofessional, were interesting and instructive to the old and young.

abstract: The engineer of a rope-walk in this City was arrested yesterday, for putting a greater head of steam on the engine connected with the establishment than allowed by law. Had he been let alone, it is confidently believed that reporters would have had a first-class explosion to record at an early day, with the usual concomitants -- loss of life and property.
lead_paragraph: The engineer of a rope-walk in this City was arrested yesterday, for putting a greater head of steam on the engine connected with the establishment than allowed by law. abstract: Capt. WM. abstract: Adjutant-General HILLHOUSE has issued a General Order, which will be found in the TIMES of to-day, giving detailed directions for the work preliminary to drafting the quota of men required from our State.
lead_paragraph: Adjutant-General HILLHOUSE has issued a General Order, which will be found in the TIMES of to-day, giving detailed directions for the work preliminary to drafting the quota of men required from our State. The quota called for from New-York is an aggregate of 120,000 -- 60,000 under the call of July 2, for 300,000 volunteers, and 60,000 under the order of Aug. 4, for a draft of 300,000.

abstract: The Columbia, S.C., Carolinian publishes a long account of Col. BLANTON DUNCAN's lithography establishment. It contains twenty-foar presses at present, and six others are shortly expected from Paris. The workmen have been imported as well as the machinery, and it is expected that soon the establishment will be able to turn out 200,000 notes of various denominations daily. Then the financial affairs of the Confederate Government will progress swimmingly.

lead_paragraph: Another important order has been issued by the War Department in relation to the coming draft, which will positively commence on the 1st of September. abstract: NEW-ORLEANS. -- Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON arrived in Washington the evening before last. He left New-Orleans on the 30th ultimo, in the transport steamship Connecticut, Lieut.-Commanding BARTON, and was landed at Fortress Monroe on the 9th inst. Judge ROSELLIUS, of New-Orleans; Dr. COTTMAN, formerly of Maryland, and Mr. CUTHBERT BULLITT were also passengers in the Connecticut.

abstract: The ad  vices we published yesterday from Stockholm, showing the demand now springing up in Northern Europe for American provisions, is one of the numerous indications which are ...
lead_paragraph: -- The advices we published yesterday from Stockholm, showing the demand now springing up in Northern Europe for American provisions, is one of the numerous indications which are multiplying every day as to the designs of Providence that this country should be to the European nations of the nineteenth century what the rich fertile fields of Sicily were to the Roman empire under the Caesars -- an exhaustless granary and a perennial source of food of every kind, to be depended on though all supplies besides should fail.

abstract: -- It seems hard for our people to unlearn one of the bad habits which our political system has created -- we mean the assumption that they have a right to force men who fill high places to speechify, nolens volens, on every possible opportunity. It was certainly pushed to the ultimate reach of impudence when Admiral FOOTE was yesterday dragged from a railroad car to gratify the curiosity of a well-meaning but inconsiderate crowd. The gallant sailor is still on crutches from the effect of his wound at Fort Donelson, and has surely a right to undisturbed transit. We have been so accustomed, hitherto, to feel that any one for the time being in the public eye was bound to speak whenever called for, that we forget that times and circumstances are now very different. Let there be some dignity, some delicacy, some consideration in this matter.
lead_paragraph: -- It seems hard for our people to unlearn one of the bad habits which our political system has created -- we mean the assumption that they have a right to force men who fill high places to speechify, nolens volens, on every possible opportunity. abstract: Still another reform of considerable importance has been commenced in the United States navy. The era of non-clads and steamers having rendered obsolete the old sailing vessels, the latter will not be used ...
lead_paragraph: Still another reform of considerable importance has been commenced in the United States navy. The era of non-clads and steamers having rendered obsolete the old sailing vessels, the latter will not be used in this country again in any active capacity worth speaking of. Certain descriptions of transports, schoolships, receiving ships and "guardos" are henceforward to be exclusively sailing craft, the steamers being required for quick movements. Fifteen months ago we had forty sail above and including the rank of corvettes on the Naval Register, all propelled by canvas. The following are now the only sailing vessels of the regular navy employed cruising:

abstract: On Thursday, some four hundred children from the various Catholic institutions of this City gave Archbishop HUGHES a serenade at his residence, on the corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-sixth street.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, some four hundred children from the various Catholic institutions of this City gave Archbishop HUGHES a serenade at his residence, on the corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-sixth street. The children were dressed in neat Summer costume, and one of their number, PETER GILLESPIE by name, read a salutatory address, to which the Archbishop responded in a manner that showed he was sensible of the affection of the little ones. The Archbishop's party consisted of Archbishop PURCELL, of Cincinnati; Archbishop CONNOLLY, of Halifax and Very Reverend WM. STARRS, Vicar-General and Rev. WALTER QUARTERS.

lead_paragraph: to a great extent to dictate terms to capital, Instead of the bloody bread riots, the assaults upon banks and the general distress of working men, which was [???] confidently predicted as the result of the war, we [???] that in both agricultural and mechanical industry, the employes are well paid, and there is room for more; that farm hands never commanded better pay, and that in this City at least a number of strikes in the iron works have resulted in procuring increased remuneration for labor -- an increase in many cases amounting to twenty per cent., and more than compensating for any depreciation of paper currency. There seems to be every probability that those who escape the draft will from this appreciation of wages, be well able to bear the pecuniary burdens which the vigorous prosecution of the war may impose upon them. There can be no doubt that the subtraction of so many working men by the vast body of volunteers which this City has furnished, has damaged business, but the evil has been to a great extent remedied by the wonderful adaptability of our people to varied employments. If a man found he could not make a living by making ladies' shoes, he soon learned to make army shoes; If he found the manufacture of spectacles decreased, he could apply his knowledge of the use of tools and machinery to the construction of arms; workers in leather soon learned to make army equipments, and builders of looms and printing-presses found little trouble in applying their skill to the creation of iron-clad gunboats.

abstract: We stated yesterday the fact that Secretary SEWARD proposed to raise fifteen volunteers by the State Department, as its quota. A little incident, which occurred yesterday, still further illustrates Secretary SEWARD's patriotism. During the morning he sent a note to Capt. HARROVER, (who is engaged in recruiting District soldiers,) requesting him to send to his office eight recruits. They were sent, and as soon as they appeared before the Secretary, he handed one of them a neat little package, upon which they retired and opened the mysterious envelope, when, to their surprise, they discovered a fifty-dollar Treasury note for each one of them. -- Washington Star, 15th.
lead_paragraph: We stated yesterday the fact that Secretary SEWARD proposed to raise fifteen volunteers by the State Department, as its quota. abstract: -- A POPULAR FALLACY REMOVED. -- Gen. SICKLES, in his speech in Brooklyn, last evening, took occasion to sweep away a fallacy which he finds possessing the minds of laboring men of the North, especially those of foreign birth, and which he regards as one serious obstacle to enlistments. It seems that it is a current belief with them that the war will ultimately end in emancipation, or at least in the liberation of so many blacks that they will crowd our Northern cities, and, by glutting the market with thews and sinews, greatly lower the demand for and value of the labor of our white working population. They are loath to help on such a result. In rebutting this notion, Gen. SICKLES did not think it necessary to touch on that cure of the anticipated evil which the President so strongly favors -- namely, the deportation of the Blacks -- and which he but a day or two since presented with renewed earnestness to the deputation of colored men that waited on him. Even if not a negro should be taken out of the country, Gen. SICKLES sees that there are inherent laws, climatic and economical, that would effectually forever prevent the Northern immigration of the freed negroes. Indeed, so great would be the demand for labor, under the combined influence of free production and the increasing demand for the Southern staples, that it would not only absorb all the blacks at the South, but draw to itself all those now in the Northern States. Negroes naturally prefer the climate of the South; they are here only to escape from Slavery, and would seek the South by choice if they could find freedom there. Nothing could be more cogent or more just than this position, and we are glad Gen. SICKLES has presented it to his audience with such lucidity and force.

abstract: Editorial on number of men needed to meet draft quotas
snippet: Editorial on number of men needed to meet draft quotas
lead_paragraph: The series of orders from the War Department, which we published yesterday, contains one clause of the highest importance. It provides that, if the old regiments shall not be filled up with volunteers before the 1st of September, a special draft will be ordered for the deficiency. This draft, therefore, will be in addition to the draft to supply the deficiency (if there shall be any) in the levy of 300,000 volunteers, and in addition to the draft for 300,000.

abstract: Somewhere in the neighborhood of 300 recruits were yesterday mustered in at the White-street office for refriments now in the field. This is about the daily average for the past week. The process, as new performed, appeals to be needlessly elaborate and tedious and might easily be amended. Especially tiresome is the number of signatures required from each individual volunteer. Every paper must be signed in duplicate, triplicate or quadruplicate until the patience of both recruit and recruiting-officer is fairly exhausted -- aggravatingly so when the former has received but [???] instruction in the mysteries of caligraphic art. The payment of bounties has been greatly facilitated by the abolition of checks. The recruit now receives his cash on the spot after attaching his name to the receipts. In one week nearly $31,000 has been disbursed in payment of the Untied States bounties alone.

abstract: The steamship Glasgow, which passed Cape Race yesterday, brings advices from Europe four days later to the 7th inst. The news is important. Parliament was prorogued on the 7th, and the Queen, in her speech on the occasion, declared ...
lead_paragraph: that she had seen no occasion to depart from the neutrality, with regard to affairs in this country, which she had steadily adhered to. The secession sympathizers in Parliament had made an effort to call out the correspondence between the rebel Commissioner MASON and the Government, but had failed. Earl RUSSELL declared, however, In the course of the discussion, that the rebel agent had not been recognized -- all communications being unofficial. Great attention had been attracted by events transpiring in Italy. GARIBALDI had issued a revolutionary proclamation, which had been followed by a counter proclamation from VICTOR EMANUEL. Another small advance had taken place in the Liverpool cotton market. Breadstuffs were declining, and provisions were dull. Consols were quotd at 93 1/2@5/8.

abstract: A serious collision occurred on last Friday morning, on the Alabama and Florida Railroad, below Greenville, by which two were killed and 42 wounded, three of whom have since died. On the same day a collision occurred on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, above Enterprise, Miss.; damage not known; and, on Monday, another collision took place on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, above Citronville, Ala. The last was very serious, one train running into the rear end of another, cutting in two a car filled with soldiers, a number of whom were killed and wounded.

abstract: -- This influential body met last evening at 8 o'clock, at the Steuben House, on the Bowery, Mr. ANDREAS WILLMAN in the Chair, and Mr. HENRY RICHARD, acting Secretary. The object of the meeting was to take council concerning the method of representing the Committee in the central State Committee, at its next session. A number of drafts of resolutions etc., were proposed, but as only ten Wards were represented in the meeting, no decisive action was had. The Committee, however protracted his billings until a late hour.

abstract: Yesterday morning about 8 o'clock, the Thirtythird Regiment Massachusetts State Volunteers, under command of Col. ALBERT C. MAGGI, arrived at Jersey City on board the Sound steamer of the ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning about 8 o'clock, the Thirtythird Regiment Massachusetts State Volunteers, under command of Col. ALBERT C. MAGGI, arrived at Jersey City on board the Sound steamer of the Stonington line, Plymouth Rock. A large concourse of people lined the decks, and as the regiment disembarked to take the Philadelphia cars, the air shook with the cheers of the throng. The regiment is one of the finest in the service, and although it has been raised and organized within a very few weeks, is already a model of discipline and drill, as well as of equipment. Its headquarters was at Camp Stanton, near Lynnfield, in the Old Bay State. The Colonel of the regiment is an Italian by birth, and served for some sixteen years in the army of Sardinia. He also claims to have accompanied and fought side by side with the patriot GARIRALDI in his South American campaigns. Having rapidly acquired here the reputation of an accomplished soldier, Col. MAGGI has found little difficulty in recruiting his regiment up to the Government standard, and he now again takes the field to renew the honors he so gallantly won as Lieutenant-Colonel of the Twenty-first Massachusetts Volunteers at the storming and capture of the rebel defences on Roanoke Island. The position he held in the Twenty-first Col. MAGGI attained by sheer merit, rising from the ranks almost at a stride. The soldiers of the Thirty-third were uniformed in the regular army suit, and armed with the Enfield rifle and fluted bayonet.

abstract: A letter was going  the rounds of the Northern papers, a few days since, purporting to have been written by Hon. GEORGE E. BADGER, of North Carolina, to a gentleman of New-York, in which the author set forth, with much earnestness, the ...
lead_paragraph: -- A letter was going the rounds of the Northern papers, a few days since, purporting to have been written by Hon. GEORGE E. BADGER, of North Carolina, to a gentleman of New-York, in which the author set forth, with much earnestness, the fact of the entire unanimity of public sentiment in the old North State against a return to the Union. The struggle for the suppression of the rebellion was pronounced hopeless, and the people of the Northern States were urged to stop a vain and fruitless war.

abstract: The match between the St. George's Club and the Queens County Club, strengthened by many of the best cricketers from other clubs, and different parts ...
lead_paragraph: The match between the St. George's Club and the Queens County Club, strengthened by many of the best cricketers from other clubs, and different parts of the country, was commenced on Wednesday on the ground of the St. George's Club, Elysian Fields, Hoboken. St. George sent Mr. WALLER and HARRY WRIGHT to the bat, against the finest bowling and fielding which has been seen in any match for a long time, and before they were parted, Mr. WALLER had scored fifteen, by some very pretty play. 3 3s and a 2 being among his figures. Messrs. CONGREVE and WALKER in turn retired, and Mr. GIBBES succeeded, and before he and HARRY WRIGHT parted company, HARRY had placed 70 on the telegraph by good cricket to all parts of the field, in which was a splendid drive for 6, a 5, 2 4s. 7 3s, and 3 2s; his brother -- young GEORGE WRIGHT -- succeeded, and entirely disappointed the hopes and expectations of all but the opposing side, as he was caught at square leg from a "slow," it being a very fine hit. Mr. GIBBES having previously retired, after placing 45 on the bulletin, by his usual fine display of cricket; his figures being 4 4s, 2 3s, and 5 2s. After Mr. CURRIE had joined Mr. GIBBES, fine play continued to be the order of the day, until the latter retired. A slow in the same over that dismissed GEORGE WEIGHT tempted out of his ground a fine cricketer, from whom much was expected -- Mr. NEWMAN, who fell as hemade the [???] and he was [???] could get back again; Mr. [???] five were well got, and Mr. CURRIE at length retired for a cautious and scientific total of 27, in which were 3 3s and 5 2s, and Capt. LAING was joined by Mr. KENDALL, [???] before the latter lost his wicket made a spirited innings of 14, in which were a 4 and three 2s; he carried his bat out. To briefly sum up the result, it may be said that the bowling and fielding of HOLLEY, from Oswego, who came with HAMPSHIRE to New-York to play in this match, was first rate, as was that of HAMMOND, SUYDAM and SADLER. HAMMOND's fielding was very fine; STACEY's long-stopping was remarkably good, considering he had dislocated a finger early in the match. After a substantial dinner had been done justice to by a large party of the cricketers and their friends, Queens County sent HAMPSHIRE and HUDSON to the wickets, neither of them doing anything: Mr. HALL and BYRON got together and made a stand for a short time, when the former retired and HAMMOND showed some fine play, and in company with SADLER, were not out when the stamps were drawn: BYRON having been caught in splendid style by GEORGE WRIGHT, from a slashing hit to long on, his figures being a 3, 4 2s and 3 1s got by spirited play.

abstract: The City was in no little perplexity yesterday in regard to the present position and proposed movements of the Army of the Potomac. On the one hand we had the concurrent outgivings of all the army correspondents for several days past that a grand movement was about to take place, and the unmistakable ...
lead_paragraph: The City was in no little perplexity yesterday in regard to the present position and proposed movements of the Army of the Potomac. On the one hand we had the concurrent outgivings of all the army correspondents for several days past that a grand movement was about to take place, and the unmistakable intimations of two or three that the movement was to be a retrograde one. In corroboration, we had the circumstantial account of the actual transfer of a large part of the men, material and munitions of war to other and better positions, and of the readiness of Gen. MCCLELLAN to execute the last part of his programme in the evacuation of Harrison's Landing.

abstract: The Confederates in the southwest now and then have spasms of honesty come over them which It is almost painful to witness. The Memphis Bulletin thus details the experiences of one Mr. Greenwald, a ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Confederates in the southwest now and then have spasms of honesty come over them which It is almost painful to witness. The Memphis Bulletin thus details the experiences of one Mr. Greenwald, a dry-goods merchant or that city, who was captured by the guerrillas when they made their raid upon Brownsville. It says: "Mr. Greenwald states that when taken he was suffering from sickness. On stating this fact to the commander of the expedition. Capt. Faulkner, a wagon and hay to he upon was procured for him, and a blanket laid over him. Each night of the march a bed was procured for him in some house. On the Thursday following his capture, they reached Senatobia in Mississippi, which he was taken before Jeff. Thompson, who treated him politely, and directed him to be taken to Gen. Villipegue at Abbeville, beyond Holly Springs. On arriving, the General examined the case, and also the cases of Mr. French, of Denmark, and Mr. Ware, of Kentucky, who were arrested along with Mr. Greenwald. He decided in each case that the parties had not been guilty of selling cotton to 'the enemy,' and that their money should be restored to them and themselves set free. Mr. Greenwald's money, amounting to $2,610 in gold and silver, and $5,000 in other money, was returned to him, and he was allowed to return home. It had been reported to Mr. Greenwald's friends that he was handcuffed and harshly treated; he states that on the contrary he was treated with kindness and courtesy during the whole of his captivity."
headline: {'main': 'PERSONAL.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'PERSONAL.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. TRAIN is probablythe best living example of our old style of stamp speakers. Dashing, defiant, rapid, full of power, full of spread-eagleism, and of a kind of eloquence always popular in this young country, he cares little what he says so that it reach and stir up the hearts of his hearers. His recent series of speeches in London on American topics, delivered before large popular audiences, and published far and wide, have not only exhibited "Young America" to old John Bull, but have brought our side of public questions before thousands of Englishmen who had no other means of information but the mendacious journals of London. He has his speeches reported and corrected, and sends them over for publication in his native town of Boston. His latest effort, we learn, is by far his greatest, and scathes Mr. Bull in a fearful style. It is on the "Downfall of England," and will be issued in the number of the Commercial Bulletin which appears, this morning, and which can be had in this City, as per advertisement in another column.

abstract: The weighty question of England's relations with America, which has claimed so much attention from Parliament while in session, ...
lead_paragraph: The weighty question of England's relations with America, which has claimed so much attention from Parliament while in session, vindicated its momentous importance by filling the closing hours of that Body. The Queen's Prorogation Speech set the seal to all the official declarations of British policy that have been made in Parliament, by the announcement that "Her Majesty, having from the outset determined to take no part in the contest, hns seen no reason to depart from the neutrality which she has steadily adhered to."

abstract: Union reported defeated in battle near Cumberland Gap
snippet: Union reported defeated in battle near Cumberland Gap
lead_paragraph: -- Chicago sent us a first-rate sensation dispatch yesterday. It was the announcement of a severe battle at Tazewell, near Cumberland Gap, East Tennessee, in which the rebels, numbering twelve to fourteen thousand, under Gens. STEVENSON and BARTON, had surrounded and routed the National forces and thereby regained possession of East Tennessee. From these auspicious premises, the Southern correspondent of the Chicago Press did not fail to deduce the natural and logical sequence, the early annihilation of Gen. BUELL, and the the grand smash generally of Union things in Tennessee.

abstract: The Tri  bune must answer our question about WENDELL PHILLIPS fairly and squarely, or confess that it lacks courage and candor to do so. We dismiss again, as we did yesterday in the must positive terms, the Tribune's statement ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune must answer our question about WENDELL PHILLIPS fairly and squarely, or confess that it lacks courage and candor to do so. We dismiss again, as we did yesterday in the must positive terms, the Tribune's statement that we have called on it for any "comparison" of the moral or legal guilt of VALLANDIGHAM and PHILLIPS. Perhaps we can agree wholly with the Tribune in making one an angel of light as compared to the other. But what we demand of the Tribune is the absolute, not the comparative, relation of PHILLIPS to the Government.

abstract: Some days ago, says the Macon Telegraph, the citizens of Lee County held a public meeting in reference to negro impressment, at which they appointed Mr. C.M. IRVIN to correspond with the War Department ...
lead_paragraph: Some days ago, says the Macon Telegraph, the citizens of Lee County held a public meeting in reference to negro impressment, at which they appointed Mr. C.M. IRVIN to correspond with the War Department by telegraph, and ascertain it the impressment had been authorized and required by the Secretary of War. If it had, they resolved, like good citizens, to acquiesce in the requisition; if not, they determined not to surrender their negroes. In pursuance of his mission, Mr. IRVIN came to Macon, and the correspondence ensued which is published below: To the Secretary of War, Richmond, Va.:

abstract: GRAND CONCERT FOR THE SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDIERS. -- The Williamsburgh Saengerbund, assisted by over twenty different Societies, will give a grand concert and pic-nic to-morrow (Monday) at Myrtle-avenue Park, for for the benefit of our sick and wounded soldiers. As the entire proceeds will be devoted to that object, it is hoped that the American citizens of Williamsburgh will take as much increased in it as the Germans, who have made the greatest preparations. The admission will only be 12 cents. The  grand concert will tale place in the afternoon.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. Strong, formerly a well-known merchant of this City, and who, for several months, has been in command at Cairo, is in this City on a leave of absence of two months. A correspondence is published in the Cairo City Gazette, between the Mayor and citizens on the one part and Gen. Strong on the other.
lead_paragraph: -- Brig.-Gen. Strong, formerly a well-known merchant of this City, and who, for several months, has been in command at Cairo, is in this City on a leave of absence of two months. A correspondence is published in the Cairo City Gazette, between the Mayor and citizens on the one part and Gen. Strong on the other. They thank him for the manner in which he has conducted affairs; pronounce his administration patriotic and just, and his conduct soldierly-like and gentlemanly. Another letter from his officers also compliments his management. Gen. Strong replies that he has labored to discharge his duties faithfully, and is grateful at their approval, as well as at the support from their public authorities and the cooperation of the citizens, which he had cordially received.

abstract: The exact value to be attached to the latent Union sentiment of the South is one of those problems on which experience throws singularly little light.
lead_paragraph: The exact value to be attached to the latent Union sentiment of the South is one of those problems on which experience throws singularly little light. If it were a purely abstract inquiry, it might be permitted to go without an effort at solution. Unhappily it is of all puzzles one of the utmost practical moment; for upon it depends the entire action of the National Government; and consequences of the direst moment to the future of the whole country, and to each of the conflicting sections, rest upon the determination. If there be really an appreciable loyal sentiment in the rebel States, it may be the duty of the Administration to advance always with words of conciliation upon its lips; to appeal to the repressed Unionists that they join the National armies and give fighting evidences of fidelity; and to discriminate jealously against any compulsory employment of the negroes and other property of Union men, when subsisting our forces upon the enemy. The entire range of relations between the Government and the people of the rebel states, is materially affected by the existence or non-existence of any considerable amount of loyalty among them.
headline: {'main': 'Unionism an Unknown Quantity in the Southern Problem.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Unionism an Unknown Quantity in the Southern Problem.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial urges using men of genius in all depts. of military rather than settling for mediocrity as is common in politics
snippet: Editorial urges using men of genius in all depts. of military rather than settling for mediocrity as is common in politics
lead_paragraph: It is the standing reproach of a democratic society that it is the purgatory of genius and the paradise of mediocrity. With ourselves it has become notorious that when a man is so unfortunate as to exhibit uncommon abilities, he usually renders himself ineligible for political honors or distinctions. It would seem that the community is possessed with that groveling quality of a sordid mind which hates superiority, and would ostracize genius, as the Athenians did ARISTIDES. One might believe it would not be unpleasing to the popular taste if some enterprising person could invent a machine for stunting intellectual development, after the fashion of idiotic barbarians who flatten the heads of their children. The masses of the community certainly appear to believe that political equality implies not only social, but should also imply intellectual equality, under pain of being severely frowned down by an outraged public opinion.
headline: {'main': 'The Worship of Mediocrity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Worship of Mediocrity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: JOHN SMITH, a slave, came into Court and asked for his free papers on the ground that his mistress, MARGARET HAUGHERY, has told him to go to the Yankees. His mistress, being present, made quite a different statement.
lead_paragraph: JOHN SMITH, a slave, came into Court and asked for his free papers on the ground that his mistress, MARGARET HAUGHERY, has told him to go to the Yankees. His mistress, being present, made quite a different statement. She said about the time the Federal troops arrived here. JOHN declared that now their time had come, that they could take up arms and use them to free themselves. She reprimanded him for using such language. She denied having told him to go to the Yankees. Upon hearing this, the Judge informed JOHN that he doubted his statement. The darkey replied: "Well, Judge, she told me if I went to Gen. BUTLER he would give me a rocking-chair and a fan." JOHN was sent to the police jail for one month.

abstract: One day's later advices from Europe have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon. She had Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The news is not specially important.
lead_paragraph: One day's later advices from Europe have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon. She had Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The news is not specially important. It was rumored that there was to be another Congress of European Sovereigns soon, at Cologne. The French newspapers were insisting on Rome being delivered to Italy. The statement is made that GARIBALDI has but about 850 followers with him -- all poorly armed. Rumor has fixed upon another King for Mexico, in the person of MURAT. This rumor was current at Madrid. Another battle had been fought between the Turks and the Montenegrins, the result of which both claimed as a victory. The later commercial intelligence by the Anglo-Saxon by way of Londonderry, has not yet come to hand.

abstract: Editorial sees war purifying atmosphere of luxury and extravagance that pervades Union; Editorial attacks falsehoods and stupidities of British press in reporting on war; Editorial sees strong Union feeling in parts of South; Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Editorial sees war purifying atmosphere of luxury and extravagance that pervades Union; Editorial attacks falsehoods and stupidities of British press in reporting on war; Editorial sees strong Union feeling in parts of South; Dispatches from Washi...
lead_paragraph: Consistency is a jewel which few European statesmen deign to wear in their coronets. A stranger to that Continent visiting the Old World, after acquiring some knowledge of its peoples and national characteristics, will assuredly expect to discover the jewel among those stolid islanders who pride themselves on the antiquity of their institutions, and whose political principles Lord PALMERSTON so well described in his anecdote of the two rival beer-house signs -- "The Old Hats," and the "Old Old Hats." Our traveler would strangely deceive himself. It is precisely in that country, of all others, that consistency is not to be found, and to such an extent has it been ignored or scouted, that its very opposite -- expediency -- has become a political virtue. Looking around the British forum, it is almost an impossibility to point out a statesman, or prominent politician, whose opinions on most questions have not changed since his entrance into public life; a change, too, be it understood, amounting not to a modification merely, but to an absolute and radical alteration. The Hon. Mr. STANLEY, leaping frantically upon the table of his Club, and threatening the House of Lords if the Reform bill were not permitted to become a law, and the Earl of DERBY, the leader of the Tory obstructives of Great Britain, appear at a distance like different individuals. The Earl, however, is merely an example of men of all parties, for we find politicians of the stamp of ROEBUCK radical in their youth, and not merely conservative, but actually pro-Austrian in their old age. We might run through the long list of English statesmen, and furnish our readers with a laughable record of such examples, the only exceptions being men of the Cobden stamp -- precisely those who wield the least influence on public affairs.
headline: {'main': 'English Consistency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'English Consistency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our attention was attracted the other day, at Messrs. BAIL, BRACK  Co.'s store in Broadway, to a  number of large books which are there on exhibition, and which upon inspection, we found to be a  Record of the Rebellion, by THOMAS S. TOWNSEND.
lead_paragraph: Our attention was attracted the other day, at Messrs. BAIL, BRACK Co.'s store in Broadway, to a number of large books which are there on exhibition, and which upon inspection, we found to be a Record of the Rebellion, by THOMAS S. TOWNSEND. The magnitude of the work induced us to examine it closely, and we were well repaid for our trouble. Although it is a work evidently of immense labor, yet it is nevertheless one of perfect simplicity. The volumes on exhibition contain the record for the year ending November, 1861, and comprise twenty-two volumes. These books embrace everything in the slightest degree pertaining to the rebellion that has appeared in the leading journals of the City, either as official, editorial, or as correspondence, foreign or domestic, during that year. With these is an Encyclopedia, in which is arranged, under its appropriate head, each subject, with a reference to the page and volume where the whole matter is to be found.
headline: {'main': 'A Chronicle of the Rebellion.; IMPORTANT AND INTERESTING DIGEST OF THE EVENTS OF THE WAR, WITH NOTICES HISTORICAL AND BIOGRAPHICAL, AND THE ENTIRE BODY OF DOCUMENTS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Chronicle of the Rebellion.; IMPORTANT AND INTERESTING DIGEST OF THE EVENTS OF THE WAR, WITH NOTICES HISTORICAL AND BIOGRAPHICAL, AND THE ENTIRE BODY OF DOCUMENTS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Postmaster-Gerneral BLAIR has caused to be written an official letter, as to who may and who may not take shelter under the broad wings of the Postoffice Department, as a legal excuse or cause of exemption from drafting.
lead_paragraph: Postmaster-Gerneral BLAIR has caused to be written an official letter, as to who may and who may not take shelter under the broad wings of the Postoffice Department, as a legal excuse or cause of exemption from drafting. It was written in answer to inquiries made at headquarters, by Special Agent HOLBROOK, which inquiries had become necessary owing to the very liberal construction of the laws claimed by certain classes having occasional and temporary custody of the mails, such as local and traveling baggage-masters, railroad conductors, railroad ticket agents, etc. Applications to postmasters, by this class of would-be officials, for certificates that they are employed in the mail service, have become very numerous.

abstract: -- The Secretary of War is always sensational. In a new batch of instructions just received here, officers recruiting for cavalry regiments are directed to receive no recruit who is not thoroughly versed in military horsemanship, and in the care of horses. As such experts can only be met with once in a twelvemonth, and as it would be necessary, in order to test them, to have a riding-school with half a dozen chargers at the command of the mustering officer, it is inferred that the Secretary, so far as mounted men are concerned, is disposed to join VALLANDIGHAM and PHILLIPS in discouraging enlistments. Of the regiments already in the service, the larger number of men are from the country, are practiced riders, and accustomed to the handling and treatment of horses. No better material than this is at the service of Government. If better be indispensable, cavalry must be dispensed with. Why should not skill in "military horsemanship" be also applied to officers of infantry; and if it were, how many, think you, would get their commissions? Upon the whole, the present restriction may reasonably be classed with that numerous category of Mr. STANTON's, orders -- those practically absurd, and promptly to be recalled.
lead_paragraph: -- The Secretary of War is always sensational. Of the regiments already in the service, the larger number of men are from the country, are practiced riders, and accustomed to the handling and treatment of horses. No better material than this is at the service of Government. If better be indispensable, cavalry must be dispensed with. Why should not skill in "military horsemanship" be also applied to officers of infantry; and if it were, how many, think you, would get their commissions? Upon the whole, the present restriction may reasonably be classed with that numerous category of Mr. STANTON's, orders -- those practically absurd, and promptly to be recalled.

abstract: We published on Thursday a table giving the proportion of troops required from each county of the State, in response to the President's last call for three hundred thousand men. This calculation is in accordance with the recent orders of Gov. MORGAN, in which it is decided that each county and town will be charged with its proportion of one hundred and twenty thousand men, New-York's quota of the last two call's, and credited with all the men it has raised since July 2, 1862. But on Friday appeared a further order from the War Department, in which each town and county is declared to be entitled to credit for all the men heretofore raised and mustered, whether before or after July 2, deducting such as have been discharged. This new rule will necessarily modify the apportionment to the several subdivisions of New-York, rendering a new estimate necessary. Will the Adjutant-General furnish it at once?

abstract: The Mobile Telegraph, of the evening of the 21st, says: "A fire broke out a few minutes before 4 o'clock this morning in the stable on the premises situated on the southeast corner of Royal and Madison streets, which consumed the entire half square, comprising a saw-mill, three warehouses, several shanties and a lumber yard. The loss is estimated as follows: Mr. J.F. JEWETT, on the building, $6,000, no insurance. Mr. DAVIS, on lumber and material in the yard and mill, from $4,000 to $5,000 -- he has about one-third insurance. GAVING & OATLAND owned most of the lumber, the exact amount not known; no insurance. Messrs. HAMILTON & YOUNG had about 1,800 sacks of guano burnt; we were unable to learn whether there was any insurance on it or not. Mr. DAVIS also lost six very valuable mules, which remained in the stable until they were completely wrapped in the flames, and so died, notwithstanding every exertion was made to get them out."

abstract: In a letter to the Nashville Union, dated Union, Aug. 7, N.Y., PARSON BROWNLOW writes: I have been speaking for four months, to crowds ranging at 500 to 5,000, and usually about two hours. I am, therefore, rendering the Confederacy all the service I can, by sterring up the North to volunteer in force, and crush out this wicked rebellion. I owe them a debt of gratitude for their imprisoning me, supressing the publication of my paper, seizing, upon my town property, and driving my wife and children out of their hell-born Confederacy, upon thirty-six hours' notice!
lead_paragraph: In a letter to the Nashville Union, dated Union, Aug. 7, N.Y., PARSON BROWNLOW writes: I have been speaking for four months, to crowds ranging at 500 to 5,000, and usually about two hours. abstract: About 1  o'clock yesterday morning the Third District was the scene of one of the most desperate negro affairs which this city has yet witnessed. Shortly before that hour the Police of that District discovered coming along the levee a large band of negroes, evidently runaways, and determined to carry out their schemes at all hazards and costs. They were armed with all sorts of weapons which plantations afford, from cane bill-books to clubs.
