abstract: Nations, as well as individuals, appear to be unable or unwilling to profit by the experience of others. It needs no demonstration to prove how much more advantageously the cost of the present war might have been devoted to Pacific railways, Atlantic telegraphs, or other stupendous labors of National importance and renown.
lead_paragraph: Nations, as well as individuals, appear to be unable or unwilling to profit by the experience of others. It needs no demonstration to prove how much more advantageously the cost of the present war might have been devoted to Pacific railways, Atlantic telegraphs, or other stupendous labors of National importance and renown. It requires no argument to establish the fact that we have enjoyed a substantial superiority over the condition of other nations, from the absence of a great debt, and the consequent immunity from onerous taxation. These truths are sufficiently evident; but their consideration has not been sufficiently powerful to deter us from military expenditures on a most collosal scale, involving an outlay in a given period for which history furnishes no precedent. The analogy thus existing between the conduct of a nation and that of an individual, will be found to be consistent, if traced through the successive stages of cause and effect to the most distant and ultimate conclusions. The man insists on testing for himself the effects of excess, physical or intellectual, rather than to accept for his guidance the example of others; the nation, in like manner, ignores history, and refuses to believe in the practical nature of any experience save its own.

abstract: Saturday, for some cause or another, has not been a very brisk day at the recruiting offices, but yesterday a more than ordinary amount of business was transacted.
lead_paragraph: Saturday, for some cause or another, has not been a very brisk day at the recruiting offices, but yesterday a more than ordinary amount of business was transacted. The week's record is a most encouraging one. Enough men have been enlisted for regiments in the field and for new organizations forming in this City and Brooklyn to form a moderate brigade. Bounties, in neatly all cases, have been promptly paid, and a general feeling of confidence and satisfaction is the result. The officers in charge of the White-street Mustering Depot declare that so good a class of men has not passed through their hands since the war commenced. Especially good has been the quality of the men since a resort to drafting was within the probabilities.

abstract: -- The message of Gov. MAGOFFIN to the Kentucky Legislature has been received. The antecedents of his Excellency had led many to doubt the fervor of his Unionism, although he has continued willing to receive his salary from a loyal State, But even Gov. MAGOFFIN's patience can be exhausted by the rebels, and his impetuous wrath excited. We me pleased to record that he boldly states his "disapproval" of the late horse-stealing raids of MORGAN into Kentucky -- and that he proposes to end the rebellion immediately by -- the adoption of the Crittenden resolutions.
lead_paragraph: -- The message of Gov. MAGOFFIN to the Kentucky Legislature has been received. abstract: A LIVELY TIME AT THE PROVOST-MARSHAL'S OFFICE. There was a very large crowd at the Provost-Marshal's office in the early part of the day, yesterday, the visitors all wishing to get their passports, for the purpose of leaving by the steamers for Europe.
lead_paragraph: A LIVELY TIME AT THE PROVOST-MARSHAL's OFFICE. -- There was a very large crowd at the Provost-Marshal's office in the early part of the day, yesterday, the visitors all wishing to get their passports, for the purpose of leaving by the steamers for Europe. They were furnished with the required documents when found to be proper persons -- that they were not leaving the United States for the purpose of evading the expected draft, and that it was no part of their intention to defraud the country of their services. After the passports were properly vised by Deputy Provost-Marshal CARPENTER, the travelers took their departure in good order, and, so far as we have been able to learn, not the slightest disturbance took place, notwithstanding the great rush, and the necessary delay in going through with all the required formalities.

abstract: A BOLD THEFT A MAN ATTEMPTS TO SWALLOW A DIAMOND RING. On Saturday evening, a man who gave his name as JOHN WRIGHT, went into a jewelrystore at No. 266 Pearl-street, and stated that he wished to purchase some rings.
lead_paragraph: A BOLD THEFT -- A MAN ATTEMPTS TO SWALLOW A DIAMOND RING. -- On Saturday evening, a man who gave his name as JOHN WRIGHT, went into a jewelrystore at No. 266 Pearl-street, and stated that he wished to purchase some rings. The clerk in attendance handed to him a box containing a large number of rings, and other jewelry, some of them very valuable. After a while, WRIGHT selected a cheap article, which he said he would purchase. At this moment, the clerk's back was turned an instant, and during that time, WRIGHT watched his opportunity, and by a dexterous movement, managed to seize from the box a diamond ring worth $75, a pair of ear-rings, and some other articles, which he secreted about his person. The clerk immediately detected the theft, and at once seized the pretended purchaser. When the latter found he was caught, he slyly thrust the diamond ring into his mouth, and then made several violent efforts to swallow it, but the ring stuck fast in his throat. Finding himself unable to secrete it in that manner, he suddenly threw it away. The clerk, meantime, held on to his prisoner until the arrival of Officer GILMARTIN, of the Second Precinct, who took him into custody. Yesterday, WRIGHT was committed to the Tombs for examination. The ring and other articles were subsequently found, and returned to the owner.

abstract: The rebel Government will not give the people of the United States the opportunity to think charitably, even for a day, of their principles or practices. For a full year they have maintained a systematic bedevilment of some portion of the Union prisoners in their hands. Finally, a system of exchange of prisoners was adopted. All the rebel men and officers were returned to them, and all our private soldiers were returned to us. But for some reason, arbitrary and unexplained, our officers were withheld, and the impression was made very generally that Confederate treachery had overcome Confederate honor. A general burst of indignation was heard. Yesterday news came of the final release and return to our lines of our long captured officers. A feeling of regret arose that injustice had been done the Confederates in regard to the exchange. But almost simultaneously came the statement that the newly-captured prisoners (officers) from Gen. POPE's command, had reached Richmond, and were to be consigned to solitary confinement in dungeons, and starved on bread and water! Thus a new chapter of horrors in this war is to be opened, the records of which are to steel the hearts and madden the brain of the population of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The rebel Government will not give the people of the United States the opportunity to think charitably, even for a day, of their principles or practices. abstract: Abp. Hughes gives war sermon, St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC
snippet: Abp. Hughes gives war sermon, St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC
lead_paragraph: It is the well-known custom of Archbishop HUGHES, on his return from the trips which he periodically makes abroad, either for the benefit of his health or in the fulfillment of the duties which devolve upon him as a prelate of the Church, to meet and greet his friends on the first Sunday after he lands in New-York, the metropolis of the province. His last voyage to Europe derived an additional interest from the fact that it was supposed to have been undertaken at the instance, in part, of this Government, by whom he was invested with semi-diplomatic powers. The announcement made on Saturday that he would preach, for the first time since his arrival, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street, yesterday, attracted an immense congregation, filling the Church almost to suffocation, and obliging many who could not obtain an entrance, to remain without the edifice or leave.

abstract: The hospital steamship Daniel Webster, Capt. BELTHEN, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Harrison's Landing and Fortress Monroe, bringing 129 sick soldiers to the Sanitary Commission.
lead_paragraph: The hospital steamship Daniel Webster, Capt. BELTHEN, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Harrison's Landing and Fortress Monroe, bringing 129 sick soldiers to the Sanitary Commission. She left Harrison's Landing Aug. 14, at 2 1/2 P.M.; anchored off Newport's News that night, and at Fortress Monroe at 6 1/2 A.M. of the 15th, leaving there those that were convalescent, and sailed at 7 1/4 for New-York, arriving at this port at 6 1/2 A.M.

abstract: The new Tariff seems to be working very satisfactorily, as far as the Government is concerned, for since it took effect the receipts for duty at our Custom-house have measurably increased.
lead_paragraph: The new Tariff seems to be working very satisfactorily, as far as the Government is concerned, for since it took effect the receipts for duty at our Custom-house have measurably increased. The Customs revenue or this country has seldom been so heavy as it promises to be this year, a variety of causes being in operation to produce this effect. First of these is the tariff imposed by the last Congress, which is sufficiently high to produce a large revenue whenever the importations are not unusually light, and which is not so exorbitant as to act as a prohibitory law. The effect of its operation has been manifest, since the 1st instant, in the largely increased revenue of the port. which has, in fact, been greater than it was during the latter part of July, when everything tended to its augmentation. Notwithstanding the fact that all the importers who owned merchandise in bond were then endeavoring to pay the duties thereon and gain possession before the new rates were put in force, the receipts not once or twice equaled those of last Thursday and Friday. On the former day they reached a sum between $500,000 and $600.000, while on the latter they amounted to nearly $400,000. These large sums have been paid, mostly, on goods arriving about the time of payment, the proportion of duty paid on merchandise withdrawn from warehouse having been small. Though the proportion was small, the sum itself was quite large for this season of the year, the average daily receipts from the Warehouse Department having been over $10,000 since the beginning of the month. This duty has been derived, in great measure, from sugar, tea and coffee, but few dry goods having been taken out of bond.

abstract: The Thirty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. GEOROR D. WILLS, arrived in Jersey City from Boston in the City of Boston, on saturday morning, on route for the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: The Thirty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. GEOROR D. WILLS, arrived in Jersey City from Boston in the City of Boston, on saturday morning, on route for the seat of war. It numbers over one thousand men, all of whom are [???] recruited in the live Western countries of Massachusetts. After remaining in Jersey City sufficiently long to obtain refreshments, the men were marched on board a train of cars, in order to proceed to Washington. The men wear the regular United States uniform, and are armed with the Springfield muskets. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: Right Rev. Bishop Grace, of Minnesota, although a native of South Carolina, does not mean to be ranked as an enemy to the Union. Col. A.D. Robertson recently visited him, and he writes to the St. Paul Times:
lead_paragraph: -- Right Rev. Bishop Grace, of Minnesota, although a native of South Carolina, does not mean to be ranked as an enemy to the Union. Col. A.D. Robertson recently visited him, and he writes to the St. Paul Times: "Bishop Grace authorized me to, state publicly, in my discretion, his sentiments in this regard, and said -- (I wrote down in his presence the following words of his conversation, which he uttered with emphasis and emotion:) The saddest day for humanity ever known would be that on which the American Union would be destroyed. Whenever spoken to on the subject. I have always encouraged my people to enlist in defence of their country. I have discouraged them from trying to avoid a draft --and that any of them have thought of doing so, I know only from rumor -- and have always told them that they have enjoyed the protection of the Government and ought to be ready at all times to defend it.' He also staled to me some facts which it may not be proper to give in detail, but which I refer to, as evidence of the loyalty of the Bishop. The substance is this: The day previous he received a letter informing him of a rumor of a movement on foot, in a certain part of the State, among Irish and French Catholics' contemplating resistance to the proposed draft. He immediately wrote a letter to the Catholic priest in charge there, (the letter was mailed a few hours before this conversation,) saying to him --" if there was any truth in the rumor -- to discourage this movement in every possible way, and to impress upon the Catholics there a sense of their duty to obey the Government and laws of the country; that their conduct might be that of good and loyal citizens.'"

abstract: The President's second call for 300,000 men, to be raised by draft from the militia of the different States, will fall with much hardship upon numbers of our fellow-citizens.
lead_paragraph: The President's second call for 300,000 men, to be raised by draft from the militia of the different States, will fall with much hardship upon numbers of our fellow-citizens. A largeproportion of the men, amenable to the call, are in receipt of much higher salaries than thirteen dollars a month, while perhaps the majority have wives and families to support, who will be thrown into comparative penury, by their husbands being taken from their offices and workshops. All such contingencies may be avoided, and families placed in ease, and comfort during the war by the following plan.

abstract: editorial on his intended move on either Rome or Venetia against King's wishes
snippet: editorial on his intended move on either Rome or Venetia against King's wishes
lead_paragraph: Italian affairs have suddenly assumed that turn which those who have at heart the good of the young nationality have all along looked forward to with anxious forebodings. It has been foreseen that the trying moment for Italy would be that when GARIBALDI should see fit to move on some new enterprise which VICTOR EMANUEL would be constrained to oppose. Hitherto, GARIBALDI has held his sword obedient always to the word of il re galantuomo. While in the memorable campaign that won Italian unity and independence, GARIBALDI repeatedly took the initiative, yet the movements themselves were always of a kind that the Turin Government could either openly approve or secretly wink at. Much of the success, indeed, of the Italian war of independence was owing to the admirable manner in which the genius of CAVOUR was able to harmonize the fiery zeal of the Republican leader with the needs of an enlightened and practical statesmanship. And if a difference of views at times seemed on the point of producing collision between the soldier and the statesman, to the honor of GARIBALDI it is on record that he invariably surrendered his individual plans to the end that the great cause itself might not suffer. There is, indeed, no trait in GARIBALDI's character more lofty than the generous self-abnegation with which his own most cherished purposes were more than once yielded up at the request of his King.

abstract: Recruiting for the Fifth New-York still continues as brisk as ever at No. 506 Broadway, and the class of young men offering are noticeable for their intelligence and respectability. The corps and its history are as familiar in New-York as "household words," and needs no elaborate nor specious praise. Its name is imperishable, and in the future will live green in the memory of New-Yorkers. A squad of fifty left last week for the regiment, and another of eighty taken its departure to-day, showing that, although the Zouaves have not stopped recruiting, they soon will, so all laggards had better hurry up before it is too late. An additional bounty of $10 is offered this morning, making in all $89 before leaving the City.

abstract: It is evident that the country is now rapidly passing from one phase to another of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: It is evident that the country is now rapidly passing from one phase to another of the rebellion. In three weeks' time everything will be different from what we now see it. We shall have new and greater armies in the field -- we shall have new combinations, new campaigns, and in many respects new rules of warfare, and new agencies at work, to end the strife between the Government and the rebellion. Let us look backward, and then forward, and measure the future by the past.

abstract: News from Confederate States
snippet: News from Confederate States
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Times has the statements of a lady and two daughters, who left Richmond a week ago last Wednesday morning. They say that a mass meeting was held before the recent battles, and it was debated whether or not they should burn the city. JEFF. DAVIS had moved his family away, and HAXALL, a wealthy man and large mill owner, who made an address, recommended that as JEFF. had nothing of any value in the city but his trunks, he had better take them and go. The Mayor JOSEPH MAYO, however, said they would die rather than surrender the city -- they would fight to the last. This seemed to he the feeling of the meeting, although many of the property owners would have much preferred to see the city taken than to have it laid in ashes. The rebels strained every nerve to make the best show of their strength, and even sick men in the hospitals, who could hardly walk, were brought out to fill up the line of battle.

abstract: At a little before 6 o'clock, last evening, FELIX MENALI shot his son twice, in the woods, about half a mile from Fort Hamilton, inflicting wounds which resulted in death a short time afterward.
lead_paragraph: At a little before 6 o'clock, last evening, FELIX MENALI shot his son twice, in the woods, about half a mile from Fort Hamilton, inflicting wounds which resulted in death a short time afterward. The murderer instantly made his escape and is supposed to be secreted in New-York or Brooklyn. Only a few particulars of this transaction could be ascertained last night. The prevailing report is that the deceased (who was an Italian,) married an Irishwoman, the daughter of his stepmother, against the remonstrance of his parent. The deceased was in the service of the United States as a musician, and stationed at Fort Hamilton. Yesterday the father and an older brother visited the place and invited the deceased and his wife to take a walk. They walked into the woods near the Fort, when the subject of the marriage was brought up and a quarrel ensued, resulting in the father shouting his son twice. There is another report, also, that the deceased made an attack upon his father with a knife before the latter [???]. The deceased was 23 years of age. The elder, MENALI is a goldsmith by trade, and resides at No. 150 Concord-street. The other son present, and who, it is alleged, participated in the quarrel, resides in New-York. A party of soldier, exasperated at the escape of the murderer, came up to the city and surrounded the house of MENALI, with a view of securing his apprehension, but he was not there.
headline: {'main': 'Murder at Fort Hamilton.; A SON SHOT BY HIS FATHER ESCAPE OF THE MURDERER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Murder at Fort Hamilton.; A SON SHOT BY HIS FATHER ESCAPE OF THE MURDERER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Another war meeting will be held on Fort Green. Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to encourage volunteering. This will probably be the largest meeting ever held in America.
lead_paragraph: Another war meeting will be held on Fort Green. Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to encourage volunteering. This will probably be the largest meeting ever held in America. The Park affords goodaccommodations on one side for at least 150,000 people and six speakers' stands will be required for the accommodation of this vast multitude. The people of Brooklyn have at last taken off their coats, rolled, up their sleeves, and are determined that the necessity for drafting in Kings County shall not exist, and Tuesday will be devoted by all classes exclusively to encouraging enlistments. To this end, every loyal citizen will close his place of business, and devote his energies for the benefit of the country. The following distinguished citizens will address the meeting:

abstract: It is still insisted upon in Washington that Gen. McCLELLAN is at Harrison's Landing on the James River. On the other hand, a private note from Fortress Monroe, dated Aug. 14, says: "The army is now moving away from Harrison's Landing, and, by to-morrow, I hear the place will be cleared.
lead_paragraph: It is still insisted upon in Washington that Gen. McCLELLAN is at Harrison's Landing on the James River. On the other hand, a private note from Fortress Monroe, dated Aug. 14, says: "The army is now moving away from Harrison's Landing, and, by to-morrow, I hear the place will be cleared. They are coming down over the Chickahominy,I learn, to Yorktown, by land. The artillery has been shipped by water. The pontoon bridges went up to bridge the river night before last."

abstract: Editorials on present and prospective national debt; Editorial speculates on future course of war
snippet: Editorials on present and prospective national debt; Editorial speculates on future course of war
lead_paragraph: Our National Debt, and the current expenditure by which it is growing, have come to be matters of absorbing interest to the entire nation. They are no longer exclusively the concern of capitalists, financiers and Cabinet officials. Finances, resources, public credit mingle with our every-day businees. Calculation and speculation concerning them have escaped from their usual confinement in the closet of the political economist and the office of the banker, and become the theme of popular discussion. Taxation, discount and the money market, commerce, crops and prices, as efficient forces involved in the one overruling solicitude for the issues of the great civil strife that troubles the Union, keep the ideas proper to financial experts constantly present to the minds of the people.
headline: {'main': 'NATIONAL FINANCES.; The Debt of the United States, Present and Prospective.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NATIONAL FINANCES.; The Debt of the United States, Present and Prospective.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: LAWYERS NONPLUSSED. Two well-known Brooklyn lawyers called at the office of the Deputy Inspector of Police on Saturday, to make some inquiry about a soldier who had been arrested for desertion, with a view of obtaining his discharge upon a writ of habeas corpus, he being a minor.
lead_paragraph: LAWYERS NONPLUSSED. -- Two well-known Brooklyn lawyers called at the office of the Deputy Inspector of Police on Saturday, to make some inquiry about a soldier who had been arrested for desertion, with a view of obtaining his discharge upon a writ of habeas corpus, he being a minor. The Deputy Inspector, who is almost dally annoyed by these applications, and who, by the way, is something of a wag, asked the disciples of BLACKSTONE if they had seen the last order of Secretary of War STANTON. They had not, and were anxious to know the purport of it. They were informed that the order was a direction to the Police authorities to arrest all lawyers who attempted to obtain the release of soldiers upon writs of habeus corpus, and commit them to Fort Lafayette. The legal gentlemen were dumbfounded and astounded both; they wondered what monstrous wrong the Secretary of War wouldn't be guilty of next, and, forgetting the interest of their client, hurriedly left the premises, to find the order and see whether it was properly verified. They have not been seen at the Deputy Inspector's office since.

abstract: One day's later advices from Europe have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon. She left Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The news is not specially important.
lead_paragraph: One day's later advices from Europe have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon. She left Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The news is not specially important. It was rumored that there was to be another Congress of European Sovereigns soon, at Cologne. The French newspapers were insisting on Rome being delivered to Italy. The statement is made that GARIBALDI has but about 850 followers with him -- all poorly armed. Rumor has fixed upon another King for Mexico, in the person of MURAT. This rumor was current at Madrid. Another battle had been fought between the Turks and the Montenegrins, the result of which both claimed as a victory. The later commercial intelligence by the Anglo-Saxon. by way of Londonderry, has not come to hand.

abstract: MAGOFFIN has done the best  thing possible for himself, in resigning the supreme magistracy of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: MAGOFFIN has done the best thing possible for himself, in resigning the supreme magistracy of Kentucky. He disagreed fundamentally, and in everything, with the State officials, the State Legislature, and the people of the State -- not to speak of the State Military Board and the Government of the United States, whose authority is now fixed and supreme in Kentucky. He had been gradually stripped of power by the Legislature and the General Government until latterly he was a mere cypher, without, as he said in a recent message, a "dollar or a soldier." He was enabled, however, by the mere fact of his position, to obstruct the work of quelling the rebellion, which the people of Kentucky and the nation have taken in hand with an earnestness which will pause before no obstacle.

abstract: A majority of the Committee on National Affairs being absent from the City, an informal meeting of both Boards of the Common Council was held at the City Hall yesterday, to take action with reference to the reception of Col. CORCORAN on his arrival in this City.
lead_paragraph: A majority of the Committee on National Affairs being absent from the City, an informal meeting of both Boards of the Common Council was held at the City Hall yesterday, to take action with reference to the reception of Col. CORCORAN on his arrival in this City. About 20 members were present at the meeting, among whom were Aldermen Boole, Farley, Dayton, Chipp, Reed, Frear, Froment, Hall, Ottiwell and Allen, and Councilmen Orton, Pinckney, Lent, Trotter, Gross, Gedney, Ross, Brice, Snyder and Repper. Aldermen FARLEY occupied the Chair, and presented a telegraphic dispatch received by him from a Committee of the Common Council now in Washington, which will be found above. There being some doubt among the members as to their authority to take any action, it being merely an informal meeting, Alderman DAYTON called the attention of the meeting to resolutions passed at a meeting of the Board in February last, when it was expected that Col. CORCORAN would arrive, and was of opinion that they had full authority to act under these resolutions. The resolutions were as follows:

abstract: McClellan evacuation and arrival at Williamsburg confirmed
snippet: McClellan evacuation and arrival at Williamsburg confirmed
lead_paragraph: The uncertainty with regard to the movements of the Army of the Potomac will be relieved this morning by the positive announcement, received from Fortress Monroe, that Harrison's Landing was evacuated on Saturday morning about 8 o'clock, and that at about the same hour Gen. McCLELLAN'S advance arrived at Williamsburgh. The public property was all removed down the James River in safety, and the army effected its movement without interruption. We shall soon hear of the Army of the Potomac again -- in a locality, perhaps, where the rebels least want it.

abstract: The Tribune, under the firm belief that WENDELL PHILLIPS regarded "the struggle now making for the Union unprincipled and futile," and was "discouraging enlistments," refused for two days to answer us whether it considered him disloyal, and a fit subject for incarceration with other men whom it demanded should be imprisoned for that identical offence. The Tribune wriggled painfully, and wrote profusely -- compared PHILLIPS to other men -- and declared that if PHILLIPS did wish to "supersede this Republic" and establish a new one, it was because he wished to get rid of "the monstrous and scandalous anomaly" of a Republic tolerating Slavery. It admitted, then and subsequently, that PHILLIPS was guilty of sedition, but refused to say he deserved punishment. On the contrary, it unmistakably intimated that in the case of PHILLIPS, "the end justified the means." It was innocent to seek the overthrow the Government if done in the interest of universal abolitionism -- otherwise, to jail with the offenders! Such was Tribunism.

abstract: The tidings which reach us of the movements of Gen. McCLELLAN'S army are so far very encouraging. His advance is already far ahead, his rear unassailed, and, ere this reaches you, let us hope our gallant leader and his men will be all safe at their destination. It is certain that the army is now safely across the Chickahominy.
lead_paragraph: OLD POINT COMFORT, Saturday, Aug. 16, 1862.

abstract: JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE is ambitious to illustrate in his single person all the vices which can make a Vice-President and a traitor detestable. It is only a day or two ago we printed a dispatch from his pen, in which he ...
lead_paragraph: JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE is ambitious to illustrate in his single person all the vices which can make a Vice-President and a traitor detestable. It is only a day or two ago we printed a dispatch from his pen, in which he claimed a victory at Baton Rouge, and represented the Union command of Gen. WILLIAMS as cut to pieces. The story was a good one, though halting in certain of its members, as in the circumstance of the bulletin bearing date ten miles away from Baton Rouge, a point reached, it seemed, "without disorder or loss" on the part of the victors. It was at once notable that victors are always presumed to hold a battle-ground secured by their prowess, especially when the ground is a strategical point for the all-important possession of which the fight was challenged, and which can hardly be said to be reoccupied by an army which, after a brief combat, marches away at top speed, only pausing when the vanquished cease, after a chase of ten miles, to harass its rear. But Gen. BRECKINRIDGE is ill-seasoned in arms. The military vocabulary may not be at his finger ends; or, in his confidence of victory, he may have shared the fatuity of Gen. TAYLOR, who never knew when he was beaten. Indeed, the cotemporary dispatches by way of Grenada not only placed the rebel General in possession of the town, hut sent the ram Arkansas to play a formidable and triumphant part in its capture. Whatever, therefore, the discrepancy of details, the result from all the various sources of evidence was the same. The rebels had occupied Baton Rouge after a battle of proportions more or less stupendous. The battle was certified to by the sign-manual of BRECKINRIDGE himself, and the occupation attested by the Grenada Appeal.

abstract: Voluntary enlistments are plentiful, and steadily increase in number from day to day. Last week more men in this City were added to both old and new regiments, than it would have been considered possible to raise in the time, even during the great uprising of a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Voluntary enlistments are plentiful, and steadily increase in number from day to day. Last week more men in this City were added to both old and new regiments, than it would have been considered possible to raise in the time, even during the great uprising of a year ago. Yesterday recruits enough came in to form a regiment, and, for several days now immediately ensuing, may be expected to respond to their country's call with unexampled alacrity. But the quota to be supplied from the City and County of New-York, and the adjoining County of Kings, is of itself a small army, and great exertions will have to be made to avoid a resort to drafting for the purpose, at least of filling up the ranks of the second 300,000 demanded by the President. The first requisition will almost certainly be satisfied before the 22d inst. by volunteering alone, and between then and the 1st of September a considerable surplus will be found that can be credited to the account of requisition number 2; but, unless an extraordinary enthusiasm be, in the meanwhile, evoked, there must assuredly remain a deficit of several thousand to be supplied by conscription. Enlistments ran up as high yesterday, in New-York and Brooklyn, as seven to eight hundred; but they must for the next fortnight average a thousand, or drafting will be indispensable. A great deal is anticipated from the excitement which will follow the series of stirring war-meetings for which arrangements are in comes of preparation, and one of which comes off to-day at Fort Greene, Long Island. The presence of the gallant CORCORAN, too, it is confidently calculated, will have an immense effect upon his brave fellow-countrymen, who will undoubtedly flock in thousands around him, should he, in his new quality of General, be authorized to unfurl the green banner of another Irish Brigade.

abstract: -- We learn that Col. CHARLES P. STONE, U.S.A., and Brigadier-General of Volunteers, who has been for many months confined in Fort Lafayette, is at liberty, and stopping with his family in this City. Why Gen. STONE was sent to Fort Lafayette is as much a mystery to the public as is his release without trial, and without, we believe, the preference of charge. It will be proper hereafter to inquire into the history of this extraordinary transaction. Certainly, whether Gen. STONE was or was not guilty when imprisoned, his discharge, untried, throws a fearful burden of responsibility upon Government.

abstract: Parliament debates question of corresponding with Confederate Comrs
snippet: Parliament debates question of corresponding with Confederate Comrs
lead_paragraph: On the 5th of August Lord CAMPBELL rose to move for copies or extracts of any correspondence which her Majesty's Government had received from Mr. MASON, the Southern envoy, relating to the acknowledgment of the Confederate States of America by Great Britain. He said, as the Government had already laid before Parliament, in the first number of the papers on America, the dispatch of Col. MANN and Mr. YANCEY, demanding the acknowledgment of the Southern Confederacy in 1861, and had also laid before Parliament a dispatch of Mr. MASON at the beginning of the present year on the blockade, there could be no technical objection to present any correspondence of a later period. It was well known that the Southern envoys, both in London and in Paris, had recently demanded the acknowledgment of the States they represented, and of which the power to defend their capital against an invading force was in the last days of June triumphantly asserted. In one sense, indeed, the paper would be useless; they could do little to enhance -- so strong was it already -- the conviction which appeared to pervade society and Parliament that the war ought to end in separation of the Northern and the Southern Powers. It was not too much to say that no class or party in the country any longer desired to see the reconquest of the South and the reconstruction of the Union. The unanimity might be traced to many different causes. It was owing in some measure to the seasonable flood of light which Mr. SPENCE, in his well-known work, had thrown upon the subject. It was owing in a still greater measure to the speech of the noble lord the Secretary for Foreign Affairs, on the 10th of March, in which he told the world that separation was the issue of the struggle which he contemplated, and that at a period not distant from the time when he was speaking. It was owing also to the labors of enlightened men in the House of Commons, of whom Mr. GREGORY had been the most conspicuous. But still more should the unanimous desire for separation and aversion to reconquest in this country be traced to the conviction that the interest of the negro race would be promoted by the former and retarded by the latter; that the area of Slavery must be limited when separation happened, and would most likely be extended if reconquest unhappily occurred. These papers were not wanted in order to give new force to that conviction, but that they might throw light upon the course which Great Britain ought to follow amid the dangers which surrounded her in consequence of this civil war. The first danger of Great Britain, viz.: the possibility of Southern subjugation, and all the evils it involved, might be, perhaps, dismissed as a remote one. The second danger, which arose from the continuance of the war -- the manufacturing distress it must occasion -- was far more serious and distressing. So long as the war continued, a scarcity of cotton must be apprehended. If, indeed, the American supply were utterly and finally extinguished, the means would not, perhaps, be wanting to replace it, but so long as the American supply was constantly impending on the market, they could not hope to get a large amount from Africa or India. And who should say what degree of social or political disorder might not follow manufacturing distress if it extended over four years or upward! Another danger for Great Britain, more likely to remain unnoticed, but not less easy to describe, was that, if the war should end in separation, before this country had merited alliance from the Southern Power, Canada was exposed without an adequate defence to at least a possible invader. If Canada was unable to support a numerous militia, if Britain was unable to send large armies to her succor, what defence could they rely on except a firm ally upon that continent, prepared at any moment to cross the frontier of the Power by which an unjust attack was made upon our dependency? Suppose Great Britain held aloof completely in the present Autumn, while the other Powers of Europe, swayed by the French Government, employed their moral force to terminate the war in Southern Independence. In two months Canada might be assailed and Great Britain be without the least support on that Continent. If, however, Great Britain had united with the other Powers of Europe (after showing every observance to the Government at Washington) in acknowledging the independence of the South, she would not be unsupported in America when separation happened. Since modern Europe came into existence no civil war had ended in the sovereignty of the insurgent Power until that Power had been recognized by neutral States, giving an example to the State which aimed at its reconquest. It was not till Portugal had been acknowledged by Great Britain 25 years that Spain consented to acknowledge her existence as an independent Power. It was not till long after nearly all the Governments of Europe had acknowledged the United Provinces of Holland, that Spain gave up the hope of reabsorbing them. The same circumstance applied to the United States, the South American. Republics, to Greece, to Belgium and to Italy. The acknowledgment by neutral Powers had always preceded the acknowledgment of the Power which first endeavored to control the insurrection. It way not too much to lay down as a principle that, war must go on against an insurgent State until neutral Powers had acknowledged it. The war for a reconquest could not be abandoned while neutral Powers sanctioned its continuance. The whole question as regarded acknowledgement appeared to turn upon the moment. If other Powers of Europe were prepared, had England a right to count upon a better one? Operations of gunboats were retarded by the dryness of the navigable rivers; operations on land by the fearful heat and the diseases it engendered. Richmond was no longer menaced. Securities at New-York had undergone a great depreciation. The war, as far as they could judge, had lost its hold on popular opinion. The Abolitionists who followed Mr. Sumner had ceased to give at their support. And if many of the most reflecting men believed that in December and January last Europe lost an opportunity of taking that step without which the war could scarcely end, and which would then, perhaps, have closed it, with what decision and dispatch ought not a new conjuncture which invited to such a mode of acting to be made use of? There was this difference between the present and the former opportunity. In January the Federals had never been victorious in battle, and, however resigned to separation, however hopeless of reconquest, might still prolong the war in order to recover their prestige and repair their military losses. How the greater balance of success was likely to extinguish such an obstacle! But if the present moment were abandoned what were they to wait for? Before granting the extrication they must owe to Europe and to us, were we to wait until the Southern forces were again aggressive and triumphant; until the invaders were invaded, until the avengers were the victims, until the Northern States were overrun, and until Washington was occupied -- until, at least, its Government had encountered new humiliations, losses and disasters at the hands of the people whom they had rashly undertaken to chastise and to subdue? At least England was hardly justified in waiting for new reverses to the Federals, unless it was the only conduct in which the other Powers of Europe would support us. In that case, no doubt, they were entitled to pursue it. Perhaps the noble Lord the Secretary for Foreign Affairs would describe such a case as being the real one. If not, his silence would explode it. The noble Lord concluded by moving for the correspondence.

abstract: The meeting at Fort Green to-day, it is expected, will surpass in humbers any meeting ever held in Brooklyn. Sickles, Hon. James Humphrey, Hon. Moses F. Odell, Hon. Wm. Wall, Ex. Mayor Powell, Brigadier-Gen. Crooke, Judge Morris, Brigadier-Gen. Spinola, Judge Garrison, Hon. H.C. abstract: The troubles in Italy and the King's proclamation were made the subject of an interpellation in the Chamber of Deputies, on the 3d, by FERRARI, who, is a long and rambling speech, more suo, reminded the Chamber that GARIBALDI had given Italy the two southern kingdoms, contended that he was not a man to be dealt with like another citizen, and warned the Ministers that if they ventured on a career of repression they would he led to one coup d'etat after another, to the utter extinction of the liberties of the country.

abstract: MORTALITY IN THE CITY. We learn from the report of the City Inspector that 685 persons died in this City last week. Of these 117 were women, 199 girls, 164 men and 205 boys. Of the children, 382 died under the age of five years.
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY IN THE CITY. -- We learn from the report of the City Inspector that 685 persons died in this City last week. Of these 117 were women, 199 girls, 164 men and 205 boys. Of the children, 382 died under the age of five years. The principal causes of death are as follows: Cholera infantum 153, consumption 66, infantile convulsions 49, congestion of the brain 24, diarrhoea 20, dysentery 14, inflammation or the bowels 25, sun stroke 35, dropsy in the head 30, disease of the heart 10, typhoid fever 10, deaths from external causes 38, among which are reported 5 premature births, 5 drowned, delirium tremens 2, suicide 1, deaths by accidents 9. There were 66 interments in Potter's Field and 99 deaths in the Institutions. The number of deaths, compared with the corresponding week of 1861 and of last week, was as follows:

abstract: A majority of the Committee on National Affairs being absent from the City, an informal meeting of both Boards of the Common Council was held at the City Hall yesterday, to take action with reference to the reception of Col. CORCORAN on his arrival in this City. About 20 members were present at the meeting, among whom were Aldermen Boole, Farley, Dayton, Chipp, Reed, Frear, Fromont, Hall, Ottiweil and Allen, and Councilmen Orion, Pinckney, Lent, Trotter, Gross, Godney, Ross, Brice, Snyder and Repper. Alderman FARLEY occupied the Chair, and presented a telegraphic dispatch received by him from a Committee of the Common Council now in Washington, which will be found above. There being some doubt among the members as to their authority to take any action, it being merely an informal meeting, Alderman DAYTON called the attention of the meeting to resolutions passed at a meeting of the Board in February last, when it was expected that Col. CORCORAN would arrive, and was of opinion that they had full authority to act under these resolutions. The resolutions were as follows:

abstract: When, with its usual enterprise, the TIMES laid before its readers last week intelligence of Gen. McCLELLAN'S removal from Harrison's Landing, journals less fortunate in getting the news condemned loudly our imprudence in ...
lead_paragraph: When, with its usual enterprise, the TIMES laid before its readers last week intelligence of Gen. McCLELLAN'S removal from Harrison's Landing, journals less fortunate in getting the news condemned loudly our imprudence in making the publication. We were charged with supplying advices to the enemy; with imperiling the success of the movement; with an entire oversight of the public good in anxiety to cater to public curiosity; and so through the long category of topics for scolding suggested by the occasion. It was not enough to refer our implacable neighbors to the fact that in this instance the censorship was too late. What was told to the loyal community in the Times had already been told to the rebels by the Richmond and Charleston Press, as extracts from those papers clearly proved. Rumors to the same purport, more or less concrete, were current in Wall-street, were serving the mischievous uses of speculation -- were exciting the profoundest anxiety generally. Confident that no evil result could ensue, in this instance at least, from a frank disclosure of the truth, and the tranquilization of the public mind, the truth was told, and we have reason to know, with the very happiest effect. Fresh hope and confidence were visible on every face. A new impulse was given to enlistments. It was felt that the crisis of the war had passed.

abstract: -- In another column will be found a note from Gen. SICKLES, in which a tribute is paid to the courage and amiable personal qualities of the Princes of Orleans. While it is gratifying to have this testimony from one so qualified by circumstances to offer it, we do not see that the TIMES has so called either the personal courage or other attributes of these gentlemen in question, as to require this emendation of its record. The departure of the Prince DE JOINVILLE and his nephews was unquestionably owing to something beyond a mere personal fear of danger. Was it not due to the consciousness that the fate of a Royal house, and its chances of once more regaining a throne, were dependent upon the safety of the young men, whose lives were needlessly exposed in a defensive battle, where there was little of glory to repay the risk? Such was the meaning of the phrase to which Gen. SICKLES takes exception. To impugn the gallantry and chivalrous devotion of his proteges would, of course, be equivalent to saying they are not Frenchmen.

abstract: After fourteen months of uninterrupted labor, principally in the Prize Court, Judge BETTS, of this District, went with his family to Saratoga Springs, about two weeks ago. On Friday last the United States District-Attorney, DELAFIELD SMITH, went on to bring before the Judge some important motions in prize proceedings. Judge BETTS, at the request of the District-Attorney, said he would be in Court, in this City, on Wednesday (to-morrow) morning, to hear applications in reference to the taking by the Government of some arms, as also several of the steamers which have recently been brought to this port as prizes.

abstract: editorial lauds Hughes as patriot priest
snippet: editorial lauds Hughes as patriot priest
lead_paragraph: We regard it as not a little auspicious that the good cause should have been reinforced by the simultaneous presence in our midst of two such powerful auxiliaries as Archbishop HUGHES and Col. CORCORAN. Each is from his personal qualities and station in life a representative man, with thousand-fold filaments of relationship and influence connecting him with his countrymen. In the one we see the gallant soldier, beloved by the people for all noble, human qualities, and doubly-beloved for his heroic sufferings; in the other, the priest clad with the authority of his high office, and united to his fellows by that which is most sacred in our nature. But both return -- the one from his diplomatic mission to Europe, the other from his exile in a Southern prison, (where, too, he found a mission of his own -- that, namely, of illustrating how a patriotic soul can add dignity even to prison walls,) -- soldier and priest, we say, both return to exercise their peculiar influence in aiding the work which Heaven has given the Nation to do. Let us, for a moment, see what we may hope from these two men, and how the great power they wield may be turned to the best account.

abstract: Two days later advices from Europe are received by the Europa, which passed Cape Race yesteeday. Our full dispatch, however, has not yet reached us, owing to a break in the telegraphic communication.
lead_paragraph: Two days later advices from Europe are received by the Europa, which passed Cape Race yesteeday. Our full dispatch, however, has not yet reached us, owing to a break in the telegraphic communication. The rebel Envoys MASON and SLIDELL, are represented to be hard at work endeavoring to procure the recognition of the Southern Confederacy. Our account has it that they had demanded the recognition, and that England had refused to accede to the demand, while France had not yet decided what to do. The Liverpool Cotton market continued quiet. Breadstuffs and Provisions were unchanged.

abstract: put into operation
snippet: put into operation
lead_paragraph: A belt of humanity, a mile and a half in extent, encircled the great Reservoir in the Central Park yesterday afternoon, to witness the letting on of the Croton for the first time. It was a splendid sight such a grand triumph of engineering skill, commenced over three years ago, in the time of profound peace, and now finished in spite of the desolating war which has darkened so large a portion of the land. It was the more significant as an illustration of the lightness with which the stern hand of war has yet touched the face of the North. Owing to more pressing demands upon the City funds, the Common Council failed to appropriate money to fittingly celebrate this era in the history of the City, but the popular interest was none the less lessened, and many thousand citizens of all classes, ages, and sexes, assembled to view the first gush of croton into the great lake. Precisely at 3 o'clock, the President and Chief Engineer of the Croton Board, members of the City Government, and other invited guests, were assembled at the North Gate-house, and, together with many privileged ladies admitted to choice seats, eagerly awaited the great event of the day. All eyes were turned upon Mr. CRAVEN, the Chief Engineer, and the imagination fondly pictured the grandeur of the scene when, amid huzzas and booming cannon, music and general rejoicing, the word should be given for the rush of waters. How the crowd trembled for the adventurous hundreds who were exploring the very bed of the reservoir, up to the months of the water-gates, to see all that was to be seen. How many tender people feared that somebody would be engulphed in the flood, while all eagerly awaited the signal. The signal was, however, known to but few. Mr. CRAVEN had stationed ten men at the water-gates, one man at the flag-staff, and a gang of men at the junction gate-house. Exactly as the hour and minute hand of the best time-piece on the ground pointed to 3 o'clock. Mr. CRAVEN quietly said.

abstract: Editorial on rumor Jackson is advancing on Potomac River
snippet: Editorial on rumor Jackson is advancing on Potomac River
lead_paragraph: -- A rumor was current yesterday at Washington that Stonewall JACKSON, leaving the front of Gen. POPE, had passed into the Shenandoah valley, and was rapidly advancing upon the Potomac. The tale was inherently probable. A raid along the Valley is a favorite pastime of the prayerful partisan; who, besides, is under engagements with the inhabitants of the district to celebrate harvest home in their company. Not to have heard from him for a week is a sign of mischief. We may be sure he is not inactive, or at all ignorant of his opportunities. If it be practicable to flank POPE, march upon and capture the capital, or carry the war to Harrisburgh, JACKSON knows all about it, and doubtless loses not a fragment of time in making necessary preparations. What his hand finds to do he is apt to do swiftly and mightily.

abstract: Yesterday the United States Mustering Office, in White-street, presented a more crowded appearance than ever. More than three hundred recruits for regiments in the field were enrolled, and over a thousand were on hand to receive the Government bounty payment of which has been partially delayed.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the United States Mustering Office, in White-street, presented a more crowded appearance than ever. More than three hundred recruits for regiments in the field were enrolled, and over a thousand were on hand to receive the Government bounty payment of which has been partially delayed for a day or two. The inspection of men is very strict under the new orders from the War Department, and recruits for cavalry have to show their capacity for the management of horses. To enable them to do this, a pony is kept in attendance all day, on which candidates are put through their paces. It is said at the White-street office that DURYEE's Zouaves are nearly filled up, and that SICKLES' Brigade is rapidly approaching its original strength.

abstract: On Sunday last, as published in yesterday's TIMES, a young married man, named PETER MENALDI, a drummer in the regular United States service, stationed at Fort Hamilton, was murdered by his father,  FELIX MENALDI, by shooting with a pistol. The father resides at No. 115 Concord-street, Brooklyn. On Sunday, himself, his sons, CRESCENT and JOHN, paid a visit to PETER.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday last, as published in yesterday's TIMES, a young married man, named PETER MENALDI, a drummer in the regular United States service, stationed at Fort Hamilton, was murdered by his father, FELIX MENALDI, by shooting with a pistol. The father resides at No. 115 Concord-street, Brooklyn. On Sunday, himself, his sons, CRESCENT and JOHN, paid a visit to PETER. Late in the afternoon they got into a quarrel, while walking on the road near the old base ball ground, at the head of Staats-lane. The dispute appeared to be about the ownership of a dog. Some blows passed between PETER and his father, and PETER's wife interfered by throwing stones. CRESCENT MENALDI struck her, and PETER ran to the house and got his sword. He swung it round, but struck at no one, when the father fired and shot him in the right breast with a pistol. The wound resulted fatally in 15 minutes thereafter. The father put the pistol in his pocket and left. His son CRESCENT also left, and neither have since been seen. The following is the evidence taken before Coroner WINANT E. BENNETT, and the verdict of the jury:

abstract: A WASHINGTON BANKER IN LIMBO Mr. CICE RO BAAKEE, a wealthy banker of Washington, was arrested yesterday afternoon, at Stapleton, Staten Island, by Detective FARLEY of this City, upon three bench warrants, issued by the Washington authorities. The prisoner in the first place is charged with an attempt to violate the person of a respectable lady of the latter city, for which an indictment has been ...
lead_paragraph: A WASHINGTON BANKER IN LIMBO Mr. CICE RO BAAKEE, a wealthy banker of Washington, was arrested yesterday afternoon, at Stapleton, Staten Island, by Detective FARLEY of this City, upon three bench warrants, issued by the Washington authorities. The prisoner in the first place is charged with an attempt to violate the person of a respectable lady of the latter city, for which an indictment has been found against him. He is also accused of felonious assault and battery upon two officials in Washington, alleged to have been committed about two months since. About the first of June last he left Washington with his wife and upon his arrival in this City he rented a fine country seat on Steten Island, where he has since been living. His friends, of whom he has a great number in this City, say there is not a word of truth in the charges which have been brought against him, but that the whole of it is a trumped up matter, initiated by his personal and political enemies. Detective FARLEY took him on to Washington last evening, pursuant to orders from the authorities of that city.

abstract: A MAN KILLS ANOTHER BY A BLOW WITH HIS FIST. -- On Monday night, about 11 o'clock, an affray occurred in the oyster saloon of JOHN DAILEY, on the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Pearl-street, between himself and two men named E. CONNERS and CHARLES STEVENS, which resulted in the death of the latter, it appears that shortly before the time above named, CONNERS and STEVENS came into the saloon and called for oyster stews. After they had got them, CONNERS, as alleged, after using the catsup stuck the bottle into the butter plate, and DAILEY, noticing the action, was very much displeased, and came over to them and told them, in an indignant manner, that he did not desire to have such conduct in his saloon. CONNERS replied: "If you don't like it, put us out;" and DAILEY said that he could do it, and then ordered them to leave. The saloon is situated in the basement, with a deep flight of wooden steps leading to the [???] and in a few moments both the men got up to [???] CONNERS was first, and got up as far as the head of the stairs. STEVENS had just reached the bottom when another dispute arose. He struck at DALEY, when the latter ordered him to leave. STEVENS replied that he was not able to put him out, when DALEY struck him a powerful blow with his fist, knocking him against the steps. He died from the effects of the injury in a few minutes thereafter. The only wound on the deceased consists of a slight cut over one eye. The deceased was a married man, residing in Lafayette-avenue, and leaves a wife and family. Coroner NORRIS will make an investigation.

abstract: A war meeting is to be held to-night (Wednesday) at the Tompkins Lyceum, Stapleton, for the purpose of raising the quota of Middletown by volunteering. A warlike spirit is abroad, and the men of Middletown feel confident that they will raise their quota without compulsory measures. A large and influential committee has been appointed to collect subscriptions. Among the speakers who are expected to address the meeting to-night are Gen. SICKLES, Gen. WALBRIDGE, Mr. GEORGE WM. CURTIS, and other distinguished orators.

abstract: We learn from our correspondent, that the Army of the Potomac had, on Sunday last, all arrived at the lower end of the Peninsula without being at all interfered with by the rebels. Gen. McCLELLAM is understood to have been at Williamsburgh on Monday morning. The weather had been cool and delightful most favorable for the movement thus effected.
lead_paragraph: We learn from our correspondent, that the Army of the Potomac had, on Sunday last, all arrived at the lower end of the Peninsula without being at all interfered with by the rebels. Gen. McCLELLAM is understood to have been at Williamsburgh on Monday morning. The weather had been cool and delightful -- most favorable for the movement thus effected. Most of the gunboats had come down the James River, but some of them remained to guard the pontoon bridges across the Chickahominy, over which the army passed on its way down the Peninsula.

abstract: It is a gratifying il  lustration of the lightness witn which the stern hand of War has yet touched tha North, that our great pacific enterprises experience no surcease. And assuredly, if any lesser object may divide the interest of the community with the mighty drama which is now being performed on this continent, with the whole ...
lead_paragraph: It is a gratifying il lustration of the lightness witn which the stern hand of War has yet touched tha North, that our great pacific enterprises experience no surcease. And assuredly, if any lesser object may divide the interest of the community with the mighty drama which is now being performed on this continent, with the whole world as spectators, it is such a public work as was yesterday brought to completion in the new reservoir. The Empire City is now imperially supplied with water. The first indispensable necessity of life is now free to our million citizens, to use plenteously for all the purposes to which nature's gift is put. We are now at the mercy of no contingency. No accident can well be conceived that can cut us off from a copious supply of water. To the resources of the old reservoir are now added the vast capacity of the new one, with its billion imperial gallons. And, as was fit with the expansive tendencies of our growing City, respect has been had not only to present needs, but to future requirements. Should New-York push its limits till it covers the whole space up to the lakes and rivers whence these reservoirs draw their floods, the teeming population would still be able to draw an abundant supply of water from the provisions now made.

abstract: It is time the Union commanders in the Southwest were waking up. It can hardly be politie for any part of a people, with a large war on their hands, to be fast asleep. We have suffered three damaging reverses, in rapid succession, in the West, in consequence of the sleepy propensities of our officers.
lead_paragraph: It is time the Union commanders in the Southwest were waking up. It can hardly be politie for any part of a people, with a large war on their hands, to be fast asleep. We have suffered three damaging reverses, in rapid succession, in the West, in consequence of the sleepy propensities of our officers. First was the disgraceful surprise end surrender of Gen. CRITTENDEN's command at Murfreesboro, Tenn. We lost 2,000 prisoners there -- all because they were "surprised." They didn't think well-bred Southern soldiers would be so uncivil as to disturb them in their sleep. CRITTENDEN was taken in bed at a hotel, and removed from Murfreesboro, before his command was attacked and made aware of his capture. His friends urge that he has been harshly judged, as he only took command of the post the evening before, and went to a tavern to sleep "because his tent had not arrived." A miserable excuse this. He knew he was in the enemy's country, and should never have slept, or thought of his tent even, till he knew his camp was safe from attack. That first night of insecurity was fatal to him as a commander.

abstract: The attack upon Baton Rouge had been anticipated for a day or two, by reports from outside. It had been known for some weeks that a body of Confederate troops were not many miles away, supposed to be under command of Gen. LOVELL. I mentioned this in my last letter; also that we had had two alarms from the pickets, causing a turn out of the soldiers, and that preparations had been made on the gunboats to defend the town.

abstract: The remainder of the news by the Europa came through by telegraph from St. Johns yesterday. The bar to recognition by France is asserted to be the unwillingness of England. Lord PALMERSTON had made a speech at a banquet in Sheffield, in which...
lead_paragraph: The remainder of the news by the Europa came through by telegraph from St. Johns yesterday. The talk of the recognition of the South by France and England seems to have no firmer basis than reports set on foot by the secession agents. The bar to recognition by France is asserted to be the unwillingness of England. Lord PALMERSTON had made a speech at a banquet in Sheffield, in which he made another declaration against intervention. GARIBALDI's movements are attracting the most serious attention. It is asserted that he has refused positively to obey VICTOR EMANUEL's proclamation, and expects to march immediately against Rome. It is believed that he will soon be at the head of 50,000 volunteers.

abstract: The repulse of Gen. BRECKINRIDGE is one of the most signal victories yet achieved by the Union arms. The rebel chief came with sixteen regiments of infantry, a body of cavalry, and ten pieces of field artillery. Before he set out on the fatal march, he assured his soldiers that they would breakfast in the capital of the State. The feast they found in readiness was something they did not anticipate.

abstract: The work of fitting the building formerly used as the Merchants' Exchange, which was leased by the Government for Custom-house purposes, last April, has been sufficiently far advanced to admit of the removal thereto of a part of the business of the Department. The removal has been commenced, the Warehouse Department of the Collector's office having been transferred to the new building.
lead_paragraph: The work of fitting the building formerly used as the Merchants' Exchange, which was leased by the Government for Custom-house purposes, last April, has been sufficiently far advanced to admit of the removal thereto of a part of the business of the Department. The removal has been commenced, the Warehouse Department of the Collector's office having been transferred to the new building. The rooms occupied by the Department in the old Custom-house were located in the upper portion of the Sub-Treasury, and were, a few months since, renovated, altered and improved. The growing necessity of having in this City, the great financial centre of the country, a sufficiently commodious edifice in which the business of the Sub-Treasury could be transacted, induced the authorities at Washington to sign a lease with the owners of the Merchants' Exchange, by which the use of that building was ceded to the United States. The intention has been to use the building leased for the business of the Collector, Naval Officer, Surveyor, Appraisers, and other officers of the Customs, and to devote the old Custom-house on the corner of Wall, Nassau and Pine-streets, to the use of Mr. CISCO, the Sub-Treasurer. The apartments occupied by that gentleman at present, were found entirely too limited, the immensely increased business of his office having rendered it necessary to employ an additional clerical force. Even in the time of peace, when our outlay and income were insignificant compared with those of the present, the edifice used as the Sub-Treasury was deemed unsuitable for the purpose for which it was used, and the request was made to the Government to furnish a better one. This was not granted till last April, when the change was provided for, at the urgent request of Mr. CISCO.

abstract: The extraordinary activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, continues unabated. There are nearly 4,000 men employed in the different workshops, and in the laborers' gangs. Some of them are frequently at work night and day.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, continues unabated. There are nearly 4,000 men employed in the different workshops, and in the laborers' gangs. Some of them are frequently at work night and day. The ordnance department, in charge of Commander TEMPLE, is continually working at guns of every calibre, for the craft almost daily leaving the station for blockading and other service. The engineers' shop is as busy as if no engines were built outside. The blacksmiths, carpenters, stonecutters, and others are also incessurtly doing.

abstract: Around this stand were gathered the real "bone and sinew" of the metting. The rough and tattered but hearty and outspoken Celt, jostled the rosy-faced pilegmatic German, and decorating the interstices of the motley throng were bevies of America's fair daughters of the more Democratic order, making the historic hillside smile with many brilliant colors.
lead_paragraph: Around this stand were gathered the real "bone and sinew" of the metting. The rough and tattered but hearty and outspoken Celt, jostled the rosy-faced pilegmatic German, and decorating the interstices of the motley throng were bevies of America's fair daughters of the more Democratic order, making the historic hillside smile with many brilliant colors. The stand was not vast in space nor imposing in height, but its booth-like appearance was relieved by a most liberal festooning of flags of all nationalities, among which the ensign of Great Britain humbly dangled on the main flag-staff beneath the Star-Splangled Banner. The tri-color of France occupied a not much more exalted position, and the flags of many other haughty Powers fluttered in quiet obedience to the popular breath. The front of the platform was signalized by a large pattern of the American colors inscribed "Massachusetts," as a mark of special honor to the Old Bay State.

lead_paragraph: The appearance of the crowd about the stand, at the hour of commencement, did not promise very enthusiastic proceedings, most of those in that vicinity having been drawn one side by the music of a band stationed on the hill beyond. A requisition made on the musicians soon increased the number to a very respectable crowd, which rapidly augmented, as the meeting progressed, until all were present who could well get within reach of the speaker's voice. Among those at this stand we noticed Admiral PAULDING, Congressman ODELL, and other distinguished gentlemen.

abstract: We see it  stated that CASSIUS M. CLAY is to have a command in source Department of the West. We are glad of it. It will give scope to the very great ability which he hay always been reputed to possess, but which, through some unlucky combination of circumstances, he has never been able to use.
lead_paragraph: -- We see it stated that CASSIUS M. CLAY is to have a command in source Department of the West. We are glad of it. It will give scope to the very great ability which he hay always been reputed to possess, but which, through some unlucky combination of circumstances, he has never been able to use. It will gratify also that exuberant martial ardor which has led him to take the field two or three times already, though it has never yet enabled him to remain in it long enough to win any very ensanguined laurels. We trust he may have better luck hereafter.

lead_paragraph: Recruiting in Brooklyn has recently been dull. For this fact there are a variety of good reasons such as that several thousands of her young men are enlisted inn New-York City regiments, that other thousands are off with the Brooklyn quota heretofore sent away, that the contribution fund gotten in NewYork from merchants and Others has been raised to a large extent from gentlemen residing in Brooklyn, and others too numerous to mention, but all of which, however just, combined, are of no avail to protect the citizens of that goodly city from the swift approaching draft and the Government's inexorable demand for the required number of men.

lead_paragraph: The Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council, was in session in the City Hall during the whole of yesterday, receiving communications from the different Societies that desire to participate in the pageantry of the affair. A programme was, finally, agreed upon, and will be found in our advertising columns. Every Hibernian Association in the City is straining its utmost to make the spectacle a splendid one.

abstract: There was no diminution of the lately aroused enthusiasm for volunteering to be noticed yesterday. Recruits for regiments in the field came in rapidly, and a very large number joined the new organizations being raised in the City and neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: There was no diminution of the lately aroused enthusiasm for volunteering to be noticed yesterday. Recruits for regiments in the field came in rapidly, and a very large number joined the new organizations being raised in the City and neighborhood. There was an immense influx of business to the United States mustering office, and the officials there had hard work 10 inspect and swear in all the applicants brought to them for that purpose. All the camps where the new regiments are stationed were in a marvelously lively condition. Squads of men desirous of being enrolled arrived every hour, and the Adjutants and Doctors there were kept busy until nearly dark.

abstract: The remains of the late Brig.-Gen. WILLIAMS, who fell at the battle of Baton Rouge, were conveyed from this City to Newburgh on Tuesday evening, in charge of the Committee appointed by the Common Council.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Brig.-Gen. WILLIAMS, who fell at the battle of Baton Rouge, were conveyed from this City to Newburgh on Tuesday evening, in charge of the Committee appointed by the Common Council. The body was delivered to the Town Council of Newburgh, who escorted the remains from the boat to St. George's Church -- the bells of the city tolling meanwhile. On arriving at the church, Alderman CHIPP formally surrendered the remains to the family of the deceased, through Rev. Dr. BROWN, in the following remarks:

abstract: -- We give place in another column to a letter addressed to the Tribune by WENDELL PHILLIPS. The concession is all the more willingly made because the distinguished Abolitionist therein takes occasion to place himself in a far better position, so far as his relations with the Government are concerned, than he occupied in making his Abingdon speech. Dissenting, as we are so often constrained to dissent, from the radical and intemperate views of Mr. PHILLIPS -- views which would be less liable to do harm, if they were not recommended by matchless graces of rhetoric -- it is true, in the present instance, to say the orator acquits himself of any premeditated disloyalty, and shows that he has zealously promoted enlistments in Massachusetts, and only leaves us to regret his imprudence in uniformly using such topics in denunciation of the Government, as tend to beget indifference as to its perpetuation, and indirectly discourage those who would else hasten to its defence.

abstract: -- This is the caption of an article in the Richmond Enquirer of Wednesday of last week, which states the fact of Gen. MCCLELLAN's moving his troops from Harrison's Bar down the James River on transports. It closes by saying that "MCCLELLAN is running away by night -- or, to speak more politely, is making another grand strategic move." There can be no doubt whatever that the rebels knew all about Gen. MCCLELLAN's movement from Harrison's Landing, from its inception to its close, although the Northern Press refrained from chronicling it until it had been effected; just as they knew all about the progress of the movement of our army on to the Peninsula a half year ago, although the public here were absolutely in the dark about it for some time after the army had got there. At least the Richmond Press, both now and then, published details of both movements, from day to day, as they progressed.

abstract: Editorial on Great Britain and France being asked to recognize Confederacy
snippet: Editorial on Great Britain and France being asked to recognize Confederacy
lead_paragraph: It seems from the telegraphic summary of European news by the Europa that our transatlantic friends are still breaking their teeth and making wry faces over that hard, rough, terrible nut, the American question. We have it in every variety of form, and on both sides of the Channel, in the Press, on the platform, in the Legislature and in the Cabinet. The prorogation of Parliament having put a stop to the outpourings of the collective wisdom of England, the members have carried the all-abserbing topic into the popular assembly PAM. has been making a speech on the subject to the cutlers of Sheffield, though all we are told of its character is that it advocated non-interference in American affairs. This is certainly a notable circumstance, as it shows the Prime Minister is openly committed to a neutral policy during the recess of Parliament. It has been urged by some, who think they see further into a millstone than other people, that the real danger of intervention would be when the close of the session of Parliament should leave the Cabinet free to act on its own responsibility. But here we have its head coming before a popular assembly and frankly counseling a continuance of the same neutral policy which England has hitherto held. Coming on the heels of the recent debates in the Lords and Commons, and the Queen's speech on the occasion of the prorogation of Parliament, it should be a sufficient quietus to the croakings of intervention which some find a mysterious pleasure in giving forth. With this official reassurance from Lord PALMERSTON, nobody probably will care a straw for the outgivings of ROEBUCK, who is reported to have followed the Prime Minister in a speech, urging the claims of the rebel Confederacy to be such as entitled it to recognition by England as an independent Government.
headline: {'main': 'England, France and the Confederacy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England, France and the Confederacy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Collector has issued an order setting forth the rates of duty which are to be levied on the arrival of goods which, paying a specific duty, have not been weighed, measured, guaged, or examined by the officers of the Customs. Since the passage of the Morrill Tariff, it has been found necessary to levy duties in this manner, as it is impossible to ascertain the weight in some cases, the quality in others, the guage in others, of articles on which importers wish to pay duty immediately on arrival. An ad valorem duty, sufficiently large to cover the probable true amount, is levied, and in case it is afterwards found to exceed the latter, the excess is refunded.
