abstract: -- The Richmond Dispatch of last Saturday urges upon the Rebel Congress, now in session, the absolute necessity of extending the Conscription Act to all persons within the ages of sixteen and fifty-five years -- the material between eighteen and thirty-five being now exhausted. By this means it is believed the rebels will be able to raise a force equal to the 600,000 Yankees which LINCOLN has now called for, as the journal in question shows that it is necessary for the Confederates to have a force equal to LINCOLN. If this measure be carried into effect it will certainly pretty nearly clean out every vestige of the white man from the Southern States. The beardless lads of sixteen and the gray-beards of fifty-five -- those whose calves are yet ungrown, and those whose calves are shriveled up, must all don their uniforms, grasp their muskets, if they can find them, and march to the music of rebellion. There will be nothing in the shape of masculine humanity (of the white variety,) in all Dixie, except very small boys and very old codgers. There will be no one able-bodied enough even to maul the niggers, who will have to assign that necessary duty to each other. If JEFF. DAVIS' despotism was anything less absolute than death, it would be impossible to enforce such a scheme as this; but this or anything else will be enforced, if necessary. We have still an advantage over the rebels, however, in the fact that our immense levies were called out two months before the old and young rebel conscripts can be; and, if they are pushed forward with proper rapidity, will be in the field fighting the present rebel army long before anything can be done in the way of raising this new one.

abstract: News from Confederate States; official report from Morgan on his guerrilla raids into Kentucky

lead_paragraph: GENERAL: I have the honor to report that, upon the day of the engagement at Tompinsville, a full report of which I have already sent you, I moved my command -- consisting of my own regiment, the Geor gia regiment of partisan rangers, commanded by Col. A.A. HUNT, and Major GANO's Texas squadron, to which was attached two companies of Tennessee cavalry -- in the direction of Glasgow, which place I reached at 12 o'clock last night.

abstract: FIVE THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS EMBEZZLED BY A NEW-YORK CLARK. A case of embezzlement of considerable interest, owing in part to the amount involved, was brought before Justice BRENNAN yesterday afternoon at the Lower Police Court.
lead_paragraph: FIVE THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS EMBEZZLED BY A NEW-YORK CLARK. -- A case of embezzlement of considerable interest, owing in part to the amount involved, was brought before Justice BRENNAN yesterday afternoon at the Lower Police Court. The offender is a young Scotchman, aged 23 years, named CHARLES W. BANKS. At the time of the commission of the offence he was in the employ of Mr. CORNELIUS DE LAMATER, iron merchant in West Fifteenth-street. Last Monday his employer handed him a check upon the New-York County Bank for the sum of $3,500, and also another check for $2,000, all of which BANKS was requested to draw and return to his employer. The day passed, and the clerk did not return. On Tuesday, BANKS not having made his appearance, the employer began to grow uneasy about his money, and be therefore dispatched Mr. PAYE, his foreman, in pursuit of the delinquent clerk. The latter was traced to Tarrytown, Nyack and Piermont, on the Hudson. At the last-named place, it was found that at a late hour on Tuesday evening, BANKS had taken the cars of the New-York and Erie Railroad for the West. Mr. PAYE continued his pursuit, and at Middletown, in Orange County, where the pursuer stopped to make inquiries, the absconding clerk was found secreted in an upper room of a hotel. He was immediately taken into custody by Constable ADAMS, of Middletown, and upon a search of his person and effects being made, the sum of $4 795 was found, the most of it in bills of the New-York County Bank. Yesterday he was brought to New-York, and after a preliminary hearing before Justice BRENNAN, he was committed to the Tombs in default of $5,000 bail. He has confessed his guilt, and says that it is the first time that he has been guilty of the commission of any crime. After he had obtained the money from the bank, and before leaving the City, he changed his clothes, put on a red shirt and military cap and boots, and had his hair and whiskers cut off quite close. The unfortunate young man had been about two years with Mr. DE LAMATER, and hitherto, so far as is known, his reputation has been good. He says that after he left the City he became so nervous, bewildered and conscience-stricken that he did not know what course to pursue. He therefore wandered around from place to place upon the Hudson and vicinity, until he was captured.

abstract: There was quite a commotion among the Knickerbocker Icemen in Furman-street, near Fulton, yesterday afternoon, caused by an unfortunate negro, who happened to pass by where a number of the others were congregated. Some uncomplimentary terms were applied to the colored man, which he answered, when he wasattacked, but being a strong, muscular chap, he handled those about him rather roughly. When the crowd became too large, and he was in danger of being badly used, he picked up a stone, and hit one of the attacking party, named JOHNNY LYNCH, on the head, inflicting a pretty severe wound. This made the crowd more furious, and having collected by this time to the number of over a hundred, they pursued the negro and beat him, and would have demolished him altogether but for the opportune arrival of two officers of the Forty-second Precinct police. The colored man was escorted to the Station-house, but the crowd did not venture to pursue him any further. As there were no charges against him, he was permitted to go.

abstract: Sarsfield vs. Van Vaughan et al. -- The former Court of Chancery never entertained an action where the matter in dispute did not exceed $50. This practice obtained by virtue of its inherent power, and without the express sanction of any act of the Legislature. The latter, by its silence, recognized this power, and never attempted to interfere with it until it provided, in the Revised Statutes, that the Court of Chancery should dismiss every suit where the matter in dispute does not exceed the value of $100. The only effect of this was to enlarge the amount from $50 to $100. This provision of the Revised Statutes was repealed by the Legislature during the last session, the effect of which was to reduce the amount again from $100 to $50. It in no respect interferes with the power which the Court of Chancery for so long a period exercised on this subject. It is an ancient and well established principle that if a statute, which repeals or modifies another statute, or a rule, is itself subsequently repealed, the first statute or rule is thereby revived, without any formal words for that purpose. This Court, as the successor of the Court of Chancery, possesses all its powers, and I think convenience requires that the rule in question should on preserved.

abstract: Editorial urges NYC enforce martial law to prevent rioting when draft is effected
snippet: Editorial urges NYC enforce martial law to prevent rioting when draft is effected
lead_paragraph: A morning paper says that it is contemplated to enforce martial law in the City next week. The statement is hardly news. For all practical intents and purposes, the City has been under martial law for the past ten days. It has had a Provost-Marshal, a Provost Guard, the free transit of passengers has been interrupted without a resort to any legal forms, and men have been placed under arrest for saying in private what could do no possible harm if proclaimed from the housetop. These interruptions of the common law privileges and immunities of the person, can only be justified, if justifiable at all, by the military code. They find no warrant under civil authority. Next week, in view of the draft, it may be necessary to give new stringency to the present restrictions. Cowards and traitors will find their names drafted, and may attempt to escape; mobs may be fomented by the concealed labors of rebel sympathizers; the service of the draft-notices may require, in some instances, the exhibition of more than ordinary force. To guard against such mischievous contingencies, it may be proper to be thoroughly armed at all points, and authority should perhaps be given, even to the irresponsible extent of martial law, to those who are charged with the preservation of public order.

abstract: Editorial lauds NYC police for raising military regiment to be called Metropolitan Guards
snippet: Editorial lauds NYC police for raising military regiment to be called Metropolitan Guards
lead_paragraph: -- It was a capital idea, first suggested by Secretary SEWARD, to take advantage of the Police organization for the purpose of raising a regiment in this City. It is obvious, at a glance, what an admirable ready-made engine of recruiting the Police force is eligible to be turned into. Each patrolman becomes a recruiting sergeant, each station-house a recruiting station; and thus at one stroke the Government obtains in this City alone a couple of thousand active efficient enlisting officers and forty or fifty rendezvous for recruits, and all, too, without the expenditure of a dollar. The mattter, however, was not allowed to remain a mere idea, but steps were immediately taken to give it practical effect. The success has already been so great that not only is one regiment now under formation, but a second one has been begun, and both are filling up with great rapidity. These regiments, to be called the Metropolitan Guards, have their rendezvous, the one on Riker's Island and the other on Staten Island; and the first already counts 500, while the second has 300 men on its muster-roll. Indeed, so briskly is the business going on that it is now quite certain that a full brigade of Metropolitan Guards, composed of first-rate fighting material will be formed and ready for marching orders before the 1st of September.

abstract: The city was all alive yesterday. Recruiting officers were seen everywhere, some with one, two, and even with six or eight men, on the way to the different head-quarters. The recruiting tents in the City Hall Park increased to nine, and the drums in...
lead_paragraph: The city was all alive yesterday. Recruiting officers were seen everywhere, some with one, two, and even with six or eight men, on the way to the different head-quarters. The recruiting tents in the City Hall Park increased to nine, and the drums in front of each kept up the music from morning till night. Tents have also been pitched in Washington Park, the City Park, at the Navy-yard, and at other eligible points. The whole city, in fact, begins to wear a military aspect. The people are aroused, the wealthy men are coming forward with their contributions, and the consequence is that men of the right stamp are enlisting in squads.

abstract: The steamer Champion arrived at this port last night, from Aspinwall on the 11th inst. She was delayed six days at Aspinwall, waiting for the arrival of the Golden Gate at Panama. She brings about $21,000 in specie from Aspinwall, and but few passengers. Affairs at Panama remain quiet.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Champion arrived at this port last night, from Aspinwall on the 11th inst. She was delayed six days at Aspinwall, waiting for the arrival of the Golden Gate at Panama. She brings about $21,000 in specie from Aspinwall, and but few passengers. Affairs at Panama remain quiet. Accounts from Bogota to the 16th ult. represent the cause of MOSQUERA as progressing favorably. The Liberals appear to be on the eve of establishing themselves permanently as the ruling party in the republic of Columbia. The Champion brings later news from Central and South America, but nothing of special importance, politically. The principal intelligence from Peru relates to the loss of the British steamer Lima, which occurred on the 11th of July. She struck upon a reef off the Lagento Islands, some fifty-five miles southward of Cobija.

abstract: One of the great masters of the military art has told us that "the transition from the defensive to the offensive is one of the most difficult and delicate operations of war." The rebels have proved the truth of this maxim in the recent events of the Peninsular campaign.
lead_paragraph: One of the great masters of the military art has told us that "the transition from the defensive to the offensive is one of the most difficult and delicate operations of war." The rebels have proved the truth of this maxim in the recent events of the Peninsular campaign. For, contrary to what is usual when an army retreats before superior numbers, the sole immediate result achieved by the much-vaunted seven days' fighting of June and July last was that the rebel loss in killed and wounded fell but little below our own, while they were forced to give up their new offensive attitude, to postpone indefinitely their projected raid on Washington, and to forego the hopeful schemes for levying contributions on the Northern cities, which they had announced with all the vain-glorious confidence of reckless and needy marauders.
headline: {'main': 'Peninsular Strategy of the Rebels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Peninsular Strategy of the Rebels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac, as will be seen by our correspondence, has all arrived in the vicinity of Fortress Monroe, and at last accounts was making rapid preparations for departure to its new field of operations -- wherever that may be. In connection with this announcement we give the following, from the Hartford Post of yesterday, for what it is worth: "We have private but direct and reliable information that Gen. MCCLELLAN will resign the command of the Army of the Potomac as soon as the new change of position is effected. The visit of the President to the Peninsula, soon after the battle-week, is said to have had connection with this event."

abstract: Coroner MORRIS held an inquest on Tuesday upon the body of CHARLES STEVENS, who was killed in an affray in an oyster saloon on the corner of Myrtle-avenue ...
lead_paragraph: Coroner MORRIS held an inquest on Tuesday upon the body of CHARLES STEVENS, who was killed in an affray in an oyster saloon on the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Pearl-street, on Monday night, by the proprietor, JOHN DAILEY. It appears that the deceased and a companion named EDWARD O'CONNER entered the saloon about 11 o'clock and called for some oysters. One of the party, as alleged, placed the catsup bottle in the butter-dish, which incensed the proprietor, and he ordered them out. O'CONNER went quietly, but STEVENS hesitated, and a quarrel ensued, when DAILEY struck him two blows, causing him to fall upon the steps with his head, and resulted in almost instant death. The following is the evidence:

abstract: A highly interesting meeting took place last evening at Clark's Hotel, No. 94 Chatham-street. It was a congregation of returned prisoners for the purpose of arranging to participate in the reception of Gen. CORCORAN and the other Union officers recently released from Southern captivity.
lead_paragraph: A highly interesting meeting took place last evening at Clark's Hotel, No. 94 Chatham-street. It was a congregation of returned prisoners for the purpose of arranging to participate in the reception of Gen. CORCORAN and the other Union officers recently released from Southern captivity. Such cordial greetings are rarely seen as here took place between old comrades, who had together braved the dangers of the battle-field, together fallen into the hands of a merciless foe, and together endured the hardships of Southern prisons. They were almost entirely representatives of the City regiments captured at Bull Run, who were subjected to all the barbarities which Southern malignity could invent, before the fortunes of War taught them that one side could capture prisoners as well as another. There were men who had for months lived in the foulest atmosphere, without sufficient food, and goaded to desperation by the taunts of unfeeling captors; men who had been wounded and now carried maimed limbs or honorable scars as mementoes of their devotion to the Union. But how changed since last they met? Many had so improved since their return that it was almost impossible for their old comrades to recognize them. But, a familiar expression, a cant word, a favorite allusion, a peculiar voice or a well known scar often recalled in a moment the dear memories of good fellowship. Among those present were the following:

abstract: Editorial on enlisting Negroes in Union Army
snippet: Editorial on enlisting Negroes in Union Army
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable how much fuss resolute zealots can make over a very small matter. Two or three of our smaller States, to judge from the noise made in them, are quite convulsed on the subject of enlisting blacks as soldiers to fight in the ranks of the Union army. GOV. SPRAGUE is busy enrolling a regiment of this class of troops, -- the Attorney-General of Massachusetts has promulgated an opinion that they cannot constitutionally be overlooked in drafting men for the war, and an able correspondent of the TIMES, writing in another column, protests vehemently against allowing negroes to shirk their share of fighting. They are men and citizens, he urges, and therefore have not only a right to be soldiers also, but should by no means be exempt from the corresponding duty.

abstract: -- The news from Mexico is not of a decisive character. The French keep close within their lines at Orizaba, depending upon very hazardous communications with Vera Cruz for their supplies. The Mexicans have not thought it prudent to attack the position; and, indeed, until the difficulties between the military leaders are extinguished, any active operations must be impracticable. Whether the nomination of COMONFORT to the chief command will have this effect remains to be seen. The only point favorable to the National cause, is the absence of any acts or successes on the side of the Mexicans that could offend the French amour propre, and lend the Imperial Government an enthusiastic popular support, which it now lacks, and without which the war must continue to languish.

abstract: -- Mr. STEWART L. WOODFORD, Assistant District-Attorney, is reported in another column as leaving a valuable office under Government to serve in the army. The sacrifice is creditable to Mr. WOODFORD, but similar instances of official devotion to the National cause are not wanting, nor have they lacked the public approval which a manly fulfillment of duty always secures. The several National departments of public service have not failed to give evidence of hearty patriotism in the crisis. Postmaster WAKEMAN set the example, well imitated by his subordinates. Stimulated by the spontaneous effort of the Post-office, where the small number of clerks and the small salaries shame the Custom-house, with its legion of employes at high pay, Collector BARNEY is moving tardily in securing a few recruits for the army, and may perhaps be regarded as doing his duty. From the office of Mr. CISCO we have yet to hear; but we shall doubtless hear to very good purpose when the subscription is announced. The District-Attorney has made the sacrifice from his small staff of a capital associate; it is possible Marshal MURRAY will spare a Deputy or two.

abstract: PATRIOTISM IN THE EIGHTH PRECINCT. Capt. HELME, of the Eighth Precinct, made a report yesterday, at Police Headquarters, that within the last few days he had collected the sum of $219, in cash, and had received subscriptions to the amount of over $400, from residents of his Precinct, all of which is to be applied to the relief of the families of those who ...
lead_paragraph: PATRIOTISM IN THE EIGHTH PRECINCT. -- Capt. HELME, of the Eighth Precinct, made a report yesterday, at Police Headquarters, that within the last few days he had collected the sum of $219, in cash, and had received subscriptions to the amount of over $400, from residents of his Precinct, all of which is to be applied to the relief of the families of those who volunteer in the regiments organized under the supervision of the Metropolitan Police. The most remarkable fact about this contribution is, that in a block in this Precinct, commonly known as "Rotten Row," the Captain obtained the sum of $19 75, cash, all in sums of 25 and 50 cents, which the poor people of that vicinity have contributed for the purpose of carrying on the war.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 18th inst. Mr. S. FITZGERALD wished to direct the attention of the noble lord at the head of the Government to the proceedings of the United States cruisers in the immediate neighborhood of Nassau.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 18th inst. Mr. S. FITZGERALD wished to direct the attention of the noble lord at the head of the Government to the proceedings of the United States cruisers in the immediate neighborhood of Nassau. On a former occasion it had been stated in that House that the United States squadron was actively engaged in enforcing the blockade on the coast of the United States; but, it appeared their cruisers had since been withdrawn, and they were now employed in blockading British ports. There could be no doubt, indeed, that the United States authorities had pressed, and were pressing to the utmost, without moderation or discretion, the rights which they might possess as belligerents, and he hoped the noble ford would give the House an assurance that this matter would not escape the notice of the Government; but that on the contrary, the most vigorous and earnest remonstrances would be made to the United States Government on the subject. He might also take that opportunity of referring to certain proceedings adopted by the Untied States authorities with respect to British goods at New-York. Hitherto it had been the practice to send British goods to New-York in steamers, and afterward to forward them in American bottoms to Nassau. It now appeared that the United States Government would not permit these goods to be exported from New-York unless the owners entered into a bond that the future owners of the goods at Nassau should not ship them either to the Confederate States, or to any port in communication with them. He hoped the noble lord would also give the House an assurance that this matter would be made the subject of a vigorous remonstrance to the United States Government. [Hear, hear.]

lead_paragraph: -- The magnificent mailed frigate New-Ironsides, of whose progress we have given details from time to time, is now fairly completed, and yesterday left Philadelphia in high spirit, and amid the applause of admiring citizens. She is an exceedingly formidable vessel, and, though not built on the Monitor style or theory -- the contract for her was given out prior to the Ericsson era -- she is constructed on the most modern and scientific principles, and is believed to be of the most serviceable build and on the most available plan for the kind of work to which she is to be assigned. What her first labor is to be is not known, as she sailed with sealed orders, and Mr. WELLES has not permitted it to leak out. The only thing stated is that she has gone in a southerly direction -- doubtless to operate somewhere between Chesapeake Bay and Galveston Bay. Ten days ago we might have thought she was going to do service in the James; but that is unlikely now. Is she going to Savannah, to fight the great ram Fingal and capture the city? or is she going to steam past Fort Sumter and into Charleston Harbor, for it is asserted that that is within her power? or is she going down to Mobile to challenge the "ten iron-clad English rams," for beholding which an unhappy fabricator is now doing penance in Alton Penitentiary? or is she going to assist PORTER in capturing Mobile itself? Is she going down to New-Orleans, to render that perilously-situated city secure from rebel rams and other assaults? There is a great deal more work than this that she might do on the coast and on one or two rivers which she can penetrate; but as she has already gone about her first labor, and is a swift craft, it would be as well for us to wait patiently a few days. But it is given out by those who pretend to know, that she is going on a mission whose greatness, importance, and almost assured success, will speedily gratify the country, and furnish another proof of the power of iron-clad vessels.

abstract: A war meeting was held at Smithtown, Long Island, on Monday, Aug. 18. The people turned out to a body, determined that the necessity for drafting from this town shall not exist. $8,000 were voted to be raised by the town, to be expended in bounties, to promote volunteering, and a Committee appointed to canvass the town and induce men to come forward to the help of our country.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall on Tuesday evening, Aug. 19, Hon. JOHN R. JOHNSTON, Mayor of the city, presided. It was revolved that a bounty of $150 be paid to each person volunteering before Sept. 1, both three years' and nine months' men.
lead_paragraph: A large and enthusiastic meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall on Tuesday evening, Aug. 19, Hon. JOHN R. JOHNSTON, Mayor of the city, presided. It was revolved that a bounty of $150 be paid to each person volunteering before Sept. 1, both three years' and nine months' men. The three years' volunteers will receive in addition the County bounty of $50 and State bounty of $12 per month to married men, and $6 per month single men. The nine months' men will also receive the State bounty. A large amount of money was subscribed and paid, sufficient to warrant the payment of the bounty to the quota required from Hoboken. The meeting adjourned to meet at the Hoboken House on Thursday evening.

abstract: Advisers from the City of Mexico to the 28th ult., from Orizaba to the 26th, and from Vera Cruz to the 1st inst., have reached us by way of Havana. The position of the respective forces of France and Mexico continues the same. The former were still at Orizaba, awaiting orders and reinforcements, and their sanitary condition is ...
lead_paragraph: Advisers from the City of Mexico to the 28th ult., from Orizaba to the 26th, and from Vera Cruz to the 1st inst., have reached us by way of Havana. The position of the respective forces of France and Mexico continues the same. The former were still at Orizaba, awaiting orders and reinforcements, and their sanitary condition is represented as good. The difficulty of communication between Vera Cruz and Orizaba is represented as very great, and is not undertaken unless with a cunvoy of 800 or 1,000 men. Affairs in the interior are as unsettled as ever, and it is stated that several of the reactionary chiefs have been shot. The French corvette Bayonnaise, which was blockading Mazatlan, has left that port. The steamer Marceau, which was blockading Tampico, is in Vera Cruz. She brought in four prizes, coasting vessels. The Eclair is no longer in the waters of Alvarado. The Grenade bombarded the port of Campeachy, destroying several houses, but was driven off by a schooner, the Pizarro, hastily armed by the authorities. The French steamer Tampico arrived at Santiago de Cuba on the 8th, reports 25,000 men as having arrived at and on their way to Martinique, and that the same day she sailed from there two frigates and two steamers, with 4,000 troops, left for Vera Cruz. The Tampico carries 128 of the corps of engineers of Martinique to the same port.

abstract: Editorial on report Cherokee Indians in South will adhere to Confederate Government; Editorial on report Cherokees in South will adhere to Confederate Government
snippet: Editorial on report Cherokee Indians in South will adhere to Confederate Government; Editorial on report Cherokees in South will adhere to Confederate Government
lead_paragraph: -- The Cherokees, if we may believe the Granada Appeal and other authorities, have finally decided to adhere to the rebels, and to fulfill the terms of the treaty which some months ago was exacted from them by threats. There can, however, be no doubt that the sympathies of the venerable chief ROSS, and of a large portion of his people, are with the National Government. For, from the year 1838, when they emigrated to their present location, as well as in earlier times, the paternal policy which the Government at Washington has ever preserved towards the Indians, stands in strong contrast with the outrages and exactions of Georgia and the other Southern States with which they are now in alliance. The Cherokees, at the time of the settlement of the Carolinas and Georgia, were a nation of fire-worshippers, who seemed endued with nobler qualities, and capable of a higher progress, both social and civil, than their Indian neighbors. They originally owned the whole of this mountain region, but their domains had been contracted, as some of their tribes had been induced to sell their lands. Changing by degrees their habits, and discarding their nomadic modes of life, they borrowed the civilization, and embraced the purer faith of the white man, and, cultivating agriculture and the arts of peace, they had become strongly attached to their rich and fertile fields, of which for centuries they and their fathers had held undisputed possession. One of their tribe had invented an alphabet, and they had established a newspaper and schools.

abstract: A dinner was given to Gen. WILCOX last evening, at the Athenaeum Club, Fifth-avenue, by our fellow-citizen, WM. P. BLODGETT, Esq., in which he was joined by a few personal friends of the General. Among the distinguished guests were Major-Gen. MITCHEL, Mayor OPDYKE, Hon. HIRAM BARNEY, CHAS, H. MARSHALL, Esq., DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Gen. ASBOTH, Col. BAYLEY MEYERS, Col. F.E. HOWE Capt. HODGES and others, all of whom made short and capital speeches, which, as the occasion was not of a public nature, we refrain from publishing. The speech of Gen. MITCHEL was one of the most beautiful and patriotic efforts of the astronomer General. Gen. WILCOX, inclosing a very interesting account of his prison experience, which he modestly requested would not be made public, expressed himself as laying no claims to be considered a martyr, and only hoped for recognition of such services as he may be enabled to render his country in the field, to which he ardently wished he might be speedily assigned.

abstract: The Confederates have, on many occasions, manifested no small degree of superstition in their conduct and judgment of affairs. They exhibit a singular mixture of perfidy and fanaticism with piety and policy. They affect a
lead_paragraph: The Confederates have, on many occasions, manifested no small degree of superstition in their conduct and judgment of affairs. They exhibit a singular mixture of perfidy and fanaticism with piety and policy. They affect a perfect intimacy with the designs of Providence in their behalf, and accept all their misfortunes as evidences of Divine favor conferring upon them blessings in disguise. The loss of Kentucky and Tennessee in the West; of New-Orleans and the mouth of the Mississippi in the South; of Beaufort, Newbern, Norfolk and the Navy-yard in the East, were only so many means of grace to the rebel Government. It taught them that they had "attempted too much," and with becoming meekness they gave up what they could not keep, and made themselves happy with what they had. They accepted the Christian text: "He that humbleth himself shall be exalted." But unless they find this truth realized in their case they will undobtedly be disappointed and vexed. They will lose their patience and perhaps censure the Divine economy for having too much respect for the Lincoln Government.

abstract: Pacific Mutual Insurance Company vs. Henry M. Bearns, et al. The plaintiffs in this action recovered judgment against John A. Machado for $6,000 in February last, and after executions returned brought this action against the present defendants as bail for...
lead_paragraph: Pacific Mutual Insurance Company vs. Henry M. Bearns, et al. -- The plaintiffs in this action recovered judgment against John A. Machado for $6,000 in February last, and after executions returned brought this action against the present defendants as bail for said Machado, under an order of arrest issued against him. Defendants set up that since this action was commenced. MACHADO had obtained from City Judge MCCUNN, a discharge, exempting him from imprisonment upon any debts arising upon contract, and moved to dismiss this action and discharge the bail from liability on their bond. The plaintiffs averred that the discharge was void, for frauds of said Machado, and also for various irregularities. The motion was heard before Judge INGRAHAM and denied, but with leave given to renew the motion on explaining the facts upon which plaintiffs relied in disputing the validity of the discharge. On the renewal of the motion the plaintiffs reiterated their objections, and applied on petition for a certiorari to review the discharge.

abstract: The City was profoundly agitated yesterday by rumors of disaster threatening the army in Virginia. The Government, controlling the telegraph, prevented the Press from receiving any news through that medium; but did not prevent private parties from obtaining, by the help of cipher, full intelligence of all that was occurring. These reports, passing from mouth to mouth, and exaggerated at every transmission, created a serious panic, which the absence of any different intelligence from the lines served to augment. Against these evils, the product of official errors, we are unable to guard the public; as we are also unable to lay before it that correct intelligence which would allay apprehension. We can only say that up to the moment the paper goes to press there has been no encounter between the Union and rebel forces in Virginia, and that Washington is not in danger.

abstract: Editorial on good response to appeals for military volunteers
snippet: Editorial on good response to appeals for military volunteers
lead_paragraph: It is, as we may now all see, a very fortunate circumstance that the commencement of drafting was put off from the 15th of the current month to the 1st of September. The delay has enabled the country to recover completely from the recoil produced by the failure of the Peninsular campaign; and the interval of a fortnight thus gained for volunteering, bids fair to see the enlistment of more men than were enrolled during the six weeks following the call of the President.

abstract: JOHN RILEY was arrested yesterday for committing an unprovoked assault upon a colored man in Furman-street, on Wednesday -- the some who was nearly killed by an infuriated mob. RILEY was brought before Justice PERRY, and committed for further examination. The accused deserted from the Fourteenth Brooklyn regiment after the battle of Bull Run. He was arrested twice and sent back, but escaped each time.

abstract: The Eighteenth Regiment Connecticut Volunteers, Col. WM. G. ELY, which was expected to arrive this afternoon, we learn by a later dispatch, will not reach here until early Saturday morning. The steamer will land at Pier No. 2 North River, and the regiment will at once proceed to the seat of war by the New-Jersey Central route.

abstract: -- A correspondent in another column furnishes some evidence of the disinclination of the Central American States to receive negro immigrants. If these representations be correct, as we have reasons, from other sources, to believe, it will be necessary for the Government to seek some other home for the exported negroes. The Brazilians have none of the hostility to black labor which seems to be general in the Spanish American States. Why not turn some of the dreams of that runaway rebel and scientific humbug, Lieut. MAURY, to the advantage of the negro? Why not, in short, with our outcast Africans, found an Empire of the Amazon? We have only to treat with Dom PEDRO II., and the thing will be halt accomplished.

abstract: THE RAVELS AT NIBLO's GARDEN. GABRIEL RAVEL and company are having things pretty much their own way in the amusement line  of business. They have dispelled the gentle dullness that pervaded the theatrical atmosphere up to the period of their advent, and once again delight one's ...
lead_paragraph: THE RAVELS AT NIBLO's GARDEN. -- GABRIEL RAVEL and company are having things pretty much their own way in the amusement line of business. They have dispelled the gentle dullness that pervaded the theatrical atmosphere up to the period of their advent, and once again delight one's eyes and ears with crowded audiences, uproarious laughter and genuine applause. Niblo's resumes its old-time appearance of Summer life and gaiety, and is again the most popular -- as it has ever been the handsomest and pleasantest -- place of public entertainment in the country. The Ravel people have had no occasion to produce anything that can be called a novelty as yet. They have simply revived five or six of the most popular pantomimes and ballets in their repertory, putting these upon the stage in their usual style of unapproachable neatness and good taste, and, with them, attracting as large a portion of the playgoing community as they can comfortably provide with seats. The only attempt they have made at a sensation has been the introduction of the wonderfully clever child -- known in private life as little JOHN HASLEM, and on the bills as "Young America" -- in perilous gymnastic feats, that no one, save the HANLONS, have ever, in the memory of the present generation, rivaled. This boy, who is, withal, one of the prettiest fellows that ever circled brows with acrobatic fillet, does things, which, tried by ordinary juveniles, would make the nervous system tingle with suppressed emotion; but which, achieved as they are by him with a certainty and ease that divest them of all symptoms of danger, inspire in his beholders feelings of unmingled admiration and delight. Without any RAVELS or preliminary dramatic performances, such as are included in the programme at NIBLO's, he alone might be relied on as a profitable exhibition; and, one of these days, if good luck carries him up to manhood with unfractured limbs, he will undoubtedly have an Academy of Music all to himself, as WILLIAM HANLON had, and make a fortune on his individual account.

abstract: The news  from the West to-day continues to be of that exciting and feverish character that has pre  vailed for several weeks past. The Mayor of Henderson, Ky., the next town to Paducah in importance on the lower Ohio, in that State, has openly declared his sympathy with ...
lead_paragraph: -- The news from the West to-day continues to be of that exciting and feverish character that has pre vailed for several weeks past. The Mayor of Henderson, Ky., the next town to Paducah in importance on the lower Ohio, in that State, has openly declared his sympathy with secession. This sympathy existed before, and has only now ripened into action. It is better to be so, for he is now deprived of office and unable to do the harm that he otherwise might have done.

abstract: By the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Teutonia, we receive advices from Europe three days later than by the Europa. The most important news by this arrival, relates to Italian affairs. The Italian squadron had been ordered to Ancona, to watch the Adriatic coast. GARIBALDI, with five hundred volunteers, was on the march, and supposed to be trying to reach Messina. He had occupied Rocca, and had made a speech, in which he declared that he opposed the Government because it would not let him go to Rome; and opposed France because she defended the Pope. He expressed his determination to have Rome or die. From France we have the rumor that the Mexican expeditionary force will be very large. The choicest officers and men of the Versailles Artillery are said to be under orders. A division of gunboats for Mexico was also being armed. The distress in the cotton districts of England is increasing. The Liverpool cotton market was quiet and steady for American varieties. Breadstuffs were generally quiet and steady. Provisions were unsettled.

abstract: -- CHAS. FASSIN a clerk in the employ of GUSTAVUS FREYGANG, No. 133 West Broadway, was arrested yesterday, upon the charge of having embezzled the sum of $450 of his employer's money. The prisoner was taken before Justice BRENNAN, where, during his examination, he denied the charge, and stated that it was a conspiracy on the part of FREYGANG and others to defraud him out of $4,000 worth of property. FASSIN was committed for examination.

abstract: MARTIN HEATH and THOMAS CARROLL got into a fight yesterday at the corner of Hoyt and Degraw streets, when HEATH, as alleged, struck CARROLL a violent blow, which knocked him over an embankment about twenty feet high, causing a fracture of one arm and leg. The injured man was conveyed to the City Hospital. HEATH made his escape.

abstract: I regret the necessity of recording the almost entire failure of the International Horse Fair, which commenced in this city yesterday, and which gave promise of reaching a degree of success equal to any Fair the Association has yet given to the horse-breeding public. abstract: Yesterday, one hundred and sixty men were enlisted in Col. CONK'S Senatorial Regiment, and eighty-two in the First Regiment Empire Brigade-- Col. JOURDAN. The parade of the First Regiment, which was to have taken place yesterday, was postponed in consequence of the reception of Gen. CORCORAN in New-York. The tents expected for this regiment on Saturday will not be forthcoming until Wednesday next, when the encampment will be formed on the parade-ground at East New-York.

The tents expected for this regiment on Saturday will not be forthcoming until Wednesday next, when the encampment will be formed on the parade-ground at East New-York.

abstract: If the letter of the late order from the War Department on the subject of enlistments be observed, no more Government bounties will be paid to recruits joining the new regiments now organizing, and recruits for regiments in the field have only another week's chance of obtaining the liberal bonus hitherto paid to every one volunteering. The knowledge that yesterday was the last day that they could claim a share in these bounties, brought out such of the volunteering element as prefer the new regiments in unprecedentedly large force, -- many encampments near the City receiving as many accessions within a few hours as had come in during a whole previous week. Several regiments nearly filled up, and, if an extension of another fortnight be granted them, will certainly be able to reach the maximum standard required by the Inspector-General, without any necessity being created on their account for either consolidation or a draft. The encampments where recruits for the new regiments are enrolled, are so numerous and scattered as to render it impossible to ascertain the exact number brought into each, or the aggregate passed at them all; but there could scarcely, have been less than a thousand passed on Thursday and yesterday. Recruits for regiments in the field are mustered in at the office in White-street, and it is easier to find how many of them there are. Yesterday there were some 400; of which a majority were for SICKLES' and the Irish brigades, DURYEE's Zouaves and the Seventy-ninth. Capt. LARNED and Lieut. KENASTON, the mustering officers, and Dr. MOTT and his assistants, who superintend the inspections, had a busy time of it. So likewise did Capt. CARR, who has in charge the disbursement of the Government bounties of $2 and $25. By persevering effort and downright hard work, Capt. CARR has managed to catch up all the arrears of his office, and is now able to take each day's work and dispose of it as it comes; so that every volunteer can make sure of being attended to directly he has been indorsed by the surgeons and taken the oath, which Capt. LARNED administers to him. Capt. CARR has nothing to do with the distribution of the State bounties. Those have to be obtained by captains of companies from Col. BLISS, but the process of getting them has been simplifies , and very little cause for dissatisfaction at delay exists. No official notice has been issued of the time when the State bounties will cease, but it is well to mention a pain that the payment of United States bounties were discontinued to recruits for new regiments  yesterday, and will be discontinued to recruits for regiments in the held on Monday week.

abstract: Orpheus C. Kerr (quere, office seeker,) has written a book. A great many other office seekers might do as this particular one has done and collect into a volume the letters which they have indited from time to time, but although they might be as comical in some respects as these, we doubt whether they would receive as cordial a reception; for Mr. Orpheus C. Kerr is no stranger to the public. His lucubrations, which appeared originally in the Sunday Mercury, have been so widely quoted from, that, it is almost useless to say, they consist of sketches, burlesqueing passing events. Most of them are admirably done, and the height of absurdity which some of them attain makes the book a timely one for such a season as this when the prospects of a draft are weighing so heavily upon the minds of so many non-exempts. The Orpheus C. Kerr papers will hardly pass into history with those of the immortal Jack Downing, but they are so greatly superior to the wishy-washy productions of certain other would-be humorists, whom it is hardly worth while to name, that Messrs. BLAKEMAN & MASON will not regret having published them.

abstract: will be held in Talcot's Hall. Sing Sing, for the benefit of St. Augustine's Church, Rev. Father MCCLELLAN, Pastor. This gentleman was for many years pastor of Transfiguration Church in this City, and some of the ladies of this Church -- among them Miss ANNE SWEENEY -- will aid this undertaking by their presence during the festival, which commences Aug. 25, and lasts until the 30th inst. The articles selected for the occasion are of the most elegant description, and the admission is reduced to 10 cents; children free. A boat leaves the foot of Jay-street every morning, and returns at 3 P.M. for the conveyance of those who desire to patronize this charitable object.

abstract: We are very glad to receive intelligence of the escape from Richmond of Mr. W.H. HURLBERT, a well-known literary gentleman of this City, who went South soon after the outbreak of the rebellion, and was at once thrown into prison, where he has been confined until quite recently. For the last six months he has been at liberty in the City of Richmond, though he has been subjected to a rigid surveillance on the part of the rebel authorities. Having been at large, however, in the Capital, he has had very good opportunities of making himself acquainted with the actual strength and condition of the rebel army.

abstract: At a meeting held at the Pavillon of the old Atlantic Hotel last night, a statement of the number of men and means was made by Mr. JOHN BOARD. It was received with acclamation. Hoboken will toe the mark and foot the bill. Mayor JOHNSTON presided, and, in his opening address, gave a cheering account of the progress made. Judge WHITLEY and HARVEY J. LYONS, Esq., addressed the meeting. The Judge eloquently appealed to the citizens capable of bearing arms, appealing in strains of lofty eloquence to the military ardor of the illustrious souls of the heroes of '76, whose blood now coursed through their veins. Mr. LYONS logically demonstrated the obligations of property to bear the pecuniary brunt of the baltic whilst our young men went forth in the panoply of war. The meeting adjourned to this evening, at Volmer's Hotel.

abstract: Gen. CORCORAN has declined accepting the banquet which the municipal authorities had tendered him for Monday next. He feels that this is no time for junketing, when the barbarians are almost at the gates of the capital, and when the liberties of the country are so terribly imperiled. He will devote all his time and energies to the raising and organizing of an Irish Brigade, which he expects to have ready for the field before the day for the enforcement of the draft, and of which his own regiment, the Sixty-ninth State Militia, will form a part. If he does this, the coming week will be a busy one with him, and with the Irish-Americans of New-York.

abstract: An elderly gentleman named GEORGE NETTICUTT was found in an insensible condition, at an early hour yesterday morning, in Gouverneur-street. He was bleeding profusely from several wounds on the head and other parts of his person. The Police conveyed him to the Hospital in a dying condition. It is not known as yet who inflicted the injuries.

abstract: -- AN IMPORTANT LETTER FROM SECRETARY SEWARD. -- A brief letter from Secretary SEWARD to J.N. GAMBLE, of Cincinnati, which we published yesterday, touches on a point of prime importance. Mr. GAMBLE, as we gather, had addressed a note to the Secretary of State, expressing apprehension of a deficiency of labor in the country, resulting from our large military operations, urging the desirableness of an increase of immigration, and also suggesting that it would be important that persons proposing to emigrate should have some official assurance that they would not be required to perform military duty.
lead_paragraph: -- AN IMPORTANT LETTER FROM SECRETARY SEWARD. -- A brief letter from Secretary SEWARD to J.N. abstract: The Harbor Police yesterday boarded the steamer Mississippi, and took therefrom fourteen men, who are charged with attempting to evade the draft. They are mostly Battery boatmen and runners, who had shipped as seamen. They were taken to the Central office, where, after an examination by the Provost-Marshal, they were discharged.

abstract: -- A meeting to consider the means of filling up the German regiments now in service will be held to-day, at noon, in the Ladies' Ordinary, Astor House. The German population will, of course, participate largely, but it is hoped our citizens of every nationality will lend their presence and encouragement. The German regiments have, in all cases, deserved well of their adopted country. The name of SIGEL will never cease to be a household word in the loyal States, and it is to give SIGEL, and other equally devoted leaders of our Teutonic soldiery, soldiers to lead, that a demonstration of the kind we refer to becomes necessary. Speakers of eminence will be present, and appeals will be made both in German and English. Let the assembly be large and liberal.

abstract: As the time for drafting approaches, all the evils inherent in the extravagant and diversified system of bounties offered by various sections begin to show themselves conspicuously. In Rhode Island the system has involved recruiting in such confusion that Gov. SPRAGUE has been compelled to call a special session of the Legislature for Tuesday next, to take the matter into consideration. We presume the difficulty in Rhode Island is of the same nature with that experienced in the other States. Volunteers rushed to enroll themselves in whatever town or county offered the largest premiums; and thus it happens that many districts from which large numbers of recruits have gone forth are credited with none over against their quota, their volunteers having enlisted elsewhere. On these, therefore, the draft will fall with great severity, as they will be compelled to raise the whole number of men to make up their original complement under both calls. We repeatedly set forth the danger of the very evils that are now being so bitterly experienced, at the time when the extravagant rivalry in bounties began, and urged the fixing of a uniform system throughout the whole country. Now that the failure to do so has got us into a complete muddle, it remains to be seen how our wise pates will get us out of it. In this regard the proceedings of the Rhode Island Legislature will be looked forward to with interest.

abstract: The attempt of the last day or two to create a fresh panic about the safety of the Capital has not met with very brilliant success. For a few hours, while there was a mysterious whisper of some terrible danger impending over the Army of Gen. POPE, but no definite statement of its extent or character, some little uneasiness pervaded the public mind. But when the news came to be proclaimed, the alarm disappeared. The upshot of it is that Gen. POPE has fallen back toward the Rappahannock. It was added, to be sure, that he was rapidly pursued by from 120,000 to 150,000 rebels -- that they would probably overtake him before McCLELLAN could join him, and that Washington was reasonably certain to fall into their hands.

abstract: editorial on NYC tribute
snippet: editorial on NYC tribute
lead_paragraph: The tribute of public respect paid yesterday to Gen. MICHAEL CORCORAN, by the population of New-York City, was one of which any man living might have been proud. The outpouring was immense, and it embraced every rank and condition of life. Many places of business were closed, and entire classes of our laboring population left their work en masse to join in the ovation. The multitude on foot, pressing on the line of procession and the point of reception, was numbered truly by the hundred thousand, and the sentiment pervading all was that of exultant pride in the man they had met to honor. The roar of artillery mingled with the not less inspiring shout of many voices to give to Col. CORCORAN a cordial welcome to his home, and to testify that with enthusiastic accord, he was crowned with the laurels he had so bravely won and so nobly wears. It were worth a life-time of toil and suffering to come to a day so illustrious and memorable at the last.

abstract: The body of an unknown man, about 40 years of age, was found yesterday in the North River, near the foot of Forty-third-street. The skull of the deceased was fractured, caused, it is presumed, by his striking against some of the timbers of the pier. The deceased was dressed in woolen pants, silk vest, a woven sailor-jacket, and a leather strap about his waist. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest upon the body, when a verdict of death from drowning was rendered.
lead_paragraph: The body of an unknown man, about 40 years of age, was found yesterday in the North River, near the foot of Forty-third-street. abstract: The Union Party in New-Jersey has set an example worthy of imitation elsewhere, in selecting as a candidate for the Governor's Chair a gentleman who is so little of a politician as to be hardly a partisan. Hon. MARCUS L. WARD, the nominee, was an Old-School Whig, and always a conservative. At all times distinguished for public spirit and liberality, since the outbreak of the war he has taken the lead in his State in promoting the Union cause, in obtaining enlistments, in aiding regiments and individual soldiers with his counsel and his purse. His beneficent activity was early directed to providing hospitals for the returning sick and wounded soldiers. Through his efforts the State Hospital for these sufferers was located at Newark, so as to be within easy reach of the transports arriving at New-York; and several capacious buildings, situated most eligibly in a sanitary point of view, were fitted up with great thoroughness, and when in all respects ready for the accommodation of a thousand men, handed over to Government. In these generous labors Mr. WARD was not only prodigal of his own time and ample wealth, but his estimable and trustworthy character commanding the confidence of the public, was the steward of the general charity. What, with his constant assiduity in the promotion of the military science, and his kindly devotion to the welfare of the soldiers, he has entitled himself fully to the distinction of being peculiarly the "soldier's friend." There can hardly be a doubt of Mr. WARD's election.
lead_paragraph: The Union Party in New-Jersey has set an example worthy of imitation elsewhere, in selecting as a candidate for the Governor's Chair a gentleman who is so little of a politician as to be hardly a partisan. Hon. MARCUS L. WARD, the nominee, was an Old-School Whig, and always a conservative. At all times distinguished for public spirit and liberality, since the outbreak of the war he has taken the lead in his State in promoting the Union cause, in obtaining enlistments, in aiding regiments and individual soldiers with his counsel and his purse. His beneficent activity was early directed to providing hospitals for the returning sick and wounded soldiers. Through his efforts the State Hospital for these sufferers was located at Newark, so as to be within easy reach of the transports arriving at New-York; and several capacious buildings, situated most eligibly in a sanitary point of view, were fitted up with great thoroughness, and when in all respects ready for the accommodation of a thousand men, handed over to Government. In these generous labors Mr. WARD was not only prodigal of his own time and ample wealth, but his estimable and trustworthy character commanding the confidence of the public, was the steward of the general charity. What, with his constant assiduity in the promotion of the military science, and his kindly devotion to the welfare of the soldiers, he has entitled himself fully to the distinction of being peculiarly the "soldier's friend." There can hardly be a doubt of Mr. WARD's election.

abstract: Soldiers riot in East NY, Brooklyn, because of non-payment of NYS bounty
snippet: Soldiers riot in East NY, Brooklyn, because of non-payment of NYS bounty
lead_paragraph: A serious riot occurred among the soldiers of the Empire Brigade, quartered at East New-York, yesterday afternoon, which resulted in the partial destruction of the Union Barracks and the complete gutting of the Howard House, opposite. A number of the officers and soldiers were seriously injured, and it was reported that several were killed, but in the great confusion that prevailed it was impossible to ascerts in the exact state of affairs.

abstract: Editorial on Canadian relations and influence of Great Britain
snippet: Editorial on Canadian relations and influence of Great Britain
lead_paragraph: The diplomatist who said that language was given us to conceal our thoughts, had, no doubt, a special reference to his own vocation. Whoever expects the modern statesman to make straight for the door through which he wishes to make his exit or his entrance, is likely to be egregiously deceived. We are not for example, to make haste to assume that Lord PALMERSTON is a friend of the United States because he requested the withdrawal of an adverse motion in the late mediation debate. Such a circumstance must simply be accepted as an evidence that a division at the present time, and under existing conditions, would, in the judgment of the veteran tactician, be unfavorable to the development of his predetermined policy. Neither are we to suppose that the Presses which take their cue from the British Government, are actuated by affection for our own, when they protest against "simple mediation;" it only proves that the Ministry has indicated, in a manner which those writers understand, that the proposed legislative action is premature; that such action would only provoke the North without aiding the South; that the temper of the English people at large is still believed to be adverse to the upholding of a mere Slave Power, and that they must wait for more National disasters and a few more turns of the screw on the unhappy operatives of Lancashire.
headline: {'main': 'British Colonial Policy The Future of Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'British Colonial Policy The Future of Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The accounts which we have from Minnesota of the Indian massacres in the vicinity of Fort Ridgeley are of the most terrible and heartrending character. It is estimated that at least five hun
lead_paragraph: The accounts which we have from Minnesota of the Indian massacres in the vicinity of Fort Ridgeley are of the most terrible and heartrending character. It is estimated that at least five hundred whites have already been murdered by the savages. It is believed that all the Sioux are banded together in the work of murder, and it is feared that they will be joined by other tribes. Gov. RAMSEY is taking prompt measures to suppress the outbreak if possible, and is already marching to the relief of Fort Ridgeley with a considerable body of men.

abstract: The Atlantic and Pacific Guano Company vs. The ship Robert Center, , and Joseph H. Arnold, Master, Opinion SHIPMAN, J. In the Winter and Spring of 1858-9, the libelants were the owners of guano on Swan Island in the Carribean Sea.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic and Pacific Guano Company vs. The ship Robert Center, , and Joseph H. Arnold, Master, -- Opinion -- SHIPMAN, J. -- In the Winter and Spring of 1858-9, the libelants were the owners of guano on Swan Island in the Carribean Sea. On the 18th day of December, 1858, they entered into a contract with one George W. Cochran, by the terms of which the latter was to charter vessels and transport guano to market, the cargoes to be subject to the payment of freight and charges, and out of the surplus the libelants were first to receive eight dollars per ton. The guano was to be delivered to the consignees of the libelants and the latter were entitled to bills of lading. There were other stipulations in the contract which it is not necessary to notice in this place, but which may be referred to hereafter when I come to examine the claim of the respondents to demurrage.

abstract: The trial of GUATI RADETSKY, for the murder of FELLNER, is to come off at Freehold,Monmoutn, N. J., on the 3d of September, proximo. It is stated by those who have the means of knowing, that much additional testimony, on the part of the people, has recently been discovered by the Police of this City.
lead_paragraph: The trial of GUATI RADETSKY, for the murder of FELLNER, is to come off at Freehold,Monmoutn, N. J., on the 3d of September, proximo. It is stated by those who have the means of knowing, that much additional testimony, on the part of the people, has recently been discovered by the Police of this City. Aside from the deep mystery in which this murder has been enshrouded, the notoriety which has been given to it by the arrest of Mrs. MARKS and her sister, ALBERTINA PHLAUM, --, who hung herself while in prison,) -- and the large amount of money and diamonds, of which the murdered man was the owner at the time of his death, there are some questions of a scientific character, which will render the trial one of more than ordinary interest. The question as to the jurisdiction by the Courts of New-Jersey will, it is said, be brought up by the counsel for the prisoner, at the outset of the trial. The deceased was last seen alive in company with the prisoner on a Friday night, and the following Monday morning, his body was found in the Shrewsbury River, beyond the Highland Light-house, in the State of New-Jersey. Ex-Judge STEWART, as counsel for RADETSKY. proposes, as one part of his defence, to show that, as a matter of law, the finding of a dead body in the State of New-Jersey is only a circumstance going to prove that the death occurred there, but one which may be rebutted and overcome by evidence tending to prove that the murder was actually committed in this City or Brooklyn. This branch of the case will be novel and interesting, as the laws of the winds and tides of the Harbor of New-York, the Bay and the channel of the Narrows leading to the sea, also the laws of specific gravity of water and of the human body, and furthermore, the medical inquiry as to the decomposition of the deceased's person, are questions which it is proposed shall be taken into consideration for the purpose of ascertaining where, as well as by whom the murder was committed. Owing to all these circumstances, the forthcoming trial of RADETSKY will doubtless be one as full of interest as any which ever took place in Monmouth County.
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; The Felluer Murder. APPROACHING TRIAL OF RADETSKY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; The Felluer Murder. APPROACHING TRIAL OF RADETSKY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The President's response to Mr. GREELEY's public letter, addressed to him last week, is explicit enough, and settles one or two disputed points as to Mr. LINCOLN's opinions and policy. His one and paramount object in the war is "to save the Union" -- to save it with or without Slavery, under one set of circumstances or another, or by one agency or another, but at all events to save it somehow. His simple platform is "The salvation of the Union." To this end his whole policy looks, and whatever he does or fails to do is with reference to its bearings upon this one great point. He could not have said anything more satisfactory to the country in general.
lead_paragraph: -- The President's response to Mr. GREELEY's public letter, addressed to him last week, is explicit enough, and settles one or two disputed points as to Mr. LINCOLN's opinions and policy. abstract: The subjoined letter tells its own story in very brief language, and suggests forcibly the inequality of the system which gives to the navy one-half of all prizes captured, while not allowing one cent to the army, even where property worth many millions of dollars has been seized. In this case, so far as the navy was concerned, the prize-steamer Ladona, laden with a cargo of wines and medicines, worth nearly a million of dollars, had accomplished a successful voyage, and was on her way rejoicing up the Savannah River -- she was hulled by several shots from the Martello Battery, and finally driven out to sea again; after which she very foolishly ran into Ossabaw Sound, not thinking it occupied by National cruisers, and almost dropped anchor under the guns of the Unadilla, which was lying concealed behind a neck of land, covered with trees. The navy is given half the value of this prize -- Capt. FERGUSON, of the Martello Battery, not one cent:

abstract: A HINT TO THE ENROLLERS. There is a class of scoundrelistic loafers in this City, known by sight to everybody, but intimately by none. They lounge conspicuously on the steps of the principal Broadway Hotels, sleep to places of doubtful no,
lead_paragraph: A HINT TO THE ENROLLERS. -- There is a class of scoundrelistic loafers in this City, known by sight to everybody, but intimately by none. They lounge conspicuously on the steps of the principal Broadway Hotels, sleep to places of doubtful -- no, undoubtful -- reputation, make their living by sly incursions upon the pockets of the unwarn, and avoid the responsibilities of citizens, having neither local habitation nor name. The Police know them. Are they to be exempt from draft? An ordinary enrollment will not catch them, and unless the authorities act upon this suggestion, these rascals, who are not even gamblers, will escape the fiery trial through which all good men must pass, and will remain an eyesore to the respectable citizens, while he laughs victoriously at them and their troubles. By law-books these people are called vagrants -- have we any law in force?
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL CITY NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL CITY NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Under date of Paris, Ky., Aug. 10, Senator GARRETT DAVIS has written a long letter to Mr. PRENTIOE, which is published in the Louisville Journal. He reviews the history of secession ab initio, and considers the duty of Kentucky in the present crisis.
lead_paragraph: Under date of Paris, Ky., Aug. 10, Senator GARRETT DAVIS has written a long letter to Mr. PRENTIOE, which is published in the Louisville Journal. He reviews the history of secession ab initio, and considers the duty of Kentucky in the present crisis. Her people, he says, know that their slaves cannot be taken from them under the Constitution, and she will undertake their emancipation in their own good time, refusing to recognize "this arrogant dictation to them to emancipate their slaves as the voice of destiny." Of President LINCOLN, Senator DAVIS says:

abstract: War rally held, Westchester, NY, to induce enlistments
snippet: War rally held, Westchester, NY, to induce enlistments
lead_paragraph: The third of a series of war meetings to induce enlistments was held at the Town Hall of West Farms on Wednesday evening, the 26th inst. The attendance was very large, the hall being crowded to its utmost capacity, and the enthusiasm was unbounded. Over $4,000 was subscribed, and during the meeting thirty-seven recruits secured. GEO. W. DEVOE, Esq., Supervisor of the town, presided over the meeting, with the following Vice-Presidents: WM. SIMPSON, JOHN B. HASKIN, H.T.W. MALI and C. BATHGATE. R.L. ANDERTON acted as Secretary.

We print the document in the columns of the TIMES to-day, and are sorry to add that its perusal will not repay the time and patience of the reader. abstract: Capt. RICHARD WAINWRIGHT, the commanding officer of the flag-ship Hartford, died on Sunday. He has ever since the entrance of the fleet into the Mississippi overworked himself, and this, too, against the advice of his chief; and his constitution became so exhausted that he yielded suddenly to a fever which he contracted up the river. Capt. WAINWRIGHT was one of the best ordnance officers in the United States Navy, and a most able, energetic and zealous sailor. He was about 42 years of age. He leaves a wife and four children. -- Ibid.

abstract: -- About 2 o'clock yesterday morning two burglars attempted to break into the store of JOHN MCMONACH, corner of Bedford and Park avenues. The noise they made awoke MCMONACH, who went softly into the store and caught one of the fellows, and handed him over to Officer IRWIN, of the Forty-fourth Precinct. The prisoner is a boy, 17 years of age, and gave his name as DANIEL GILLEN.

abstract: There is no doubt that before this time the junction of the two great armies under Gen. McCLRLLAN and Gen. PORE has been fully effected, and the rebels are thus foiled in their intention to crush the latter with overwhelming numbers.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that before this time the junction of the two great armies under Gen. McCLRLLAN and Gen. PORE has been fully effected, and the rebels are thus foiled in their intention to crush the latter with overwhelming numbers. Gen. POPE's army, it is now well understood, has fallen back from the Rapidan, and established its lines at the Rappahannock. This movement was effected with perfect success, although it is believed that the rebels were pressing closely in the rear. They are now in heavy force on the south bank of the Rappahannock, and from all we can learn, have made several attempts to cross, and to turn our right and left flanks, but have in every case been repulsed. Now that our two armies can act together, we may expect a great battle to be fought very soon -- perhaps to-day. The Washington Star of Thursday says: "Skirmishing has doubtless been going on for the last two days at different points, between comparatively inconsiderable portions of the two great antagonist armies, between here and Richmond. So far it has had no results worthy of notice, though a number on both sides have been killed and wounded. Up to the latest advices, (just before we go to press,) all was well within the Union lines."

abstract: It is a well-known fact that the German element and the Irish element in the United States entertain a certain antipathy to each other. This is quite remarkable, and to many it is quite inexplicable. It would seem, in the nature of things, that the reverse would be found true that instead of antipathy, a strong feeling of mutual sympathy would exist.

abstract: The facts in the case of this officer appear to be, that after applying three or four times at the War Department, to learn if there were any charges against him, and obtaining no reply whatever, he at length received a notice that his commission as Brigadier-General was revoked.
lead_paragraph: The facts in the case of this officer appear to be, that after applying three or four times at the War Department, to learn if there were any charges against him, and obtaining no reply whatever, he at length received a notice that his commission as Brigadier-General was revoked. No reason was assigned for the act. Upon a direct application at the office where all accusations against officers should be filed, he found two letters of Gen. HUNTER, as the only matters of consequence beyond what has been previously published in the newspapers. One of these letters asserted that BENHAM's subordinate Generals had warned him that he was about to fight a battle in violation of orders. The letter, however, on which this statement is based did not make this charge; and the card of Gen. STEVENS, published in the TIMES of July 22, directly contradicts it.

abstract: A telegram from Cape Race announces that the United States gunboat Tuscarora has been ordered away from Queenstown. This is done doubtless in accordance with the Admiralty orders issued last January prohibiting the cruisers of either belligerent to enter any British port. This measure was adopted at a time when the British sensibilities were so shocked by the simultaneous presence of United States and rebel war vessels at Southampton and Gibraltar, and when there was a fair prospect that the "two pot boys," as they politely designated the Tuscarora and the Nashville, would come to blows within sight of horror-stricken British eyes. But now that the rebels do not even claim to have a navy, and both the Sumter and Nashville have gone up (or down,) it is, to say the least, very ungracious that this restrictive enactment should be applied against us. Is it not time for Mr. SEWARD to enter a protest on this point?

abstract: We understand that the City Fathers have arrangements in progress for a grand Union war meeting, to be held some day this week, in the City Hall Park, with the object of stimulating enlistments. Volunteering ends this week -- drafting commences next; and for every man who enlists this week, there will be one man less drafted next week. So let every citizen work with might and main. The orators at the meeting are neither to be the old party hacks, nor the kid-gloved gentry, but those who have power with the democracy, and whose words have weight with the bone and sinew of New-York. We expect to see a tremendous turnout; and we hope the result, in the shape of recruits, will be something better than appeared from the July mass-meeting in Union-Square.

abstract: PRESIDENT LINCOLN's LETTER TO HORACE GREELEY. -- The editor of the Tribune lately addressed a prayer to President LINCOLN, in the name of "twenty millions of people." This was not considered very modest in our neighbor, for it was a hold assumption to claim to represent the views of so vast a constituency. With characteristic modesty and good breeding, Mr. LINCOLN did not question the sublime sufficiency of his correspondent, but answered Mr. GREELEY in a letter as brief and pithy as the epistle of the latter was long and diffuse.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT LINCOLN's LETTER TO HORACE GREELEY. -- The editor of the Tribune lately addressed a prayer to President LINCOLN, in the name of "twenty millions of people." abstract: The remains of this gallant officer, who fell at the head of his regiment, in the recent battle at Baton Rouge, arrived here on Saturday evening, on the steamer Blackstone, from New-Orleans, having been embalmed and sent home by the officers of his command, who were devotedly attached to him. Col. ROBERTS' brother-in-law, Gen. H.H. BAXTER, of Rutland, Vt., who has been in this City for several days, awaiting the arrival of the remains, in company with Col. HOWE, State Agent of Vermont, Mr. HOLBROOK, son of the Governor of that State, Maj. GEO. BROWN, the Sons of Vermont, and a committee of the New-England Association, met the body and escorted it to a private house, where it will be prepared for its departure to Vermont on Monday, by the 11 o'clock train. A deputation of the Sons of Vermont and New-England Association will accompany the remains to the Hudson River Railroad.

abstract: The body of a drowned man was picked up at the foot of Little-street, yesterday morning, by Mr. JESSE WILLIAMS. The deceased was apparently about 60 years old, 5 feet 4 inches in height; had on a black broadcloth coat, black ribbed pantaloons, yellow-figured vest, white shirt and black stock. His nose is very prominent. His hair, gray-mixed. The body was taken to the dead house by order of Coroner NORKIS, where it will be retained for a reasonable length of time for identification.

abstract: The Winter Garden is re-opened this evening for the regular season which is to last until next June, should fortune meantime smile upon the endeavors of the manager. The managerial policy of the place ...
lead_paragraph: The Winter Garden is re-opened this evening for the regular season which is to last until next June, should fortune meantime smile upon the endeavors of the manager. The managerial policy of the place will be of the "star" order throughout; that is, a working company of moderate capability is permanently engaged, and, in regular succession, will act as a medium through which histrionic luminaries, of magnitude sufficient to have illuminated posters of their own, can irradiate the stage and beam on a discriminating public. Of luminaries already secured, the most popular are Mr. FORREST, EDWIN BOOTH, Mr. and Mrs. BARNET WILLIAMS, and Miss BATEMAN. This last named talented young tragedienne inaugurates the season with a revival of "The Hunchback.' wherein she made a sensation, several months ago, at this same theatre. She will be specially sustained, as before, by Mr. J.W. WALLACX, Jr., and Mr. EDWIN ADAMS, and receive auxiliary aid from Mrs. ALEXINA FISHER BAKER, and other well known performers' whose names the advertisements very unwisely conceal. The Winter Garden has, during the recess, been handsomely re-decorated, and the gas department, which, in former periods, occasionally assumed the dimensions of a positive nuisance, is said to be entirely remodeled.
