abstract: The following account of the condition of things in Richmond has been obtained by one of our reporters from a highly intelligent lady, who has resided in that city for the last two years. She left Richmond on Tuesday, the 12th inst., and arrived in this City on Tuesday last. She is a woman of highly respectable family, the sister of a gentleman well known in this community, both ...
lead_paragraph: The following account of the condition of things in Richmond has been obtained by one of our reporters from a highly intelligent lady, who has resided in that city for the last two years. She left Richmond on Tuesday, the 12th inst., and arrived in this City on Tuesday last. She is a woman of highly respectable family, the sister of a gentleman well known in this community, both as a lawyer and a Judge, and the information which she gives may be relied upon as authentic in every particular. While residing in Richmond she had ample opportunity to see and hear much that was transpiring around her, and, though at heart a staunch Union woman, she was compelled, by the force of circumstances, during her two years' sojourn in rebeldom, to smother her feelings and keep her tongue as quiet as possible. At the time of the breaking out of the rebellion her husband was doing a prosperous mercantile business in that city, but he was soon after pressed into the Confederate service as a common soldier, and since that time she has been left to manage his affairs as best she could. By great exertion on her part, she contrived to keep the business going for a few months, but at the time the Southern Capital was removed to Richmond, she found that everything was in such a state of confusion and chaos, that, at a great sacrifice, she disposed of what stook she could, and with all the funds which it was possible to save from the general wreck, she determined to make her way to her native city, New-York. But this was more easily contemplated than accomplished. No person, of whatever age, sex or condition, was permitted to leave for New-York, without a special permit from the highest authority, viz., JEFF. DAVIS, and no permits to leave the State were given, under any consideration, if, as in her case, the party applying was suspected of sympathizing with the North. From that time until now she has been constantly endeavoring, by every means in her power, to find some way whereby she would be enabled to leave the city inwhich she had suffered everything but death, and where she had sacrificed nearly all that renders life endurable. Being on terms of intimacy with many of the first ladies in the City of Richmond, she frequently expressed to them since the commencement of warm weather, her desire to go to some watering-place, for a few weeks, for the benefit of her health, and it was only by this plan, that she has at last succeeded in getting released from rebeldom. In company with three other ladies, two of whom had friends in Baltimore, and the other resided in Annapolis, she was at last permitted to leave the city. The party came down to Harrison's Landing under a flag of truce. After much suffering and hardship, which lasted for about five days, she at length foued herself among some of her Union friends in Baltimore, and from there she soon after proceeded on to this City.

abstract: The junction of the two great armies in Virginia, under Gen. McCLELLAN and Gen. POPE re  pectivety, has now been effected, and the rebels are thus foiled in their intention to crush the latter with overwhelming numbers before he could receive the cooperation of the veterans of the old Potomac Army. Gen. POPE'S army, it now well ...
lead_paragraph: The junction of the two great armies in Virginia, under Gen. McCLELLAN and Gen. POPE re pectivety, has now been effected, and the rebels are thus foiled in their intention to crush the latter with overwhelming numbers before he could receive the cooperation of the veterans of the old Potomac Army. Gen. POPE's army, it now well understood, has fallen back from its advanced position at the Rapidan, and is now on the north bank of the Rappahannock. The movement across the latter river was made on Wednesday morning last, his advance having commenced moving from Culpepper at 3 o'clock on Monday evening. There was some skirmishing on the way between our near guard of cavalry and the rebels, but with no serious losses. It was expected at one time that a general engagement would occur, but it was avoided through the stubbornness with which our cavalry contested the advance of the enemy. The crossing of the Rappahannock was a perfect success, and our forces at last accounts -- up to Friday morning -- still occupied the north bank, while the rebels have a heavy force on the south bank, with batteries at intervals, extending from the Sulphur or Warrenton Springs, nine miles above the railroad bridge, to six miles below at -- fifteen miles in all. All attempts to force our lines had been repulsed, and our troops were in the best of spirits. Now that our two great armies have been rolled into one, it seems more than likely that a great battle will be fought soon. It may be now in progress.

lead_paragraph: Capt. JOHN DOWNEY, of the First Fire Zouaves, was taken prisoner at the battle of Bull Run. He was exchanged at the same time as CORCORAN, WILCOX and others, and is to reach this City to-day at 4 o'clock. The various fire companies throughout the City intend to turn out, and will assemble at Washington Parade Ground at 3 o'clock, where the line will be formed, under direction of Chief-Engineer JOHN DECKER, and will thus proceed to the foot of Cortlandt-street. The following order has been issued by the Committee of Arrangements:

abstract: During the past month, a portion of the army of the Mississippi has moved from its old station, around and about Corinth, eastward. There were a couple of very good reasons for this: 1. The protection of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, 2. The health of the army. It is a notorious fact, that an army suffers more by inaction than enduring all the fatigues of the severest campaigns and actual loss by battles.

abstract: Gen. CORCORAN visited St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, in company with Alderman DAYTON and Alderman WALSH. His presence occasioned ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. CORCORAN visited St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, in company with Alderman DAYTON and Alderman WALSH. His presence occasioned considerable enthusiasm, and upon his entrance and exit he was warmly greeted by his many friends among the Irish population and Catholic persuasion. He bore his blushing honors with his accustomed modesty, and, while he cheerfully greeted all who could obtain access to him, delighted all by not "putting on airs." The General seems, in fact, well calculated to stand prosperity.

abstract: FIGHT AMONG SOLDIERS. Quite a serious fight occurred on Saturday night at the New-Jersey Railroad Depot, Jersey City, among the soldiers of the One Hundred and Seventeenth New-York Regiment.
lead_paragraph: FIGHT AMONG SOLDIERS. -- Quite a serious fight occurred on Saturday night at the New-Jersey Railroad Depot, Jersey City, among the soldiers of the One Hundred and Seventeenth New-York Regiment. A party of about twenty-five of the men, under the influence of liquor, got into a row among themselves, in which they freely used knives and other weapons, resulting in one of the officers, who was endeavoring to quell the disturbance, being severely stabbed, and several of the men frightfully cut. The rioters were finally overpowered, hand-cuffed, gagged, and chained together in a car, when the regiment departed.

abstract: Editorials lament report correspondents are to be expelled from military lines in East; Editorials deplore report that newspaper correspondents are to be expelled from military lines in East
snippet: Editorials lament report correspondents are to be expelled from military lines in East; Editorials deplore report that newspaper correspondents are to be expelled from military lines in East
lead_paragraph: When Gen. HALLECK was in command of the Southwestern army in front of Corinth, he expelled all the correspondents of the Press from his lines, classifying them among the "unauthorized hangers-on" of his army. It is now given out that the same policy is to be applied in the East; and that those who furnish the public of the present day, and the public of all future days, with the record of the deeds and achievements of our army, are also to be expelled from the lines. This will produce several results. Of battles, sieges, and military operations of all sorts, of the details of life in camp, of the wants and feelings of the soldier, &c., the people will know nothing except what may be picked up by scribblers outside of the lines, or what may be furnished in official documents. It is true that this would neither be very lively nor veracious reading; but it would, in some respects, be better than nothing. In Europe, however, the act would have a very prejudicial effect upon the Northern cause. So far, the European journals have generally transferred to their columns the accounts of the different battles given by the correspondents of this and other American newspapers, accompanied by Southern versions from Southern newspapers. Some of these latter, given by army correspondents of rebel Journals, have been admirably written, particularly the Richmond Examiner's sketches of the seven days' battles on the Peninsula, which were copied all over Europe; and, had they not been offset by the army correspondence of the New-York journals, would have produced abroad a very contemptible opinion of the courage of our soldiers and the skill of our officers. If correspondents are expelled from the lines by Gen. HALLECK, of course Europeans will only see one side, and that the rebel side, of these things. For, unhappily, over there, they will not believe, even if they read, our official military documents. "False as an official bulletin," is an old proverb; and the style in which some of ours have been commented upon abroad shows the estimate in which they are unjustly held. Besides, not one man in a thousand ever reads an official document of any kind. Our official military reports have been heavy, statistical, lumbering, one-sided, unpicturesque, written by men who know nothing of literary composition or effect, and whose principal aim is to glorify themselves -- generally as different as possible from the vivacious narratives of the ubiquitous Press correspondents. Of some of the greatest battles of the war, again, we have had no report whatever from the officer in chief command, as in the instance of the battle of Shiloh, concerning which Gen. GRANT has been steadily silent; while of the seven days' battles in front of Richmond, Gen. MCCLELLAN has given no report. Of course, we cannot expect Europeans to toil through the mass of reports of inferior officers -- even if it were possible for them to understand them. Just as little confidence is there in Europe in our telegrams; for it is known that the telegraph is under the supervision of the Government, and they cannot be convinced that Government is either impartial or credible. But the sketches of the correspondents are too life-like to be denied, too impressive to be argued about. If the army correspondents are expelled from the lines, and the European Press publishes only rebel accounts of battles, we cannot blame Europeans for vaunting Southern valor and despising Northern poltroonery.

abstract: We give this morning the statement of a New-York lady just returned from Richmond, as to the condition of affairs in that capital. It is certainly bad enough. Nothing but want, disease, misery and panic. It is a capital worthy of the arch-fiend, JEFF. DAVIS, who presides there. By his infernal machinations it is that it has been brought to this pass -- reduced from the gay and beautiful Virginia capital of two years ago to being the Confederate charnel house. The lady can have no possible motive for misrepresentation or exaggeration; and if but one half her narrative were true, it ought to nerve the nation to redoubled efforts to save the South from rebel rule before it is wholly and irretrievably ruined.

abstract: A serious riot occurred at the Union Barracks, East New-York, on Saturday, among the soldiers attached to the Empire Brigade, under command of Brig.-Gen. F.B. SPINOLA. Some account of the affair was given in yesterday's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: A serious riot occurred at the Union Barracks, East New-York, on Saturday, among the soldiers attached to the Empire Brigade, under command of Brig.-Gen. F.B. SPINOLA. Some account of the affair was given in yesterday's TIMES. At one time the most serious consequences were threatened, but by the prompt arrival of a portion of the police, and the exertions of the officers, the riot was quelled, but not before a number had been injured, among them the Sergeant-Major of the Fourth Regiment MARTIR VAN BUREN, who was shot in the neck with a pistol, but not dangerously wounded. Some twenty of the soldiers were severely clubbed by the police, and several of the latter were more or less hurt with stones and bottles, which were freely used by the rioters.

abstract: Editorial on lack of knowledge of Confederate financial conditions
snippet: Editorial on lack of knowledge of Confederate financial conditions
lead_paragraph: It has been a long time since we were edified by any high-sounding emanations from the head of the Confederate Treasury Department. The only thing we have seen for a great while from the rebel Secretary of the Treasury, is a very brief note dated the 1st of the current month, defining certain nice points concerning Confederate Treasury Notes. One might suppose that Mr. MEMMINGER, of South Carolina, was either dead or retired; but we believe the contrary is the fact. He still lives and draws his salary as the chief of Southern financiers.

abstract: The accounts which we have from Minnesota of the Indian massaacres in the vicinity of Fort Ridgeley are of the moat terrible and heartrending character. It is estimated that at least five hundred whites have already been murdered by the savages. It is believed that all the Sioux are ...
lead_paragraph: The accounts which we have from Minnesota of the Indian massaacres in the vicinity of Fort Ridgeley are of the moat terrible and heartrending character. It is estimated that at least five hundred whites have already been murdered by the savages. It is believed that all the Sioux are banded together in the work of murder, and it is feared that they will be joined by other tribes. Gov. RAMSEY is taking prompt measures to suppress the outbreak if possible, and Ex.-Gov. SIBLEY is already marching to the relief of Fort Ridgeley with a considerable body of men.

abstract: editorial notes strong Union line on Rappahannock
snippet: editorial notes strong Union line on Rappahannock
lead_paragraph: We suppose it may be said that we have once again a concentrated army in Virginia. The bodies under Gens. McCLELLAN and POPE, as well as the column of Gen. BURNSIDE from North Carolina, now form a mass, which, if not conpacted together, is within mutually supporting distance in each of its parts, and prepared to cooperate all together in case of emergency. The lines extend, or at the close of last week did extend, along the left bank of the Rappahannock, with its centre, under Gen. POPE, near to the point where the Orange and Alexandria Railroad crosses that river, its left extending down to Fredericksburgh, and its right stretching but a short distance to the north, if it may not be said to sweep in a thin and desultory line as far up as Strasburgh in the Shenandoah Valley. If the rebels choose to bring on another battle, it will be fought, we would fain hope, with the whole of our Virginia army -- a phenomenon which did not occur either in the great battle at Manassas last Summer, nor in the great series of battles on the Peninsula this Summer. At Yorktown, and Norfolk, and at other points in Eastern as well as Western Virginia, there are still small detachments of our taoops for garrison and defensive purposes; but, with these trifling exceptions, the whole of the grand army of the East is along the line which we have indicated. Gen. POPE fell back here last week from the Rapidan, or rather from Culpepper Court-house; and, during the same eventful week, the troops of Gen. MCCLELLAN have been hastening northward to the same point with all the rapidity possible to steam and innumerable transports. The different columns of the army are still, we suppose, under the command of MCCLELLAN, POPE and BURNSIDE, respectively, though the whole force is so near to Washington, and so immediately under the eye of Gen. HALLECK, that he can personally direct all its movements until the event of a battle, in which case, it is said, he will himself take the field.

abstract: It was very good news  yesterday from POPE'S army, that Gen. SIGEL had captured two thousand rebel troops on the Rappahannock, and Wall street was bright and stocks buoyant on the strength of it. Everybody hoped that the captives might be somewhat more tangible and somewhat less ...
lead_paragraph: -- It was very good news yesterday from POPE's army, that Gen. SIGEL had captured two thousand rebel troops on the Rappahannock, and Wall street was bright and stocks buoyant on the strength of it. Everybody hoped that the captives might be somewhat more tangible and somewhat less invisible that the ten thousand which POPE's cavalry "bagged" after the evacuation of Corinth. It is true it looked somewhat dubious that the capture, as reported, took place as far back as last Tuesday, while we had advices from along the lines on the Rappahannock as late as Saturday, which made no mention of such an important event; and it was also remarkable that the prisoners, instead of being hastened to Washington, should have been retained within POPE's lines for a week, when an attack on SIGEL's or any other corps was so imminent, and when they could not afford to be burdened with such a number of rebel prisoners. But still it was hoped the news was true; though, the balance of prisoners being still against us, this new haul would simply have been shipped back again to the dominions and the army of JEFF. DAVIS. In the evening, however, we were gently let down from our noonday hopes by the receipt of a dispatch which announced that "the reported capture of two thousand rebel prisoners was not confirmed," and a still later telegram narrated that two hundred of our soldiers on the Rappahannock had been taken prisoners by the rebels. This was almost as much of a change in the facts as took place in the telegrams concerning the late battle of Cedar Mountain, which asserted that after the engagement the rebels had asked permission to bury their dead, when the fact wasthat we had to ask leave of JACKSON to bury our poor fellows. There is nothing gained by these authorized misstatements, that come so thick and fast from Gen. POPE's Department. If they hoist stocks up for a moment, they eventually and inevitably tumble public confidence down. Moreover, we cannot possibly equal the rebels in this style of fabrication, and it would be better that our telegraphic wires should not be defiled with it at all. It was so likely that Gen. SIGEL should do just such a thing as was reported of him, that its credibility was universally concurred in. We have no doubt that when the news reaches the gallant General, he will proceed to verify it in a manner which will be acceptable to the public.

abstract: -- The scheme officially proposed by President LINCOLN, and sanctioned by the last Congress, of beginning the work of colonizing, outside of the United States, the negroes free and to be freed in the progress of the war, is about to be carried practically into effect. Senator POMEROY has issued an address to the free colored people of the United States, and which has been approved by the President, in which he proposes, at as early a date as five weeks from this time, to take out to Central America a colony of five hundred colored persons, to be settled permanently in that country. The immediate point of their destination is to be Chiriqui -- well known from the late discoveries of gold mere -- in New-Granada, which is but a week's voyage from this port. They are to be carried out at the expense of Government, and supported for the first season at Government expense -- a small fund for this purpose having been appropriated by the last Congress. The sum required will be small, as they will be carried out in National vessels, while the country to which they emigrate is so fertile and so profuse in edible products of all sorts, that the only support required will be implements and seeds, and a temporary supply of provisions until the bursting soil can give forth of its bounty. Senator POMEROY has taken upon himself a difficult work; but he is a man both of energy and experience. We regard the scheme of deporting the four millions of Africans that are rooted in the Southern soil as utterly impracticable, but still the experiment of black colonies in Central America and elsewhere is well worth trying. The negro certainly has invitations and urgings enough to leave us, and small enough inducements to stay. Jamaica and all the British West Indies beg him to come; Hayti stretches forth her hands and implores his presence; the Danish West Indies softly woo him; Central America invites him with open arms; and even his old African home longs to get him back. Here he has but personal slavery, or social degradation. If he chooses to leave us, Heaven speed him!
lead_paragraph: -- The scheme officially proposed by President LINCOLN, and sanctioned by the last Congress, of beginning the work of colonizing, outside of the United States, the negroes free and to be freed in the progress of the war, is about to be carried practically into effect. Senator POMEROY has issued an address to the free colored people of the United States, and which has been approved by the President, in which he proposes, at as early a date as five weeks from this time, to take out to Central America a colony of five hundred colored persons, to be settled permanently in that country. The immediate point of their destination is to be Chiriqui -- well known from the late discoveries of gold mere -- in New-Granada, which is but a week's voyage from this port. They are to be carried out at the expense of Government, and supported for the first season at Government expense -- a small fund for this purpose having been appropriated by the last Congress. The sum required will be small, as they will be carried out in National vessels, while the country to which they emigrate is so fertile and so profuse in edible products of all sorts, that the only support required will be implements and seeds, and a temporary supply of provisions until the bursting soil can give forth of its bounty. Senator POMEROY has taken upon himself a difficult work; but he is a man both of energy and experience. We regard the scheme of deporting the four millions of Africans that are rooted in the Southern soil as utterly impracticable, but still the experiment of black colonies in Central America and elsewhere is well worth trying. The negro certainly has invitations and urgings enough to leave us, and small enough inducements to stay. Jamaica and all the British West Indies beg him to come; Hayti stretches forth her hands and implores his presence; the Danish West Indies softly woo him; Central America invites him with open arms; and even his old African home longs to get him back. abstract: The pith and essence of President LINCOLN'S letter to Mr. GREELEY is, that he regards Slavery and everything relating to it as subordinate to the preservation of the Union. He does not intend to regulate his policy by his opinions concerning Slavery, either way.
lead_paragraph: The pith and essence of President LINCOLN'S letter to Mr. GREELEY is, that he regards Slavery and everything relating to it as subordinate to the preservation of the Union. He does not intend to regulate his policy by his opinions concerning Slavery, either way. He will not seek primarily to preserve it, nor to destroy it, nor to affect it in any manner. As an end of the war -- as something aimed at and sought for by the war -- he has nothing to do with Slavery. What he seeks is the preservation of the Union -- not the preservation or the destruction of Slavery. But he holds Slavery subordinate to the Union -- not superior to it, and he will use it so as to save the Union, if possible. If preserving Slavery will save the Union, he will preserve it; if destroying Slavery will save the Union, he will destroy it. The Union is the main thing. It is the sole object for which the war is waged. Everything else, Slavery included and Abolition included, must yield to it.

abstract: From Cape Race we learn of the passage of the steamship Hibernian, which left Liverpool on the 14th, and Londonderry on the 15th inst., with European advices one day later. Gen. CONCHA had presented his credentials at the French Court as Ambassador from Spain. The 15th instant was looked forward to generally as the time fixed upon for a demonstration throughout Italy against France.
lead_paragraph: From Cape Race we learn of the passage of the steamship Hibernian, which left Liverpool on the 14th, and Londonderry on the 15th inst., with European advices one day later. Gen. CONCHA had presented his credentials at the French Court as Ambassador from Spain. The 15th instant was looked forward to generally as the time fixed upon for a demonstration throughout Italy against France. The course of GARIBALDI, however, was condemned by the moderate journals of Italy. Advices from India to the 24th of July had reached England. An intense excitement existed in the Bombay cotton market, and an advance of 50 per cent, had taken place in some instances. There was also great excitement in the Calcutta market. A conference between representatives of cotton-growing countries, and a deputation of the Cotton Supply Association, had been held at London, where favorable representations of future supply were made. The sales in the Liverpool Cotton market for the week has been fifty thousand bales, and the market closed firm, at an advance of 1/4d.@3/8d. Breadstuffs tended downward, and Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 93 for money.

abstract: The Twelfth Annual Festival of the New-York Turnverein was celebrated yesterday at Jones Wood, with great spirit. The Turner Association of this City is an extensive, powerful and influential body, and embraces among its members some of the finest talent to be found within the circle of the German community of New-York, if not, indeed, of the whole Union.
lead_paragraph: The Twelfth Annual Festival of the New-York Turnverein was celebrated yesterday at Jones Wood, with great spirit. The Turner Association of this City is an extensive, powerful and influential body, and embraces among its members some of the finest talent to be found within the circle of the German community of New-York, if not, indeed, of the whole Union. The yearly celebration is usually conducted with immense eclat, but the Society having, within 18 months, sent a whole regiment to the war, and reinforced it several times, the number of regular members who could unite in the festivities of 1862 was much reduced.

lead_paragraph: A few days since we gave the official figures of our public debt, and deduced from them the probable expenditure of the current year ending 1st of July, 1863. The debt of 1st of July, 1862, we know to be five hundred and four and a half millions after deducting the money subject to draft then in the Treasury. The National debt on the 1st of July, 1863, we fixed at six hundred and twenty-six millions, after applying the ordinary revenue of the year, and the expected proceeds of the direct tax. This estimate is not a conjecture or a prophecy, but a calculation having the facts and figures of our last sixteen months' experience for its elements.

abstract: The letter in another column reviewing the conduct of the Military Department of the South, and presenting the results really achieved under the administration of Gen. HUNTER, does no more than justice to a valuable officer. We learn from our correspondent, that it was no part of the design of Government ...
lead_paragraph: The letter in another column reviewing the conduct of the Military Department of the South, and presenting the results really achieved under the administration of Gen. HUNTER, does no more than justice to a valuable officer. We learn from our correspondent, that it was no part of the design of Government to attack Charleston or Savannah, or to push any active operations toward the uplands of South Carolina and Georgia. The mission of Com. DUPONT and Gen. SHERMAN was rather to seize and hold certain points on the Southern coast, desirable as naval depots and harbors of refuge -- Port Royal being the chief of these, and being therefore strongly defended by the rebels. How effectually this was done we all know. Beaufort, Fernandina, St. Augustine -- positions of the highest value to our blockading squadrons, and indeed to the mercantile navy of the entire world -- were secured by the skillfully directed enterprise of our commanders. The forces placed at their disposal were apparently adequate to nothing more than this; and yet obtaining, by importunity, license to attack Fort Pulaski, then believed to be an impregnable fortification, they succeeded in achieving what the engineering department of the service had pronounced an impossibility.

abstract: The news from our armies in Virginia is meagre, but good what there is of it. lead_paragraph: The news from our armies in Virginia is meagre, but good what there is of it. A dispatch from Washington, dated Sunday, states that skirmishing had been going on during the past three days -- several attempts having been made by the rebels to cross the Rappahannock, which had all been successfully repulsed, and in one instance quite a number of prisoners captured. When the tried veterans under MCCLELLAN shall have reached their assigned positions, we may expect to hear of stirring events. It will be seen by our correspondence that they are well on their way.

abstract: The citizens of Hawley, above the age of 45, have organized an independent company of 120 men, and offered their services to the Government without bounty or pay. They say the whole honor of subduing the rebellion is not to be left to the boys; and they propose to prove that mature men of what is called middle age, have more of the heroic leaven than striplings. Hawley, it will be remembered, is at the head-waters of the Delaware and Hudsun Canal.

abstract: HOMICIDE IN WATER-STREET A WOMAN KICKED TO DEATH BY HER HUSBAND. At a late hour on Sunday evening, a woman named ANN DOWNING was so severely kicked and beaten by her husband that she died soon afterward, at her residence, No. 313 Water-street. An request was held upon the body yesterday, by Coroner RANNEY, when the following facts were disclosed.
lead_paragraph: HOMICIDE IN WATER-STREET -- A WOMAN KICKED TO DEATH BY HER HUSBAND. -- At a late hour on Sunday evening, a woman named ANN DOWNING was so severely kicked and beaten by her husband that she died soon afterward, at her residence, No. 313 Water-street. An request was held upon the body yesterday, by Coroner RANNEY, when the following facts were disclosed. In the early part of the evening RICHARD S. DOWNING, the officers, with his [???] and son, a lad about ten years of age, made a call upon a sister of the deceased, named ELLEN CONNER, at No. 36 Cherry-street. While at the latter place, the deceased, at the request of her husband, sent out and obtained a quart of beer. When this had been consumed, the husband insisted upon her sending for another quart, which she declined to do, and assigned as a reason that she had no more money. DOWNING then became very much enraged at his wife, and before leaving the house he applied many vile and abusive epithets to her. About 10 1/2 o'clock, they left the house for their residence. JAMES DOWNING, the son above alluded to, was the only witness as to what transpired after this time. He testified upon the inquest, that while they were going down the steps of No. 36 Cherry-street, his father struck his mother a violent blow with his fist, and that he continued to abuse her in one way and another until they arrived at their house. As soon as they entered their room the father began to kick and strike the woman upon various parts of her body, thereby inflicting injuries so serious that she died. What adds to the brutality of the offence is the fact, that at the time the woman was enceinte, and the outrage committed upon her person while in this condition renders the offender guilty of a double murder. A post-mortem examination made by Dr. GALEN HUNTER, made it evident that death ensued from an injury to the placenta. The jury rendered a verdict to the effect that the deceased came to her death by violence at the hands of her husband. Upon rendition of this verdict, DOWNING, who is an Irishman, about 38 years of age, was committed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The Winter Garden Theatre, handsomely refitted and redecorated throughout, was opened last evening for the Fall and Winter season under the management of Mr. JACKSON, whose direction of its fortunes during the past year was crowned with such remarkable success.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The Winter Garden Theatre, handsomely refitted and redecorated throughout, was opened last evening for the Fall and Winter season under the management of Mr. JACKSON, whose direction of its fortunes during the past year was crowned with such remarkable success. The house looks all the better for the freshening up it has received. Its walls no longer reflect a dubious shade of dingy red, dismal to the view of artistic male creatures, and ruinous to the complexion of lovely woman; but are tinted with a softening shade of delicate blue, judiciously relieved and brightened with a liberal amount of golden ornament. New curtains -- blue and yellow -- festoon the private boxes; a new and noise-subduing carpet mitigates the horrors of the middle passage that leads down to the orchestra stalls; new matting pervades the lobbies, within and without; the seats, in parquette and circle, have been beaten and brushed till they look rather better than new; and, in short, in every reasonable way, the entire premises have been made to assume as clean, brilliant and generally attractive an appearance as a fastidious but discriminating public can possibly desire.

abstract: -- We copy from the San Francisco Bulletin the following notice. When we state that the young officer referred to is the grand-son on one side, of the late Leonard Kip, Esq., many years ago President of the North River Bank, and, on the other side, of the late Isaac Lawrence, Esq., of this City, he will be acknowledged to be "an old New-Yorker." "After the battle of Williamsburgh, four officers of the regular army were recommended to headquarters as deserving brevets 'for gallant and meritorious conduct on the field.' One of these was the sun of the Bishop of California, First Lieut. Lawrence Kip, of the ThirdArtillery, who is now Senior Aid-de-Camp to Gen. Sumner, with the rank, of Major. After the battle of Fair Oaks, there was another recommendation of seven regular officers from Sumner's Division, for their gallantry in that two days; fight, and in this list the name of Major Kip was again included for gallant conduct. In the last decisive bayonet charge, which Gen. Sumner led in person, and which broke the ranks of the enemy. Maj. Kip rode at his side, under the heavy fire of the Confederate line, and escaped unhurt, his horse only being wounded. Since then, he has been through the seven days' severe lighting before Richmond, where Gen. Sumner was wounded."

abstract: We do not expect to live long enough to see a Government which knows how to deal with the public Press. The official portion of mankind seems to be divided into two classes on this subject: one class regards the Press as a wild beast, to be hunted and harried by every available weapon, and the other as a ...
lead_paragraph: We do not expect to live long enough to see a Government which knows how to deal with the public Press. The official portion of mankind seems to be divided into two classes on this subject: -- one class regards the Press as a wild beast, to be hunted and harried by every available weapon, and the other as a powerful monster, to be appeased by sycophancy and toadying. Both may possibly find, in specific cases, ground for their opinions. But it seems a little singular that, in a free country, living under republican institutions, men in power should be unable to form any more just estimate of the public Press, as a whole, than such sentiments indicate.

abstract: BROOKLYN MILITARY AFFAIRS. The men of the Empire Brigade returned yesterday in large numbers, and before night about 1,500 recruits had arrived at the barracks in East New-York. All the members of the First Regiment, Col. JOURDAN, are coming back, and by Wednesday, every man heretofore enlisted will be in camp.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN MILITARY AFFAIRS. -- The men of the Empire Brigade returned yesterday in large numbers, and before night about 1,500 recruits had arrived at the barracks in East New-York. All the members of the First Regiment, Col. JOURDAN, are coming back, and by Wednesday, every man heretofore enlisted will be in camp. The Captains and Lieutenants are acquainted with most of their men, and are confident that all will report within a day or two, and do duty as heretofore. Notwithstanding the disturbance on Saturday afternoon, the First Regiment enlisted 36 men yesterday. They now number 600 men, and by the end of this week will have the full quota. The following order, issued by the Brigadier-General, was promulgated on the 25th inst.

abstract: -- How many deputise does Sheriff LYNCH require just now? We are prompted to make the inquiry from having heard of several persons who have received appointments at his hands since the order for a draft was issued. By a somewhat curious coincidence, the persons so favored happen in most cases to be those who are thoroughly secesh in their sympathies. We respectfully submit to the Sheriff that he aided the Secessionists quite as much as any one man ought to do, by "marching to the rear to the sound of the enemy's cannon" at Bull Run. It is not fair for him to screen others from doing military duty.

lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Twentieth Regiment New-York Volunteers, recruited under the last call, arrived in this City by steamboat and barges yesterday morning. They were quartered in the Park Barracks during the day, and left for Washington at 6 o'clock last evening, via the New-Jersey Railroad. The regiment was recruited in Ulster County, and is composed of fine, healthy and rugged material. Several of its officers have seen service, among them the Colonel, GEO. H. SHARP, who served as Captain in the Thirtieth Regiment N.Y.S.M. The following is a list of the officers:

abstract: Among the speakers at the Pennsylvania Democratic Convention on Saturday was Mr. CHARLES J. INGERSOLL, a noted politician and noteless historian, who said, on that occasion, sundry very foolish things. Among others, these: "The war is an abolition war; it is waged by the Administration with a view to emancipation, and not to a restoration of the Union and the preservation of the Constitution; that vast sums and vast armies have been raised by the Government, and remain unaccounted for; that the Government is corrupt, despotic, revolutionary, and should be displaced from power." Now, Mr. INGERSOLL knew that every word he uttered was just the word that JEFF. DAVIS, had he wherewith to pay, would have paid him lavishly to utter; that every period was a stab at the very heart of the nation; and that he was fairly exposing himself to just the punishment merited by the man who, whether rebel General-in-Chief, soldier or hired emissary, most effectually promotes treason. He had obviously this fact before his eyes when he consoled himself with the reflection:

abstract: The steamer Metropolis, her tackle and cargo, vs. The United States. BETTS, J. This vessel and cargo was captured off Charleston harbor July 31, 1862, and brought into this port by a prize master on the 4th of August afterward.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Metropolis, her tackle and cargo, vs. The United States. -- BETTS, J. -- This vessel and cargo was captured off Charleston harbor July 31, 1862, and brought into this port by a prize master on the 4th of August afterward. On the 7th of August.the District-Attorney addressed a letter to the Judge, then absent from the City, and out of the District, stating that no appearance had been given in Court for the prize, and upon the usual evidence requesting, in behalf of the Government, the appointment of appraisers to value the vessel and cargo, and that thereupon the prize be appropriated and delivered over to the public use on depositing its appraised value in the office of the Assistant Treasurer, subject to the judgment and direction of the Court. The order was signed by the Judge and remitted to the District-Attorney, and was filed in Court on the 13th of July, and by the papers filed on this motion it would appear that the order so signed was received here on the 9th of August. On the 8th of August the vessel and her fitments were libeled by the United States for condemnation as prize of war, and on the 9th of the same month a proctor for the claimants gave notice to the District-Attorney of his appearance in the suit.

abstract: Gov. WASHBURN, of Maine, announces that the draft will not commence in that State till thy 10th of September. It is published in Indiana that the drafting there will not commence till the 15th of September.
lead_paragraph: Gov. WASHBURN, of Maine, announces that the draft will not commence in that State till thy 10th of September. It is published in Indiana that the drafting there will not commence till the 15th of September. The dispatches from Washington announce that there is present at the Capital a strong delegation from Pennsylvania, to urge the extension of the time before the draft shall begin in that State. On the other hand, it has been published, that in regard to the State of New-York, Secretary STANTON is immovable in his purpose to have the draft begin on the 1st of September -- "if for no other purpose, to show that the Government has power to compel its citizens to its support."

abstract: Editorial on exemption of Quakers from military duty because of their conscientious scruples; Editorial on exemption from military duty because of beliefs
snippet: Editorial on exemption of Quakers from military duty because of their conscientious scruples; Editorial on exemption from military duty because of beliefs
lead_paragraph: -- The Evening Post raises a question as to the propriety of exempting Quakers from military duty. This is done in this State by law, and the law of Congress exempts all who are exempted by State laws. We concur with the Post in doubting the justice or wisdom of such exemption. The ground on which it is granted is that the Quakers have conscientious scruples against fighting. But a legal concession to such scruples is, in fact, an acknowledgment that the laws requiring military service are fairly open to objection on moral grounds, -- in other words, that it is or may be immoral to require a citizen to fight for his country; and such a concession as this, it is not right for any Government to make.
headline: {'main': 'THE EXEMPTION OF QUAKERS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE EXEMPTION OF QUAKERS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We under  A DIVISION FOR GEN. CORCORAN. We under  stand that, up to this time, Gen. CORCORAN has received the offer of over twenty regiments, of which, so far, he has accepted but two, Col. HEENAN'S, and Col. McMAHON'S Buffalo Regiment, which, with the original New-York Sixty-ninth, will leave him only one vacancy he can fill, under his Brigadier's commission.
lead_paragraph: -- We understand that, up to this time, Gen. CORCORAN has received the offer of over twenty regiments, of which, so far, he has accepted but two, Col. HEENAN'S, and Col. McMAHON'S Buffalo Regiment, which, with the original New-York Sixty-ninth, will leave him only one vacancy he can fill, under his Brigadier's commission. The question now is, whether it is not to the interest of the Government to take immediate advantage of the wonderful enthusiasm for this brave soldier, and, without the delay of an hour, empower him, as Gen. ANDERSON was empowered in Kentucky, to raise as many regiments as he may see fit.

abstract: Judge-Advocate-General ANTHON and his aide are progressing rapidly with the work of enrollment. Yesterday a number of clerks were employed faircopying the returns of the enrolling-officers. Occasional complaints are made by people whom the officers have visited for information complaints of which the staple is that the officers are unpleasantly energetic and determined in the execution of their disagreeable duties.
lead_paragraph: Judge-Advocate-General ANTHON and his aide are progressing rapidly with the work of enrollment. Yesterday a number of clerks were employed faircopying the returns of the enrolling-officers. Occasional complaints are made by people whom the officers have visited for information -- complaints of which the staple is that the officers are unpleasantly energetic and determined in the execution of their disagreeable duties. These complaints the Judge-Advocate hears and adjudicates upon. Very few of them, though, demand any serious notice. The special police appointed to assist the enrolling-officers have had to be called upon in several instances, but, as a general thing, names are obtained with less difficulty than was anticipated. It is useless for housekeepers to try to evade the inquiries made of them. They only cause themselves and the officers useless trouble. They should cheerfully give any information in their power, and instruct their servants to do the same. Especially should they do this in large boarding establishments, where an extensive class of young men reside, whom it is difficult for the officers to follow and lay their hands upon. All able-bodied males are liable to be enrolled. Those entitled to exemption can have their claims examined by the Drafting Commissioners.

abstract: Articles on police dept. operations
snippet: Articles on police dept. operations
lead_paragraph: The police in France is not simply a body organized with a view to the prevention and repression of crimes and misdemeanors. It is the executive of the thousand and one laws and regulations which have been decreed for the welfare of the community at large, and of each individual in particular. Unless the police be invested with peculiarly extended powers, it only reacts negatively upon the citizens, positively upon the criminal. For example, in America, so long as you or I behave ourselves decently -- and even here a considerable latitude is given in the interpretation of out conduct -- so long as we neither kill, rob, nor assault, so long as we are neither killed, robbed, nor assaulted, we may pass our entire existences without knowing a policeman save as a quiet individual who stands upon the corner of our street in a state of somnolent stupidity. To the criminal this individual is invested with peculiar terrors; he represents the avenging spirit of the law, and to the evil doer he is one who can cause to be inflicted a punishment more or less severe. Save in the great points of public safety, the policeman does not interfere with the well-behaved citizen in any wise. As regards the petty annoyances of our everyday life, these are matters over which we may watch ourselves. If our grocer chooses to mix plaster of Paris with the powdered sugar he sells us, the affair lies between ourselves and him. If our milkman delivers us cream containing 75 per cent. of pump-water, we are at liberty to discharge him. It requires a general outburst of popular indignation to effect the suppression of such an institution as distillery cow stables. Who would ever think of appealing to the policeman at the corner? We may drink our decoction of logwood, or our strychnined whisky, with impunity; we may even offer glasses of them to the policeman of our beat. We may tell him, if we choose, that they emanate from the distillery of J. Smith & Sons. All this is none of his business. Our infant children may die in their cradles from contaminated food; we ourselves may suffer from the mistakes of ignorant apothecaries' apprentices; the great social evil may stalk in rusty satin and rouge beneath the windows at which our wives and daughters dare no longer sit; but so long as there is no physical attempt at disturbing what is conventionally called the public peace; so long as there is no flagrant outrage to what are called public morals, the policeman quietly dozes against his lamp-post, and if, perchance, elected to a quiet neighborhood, may pass weeks in the passive fulfillment of his duties.
headline: {'main': 'THE FRENCH POLICE.; Its Duties as a Body Protective of Public Interests, and Conducive to Public Comfort. abstract: MILITARY AFFAIRS IN BROOKLYN. Recruiting continues brisk with both Col. JOURDAN'S and Col. CONK'S regiments, and the prospects now are that both will be filled within the coming week. A camp for the first regiment will be formed on the parade ground at East New-York to-day, when the barracks will be relieved of a sufficient number of its overcrowded occupants to make it more comfortable for those who remain.
lead_paragraph: MILITARY AFFAIRS IN BROOKLYN. -- Recruiting continues brisk with both Col. JOURDAN'S and Col. CONK'S regiments, and the prospects now are that both will be filled within the coming week. A camp for the first regiment will be formed on the parade ground at East New-York to-day, when the barracks will be relieved of a sufficient number of its overcrowded occupants to make it more comfortable for those who remain. A camp for Col. CONK's Regiment has been formed on the City Park, opposite the Navy-yard. The men are ordered to go into quarters to-day.

abstract: Gen. CORCORAN, with his "bully boys" of the gallant Sixty-ninth, will be here to-day. God bless them! It is understood that the regiment is returning home to reorganize for the war, and to be a portion of the Irish Legion which Gen. CORCORAN proposes raising immediately.
lead_paragraph: Gen. CORCORAN, with his "bully boys" of the gallant Sixty-ninth, will be here to-day. God bless them! It is understood that the regiment is returning home to reorganize for the war, and to be a portion of the Irish Legion which Gen. CORCORAN proposes raising immediately. In consideration of this fact the Common Council will pay them the unprecedented compliment of escorting them to the City Hall, from Jersey City, in a body, on foot, bearing their municipal slaves of office. The Committee on National Affairs intend to pay the same honor to any of our three months regiments returning home with a view of reorganizing for further service in the field. The members of the Common Council are to meet at the City Hall at noon, to-day.
headline: {'main': 'Sixty-Ninth Home Again.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Sixty-Ninth Home Again.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The firemen having had their reception of the brave Capt. DOWNEY, of the Ellsworth Zouaves, just returned from southern captivity, the Municipal authorities in turn gave a banquet in honor of the same gentleman, last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
lead_paragraph: The firemen having had their reception of the brave Capt. DOWNEY, of the Ellsworth Zouaves, just returned from southern captivity, the Municipal authorities in turn gave a banquet in honor of the same gentleman, last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Alderman FARLEY, Chairman of the Committee on National Affairs, occupied the head of the table. On his right were Capt. DOWNEY, the guest of the evening; Gen. ANTHON, Chief Engineer DECKER, Fire Commissioner WILSON, Alderman MITCHELL and Councilman LONG. On his left were Alderman SMITH; Lieut.-Col. JENKINS, of the Ninety-ninth New-York; Councilman LENT, JONAS N. PHILLIPS, Esq., and others. The tables were filled with members of Engine Company No. 34, and many gentlemen of note in the Government of the City. The tables were loaded with one of the St. Nicholas' best collations, to which good appetites did full justice. The ornaments consisted of flowers, several Hibernian harps, and fancy confectionery pieces: Although nominally commencing at 8 o'clock, the feast did not begin until near 10, and the hour-hand was fast approaching 11 before the cloth was removed, and Alderman TERENCE FARLEY announced the first regular toast -- "The President of the United States " -- which drew forth three glorious cheers and a tiger.

abstract: Three more full reviments, from New-England, passed through this City yesterday, on their way to the seat of war, viz.: the Fourteenth Connecticut, Eighteenth Maine and Ninth New-Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Three more full reviments, from New-England, passed through this City yesterday, on their way to the seat of war, viz.: the Fourteenth Connecticut, Eighteenth Maine and Ninth New-Hampshire. The Connecticut Regiment arrived in the steamboat City of Hartford, at 6 o'clock in the morning, and landed at Pier No. 2, North River, and soon after embarked for Elizabethport, N.J.; whence they took the cars for Philadelphia. The regiment numbers over 1,600 men, and is armed with the Springfield rifle. Nearly all of the officers have seen service in the present war -- the Lieut.-Colonel (S.H. PERKINS) having been in the seven days' fight in front of Richmond, as an officer of the First Connecticut Artillery.

abstract: The design of the Committee who have in charge the great gathering in the Park this afternoon is an admirable one. It is designed to be purely a War meeting. Mere spouting is to be strictly eschewed, and the whole concourse will form itself into a Committee on the three following duties: 1. To fill up the veteran regiments of New-York volunteers. 2. To make full response to the call for new regiments. 3. To organize and fill up the Corcoran Brigade before the month expires. We shall measure the success of the meeting by the shortness of the speeches, and the length of the subscription and volunteering rolls.

abstract: RECRUITING IN HUDSON, N.J. At West Hoboken, the quota under the first call is more than made up, and the number needed under the second call will undoubtedly be; and if 500,000 more are wanted, West Hoboken will send her quota as volun  teers. The town gives $100 bounty to each, and provides for the families.
lead_paragraph: RECRUITING IN HUDSON, N.J. -- At West Hoboken, the quota under the first call is more than made up, and the number needed under the second call will undoubtedly be; and if 500,000 more are wanted, West Hoboken will send her quota as volun teers. The town gives $100 bounty to each, and provides for the families. The people hold meetingsevery day, at which Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL has presided, assisted by all the clergy and the leading men of the town. A grand demonstration and procession comes off on Thursday night. At a large meeting on Saturday, the vote was unanimous to give bounty by the town. No man rose in the vote to oppose it. Party issues are all buried. It is the Union -- let it be saved, whatever else perishes.

abstract: -- A correspondent writes from Frankfort-on-the-Main, that large numbers of Germans of every rank are offering themselves at the American Consulate for service in the Union army. Among the number is Karl Washington, a Bavarian baron, a Lieutenant in the army of that country, a nobleman of high standing. He is wealthy, speaks French, German and English. His ancestors, he says, were Hollanders, and emigrated from England to Holland abuot two hundred years ago; and he has the WASHINGTON pedigree, showing the original families were probably the same. Strange to say, he is a Roman Catholic.
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent writes from Frankfort-on-the-Main, that large numbers of Germans of every rank are offering themselves at the American Consulate for service in the Union army. His ancestors, he says, were Hollanders, and emigrated from England to Holland abuot two hundred years ago; and he has the WASHINGTON pedigree, showing the original families were probably the same. Strange to say, he is a Roman Catholic.

abstract: Some of our neighbors have a good deal to say of the alacrity with which they have complied with the wishes of the Government in withholding from the public news of army movements.
lead_paragraph: Some of our neighbors have a good deal to say of the alacrity with which they have complied with the wishes of the Government in withholding from the public news of army movements. We indorse heartily all the commendation they bestow on themselves for their abstemiousness. For ourselves, we have only to say that we have never received from "the Government" any intimation that they had any wish whatever on the subject of army news. Previous to the expected advance upon Richmond, we were requested to publish no reports of the movement of troops, the location of camps, or anything else that could give information of value to the enemy; -- but after Gen. MCCLELLAN concluded not to advance upon Richmond, we were notified that the restrictions upon correspondence had been removed. Since then, the Press, so far as we are aware, has received no instructions, requests, or notifications of any kind from the Government at Washington. We have been permitted to expend large sums of money in keeping correspondents with the army, in order to report for the public information whatever the army might do. And just as the army gets ready to do something, our correspondents are summarily dismissed as meddlers and interlopers; and the Press is left to pick up information as it can from army stragglers and public rumor. The public, we trust, will not hold the Press responsible for the accuracy of intelligence thus collected.

abstract: Rice et al. vs. Whitlock. This was an action upon an undertaking executed by the defendant as surety in an action in which these plaintiffs were plaintiffs, and one Isham, the defendant, on an appeal therein from the Special to the General Term.
lead_paragraph: Rice et al. vs. Whitlock. -- This was an action upon an undertaking executed by the defendant as surety in an action in which these plaintiffs were plaintiffs, and one Isham, the defendant, on an appeal therein from the Special to the General Term. The judgment was affirmed at the General Term, and from that affirmance an appeal (before the commencement of this action) had been taken to the Court of Appeals by Isham, and the usual undertaking to stay proceedings under sections 334 and 335 of the Code, was filed and served. Upon the call of the case for trial, the defendant's counsel appeared, and objected to proceeding to trial, showing the following facts: That immediately after the commencement of this action, the defendant moved at Special Term for a stay of proceedings in this action until the decision of the case in the Court of Appeals; that the motion was granted unless the plaintiff should, within ten days, execute a bond, with two sureties, to the defendant, conditioned to return the money that should be collected in this action, in case the said judgment should be reversed in the Court of Appeals; that on the 10th day plaintiffs' attorney served a copy of a bond, under and pursuant to the requirements of the order, with a notice that the original was filed with the Clerk of this Court. The defendant's attorney thereupon objected, in writing, that such filing was not a good delivery of the bond, and demanded that the original bond be delivered; on that or the following day, and that the plaintiffs' attorneys refused to do so.

abstract: The rain of Friday afternoon and night, and Saturday last, in the vicinity of the Upper Rappahannock, served to swell the river so as to make it unfordable anywhere below the mountains, a few miles back of Warrenton Springs, which, of course, put a stop to efforts of the rebel army on its western and southern bank to repeat their apparent attempts of Thursday and Friday last to cross the river in force.
lead_paragraph: The rain of Friday afternoon and night, and Saturday last, in the vicinity of the Upper Rappahannock, served to swell the river so as to make it unfordable anywhere below the mountains, a few miles back of Warrenton Springs, which, of course, put a stop to efforts of the rebel army on its western and southern bank to repeat their apparent attempts of Thursday and Friday last to cross the river in force. Nevertheless, the artillery firing at nearly all the fords, from the Springs down to Fredericksburg, was kept up on Saturday and yesterday with more or less spirit, but with no results that have been deemed sufficiently important to be reported here by persons coming from that quarter.

abstract: The rebel legislators who have just assembled in their Congress at Richmond, strikingly reveal the terror with which the prospective arming of the negroes inspires them, for no less than two bills on the subject were introduced on the first day of their sitting. The one was introduced by Mr. MILES, of South Carolina, and the other by Mr. FOOTS, of Tennessee; and both provide that slaves taken in arms shall be delivered up to the authorities to be disposed of, while their commanders are to be "hung or shot, as may be most convenient." But what is most notable in the matter is that the measure is looked, upon with equal dread whether it shall be employed by themselves or by us. In no instance hitherto have they dared to put arms into the hands of the negroes; and when lately Gen. MERCIER, of Georgia, issued an order for the enrollment of one-fifth of the male slaves of that State, it so alarmed the people of Georgia that the Confederate Secretary of War was compelled to issue an order severely reprobating the proposition. Now, it is very proper for the rebels to shrink from the idea of the arming of the slaves, even by themselves, for they know to what den of horrors it will ultimately open the door; but if they expect that we are to be scared off from using this or any other means, if necessary, by any threats of theirs, they commit a fatal error. The employment of the negroes as soldiers is, perhaps, the only important question in the conduct of the war touching which there is a division of sentiment among the people of the loyal States; but the division is, after all, but superficial, and may readily give way to the teaching of events. The present course of the rebels is fast tending to change public opinion on this point. And if the rebel legislators wish to make the fusion perfect, they have only to adopt the menacing measures which these bills propose.

abstract: THE FOOD FOR SOLDIERS. The ladies having the control of the Society for the Relief of Sick and Wounded Soldiers, sometime since complained publicly that those people were not well treated at the hospitals on Bedloe's Island.
lead_paragraph: THE FOOD FOR SOLDIERS. -- The ladies having the control of the Society for the Relief of Sick and Wounded Soldiers, sometime since complained publicly that those people were not well treated at the hospitals on Bedloe's Island. They in particular did not approve of the food given them, thinking very strangely that sick and wounded soldiers, who were convalescing, needed something besides the hard and unpalatable fare provided for the tough and hungry soldier in the field. To this view and interference, Gen. HARVEY BROWN took exception in a card, and rather broadly intimated that if the ladies would allow the Government to attend to its own business, and would confine themselves to the care of the families of the soldiers, it would, perhaps, be just as well for all concerned in the end. The ladies, nothing daunted, reply to Gen. BROWN, and, in closing, say:

abstract: Editorial favors full publicity on all military operations
snippet: Editorial favors full publicity on all military operations
lead_paragraph: -- The Herald suggests that Gen. HALLECK should at once apply to Gen. STUART'S rebel cavalry the same rule which he has enforced against newspaper correspondents, and that they be excluded wholly from the lines of our army. They certainly get a great deal more valuable information than our Press could give them, especially if the report is true that they dashed in one morning and seized all Gen. POPE's baggage, private papers, charts, maps, &c., including Gen. HALLECK's dispatches, plans of the campaign, and specific instructions about newspaper correspondents. Something of the energy and vigilance so lavishly used in preventing the loyal people of the country from knowing what their army is doing, might be usefully bestowed on the rebel cavalry.

abstract: Editorials discuss fairness of draft over volunteering
snippet: Editorials discuss fairness of draft over volunteering
lead_paragraph: We regard with great suspicion the efforts made in various quarters to delay or prevent altogether the enforcement of the draft. Drafting is the most just and equitable mode of securing from the people the performance of military duty. Every man owes that duty to his country. In this respect all stand upon precisely the same footing. Volunteering throws the whole burden of military service upon those who are willing to perform it, -- leaving the least patriotic portion of the public entirely free from the hardships and obligations which patriotism imposes upon all alike.
headline: {'main': 'Drafting and Volunteering.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Drafting and Volunteering.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Sixty-ninth Regiment, with Col. CORCORAN at the head, returned from Washington yesterday, and arrived in time to receive the greetings of the thousands of citizens assembled at the great war
lead_paragraph: The Sixty-ninth Regiment, with Col. CORCORAN at the head, returned from Washington yesterday, and arrived in time to receive the greetings of the thousands of citizens assembled at the great war meeting in the Park. At the railroad stations on the route to this City the regiment was received with the greatest enthusiasm by the people, and on their arrival at the Jersey City depot they were surrounded, on emerging from the cars, by thousands of citizens, who cheered them as they entered the ferryboat. The Common Council, with their badges of office, met the regiment at the Cortlandt-street ferry, and at 4 o'clock the procession was formed, and moved to the City Hall Park in the following order:

abstract: At the late half-yearly meeting of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, the Chairman, after describingthe steps which the Chamber had taken relative to the principal questions noticed in the report, said they had not felt it their duty to make any representations to the Government relative to the present unfortunate struggle in America. It was impossible for any one to foretell how that struggle would end; but if it ended in the separation of the Southern from the NorthernStates, he (Mr. CHILTON,) had no doubt that ultimately, as had been the case with our own colonies, that separationwould be regarded by both of the parties at present contending as a blessing.

abstract: Edward Cunningham vs. Philo B. Buckingham, impleaded, &c. -- This was a motion to compel the defendant, Buckingham, to produce certain books which were used on the trial in June last, and for the appointment of a receiver for certain notes alleged to have been taken by Buckingham while there was a stay of proceedings. An attachment had been issued in the cause and served on one Cromwell, who is said to have owed Buckingham. After the verdict of the jury, and while there was a stay of proceedings, it is alleged that Buckingham obtained from Cromwell his negotiable notes. The books referred to used on the trial, were produced by defendants, who now refuse to furnish them on making a case for a new trial on the ground of surprise.

abstract: oughly as to leave little cause for complaint and less chance for evasion. It is the Judge-Advocate's intention to execute the duty assigned him with as small an amount of vexation or annoyance to the public as possible; but he means to execute rigorously for all that. He means to have upon his lists the name of every able-bodied citizen within the limits of his jurisdiction. If he can obtain those names by fair means, he will be highly gratified; but should stern measures be rendered necessary, he will not hesitate to resort to them. There is reason to believe that many attempts have been made to deceive and mislead the enrolling officers. Some of these attempts are temporarily successful. Yet they cannot be permanently so; and, when exposed, they will be the cause of trouble and unpleasantness to all who have been foolish enough to make them. The conscription law not only provides for the enrollment of able-bodied citizens, but it also provides punishment for those who seek to avoid the draft themselves, or endeavor to shield others from its legitimate effects. A case in point was brought under the Judge Advocate's cognizance yesterday. It seems that the book-keeper of one of the leaning gas companies, when called on for the names of the employes of the concern, furnished the enrolling officer with a correct list of names, but opposite the names put a number of fictitious addresses. The book-keeper was immediately arrested, and will speedily undergo examination. By way of facilitating the procurement of correct lists, it has been suggested that all the rolls shall be published, when it is expected that every one whose name is down will, on finding the names of persons he knows omitted, give information of the fact, and have it remedied. The suggestion is a shrewd one, and must have been made by an admirer of the amiable side of human nature. The Judge-Advocate General's office is just now, with the exception, perhaps, of the Quartermaster's, the busiest place in New-York. A small army of clerks is engaged there copying the enrolling officers' entries into election district books, and then engrossing from the district books into Ward books. The administration of the Enrollment Police Department affords an agreeable variety to the clerical business of the establishment.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: The important correspondence between Secretary SEWARD and Earl RUSSELL, which we published in full yesterday, opens up a new and interesting chapter in our diplomacy. The dispatch of Earl RUSSELL, transmitted by telegraph the day previously, gave an indication of the line of argument submitted by Mr. SEWARD; though the evasive and cynical reply of the Foreign Secretary but half revealed, while half concealing, the real import of this significant (?) State paper. Published side by side, they explain and supplement each other.

abstract: The intelligence from our armies in Virginia isbrief, but of an encouraging character. Everything was quiet at Warrenton and Warrenton Junction on Sunday and Monday, and it was believed that this side of the Rappahannock was entirely clear of the rebels relative to whose
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from our armies in Virginia isbrief, but of an encouraging character. Everything was quiet at Warrenton and Warrenton Junction on Sunday and Monday, and it was believed that this side of the Rappahannock was entirely clear of the rebels -- relative to whose movements, however, there appears to be no very definite knowledge, though it was recently reported that they were falling back, toward Culpepper. On Saturday last they made a formidable demonstration against Rappahannock Station, and forced its abandonment by our force there. Before falling back, our troops burned the bridge across the Rappahannock, and blew up the abutments. Our stores and ammunition were also removed, and the houses at the Station were burnt -- all of which was accomplished without my casualties on our part. The Washington Star of Tuesday evening is of opinion that the great bulk of the rebel force has fallen back again to Gordonsville.

abstract: -- The Government was very properly taken in hand the speculative gentlemen who have embarked in the business of insuring against drafting. An order, transmitted through the Police yesterday, gave notice that this, as one of the methods of "discounting enlistment," must be discontinued and the advertisements withdrawn from the newspapers. So far as the Press is concerned the order is received with entire satisfaction. There can be no question that the eager and public canvass of the means of escaping the draft, and of evading military service altogether, must act offensively and discouragingly upon those who are volunteering, under the compulsion of the coming draft, and whose insufficient means prevent them from purchasing immunity. But this is a secondary evil. Such extreme activity in the substitute market naturally prompts the half-decided to reserve their valuable persons for the better prices which are to prevail after the draft, if the present artificial excitement produce its natural effect upon the rates. Thus thousands are withheld from volunteering by considerations of an utterly sordid character.

abstract: Yesterday a naval general Court-Martial convened at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, to try Lieut.-Commander BARRETT, of the navy, whose arrest we noticed on Friday last. Commodore MERVINE and Commodore BREEZE are among the officers of the Court. The offence with which the Lieutenant-Commander is charged is alleged to have been committed while the sailors of the North Carolina were proceeding to the Union meeting at Union-square. It it said Lieut. BARRETT ordered the men to groan for the Abolitionists. On the other hand, his friends claim that he is a genuine Union man; that he has always proved his loyalty, and that no proof of disaffection toward the nation can be substantiated. The proceedings of the Court will be conducted in private.

abstract: We are informed from a most loyal and reliable source that Sheriff LYNCH has not made any appointments as general deputies since the order for draft commenced, nor even at a time when a draft was talked about. That his deputies are all loyal men. And that his special deputations can in no wise be construed as exempting the temporary holders. Under these assurances we take pleasure in correcting our previous information.

abstract: THE MOVEMENT IN HUNTERDON COUNTY. -- At a meeting held in Union Township, Hunterdon Co., N.J., on Monday, Aug. 25, it was unanimously resolved that a bounty of $125 be given to every man who shall volunteer to serve in the army in accordance with the last call of the Governor. A muster roll was furnished and several hardy men at once enlisted. This township is fully alive to the duties which devolve upon it, and every man emulates the spirit of his sires, knowing that patriotism is "the noblest passion that animates a man in the character of a citizen."

abstract: Another splendid regiment from the Old Bay State passed by New-York, yesterday, on its way to the Capital. This regiment, which will be known as the Thirty-eighth Messachusetis, has been rapidly recruited, chiefly in the extreme eastern counties, and...
lead_paragraph: Another splendid regiment from the Old Bay State passed by New-York, yesterday, on its way to the Capital. This regiment, which will be known as the Thirty-eighth Messachusetis, has been rapidly recruited, chiefly in the extreme eastern counties, and is as splendid a body of men as ever New-England has yet sent to the war. There isn't a small or puny individual amongst them. They are stalwart, able-bodied fellows, every one of them, and of a different class from many of those who go from the large cities. They have not enlisted for the sake of the bounty, but from a higher motive of patriotism; from a deep conviction of the unrighteousness of the Rebellion, and with the firm determination to do their best to put it down. In the six weeks they have been in camp at Lynn, they have learned the advantages of discipline, and some of the rudiments of drill. Through the pressure on the Quartermaster's Department of Massachusetts, it has not been found possible to supply the whole regiment with uniforms and equipments. These, however, will be distributed on the regiment's arrival at Washington. But each man has an Enfield rifle of the very best description, and every one of them has a true soldier's heart in his breast, though his trousers may not be of the regulation pattern. There are 1,040 men in the Thirty-eighth, nearly every one of whom is American born, and of respectable family. Professional men are in the ranks, as well as farmers, artisans and clerks. The officers are all believed to be competent. The Colonel is now with the Eighteenth Massachusetts, from which regiment he is detailed to take command of this. The Lieutenant-Colonel was out with the Fifth Massachusetts Militia three months, and has lately been Major of the Twenty-second Massachusetts Volunteers, leading it through all the perils of the Peninsula campaign.

abstract: A HOMICIDE IN THE TENTH WARD. About 3  o'clock yesterday morning, a disturbance occurred between a man named JACOB WEILER and his wife, at No. 154 Essex-Street. Officer LEWIS, of the Tenth...
lead_paragraph: A HOMICIDE IN THE TENTH WARD. -- About 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, a disturbance occurred between a man named JACOB WEILER and his wife, at No. 154 Essex-Street. Officer LEWIS, of the Tenth Precinct, was in the vicinity at the time, and hearing a report of a pistol at the house above indicated, he immediately went there, and, upon entering a room on the third floor, he found the deceased, Mrs. JOSEPHINE WEILER, lying upon the floor of the room, and bleeding profusely from the effects of a wound in the left breast. She expired in a few minutes afterward. The body was examined yesterday afternoon by Dr. ROBINSON, Deputy Coroner, who gave it as his opinion, upon the inquest held by Coroner NAUMANN, that death ensued from a pistol-shot wound, in or near the heart. A sister of the deceased testified that she saw the prisoner and his wife nearly all day on Tuesday, and that in the evening, about 9 o'clock, she was present when the prisoner and deceased had a quarrel, during which the prisoner said to the deceased that if the latter said another word to him he would shoot her. Coroner NAUMANN began an inquest at the Tenth Precinct Station-house yesterday, but after the examination of two witnesses the case was adjourned until to-day.
