lead_paragraph: The Mass Meeting held in the Park yesterday afternoon was a tremendous affair. The Park was full. The enthusiasm equalled that exhibitied at any other meeting of the season, and when CORCORAN, with the Sixty-ninth, appeared, it seemed as if the entire vox populi was doing its best to thunder out a welcome. A full report of the meeting, with the eloquent remarks and practical results thereof, will be found in another part of the paper.

abstract: The recent  decision of the State Department, declaring exempt from military service foreign residents who have simply declared their intention to become citizens, conflicts with the previous
lead_paragraph: -- The recent decision of the State Department, declaring exempt from military service foreign residents who have simply declared their intention to become citizens, conflicts with the previous policy of the Government. KOSZTA, whom Capt. INGRAHAM removed from beneath the Austrian flag, had only declared his intentions, but was, nevertheless, regarded as an American citizen, fully entitled to the protection of the American flag. The same doctrinehas been consistently held in cases where an intending subject of this Government has been impressed in foreign military service. All such have been uniformly regarded as so bound to military obligations in this country as to be necessarily exempted abroad. Mr. SEWARD's dictum is important as determining, in a more rational and positive form, the rights of this class of our residents.

abstract: -- A method of extracting alcohol from coal gas has been discovered at St. Quentin, France, by a young chemist named COTELLE. abstract: The Nineteenth Regiment Maine Volunteers arrived here in the steamer Commonwealth, yesterday morning, and landed at Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: The Nineteenth Regiment Maine Volunteers arrived here in the steamer Commonwealth, yesterday morning, and landed at Jersey City. The regiment left their camp at Bath on Wednesday morning, having been presented just previous to their departure with a magnificent stand of colors, the gift of the citizens of Bath. The regiment numbers over 1,000 men, and is splendidly equipped, and armed with Enfield rifles. The officers have all seen service. They left for Washington at 11 o'clock via the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. The following is a list of the officers:

abstract: The return match between the above Clubs took place yesterday on the ground of the New-York and Manhattan Clubs at Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: The return match between the above Clubs took place yesterday on the ground of the New-York and Manhattan Clubs at Hoboken. It terminated in another victory for St. George. This contest was remarkable for the fine scores of Mr. WALLER -- in which were three threes and seven twos -- and of Mr. CREIGHTON and young GEORGE WRIGHT, the former scoring three threes and nine twos in his finely obtained score, and GEORGE getting a four, four threes and nine twos, in his splendid half hundred. Capt. LAING played very steadily for three twos and two singles.

abstract: A force of 50,000 rebels their whole left wing  crossed the Rappahannock on Sunday morning last, near the Warrenton Springs. The force embraced infantry, cavalry and artillery, and the indications were that they had crossed with a determination to stay. They were promptly met by our forces in the vicinity, and after a brief skirmish the enemy retired, no doubt not relishing the appearance of what they had to contend against.

abstract: Our advices from Virginia this morning, are not of the most agreeable character. The rebels have made another raid, this time in the rear of Gen. POPE's army, and have succeeded in temporarily ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Virginia this morning, are not of the most agreeable character. The rebels have made another raid, this time in the rear of Gen. POPE's army, and have succeeded in temporarily severing communications between the army and Gen. HALLECK's headquarters in Washington. A body of two thousand rebel cavalry, accompanied by flying artillery, on Tuesday night, or early Wednesday morning, made a successful dash at Manassas Junction, on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, captured three or four trains, a number of prisoners, and quartermasters' stores to a considerable amount -- one account says a half a million dollars. They also tore up the railroad track, demolished the telegraph, and are believed to have burnt the railroad bridge over Bull Run, which is some six miles this side of Manassas Junction. A dispatch received in Washington from Alexandria, dated at noon on Wednesday, states that fighting was then going on at Manassas, and that a great many troops were going out to "regulate matters." From this we inter that the rebel force has not been allowed to escape with impunity. We hope so. Meantime we are glad to receive assurances that everything is going on well in the extreme front. It is still asserted that the main rebel force is retreating, and that our army is already advancing. One of our correspondents expresses confidently the belief that the fate of the rebellion will be decided within two weeks.

abstract: The English newspapers, at the latest advices, were in a high fever of excitement over the exploits of the rebel ram Arkansas They were quite confident that the Union forces were about to lose command of the Mississippi, and that the rebel navy would speedily accomplish great things for the rebel cause. By this time they are at liberty to reflect upon the complete destruction of said invincible ram by our gunboats, which drove her into such close quarters that her own men were compelled to blow her up.

abstract: The news of the last few days from the vicinity of Cumberland Gap shows that the Union troops now occupying that stronghold ...
lead_paragraph: The news of the last few days from the vicinity of Cumberland Gap shows that the Union troops now occupying that stronghold are placed in a condition of extreme peril by the recent movements of the rebels. The value of the position is to them incalculable; and it would appear that, encouraged by their recent successes in other parts of Tennessee and Kentucky, they are determined to make a great effort to recover a stronghold which was captured from them rather by skillful strategy and extraordinary labor, than by superiority of force on our part, or lack of spirit on the part of the rebels. According to our dispatches and correspondence from that region, the rebels have of late been quietly massing large bodies of troops on either side of the Gap -- 15,000 men on the south side, and 30,000 on the north side, it is said -- with the idea of capturing or destroying the small National force under Gen. MORGAN, which seized this formidable mountain stronghold, and has held it in defiance of the rebels for nearly three months. Their troops are occupying every available pathway to and from the Gap, with the idea of hemming our little force completely in; and an energetic letter from Parson BROWNLOW, which we publish in our present issue, states that "our army at the Gap is already surrounded, and, if not speedily relieved, will be cut to pieces or forced to surrender" from starvation. There is probably little danger of the rebels capturing the place by assault, unless they really have the enormous force attributed to them; for Gen. MORGAN has been busy at work, and has completed the artificial and engineering labor necessary for rendering the position as nearly impregnable as any place can be; and from what we know of the situation of affairs, our impression is that, even though Gen. MORGAN have not one-fifth of the number of troops which the rebels have brought against him, he can still defy and repel them from his American Thermopylae. The movements of the rebels, however, indicate that they understand and are acting on the policy that the only plan of capturing Cumberland Gap is by starving out Gen. MORGAN's forces. This is quite a feasible project, for all MORGAN's supplies have to be hauled in ox-teams, over a distance of a hundred miles in Eastern Kentucky, over and through a congeries of wild, savage and roadless hills and mountains, where a few rebel guerrillas would hold the wagons, their drivers and escort completely at their mercy. Already some of the teams have been destroyed by the marauders; and we judge that MORGAN's communications are now altogether cut off, from the fact that a rebel telegram, as well as BROWNLOW's letter, affirm that the rebels are in possession of Barboursville, in Kentucky, on the direct line leading to the Gap, and also that they have concentrated a force at a point called Flat Lick, twenty miles from the Gap, and have thus entirely cut off supplies. Our own telegraph, however, comforts us with the assurance that "Gen. MORGAN is in no danger, as he has provisions and forage enough to last him thirty days;" though it does not inform us what he is going to do after the lapse of the brief time specified. Thus, solitary and isolated, is this gallant soldier, with his little army, upholding the flag of the Union on these wild Cumberland mountain peaks; and thus is the very existence of his daring force imperiled by the rebels. The Richmond Dispatch of a very late date, in speaking of affairs in this region, says that the "Confederate officers and men are fully alive to the opportunity of now striking an effective blow at the minions of Lincoln, and stirring news must he heard before many days from Cumberland Gap."

abstract: There is one feature of the current advices from Washington which strikes the country unpleasantly; we mean the reiterated assurances that our army is safe, that our position is strong, and that Washington is out of danger. This is all very well as preliminary to something else. But the public is not ...
lead_paragraph: There is one feature of the current advices from Washington which strikes the country unpleasantly; we mean the reiterated assurances that our army is safe, that our position is strong, and that Washington is out of danger. This is all very well as preliminary to something else. But the public is not free from suspicion that it means more than that. It sounds too much like the old story. It has been the burden of our boasts for the past year and a half. Our army has been safe too long. The people expect it now to incur some danger, -- to take risks, -- in the hope of achieving some positive success.

abstract: When so good a cause as recruiting is pushed forward with such zeal as we now witness, it is a little ungracious to pick flaws, even if this zeal should in some cases find vent in forms that prudence cannot approve. But we can as little afford to dispense with discretion and discrimination in this as in any other good cause.
lead_paragraph: When so good a cause as recruiting is pushed forward with such zeal as we now witness, it is a little ungracious to pick flaws, even if this zeal should in some cases find vent in forms that prudence cannot approve. But we can as little afford to dispense with discretion and discrimination in this as in any other good cause. The margin, both as regards physical and moral qualities, within which we may recruit soldiers for the armies of the Union, is immense; but there are, after all, limits beyond which we may not wisely go. The barber in DICKENS was fain to fix some bounds beyond which he would not descend in the exercise of his art, so he determined to stop at coal- heavers. We may safely say that our zealous recruiting sergeants should stop at (that is, this side of,) jail-birds. We particularize this class, because applications have actually been made to allow convicts now confined in the Penitentiary to be released on condition of enlisting in the army. We may cite in illustration the following announcement which Judge CHUMASERO, of Monroe County, has lately made in answer to propositions of this nature.

abstract: The Negro Colonization project of Senator POMEROY's seems likely to encounter difficulties at the outset. The Minister from Costa Rica and the Representative of one of the other South American Republics are to have an interview with Mr. SEWARD, to-morrow, on the subject. They insist that the parties turning over the land at Chiriqui to our Government, have no legal claim to it; and further represent that, while they gladly welcome emigrants from very quarter, and of every color, and accord them every political and social advantage, they must object to the establishment of colonies on their territory, under the protection of a foreign flag.

abstract: THE TENTH WARD HOMICIDE CONCLUSION OF THE CORONER'S INQUEST. Coroner NAUMANN, yesterday, concluded his investigation in the case of Mrs. JoSEPHINE WEILER, the woman who, it was alleged, had been shot through the heart, at her late residence, No. 154 Essex-street, by a revolver in the hands of her husband, JOSEPH WEILER.
lead_paragraph: THE TENTH WARD HOMICIDE -- CONCLUSION OF THE CORONER'S INQUEST. -- Coroner NAUMANN, yesterday, concluded his investigation in the case of Mrs. JoSEPHINE WEILER, the woman who, it was alleged, had been shot through the heart, at her late residence, No. 154 Essex-street, by a revolver in the hands of her husband, JOSEPH WEILER. A large number of witnesses were, examined during the inquest, but no testimony was elicited, going to show that the husband was the guilty party. The evidence, however, revealed the fact, that WEILER and his wife had, for a long time past, lived very unhappily together, and one witness gave evidence to the fact, that recently he had heard the prisoner threaten to shoot his wife. The showing verdict was recorded by the jury: "The deceased came to her death by a pistol shot wound, but whether suicide or not the Jury are unable to determine." Upon the rendition of this verdict the Coroner concluded to detain the husband, JACOB WEILER, until he could consult with the District Attorney as to whether the case was one in which [???] could be taken. The prisoner denies most emphatically that he shot his wife. His account of the affair is that she seized the pistol from him, and before he had time to present her, she pointed it toward her heart and fired. He is about 26 years of age, was born in this city, and is by occupation a clerk.

abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the Philadelphia Ledger writes: "The son of Hon. Pierre Soule paid a visit to his father in Fort Lafayette, on Saturday, I understand, also, that Judge Roselius, of New-Orleans, had an interview with him. Soule is said to complain bitterly of his incarceration, without a hearing and without a trial. He says he never was disloyal to the Government, but that he was the victim solely of Gen. Butler's caprice. Inasmuch as the Government had seen fit to reverse at least one decision which \v ~\v0 Gen. Butler had made, (the confiscation of the money and merchandise belonging to the foreign Consuls,. he expresses the hope that it will also find occasion, on ascertaining all the facts connected with his arrest and imprisonment, to reverse the Generals [???] as regards himself. Soule's health is said to be beginning to fail him, and the effect of close confinement upon his spirits is depressing in the extreme. Since his incarceration none but his nearest relatives have been permitted to have any communication with him.

abstract: The immediate and most desirable effect produced by the great mass meeting, held in the City Hall Park on Wednesday, was to stimulate recruiting  to stimulate it on the spot, and create a patriotic enthusiasm for volunteering which will last several days. Tents in the neighborhood of the stands where CORCORAN, MITCHEL, WEIGHT and SICKLES spoke, reaped a perfect harvest, even whilst the meeting was going on, a portion of which was at once garnered...
lead_paragraph: The immediate and most desirable effect produced by the great mass meeting, held in the City Hall Park on Wednesday, was to stimulate recruiting -- to stimulate it on the spot, and create a patriotic enthusiasm for volunteering which will last several days. Tents in the neighborhood of the stands where CORCORAN, MITCHEL, WEIGHT and SICKLES spoke, reaped a perfect harvest, even whilst the meeting was going on, a portion of which was at once garnered in at the Mustering office, though more had to be held in trust for the morrow. Of course some of the first blush of patriotic ardor faded away before the morning of yesterday; yet enough was left to prove that the meeting had, to a considerable extent, accomplished its mission, and that the eloquence of those who had appealed to their fellow-citizens from the impromptu forums around which the gathering took place, had not all fallen on stony ground, but that much of it had taken root and prospered, and would, in the fullness of time blossom into crops of armed men. The meeting would not have entirely failed of its purpose had only one man been induced to enlist for every speech that was made; for words are cheap and plentiful, and many of them may be expended profitably in the production of a single soldier; but there is no question that every speech produced its tens and its hundreds, and that the Union hosts will soon be regiments stronger for the healthful excitement that a few eloquent phrases uttered in season thus produced. And not merely in the way of immediate enlistments was the meeting fruitful. The appeals there made reached the pockets of those whose persons could not be given to the cause, and many a thousand dollars, donated to sustain the country's life, will have its date of gift from Wednesday. Probably this meeting alone has brought in men and money enough to stave off need of a draft in the Empire State. It has partially done so, at any rate, and if more meetings of the same kind are wanted, we have orators and enthusiasm enough left to organize them.

abstract: A writer and drughtsman named CALOCHE, well known as a prominent member of the "Bohemians" of Paris, has recently died. The following ancedote is related of him: "He was returning from Verseilles, when he heard that FIESCHI had fired at the King, and the idea occurred to him that it would be a good speculation to sell the portrait of the conspirator, and, not to lose time, he drew the face of an ill-looking man sitting opposite him in the carriage in which they were traveling. A print-seller published the portrait, which was purchased eagerly in Paris, and even by the person who had unknowingly sat for the likeness. This dash of a pencil produced to the artist several thousand francs."

abstract: Postage stamps during the past few weeks have been generally used in a manner little thought of until recently. Silver and gold for a time went almost... out of use. both being held as an article of merchandise, like cotton or flour.
lead_paragraph: Postage stamps during the past few weeks have been generally used in a manner little thought of until recently. Silver and gold for a time went almost... out of use. both being held as an article of merchandise, like cotton or flour. The extraordinary rise in their value, which no one had foreseen or was able to foresee, speedily drove them out of circulation, and resulted in creating great discomfort and inconvenience to every class of the community. To remedy this evil some expedient was necessary, and to prevent advantage being taken of the unusual state of affairs, legislation was demanded.

abstract: Gen. CORCORAN was busily engaged in his rooms at the Astor House yesterday, in receiving the crowds of distinguished citizens who called to see him. lead_paragraph: Gen. CORCORAN was busily engaged in his rooms at the Astor House yesterday, in receiving the crowds of distinguished citizens who called to see him. The preference was, of course, given to the arrangements for additions to the Irish Legion. During the morning an interesting meeting of the officers of the Sixty-ninth was held, at which almost all unanimously decided to enlist, not as the phrase runs, "for three years of the war," but for "the war" unqualifiedly. A Committee from the Common Council of Boston, accompanied by a Committee from Roxbury, waited upon the General, and prevailed upon him to visit those places. The General accompanied by Alderman FARLEY, Councilman PINCKNEY, Capt. KIRKER, Capt. DUFFY, and [???] of his suite, left by the Fall River route last evening. From Myrick's Station the train will proceed over the Providence Railroad to Roxbury, where it will arrive at 10 o'clock to-morrow. He will be accorded, a grand reception at Roxbury, and, with his friends, escorted to the Boston Station, where he will be welcomed by Mayor WIGHTMAN. The procession in Boston will consist of a battalion of Lancers, the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, and a variety of Hibernian and other [???]. Upon arriving at the Commons, Gen. [???] will [???] make a brief address. The General [???] at the Revere House, in Boston, and be [???] city.

abstract: The Nineteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Col. WM. R. BROWN, returned from their three months' service in Maryland early yesterday morning. The regiment belongs in Newburgh and vicinity, and most of its members have expressed their desire to return for the nine months' service under the last call. During their absence they have been stationed most of the time at Havre de Grace, guarding the railroad and watching prisoners. They have lost during their absence, four members, from typhoid fever. Col. BROWN received notice the other day that 300 recruits were desirous of joining the regiment in case it returned to the field. They were accepted and are now in camp. The regiment left for Newburgh by steamboat yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The Nineteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Col. WM. R. BROWN, returned from their three months' service in Maryland early yesterday morning. abstract: Everett speech at Aug. 27 war meeting, Boston Common, noted; Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Everett speech at Aug. 27 war meeting, Boston Common, noted; Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: I rejoice, fellow-citizens, to behold this mighty throng. It shows that the spirit of our fathers is again abroad in the land, and that you are resolved that the Union which they established, shall not be rent asunder; that the mildest and most beneficent Government on earth shall not be sacrificed to the ambition of a few disappointed aspirants to office. We have now reached not only the most important week in the history of the war up to the present time, but the week which will most powerfully influence the future. The fate of this year's campaign depends upon the manner in which the call of the President is responded to by the people, and this campaign will go far to settle the question, whether we are to have a short or a long war.

abstract: This regiment arrived from New-Haven yesterday afternoon, and landed at the pier foot of Twenty-seventh-street. From thence they marched up to Fourth-avenue and down Broadway to the Battery, where they took the boat of the Camden and Amboy line for Philadelphia. The regiment is called the Lyon Regiment, in honor of Gen. LYON, who fell at the battle of Wilson's Creek. It is commanded by Col. DEXTER WRIGHT.

abstract: The rebels certainly succeed in harvesting the credit of all the dash and enterprise of the war. On Tuesday night, the cavalry of Gen.
lead_paragraph: The rebels certainly succeed in harvesting the credit of all the dash and enterprise of the war. On Tuesday night, the cavalry of Gen. STUART, for a third time in the history of the Summer campaign, made their appearance in the rear of the Union army. Manassas is between Gen. POPE's centre and Washington City. It was upon the Manassas station the rebels made their descent, in numbers stated -- probably with exaggeration -- at two or three thousand men, capturing a battery of New-York artillery, some empty cars, and destroying a serious amount of army stores. Such thorough workers, we may be sure, did not leave the railroad track and the telegraphic wire untouched; and we shall not be surprised if stories of the destruction of two or three important bridges should prove true. To the rest of the narrative, as sent us by straggling correspondents, we may give more reserved credit. It will turn out, we suspect, that the rebels did not burn the railroad bridge six miles nearer Washington; and that the panic-like story of their continuing to bold Manassas in strong force, is founded only in a frightened fancy. Nothing is less probable than that with a heavy body of MCCLELLAN's army threatening to flank their main body on the South of the Rappahannock, they would place a considerable force at Manassas, where it must certainly be cut off and captured. This view gathers strength from a later report of the army of POPE having assumed the offensive, and commenced its advance upon the enemy; a movement certainly not undertaken with a hostile army and broken communications in the rear.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Dash at Manassas.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Dash at Manassas.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We learn from gentlemen who arrived here last evening, from Loudon County, that yesterday was a day of great excitement in that vicinity, as well as in the Valley.
lead_paragraph: We learn from gentlemen who arrived here last evening, from Loudon County, that yesterday was a day of great excitement in that vicinity, as well as in the Valley. The guerrilla bands were scouring the country, and WHITE's rebel cavalry, supposed to be the same which made the dash on Saturday last on the Winchester Road, and destroyed a train of cars have appeared at Waterford, a short distance from London, capturing a company of cavalry stationed there, with all their horses and arms. The men, we learn, were paroled, and the rebels made good their escape with their booty. They were overpowered by superior numbers after a sharp fight, in which a number were wounded on both sides.

abstract: Among the speakers at the Park War meeting, on Wednesday afternoon, was Maj.-Gen. O.M. MITCHEL, lately of the Army of the Southwest. Of course Gen. MITCHEL's speech ...
lead_paragraph: Among the speakers at the Park War meeting, on Wednesday afternoon, was Maj.-Gen. O.M. MITCHEL, lately of the Army of the Southwest. Of course Gen. MITCHEL's speech was eloquent, enthusiastic, patriotic; for, as the people of New-York have had many opportunities of knowing in former years, his genius illustrates and glorifies whatever subject it may touch. But why, in this hour of tremendous peril to the nation's armies, is this accomplished, gallant and educated soldier, clad in his Major-General's uniform, haranguing a crowd in the highways of New-York? When the territory, the towns and the fields which he won from the rebels in Tennessee and Alabama are being rapidly regained by them; when the army which, under him, marched only and always to victory, is now engaged in less else but surrendering piecemeal to the rebels -- why is he not given back his command, that he may have a fresh opportunity to demonstrate that his style of strategy -- the strategy of activity and aggression -- is the true style, as it is assuredly the only one which will prevent the rebels from utterly extirpating our Southwestern armies in course of time, and carrying their raids up to the Ohio? We know there were certain charges made against Gen. MITCHEL; but they were so preposterous, so utterly false on their very face, that the authorities have refused to listen [???] Still, they have been sufficient to [???] out of the field, strongly against his will, for two or three months, during which time the rebels have invaded the region which he conquered, and of which he was formerly in command, and, according to the boast of the guerrilla MORGAN, have destroyed ten million dollars worth of military stores, captured forty towns, taken prisoner ten regiments of National troops, and spread dismay over two or three of the most populous States of the West. When MITCHEL was deprived of his command, he was on the very point of marching his army into East Tennessee, and had already made the initial movements for that end; now the liberation of that section has been apparently postponed until every white man there is drafted into the rebel army, and the loyal women and children are persecuted and plundered until they resign themselves to despair. When the Union army is so disgraced, and our soldiers suffer so severely from imbeciles, quacks and political Generals, it is certainly strange that Gen. MITCHEL, whose military record is one of the brightest which can be shown by any man in the service, should be exiled to New-York, where, in order to do some little work for his country, he is driven to the necessity of speechifying before an assemblage in the City Hall Park.

lead_paragraph: "According to the Journal de St. Petersbourg, the Russian Government desires to see the war in America put an end to by a prudent and honorable compromise. Russia, it is said, has always sympathized with the United States, with the feelings of humanity which revolt at a war of extermination; and she therefore impresses America 'not to divide, but to bring together and reunite adversaries who ought always to remain brothers.'"

abstract: ANOTHER GREAT WAR MEETING. -- At the meeting of the War Conference Convention on Wednesday afternoon, a resolution was adopted to the effect that the city bells be rung at 4 o'clock P.M. on Monday, the 1st inst.; that the proprietors of stores be requested to close them; and that the people be invited to assemble in Fort Greene Park to take counsel together and encourage one another in the prosecution of the patriotic work now going on in this country. A Committee was appointed to make arrangements, and a meeting was held last evening, when it was decided to make the demonstration in the City Hall Park, instead of Fort Greene Park. Four stands are to be erected; three of which will be in front of the Hall and one on Remsen-street, opposite. Reflectors will be so arranged as to light the neighborhood, and a band of music will be present. The speakers invited and who are expected to be present, are Generals Corcoran, Mitchel, Busteed, Spinola and Walbridge. Hon. M.F. Odell, Joseph Hoxie, D.C. Winslow, S.D. Morris, Hon. H.C. Murphy, Hon. Mr. Stanton, and others. The time of the meeting was fixed for 7 o'clock P.M., and the bells are to be rung from 6 1/2 to 7 o'clock, instead of 4 o'clock. There is no doubt but that the meeting will be an immense one.

abstract: Three battalions of cavalry, composed chiefly of men recently enlisted for the mounted service of the United States, have, within a few days, arrived at Carlisle, Penn., from different parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: Three battalions of cavalry, composed chiefly of men recently enlisted for the mounted service of the United States, have, within a few days, arrived at Carlisle, Penn., from different parts of the country. They are now in course of training for the field, and, when supplied with steeds and equipments, will be drafted for active duty. The last regiment of cavalry added to the regular army is approaching completion. It will consist, when entire, of three full battalions of 800 men each, or, 2,400 in all. The headquarters of the regiment is at Pittsburgh.

abstract: To-day Saturday, August the 30th is the last day on which any volunteer for the army whether into regiments new or old will be paid one cent of State or United States bounty. It appears to have been definitively decided at Washington and Albany that if a man had not sense enough already to make sure of his $92 or $63 by enlisting before the end of...
lead_paragraph: To-day -- Saturday, August the 30th -- is the last day on which any volunteer for the army -- whether into regiments new or old -- will be paid one cent of State or United States bounty. It appears to have been definitively decided at Washington and Albany that if a man had not sense enough already to make sure of his $92 or $63 by enlisting before the end of the month, it would be useless waiting any longer. The amount of bounties offered have been generous beyond all precedent. They have been so large that any man who required pecuniary inducements to make him patriotic must have been tempted by them. If the temptation has failed, still leaving the quota of New-York deficient, that deficiency must be made up by draft. The draft may not be put in force for two or three weeks yet, it is true, and, in the meantime, volunteering may go on; but it will be volunteering for love of country or desire of military adventure, and will not be encouraged by any special premiums from official sources. Some few regiments will, from private sources, continue to be assisted in their efforts to fill up; but private liberality can afford no such munificent aid as has hitherto come from the State and National Governments. Of course there is a class of men in business, or enjoying lucrative employment, who wish to serve the country willingly, but who nevertheless defer enlisting to the latest possible moment. To this class bounties are unimportant. They will come in before drafting begins, but at a time of their own choosing.There are, however, a great many men whose families want all the relief that can be obtained for them, and these men and those dependent on them will be sorry, when they find themselves absorbed by the draft, that they procrastinated so foolishly beyond the acceptable time. They will have no remedy, though, then. They will have no remedy if they lose the final chance offered them to-day. Any time before this 30th of August merges into the irretrievable past, they can enroll their names, and claim a snare of the bounties which have so long been fruitlessly held within their reach. Actual enlistment -- that is, "mustering in" -- will do on Monday; but names must be enrolled before this day is through. It is a question of a few hours; and on the enlistment or non-enlistment of a man within or beyond those few hours depends his securing for the immediate use of himself or family $92, if he join a regiment now in the field, or $63 if he join one of the new regiments now organizing. There are plenty of men who mean to volunteer. Why should they want only throw away so large a sum of money?

abstract: The remains of the late distinguished divine, orator and poet, GEO. W. BETHUNE, D.D., reached this City early in the present week from Florence, where, it will be remembered, Death overtook the deceased in April last. The funeral services, we are requested to state, will take place in the church at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, on Wednesday next, at 2 P.M. The clergy are invited to meet at 1 o'clock of that day, at the church of which Dr. BETHUNE recently had pastoral charge, in Twenty-first-street, near Sixth-avenue. It is expected that the numbers of the Historical, and other secular societies of which the deceased was a member, as well as the faculty of the Theological Seminary of New-Brunswick, will be present. The Journal of Commerce very justly observes:

abstract: -- The New Ironsides turns up at Fortress Monroe; but we hope she is not to take her place among the fleet of idle iron-clads lying there. If no active serve can be found for her, let her be sent down to Charleston to make the blockade a little less imperfect than it now is; for with all the vessels we have there at present, there is greater commerce at that port than has been known any time since the Revolution! Give her something to do, anyhow.

abstract: Editorial on report McClellan will be given command on Army of Virginia
snippet: Editorial on report McClellan will be given command on Army of Virginia
lead_paragraph: -- We have a statement from Philadelphia and from Baltimore that Gen. McCLELLAN has been appointed to, and has accepted, the command of the Army of Virginia. (The "Army of Virginia," technically so called, is the army now commanded by Gen. POPE.) Gen. BURNSIDE. it is further said, in one dispatch, is to command the "Army of the Potomac," and Gen. POPE the "Army of the Rappahannock" -- the latter being a new designation. We judge that all the National forces in Virginia must be reorganized before these changes of commanders can take place. Indeed, even now, the late commands of MCCLELLAN, POPE and BURNSIDE, have been fundamentally altered in their composition -- many of MCCLELLAN's divisions and brigades being with POPE, others with BURNSIDE, while MCCLELLAN himself has been assigned part of the troops of each of the last mentioned Generals, besides many of the new levies. One object of these changes is probably to distribute the veteran troops among each of the army divisions -- so that our whole force in the field may be made at once effective. Furthermore, after the peninsular experiment, the military authorities would certainly not give Gen. MCCLELLAN the chief command of the army he had there, on any other field of action. MCCLELLAN's new army will, most likely, be either the central column of the "Onward to Richmond" forces, or its reserve.
headline: {'main': "GEN. McCLELLAN'S NEW COMMAND.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "GEN. McCLELLAN'S NEW COMMAND.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news licensed to reach us from Washington does not place the progress of our arms in an encouraging point of view, nor is it the story we would care to send away upon the steamer to-day. Notwithstanding...
lead_paragraph: The news licensed to reach us from Washington does not place the progress of our arms in an encouraging point of view, nor is it the story we would care to send away upon the steamer to-day. Notwithstanding the powerful concentration of Union forces along the Rappahannock, the result of a junction of MCCLELLAN with BURNSIDE and POPE, our leaders seem to have been outgeneraled, our army is flanked and cut off wholly from Washington, and those communications and lines of retreat, which Gen. POPE ridiculed, perhaps untimely, are unhappily in the hands of the enemy. We are told of large bodies of rebels on the left bank of the Occoquan, at Fairfax, Centreville, Leesburgh. One-half of a New-Jersey brigade, after a gallant resistance, is rumored to have surrendered -- a brigade fifteen hundred strong, flung right into the midst of the enemy, without cavalry or artillery to attend and save it. Government depots have been captured; loaded trains have been seized; in fact, the entire region from Bull Run to Edwards' Ferry, would appear to be at the mercy, if not actually in possession of the rebels.

abstract: THE QUOTA OF HUDSON COUNTY FILLED BY VOLUNTEERS. The quota for Hudson County (514 men) for nine months' service has been filled by volunteers, all of whom are now at the rendezvous at Trenton. Notwithstanding the quota is full, Gov.
lead_paragraph: THE QUOTA OF HUDSON COUNTY FILLED BY VOLUNTEERS. -- The quota for Hudson County (514 men) for nine months' service has been filled by volunteers, all of whom are now at the rendezvous at Trenton. Notwithstanding the quota is full, Gov. OLDEN has consented to accept all who volunteer up to Saturday night, consequently several additional companies are forming, all of which will be filled up within the specified time. All excess over the quota will be credited on any subsequent call that may be made. The work of raising the quota has been accomplished in four days.

abstract: The announcement  made to day, in an official bulletin, of the dismissal, from the service, of the twelve officers of the Seventy-first Ohio Volunteers, who, in a published card, stated that they advised Col. R. MASON to surrender Clarksville, Tenn., to the rebel force, is a gratifying evidence of a kind of vigor which...
lead_paragraph: -- The announcement made to day, in an official bulletin, of the dismissal, from the service, of the twelve officers of the Seventy-first Ohio Volunteers, who, in a published card, stated that they advised Col. R. MASON to surrender Clarksville, Tenn., to the rebel force, is a gratifying evidence of a kind of vigor which the nation has so long waited for, as almost to despair of ever seeing it. It is nothing to the purpose to say that the laxity, thus far, of the authorities in punishing cowardice and incompetence has been appalling, and that the history of the war shows a record of military and naval blunders never brought to a reckoning, the like of which was probably never seen; enough that we have at last an act of justice that inspires the hope of a new era in the military administration. In cashiering Col. MASON, and dismissing the officers who counseled the surrender of the post they were set to defend, Gen. HALLECK doubtless acts on evidence that puts the cowardice of those men beyond a doubt.

abstract: THE FIRE DEPARTMENT. Chief-Engineer FUREY,of the Western District Fire Department, has just returned from Albany, where, in connection with the Chief-Engineer of the New-York Department, he had a conference with the State authorities in reference to the proposed draft. The Governor stated, in...
lead_paragraph: THE FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- Chief-Engineer FUREY, of the Western District Fire Department, has just returned from Albany, where, in connection with the Chief-Engineer of the New-York Department, he had a conference with the State authorities in reference to the proposed draft. The Governor stated, in answer to questions, that it would be hard to draft men who had rendered, perhaps, years of active service -- supposing that they were exempted from military duty -- but as the Fire Departments, particularly in the country villages, had been made a place of refuge from the draft, it could not, injustice to all, be avoided. It was finally agreed that if all the Departments should voluntarily furnish their quote they should be exempted from the draft. Under this construction the quota of the Western District of Brooklyn will be about 140, which number there will be no difficulty whatever in raising.

abstract: drops plan; Editorial laments Union situation in Virginia
snippet: drops plan; Editorial laments Union situation in Virginia
lead_paragraph: The accounts which we receive from Virginia are somewhat confused, but still sufficiently definite to warrant the belief that the rebels have gained Gen. POPE's rear, in much larger force than was at first supposed. There was a battle of considerable magnitude on Wednesday, for the possession of the railroad bridge across Bull Run, and another at Bristow Station, beyond Manassas, in which Gen. HOOKER's Division was engaged, and drove back the enemy to Manassas -- the latter having apparently made an effort to advance against Gen. POPE's rear. The losses in this last engagement are reported to be heavy. The Washington Star has information that on Wednesday morning the rebels were encamped at Gainesville, some twenty or thirty thousand strong, and we have rumors of the appearance of bodies of them at Fairfax Court-House, Leesburgh, and Vienna -- the latter point only twelve miles from Washington. The rebels are evidently playing a desperate game, but one which, we are assured, will end in their own discomfiture. They have now veteran troops in their front and rear.

abstract: editorial on planned convention, Chicago, to appoint supervisors for work on extending railroad lines from Missouri River to Pacific Coast
snippet: editorial on planned convention, Chicago, to appoint supervisors for work on extending railroad lines from Missouri River to Pacific Coast
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday next, Sept. 2, the persons named in the act to provide for the construction of a Railroad from the Missouri River to the Pacific Ocean, and the Commissioners appointed by the Government, meet at Chicago for the purpose of organizing a body for the management and prosecution of this great enterprise, the grandest proposition yet submitted to human effort or to engineering skill, and, if successful, to be their highest achievement. A continuous line is to be constructed 2,500 miles long -- traversing vast and sterile plains -- threading its way through ranges of mountains for more than 1,500 miles, with its line for a long distance at an altitude of 8,000 feet above the sea. The greater portion of the route is nearly destitute of wood, with so little rain fall as to be uncultivable, except by irrigation. The wide wastes traversed may, and probably do, possess mineral treasures to compensate for sterility of soil; but the richness beneath the surface does not yet avail to aid in the construction of the work which is to give to it an available and commercial value.

abstract: The town of Rye has sent two hundred and twenty-two men previously to the 2d day of July, and now bas a company of seventy men enlisted, besides a great many who have entered Duryee's Zouaves and other regiments, since that date. If her quota was counted according to the orders of the Secretary of War, her quota on both calls would be fully responded to and over -- but owing to some defect in the enrollment of men previously to the 2d July, incident, undoubtedly, to the heavy pressure on the department at Albany, the may, perhaps, lose the advantages she has been making so many sacrifices to acquire.

abstract: The Savannah News commissary as follows on the rumor that Gen. MCCOOK's soldiers had killed seventeen partisan rangers to avenge his murders "If 'it is said' does not lie, this will prove the worst day's work 'his soldiers' ever performed, as our scouts will string them up like Weathersfield [???] in retaliation for the outrage. When BILLY BOWLEGS was informed that Gen. HARNEY was coming after him, and that HARNEY would hang him when taken, BILLY is said coolly to have replied: [???] HARNEY catch, BILLY hang -- BILLY catch. HARNEY hang. Our war is coming to that very last. It is a game at which two can play at, and in which we have not only equal opportunity, but certainly all the right on our side. The sooner it is understood that the rules of Christian warfare are to be utterly disregarded the better for us. We should have commenced hanging thieves, insurrectionists and murderers long ago.

abstract: In the closing week of June last, the socalled Confederate President, JEFF. DAVIS, from his chamber at Richmond, listened to the thunder of the cannon of hostile armies battling before his capital. In the closing week of August, President LINCOLN, from the White House, heard the deep peals of the artillery
lead_paragraph: In the closing week of June last, the socalled Confederate President, JEFF. DAVIS, from his chamber at Richmond, listened to the thunder of the cannon of hostile armies battling before his capital. In the closing week of August, President LINCOLN, from the White House, heard the deep peals of the artillery of the contending hosts which, having now changed location, are struggling for supremacy before the National Capital. The geographical change of position does not indicate that Richmond is any the less likely to fall, or that Washington is any the less safe now than it was then. In truth, the fact rather is, that if we have any one. General with sense and pluck enough to take advantage of the palpable opportunity the rebels have given us, we may be said to he much nearer to Richmond now when the battle-field for its possession is a hundred miles away from, it than we were two months ago, when our fevered and shrunken army had shoveled its way up to within seven miles of its outskirts.

abstract: MOVEMENTS AMONG THE POLICE. The following changes have been made in the Police Department during the past week: Appointments Wm. N. Simpkins and Gilbert Bain, to the First Precinct; Jeremiah Teahan, to the Second Precinct, and Jacob
lead_paragraph: MOVEMENTS AMONG THE POLICE. -- The following changes have been made in the Police Department during the past week: Appointments Wm. N. Simpkins and Gilbert Bain, to the First Precinct; Jeremiah Teahan, to the Second Precinct, and Jacob P. Hoffner, to the Twenty-third. Resignations -- Geo. Rowland, of the First; Martin P. Fogle, Patrick Oates, Bartholomew, Griffin, Geo. W. Bently and Wm. A. Hallock, of the Third; John D. Arthur, of the Sixth; Henry C. Raymond, of the Sixteenth; Fred. Von Prubargh, Twenty-ninth, and Wm. Maguire, of the Broadway Squad. These resignations are all made by men who have volunteered in the Metropolitan Guard for the purpose of serving their country. Their situations will be reserved for them. Sergeant Hugh Monahan, of the Tenth, doorman; Joseph Tower, of the Forty-fifth, and Patrick White, of the Forty-second, have resigned for other reasons.

abstract: framer, should be permitted to excite and agitate the public. A better reason might, however, serve the Provost's turn. The posting of bulletins in some of our narrower thoroughfares seriously obstructs the sidewalk, rendering transit next to impossible. Very frequently the mass of interested readers take entire possession of the pavement, while wayfarers must betake themselves to the perils of the carriage-way. A prime duty of the Police is to keep the sidewalks clear. In London the perpetual cry is "Move on," wherever there happens to be an eddy of the living tide. Here, in New-York nothing is more common than to see two or three burly policemen adding their bulk to swell the immovable and constantly-recruited mob in front of the bulletin-boards; and no one has ever heard of their opening or maintaining a path for the by-passer. Let the Police Commissioners abolish the bulletins, or see that the pavements are unobstructed.

abstract: The sum of $50,000 was, on Friday, sent to Washington by the Prize Court of Philadelphia. The sum is the proceeds of a single sale of a prize vessel condemned and sold in this port. The whole sum will be divided among the officers and crew of a single vessel. Over $300,000 more will be sent on for the same purpose during the next week.

abstract: The Fifteenth Regiment of New-Jersey Volunteers, Col. SAMUEL FOWLER, left for Washington at noon to-day. The regiment is nine hundred and forty strong, and is armed with Enfield rifles. abstract: On Saturday, at 12  o'clock, the United States iron-clad gunboat Passaic, which has been known as "Ericsson Battery No. 2." (the Monitor being Number One,) was successfully launched at the Continental Iron Works, Greenpoint. As the affair had been advertised to come off, a considerable assemblage was present.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, at 12 1/2 o'clock, the United States iron-clad gunboat Passaic, which has been known as "Ericsson Battery No. 2." (the Monitor being Number One,) was successfully launched at the Continental Iron Works, Greenpoint. As the affair had been advertised to come off, a considerable assemblage was present. The navy was pretty largely represented. Rear-Admiral HIRAM PAULDING, of the Brooklyn Navy-yard; Commodore RINGGOLD, of the Sabine: Rear-Admiral GREGORY, General Superintendent of Iron Naval Vessels; Chief-Engineer STIMERS, the superintendent of the machinery of the new iron-clads; Naval-Constructor POOK, Gen. HAIL, Mr. CUSHMAN and Mr. QUINTARD, were on the platform. Mrs. STIMERS, wife of Chief-Engineer STIMERS, christened the craft, but was too nervous to stand on the ship, and broke the bottle of champagne from the platform, amid tumultuous applause. Mr. STIMERS acted as Master of the Ceremonies in the most polished manner.

abstract: VICTOR HUGO, in his latest and most famous romance, represents his hero Marius, as "unrturing within himself, with the deep divination of a man of the people, what we now call the idea of nationality."
lead_paragraph: VICTOR HUGO, in his latest and most famous romance, represents his hero Marius, as "unrturing within himself, with the deep divination of a man of the people, what we now call the idea of nationality." The author, who is at once a politician and a philosopher, perceives the strength of the connection which exists between freedom and patriotism; and, correlatively, he detects how inevitable is the alliance between Slavery and the absence of a true love of country. It would be easy to prove by an inductive process how natural and consistent are these affinities; but such a process is practically unnecessary when their coincidence can be deduced from numerous historical illustrations. Of these, none more striking has ever presented itself than is afforded by the present Pro-Slavery rebellion. We are not called upon to affix the stigma, for they themselves acknowledge and glory in it. They care nothing for their country -- nothing for its past heroism, its future mission. All these are alike indifferent to men whom the despotism of Slavery has deprived of all idea of nationality.
headline: {'main': 'The Idea of Nationality.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Idea of Nationality.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The call of President LINCOLN for three hundred thousand more volunteers was noticed by the Charleston Mercury not without disturbance. It "had not a doubt that they would be raised.
lead_paragraph: The call of President LINCOLN for three hundred thousand more volunteers was noticed by the Charleston Mercury not without disturbance. It "had not a doubt that they would be raised. With starvation to the laboring population on the one hand and money on the other," the army of the United States was sure to be recruited. It erred, of course, in speaking of starvation to our laboring population. No such motive as that has pressed upon our people. But the determination to put down rebellion, and to preserve the Union which our fathers established, has wrought powerfully, and the confidence of the Mercury has been proved not to be misplaced.

abstract: The Delta publishes the following note: "In the correspondence between Brig.-Gen. BRECKINRIDGE, of the Confederate Army, and Col. PAYNE, of the United States forces, at Baton Rouge, it will be perceived that Gen. BRECKINRIDGE says that VAN DORN threatens to raise the black flag. That threat is wholly unnecessary, as the black flag has already been raised in this city under the authority of the Confederate General in command of this department, on the 28th of December, 1861, in the general review then held on Canal-street, when a black flag was paraded on Canal-street, in front of Major-Gen. LOVELL, Gov. MOORE and Gen. LEWIS, bearing the motto, 'We ask no quarters, and give none.' Thousands of persons now in this city saw that flag. G."

abstract: The news from Virginia, this morning, is of the most important and exciting character, Fighting heavy fighting has been going on there for several days, with results favorable to our arms. We have given from day to day, as they have reached us, somewhat imperfect accounts of the important events which have occurred necessarily imperfect, because in most cases written at a distance from the scenes of operations.
lead_paragraph: The news from Virginia, this morning, is of the most important and exciting character, Fighting -- heavy fighting -- has been going on there for several days, with results favorable to our arms. We have given from day to day, as they have reached us, somewhat imperfect accounts of the important events which have occurred -- necessarily imperfect, because in most cases written at a distance from the scenes of operations. They have been sufficient, however, to give a general idea of the great movements which have been affected, and the series of skirmishes and battles which culminated on Thursday in the great struggle, of which we give an official account elsewhere. We yesterday morning published a dispatch from Gen. POPE to Gen. HALLECK, giving an official account of the battle of Thursday, which was ended by the darkness of night, and expressing the expectation that it would be renewed in the morning. In a dispatch dated yesterday, Gen. POPE states that a terrific battle was fought on Friday, on the old Bull Run battle-ground, with the combined forces of the enemy, lasting with continuous fury from daylight until after dark, by which time the enemy was driven from the field, which was occupied by our forces, who wore too much exhausted to push matters. Gen. POPE intended to pursue as soon as reinforced by FITZ-JOHN PORTER's corps, which was exported up during the morning. At the moment of closing his dispatch, however, word was brought to Gen. POPE that the enemy were in full retreat toward the mountains. What their chance of escape was may to inferred from the general tenor of our advices. The rebel force seems to have been pretty thoroughly surrounded, and it is difficult to imagine how it could escape capture or total annihilation. Gen. POPE estimates our losses on Friday at not less than eight thousand men killed and wounded, and the losses of the rebels at fully double that number. Our captures in this battle are said to be great. Their extent will probably soon be made known.

abstract: At the annual meeting of the Maine Historical Society, held at Brunswick on Thursday, Aug. 7, inst., resolutions were adopted for carrying into effect the public celebration of the first formal act of possession of the soil and territory of New-England, by the founding of the Popham colony, at the mouth of the Kennebec River, Aug. 19, 1607 (O.S.,) which...
lead_paragraph: At the annual meeting of the Maine Historical Society, held at Brunswick on Thursday, Aug. 7, inst., resolutions were adopted for carrying into effect the public celebration of the first formal act of possession of the soil and territory of New-England, by the founding of the Popham colony, at the mouth of the Kennebec River, Aug. 19, 1607 (O.S.,) which possession and occupation, under the Royal charter of April 10, 1606, gave to the English race its title and dominion in the New World. Under the auspices of the Historical Society, the arrangements are now perfected by the very efficient committee appointed at the public meeting at Bath on the 28th of July last.

abstract: THE BATTLE OF BULL RUN ENLISTMENTS IN THE EMPIRE BRIGADE THE OTHER REGIMENTS RAISING  IN BROOKLYN, The news received yesterday of the defeat of the rebels at Bull Run had the most enlivening effect. The excitement was intense. All the military headquarters were crowded with persons anxious to hear the latest intelligence.
lead_paragraph: THE BATTLE OF BULL RUN -- ENLISTMENTS IN THE EMPIRE BRIGADE -- THE OTHER REGIMENTS RAISING IN BROOKLYN, &c. -- The news received yesterday of the defeat of the rebels at Bull Run had the most enlivening effect. The excitement was intense. All the military headquarters were crowded with persons anxious to hear the latest intelligence. The square about the City Hall was thronged. A large number of men enlisted in consequence of the good news, and Col. JOURDAN's regiment of the Empire Brigade was nearly filled under the impulse of the hour. Only a few men are now wanted to fill the regiment to the minimum standard, and in three days from this time there will be one thousand men in the ranks. The tents are all up on the parade-ground at East New-York, and the men have taken possession. They are well satisfied with the arrangements.

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment is bring largely reinforced. A few days since 25 men started for Virginia, and yesterday morning 31 marched from the City Armory for the seat of war. Hon. M.F. ODELL addressed them when leaving their late headquarters in a strain of patriotic fervor, which no one but a patriot and ardent lover of his country could do. Former cheered rapturously, and then marched off down Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and proceeded on their way to the seat of war. They were a noble banking set of men, and will do good service to their country.

abstract: -- The statements of Captains HUDSON and PEARSON, as to the loss of that splendid but unfortunate steamer, the Golden Gate, clears up many of the difficulties attending the telegraphic accounts, but do not render any intelligible verdict as to the responsibility of the Company. We are not told how nearly sufficient were the means of saving the lives of all the passengers; and the extent of the precautionary instrumentalities against fire is not referred to. The inference would seem to be justified that neither was adequate to the emergency. As two-thirds of the passengers were drowned, the life-saving apparatus of boats and floats must have been grossly imperfect; and as the fire broke out in the galley, within reach of sight and hand, the only sensible explanation of the headway the fire at once obtained, must be found in the absence of the proper machinery for extinguishing tires. We hear of fire-buckets and hose, but the latter seems to have been out of order, while the intense heat by the time they were put in service rendered the former practically useless. We trust further investigation will throw specific light on these doubtful points. The narrative of the two Captains is suspiciously obscure about both of them.
lead_paragraph: -- The statements of Captains HUDSON and PEARSON, as to the loss of that splendid but unfortunate steamer, the Golden Gate, clears up many of the difficulties attending the telegraphic accounts, but do not render any intelligible verdict as to the responsibility of the Company. We are not told how nearly sufficient were the means of saving the lives of all the passengers; and the extent of the precautionary instrumentalities against fire is not referred to. The inference would seem to be justified that neither was adequate to the emergency. As two-thirds of the passengers were drowned, the life-saving apparatus of boats and floats must have been grossly imperfect; and as the fire broke out in the galley, within reach of sight and hand, the only sensible explanation of the headway the fire at once obtained, must be found in the absence of the proper machinery for extinguishing tires. We hear of fire-buckets and hose, but the latter seems to have been out of order, while the intense heat by the time they were put in service rendered the former practically useless. We trust further investigation will throw specific light on these doubtful points. The narrative of the two Captains is suspiciously obscure about both of them.

abstract: That was a disastrous moment last Winter, when the enlistments were stopped; regiments, with numbers nearly complete, disbanded; and contracts for the manufacture of arms cancelled. To-day Government lacks arms for even the first half of the 600,000 men called for. It is obliged to appeal to the several States to arm the regiments forwarded by them to the seat of war; and it will only be by the promptitude and success of the negotiations for arms in Europe, and the instant patriotism of the loyal States in transferring their supplies to Government, that the crisis can be met. Already, we learn, a dozen Government agents are scouring the English markets for Enfield rifles, their eager competition advancing the price seriously. But in this case "price is no object," and we can congratulate ourselves that the deficient supply of weapons will be only momentary. In the meantime, the various State arsenals can furnish muskets as serviceable as those wielded by a majority of the rebel army, and with these our brave volunteers will gladly take the field. The old-pattern Springfield musket, loaded with ball and buckshot, is more fatal than an Enfield.
lead_paragraph: That was a disastrous moment last Winter, when the enlistments were stopped; regiments, with numbers nearly complete, disbanded; and contracts for the manufacture of arms cancelled. To-day Government lacks arms for even the first half of the 600,000 men called for. Already, we learn, a dozen Government agents are scouring the English markets for Enfield rifles, their eager competition advancing the price seriously. But in this case "price is no object," and we can congratulate ourselves that the deficient supply of weapons will be only momentary. abstract: We find the wildest ideas regarding the progress of volunteering current in conversation and the Press. Extravagant anticipations are expressed that the full quota of this State will be raised by the 1st of September  and certainly will be so if a little extension of time be but given.
lead_paragraph: We find the wildest ideas regarding the progress of volunteering current in conversation and the Press. Extravagant anticipations are expressed that the full quota of this State will be raised by the 1st of September -- and certainly will be so if a little extension of time be but given. It is worth while to bring down these high-flown notions by a reference to the sober facts of statistics. Now, according to the latest official returns from headquarters in Albany, published two or three days ago, New-York State still requires 14,000 men to make up her quota under the first call for 300,000 men. The ratio for our State is, in round numbers, 60,000, and but 46,000 of these have been raised thus far. It is, perhaps, fair to calculate that the deficit of 14,000 lacking at the time of the latest returns will, with the stimulus to enlistments which the presence of Gen. CORCORAN inspires, be forthcoming by the 1st of September.

abstract: The United States gunboat R.R. Cuyler, Commander PHILLIPS, Gate Commander WINSLOW, who died at sea from Key West Aug. 20, and Nassan, N.P., Aug. 26, arrived yesterday morning. On the 23 Inst.,...
lead_paragraph: The United States gunboat R.R. Cuyler, Commander PHILLIPS, Gate Commander WINSLOW, who died at sea from Key West Aug. 20, and Nassan, N.P., Aug. 26, arrived yesterday morning. On the 23d inst., off the Isaacs, spoke United States gunboat Huntsville, which reported having lost its surgeon the day previous, and had five officers then sick with yellow fever. On Aug. 27, in lat. 30 23', [???] 70 15' [???] the British schooner Anna Sophia, of Nassau, from Escuma, trying to evade the blockade at Wilmington, N.C.; put a prize crew on board, in charge of Acting Master N.W. DYER, and sent her to New-York, Aug. 26, off Nassau, was boarded by H.B.M. gunboat ???], who sent her surgeon, Dr. RADCLIFF, to render assistance to a number of the crew, who, with the ship's surgeon, were sick at the time.
